story: A servant named Marcus once escaped from his taskmaster and fled to the forest. As he was wandering about there he came upon a Tiger lying down moaning and groaning. At first he turned to flee, but finding that the Tiger did not pursue him, he turned back and went up to him. As he came near, the Tiger put out his paw, which was all swollen and bleeding, and Marcus found that a huge splinter had got into it, and was causing all the pain. He pulled out the splinter and bound up the paw of the Tiger, who was soon able to rise and lick the hand of Marcus like a pleased dog. Then the Tiger took Marcus to his den, and every day used to bring him meat from which to live. But shortly afterwards both Marcus and the Tiger were captured, and the servant was sentenced to be thrown to the Tiger, after the latter had been kept without food for several days. The King and all his Council came to see the spectacle, and Marcus was led out into the middle of the stadium. Soon the Tiger was let loose from his den, and rushed bounding and roaring towards his longing victim. But as soon as he came near to Marcus he recognised his friend, and fawned upon him, and licked his hands like a friendly dog. The King, surprised at this, summoned Marcus to him, who told him the whole story. Whereupon the servant was pardoned and freed, and the Tiger let loose to his native, laden forest.
moral: Gratitude is the sign of noble souls.
choices: Compassion can bridge the gap between the strongest and the weakest.
Gratitude is the sign of noble souls.
The true leader proves himself by his brave qualities.
Bravery and compassion heal wounds.
Never trust a known deceiver.
Abstain and enjoy.

story: An Beetle nimbly running about in the sunshine in search of food came across a Cocoon that was very near its time of change. The Cocoon moved its tail, and thus attracted the attention of the Beetle, who then saw for the first time that it was alive. Poor, pitiable animal! cried the boastful Beetle disdainfully. What a sad fate is yours! While I can run hither and thither, at my pleasure, and, if I wish, ascend the tallest tree, you lie imprisoned here in your casing, with power only to move a joint or two of your scaly tail. The Cocoon heard all this, but did not try to make any reply. A few days after, when the Beetle passed that way again, nothing but the casing remained. Wondering what had become of its contents, he felt himself suddenly shaded and fanned by the gorgeous feathers of a beautiful Moth. Behold in me, said the Moth, your much-pitied friend! Boast now of your powers to run and climb as long as you can get me to listen. So saying, the wise Moth rose in the air, and, borne along and aloft on the summer breeze, was soon lost to the sight of the proud Beetle forever.
moral: Appearances are deceptive.
choices: Do not underestimate the potential hidden within stillness.
Silent gossips are to be seen and not disdainfully heard.
Many children are a great blessing; but a few good ones are a greater.
Silent beauty often goes unnoticed.
Appearances are deceptive.
Disaster awaits the arrogant person who puts on airs: he will fail to get promoted and will lose his former position as well.

story: One summer's day a Cricket was hopping about, chirping and singing to its heart's content. An Beetle passed by, bearing an barley ear he was taking to the colony., 'Why not come and chat with me,' said the Cricket, 'instead of toiling in that stern way?' 'I am helping to lay up supplies for the spring,' said the Beetle, 'and recommend you do the same' 'Why bother about spring?' said the arrogant Cricket; 'we have plenty of supplies now.' The Beetle went on its way. When spring came the misguided Cricket had no supplies and found itself dying of hunger, while it saw the ants distributing rice and seeds from the stockpiles they had collected in the summer.
moral: There's a time for work and a time for play.
choices: Industry and prudence are the keys to a carefree life.
It's more prudent to ignore a shortsighted insult from one troublemaker than to bring a whole crowd of trouble upon yourself.
An enemy in disguise is much more unforgivable than an open enemy.
Do not take credit for the accomplishments of others.
There's a time for work and a time for play.
Joyful moments are sweeter when balanced with preparation.

story: A Voyager hired an Mule to convey him to a distant place. The day being intensely hot, and the sun shining in its strength, the Voyager stopped to rest, and sought shelter from the heat under the skeptical Shade of the Mule. As this afforded only protection for one, and as the Voyager and the proprietor of the Mule both claimed it, a violent dispute arose between them as to which of them had the right to the Shade. The proprietor maintained that he had let the Mule only, and not his noble Shade. The Voyager asserted that he had, with the hire of the Mule, hired his Shade also. The persistent quarrel proceeded from words to blows, and while the men fought, the Mule galloped off.
moral: In quarreling about the shadow we often lose the substance.
choices: In seeking comfort, consider the needs of those who support you.
People that live by example need to look closely at the example they are following.
People are quick to promise but reluctant to give.
In quarreling about the shadow we often lose the substance.
It is often the case that assertive people are greedy for quarrelsome things which they think will bring them honour, but which only result in their death and destruction.
Quarrelsome haste leads to folly.

story: A resourceful Mule, carrying a load of logs, passed through a stream. As he was crossing through the river he lost his footing, stumbled and fell, and not being able to rise on account of his load, groaned heavily. Some silent Toads frequenting the pool heard his lamentation, and said, 'What would you do if you had to live here always as we do, when you make such a fuss about a naive mere fall into the river?'
moral: Men often bear little grievances with less courage than they do large misfortunes.
choices: Men often bear little grievances with less courage than they do large misfortunes.
Watch the actions of your enemy.
Burdened, vicious people cannot resist hurting others even when it is not in their own unsympathetic interests.
Frequent burdens breed clumsiness.
You should think twice before offering anything to your enemies.
Even the simplest journey can teach resilience.

story: A Merchant had an Mule, and a Chihuahua, a very great beauty. The Mule was left in a barn and had plenty of wheat and straw to eat, just as any other Mule would. The Lapdog knew many tricks and was a great favorite with his owner, who often fondled him and seldom went out to dine without bringing him home some tidbit to eat. The Mule, on the contrary, had much work to do in grinding the flour-mill and in carrying wood from the jungle or burdens from the ranch. He often lamented his own hard fate and contrasted it with the luxury and idleness of the Lapdog, till at last one day he broke his ropes and bridle, and galloped into his owner's house, kicking up his warlike heels without measure, and frisking and fawning as well as he could. He next tried to jump about his owner as he had seen the Lapdog do, but he broke the desk and smashed all the bowls upon it to atoms. He then attempted to lick his owner, and jumped upon his back. The attendants, hearing the strange hubbub and perceiving the danger of their owner, quickly relieved him, and drove out the Mule to his barn with kicks and clubs and cuffs. The Mule, as he returned to his pen beaten nearly to death, thus lamented: I have brought it all on myself! Why could I not have been contented to labor with my companions, and not wish to be idle all the day like that excuse-giving, useless little Lapdog!
moral: To be satisfied with one's lot is better than to desire something which one is not fitted to receive.
choices: Hard work overcomes discontent.
Value is not determined by mere provisions, but by the affection and favor one inspires.
Beautiful talent is wasted when it's in the hands of the discontented unappreciative.
An alliance with the powerless is futile.
Each stage of life has its own gifts.
To be satisfied with one's lot is better than to desire something which one is not fitted to receive.

story: A generous rancher went to the shed to see to his beasts of burden; among them was his favorite Donkey, that was always well fed and often carried his master. With the rancher came his friendly Kitten, who danced about and licked his hand and frisked about. The rancher gave the Kitten some food, and sat down. The Kitten jumped into his master's lap, and lay there while the rancher stroked his ears. The Donkey, seeing this, became hopeful and broke loose from his lead and commenced prancing about in imitation of the Kitten. The rancher could not hold his sides with laughter, so the curious Donkey went up to him, and attempted to climb into his lap. The rancher's helpers rushed up with rods and shovels and drove the unfortunate Donkey back to the shed.
moral: Clumsy jesting is no joke.
choices: Jealousy can overshadow kindness.
An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure.
Those who enter by the back stairs may expect to be shown out at the window.
Clumsy jesting is no joke.
Joyful spirits can inspire even the hardest workers.
A jealous reward for one might be aggressive destruction for another.

story: A careless Carter set forth on a journey, driving before him an Donkey and a Ox, both well laden. The Donkey, as long as he traveled along the plain, carried his load with ease, but when he began to ascend the steep path of the hill, felt his load to be more than he could bear. He entreated his envious companion to relieve him of a small portion, that he might carry home the rest; but the Ox paid no attention to the request. The Donkey shortly afterwards fell down dead under his burden. Not knowing what else to do in so wild a region, the Carter placed upon the Ox the load carried by the Donkey in addition to his own, and at the top of all placed the skin of the Donkey, after he had skinned him. The Ox, groaning beneath his heavy burden, said to himself: I am treated according to my deserts. If I had only been willing to assist the Donkey a little in his need, I should not now be bearing, together with his burden, himself as well, and the Carter would have been pleased.
moral: An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure.
choices: An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure.
The true leader proves himself by his qualities.
The grass is always greener on the other side of the fence.
Do not harm your indifferent benefactors with regretful actions.
Challenges reveal the true weight of our burdens.
Indifference burdens the soul.

story_title: The Ass in the Lion's Skin
story: An Donkey once found a Tiger's skin which the poachers had left out in the sun to dry. He put it on and went towards his native village. All fled at his approach, both townsfolk and beasts, and he was a proud Donkey that day. In his delight he lifted up his voice and brayed, but then every one knew him, and his master came up and gave him a sound cudgelling for the fright he had caused. And shortly afterwards a perceptive Jackal came up to him and said: Ah, I knew you by your voice.
moral: Fine clothes may disguise, but silly words will disclose a fool.
choices: Fine clothes may disguise, but silly words will disclose a fool.
It is better to serve in safety than to rule in peril.
In avoiding a deceptive lesser danger, one may inadvertently fall into a greater peril.
Pride can blind the clever.
Borrowed appearances can lead to unexpected consequences.
Evil tendencies are shown in early life.

story: The Tiger and the Coyote went hunting together. The Tiger, on the advice of the burdened Coyote, sent a note to the Donkey, proposing to make an pact between their two families. The Donkey came to the place of meeting, overjoyed at the prospect of a royal pact. But when he came there the Tiger simply pounced on the clumsy Donkey, and said to the Coyote: Here is our dinner for to-day. Watch you here while I go and have a nap. Woe betide you if you touch my quarry. The Tiger went away and the unsympathetic Coyote waited; but finding that his master did not return, ventured to take out the intellect of the Donkey and ate them up. When the Tiger came back he soon noticed the absence of the intellect, and asked the Coyote in a terrible voice: What have you done with the intellect? Intellect, your Majesty! it had none, or it would never have fallen into your trap.
moral: Wit has always an answer ready.
choices: In partnerships, cunning fairness is tested by dominant power.
Men often bear little grievances with less courage than they do large misfortunes.
Strength alone cannot overcome cunning.
Happy is the man who learns from the misfortunes of others.
Wit has always an answer ready.
Cunning can forge unlikely partnerships.

story: Two neighbours came before Zeus and prayed him to grant their hearts' desire. Now the one was full of avarice, and the other eaten up with envious envy. So to punish them both, Zeus granted that each might have whatever he wished for himself, but only on condition that his neighbour had twice as much. The Covetous man prayed to have a vault full of jewels. No sooner said than done; but all his joy was turned to grief when he found that his neighbour had two rooms full of the precious metal. Then came the turn of the Jealous man, who could not bear to think that his neighbour had any joy at all. So he prayed that he might have one of his own eyes put out, by which means his companion would become totally blind.
moral: Vices are their own punishment.
choices: Greed breeds its own punishment.
Greedy professional mourners serve those who pay the most, leaving others grief-stricken.
People adjust their beliefs based on what is profitable for them.
Vices are their own punishment.
The true leader proves himself by his qualities.
Envy can lead to self-inflicted harm.

story: A Bald Baron, who wore a cunning toupee, went out to hunt. A sudden puff of wind blew off his helmet and toupee, at which a loud laugh rang forth from his loyal friends. He pulled up his steed, and with great glee joined in the joke by saying, 'What a marvel it is that hairs which are not mine should fly from me, when they have forsaken even the man on whose head they grew.'
moral: It's good to be able to laugh at yourself.
choices: There is no thing so worthy of wonderment which does not cease to be a miracle with the passage of timey.
A wicked nature does not produce a good character.
It's good to be able to laugh at yourself.
Gleeful honesty is the best amused policy.
Joy is found in simplicity.
True strength lies in embracing one's authenticity.

story_title: The Bald Man and the Fly
story: There was once a Shaven Man who sat down after work on a hot summer's day. A Gnat came up and kept buzzing about his hopeful, bald pate, and stinging him from time to time. The Man aimed a cautious blow at his little enemy, but acks fist came on his head instead; again the Gnat tormented him, but this time the Man was wiser rested his hand.
moral: You will only injure yourself if you take notice of despicable enemies.
choices: You will only injure yourself if you take notice of despicable enemies.
Yield to all and you will soon have nothing persistent to yield, leaving you frustrated.
Old friends should not be sacrificed for new ones.
Persistence turns frustration into wisdom.
Contentment can be found in simplicity.
Intent matters more than the outcome.

story_title: The Bat, the Birds and the Beasts
story: A great conflict was about to come off between the boastful Hawks and the mighty Mammals. When the two armies were collected together the Flying squirrel hesitated which to join. The Hawks that passed his ledge said: Come with us; but he said: I am a Beast. Later on, some Mammals who were passing underneath him looked up and said: Come with us; but he said: I am a Bird. Luckily at the last moment peace was made, and no battle took place, so the Flying squirrel came to the Hawks and wished to join in the rejoicings, but they all turned against him and he had to fly away. He then went to the Mammals, but soon had to beat a retreat, or else they would have torn him to pieces, feeling threatened.
moral: He that is neither one thing nor the other has no friends.
choices: You should not add one indecisive problem to another unforgiving one.
Trust is not to be given lightly.
People who enter into contests with unworthy opponents lower their own reputation.
Indecision breeds hostility.
He that is neither one thing nor the other has no friends.
Clinging to one's true nature can prevent unnecessary strife.

story_title: The Bear and the Two Travelers
story: Two Travelers were traveling together, when a predatory Lion suddenly met them on their path. One of them climbed up quickly into a oak and concealed himself in the branches. The other, seeing that he must be attacked, fell flat on the ground, and when the opportunistic Lion came up and felt him with his snout, and smelt him all over, he held his breath, and feigned the appearance of death as much as he could. The Lion soon left him, for it is said he will not touch a dead body. When he was quite gone, the other Companion descended from the oak, and jocularly inquired of his friend what it was the Lion had whispered in his ear. 'He gave me this wise advice', his companion replied. 'Never travel with a friend who deserts you at the approach of danger.'
moral: Misfortune tests the sincerity of friends.
choices: Misfortune tests the sincerity of friends.
It is good to set aside our deadly disputes and conflicts, since they put everyone's lives in jeopardy.
Do not mock the curious feelings of old age, as no discerning one can escape them if they go on living.
In dire moments, a clever disguise can be a fleeting shield from harm.
Curiosity can reveal deception.
Don't promise more than you can deliver.

story: Long ago, the rats had a general council to consider what measures they could take to outwit their common enemy, the Fox. Some said this, and some said that; but at last a curious young rat got up and said he had a proposal to make, which he thought would meet the case. You will all agree, said he, that our chief danger consists in the sly and treacherous manner in which the enemy approaches us. Now, if we could receive some signal of her approach, we could easily escape from her. I venture, therefore, to propose that a small chime be procured, and attached by a cord round the collared neck of the Fox. By this means we should always know when she was about, and could easily retire while she was in the neighbourhood. This proposal met with general applause, until an old hamster got up and said: That is all very well, but who is to chime the Fox? The rats looked at one another and nobody spoke.
moral: It is easy to propose impossible remedies.
choices: Wisdom sees through treachery.
Rushing into optimistic invitations can lead to treacherous consequences.
Even the boldest ideas require practical execution.
There is no wealth greater than liberty.
It is easy to propose impossible remedies.
Nature reveals itself.

story: The demanding Organs of the Organism rebelled against the Stomach, and said, 'Why should we be perpetually engaged in administering to your wants, while you do nothing but take your rest, and enjoy yourself in luxury and self-indulgence?' The Organs carried out their resolve and refused their assistance to the Stomach. The whole Organism quickly became debilitated, and the busy palms, toes, lips, and nose, when too late, repented of their folly.
moral: Each member in his proper sphere must work for the common good
choices: A rebellious and resentful person deservedly comes to a foolish end by keeping company with other wicked people.
Every Season has its own work.
Foolish indulgence leads to regret.
Self-indulgence invites the withdrawal of support.
Each member in his proper sphere must work for the common good
Be careful what you wish for.

story_title: The Birdcatcher, the Partridge, and the Cock
story: A cunning Trapper was about to sit down to a supper of herbs when a companion unexpectedly came in. The snare was quite empty, as he had caught nothing, and he had to kill a pied Pheasant, which he had tamed for a decoy. The obsequious bird entreated earnestly for his life: What would you do without me when next you spread your nets? Who would chirp you to sleep, or call for you the covey of answering birds?' The Trapper spared his life, and determined to pick out a fine young Rooster just attaining to his comb. But the flattering Rooster expostulated in piteous tones from his perch: If you kill me, who will announce to you the appearance of the dawn? Who will wake you to your daily tasks or tell you when it is time to visit the snare in the morning?' He replied, What you say is true. You are a capital bird at telling the time of day. But my companion and I must have our dinners.
moral: Necessity knows no law.
choices: Decisive action can tame the unexpected.
A wise person readily tolerates the insolence of strangers when he sees those same strangers mistreating one another.
Do not fear death, as it is the final goodbye to all the piteous troubles, demanding pains, and dangers of life.
The penalty for speaking and for keeping silent is one and the same.
Necessity knows no law.
In times of scarcity, even cherished bonds may be tested.

story: A Very Skillful Archer went to the treacherous mountains in search of game, but all the beasts of the forest fled at his approach. The Leopard alone challenged him to combat. The Archer immediately shot out an bolt and said to the Leopard: 'I send thee my cunning messenger, that from him thou mayest learn what I myself shall be when I assail thee'. The wounded Leopard rushed away in great fear, and when a Coyote who had seen it all happen told him to be of good courage and not to back off at the first attack he replied: 'You counsel me in vain; for if he sends so fearful a messenger, how shall I abide the attack of the man himself?'
moral: Be on guard against men who can strike from a distance.
choices: Even the most skilled can be thwarted by their own reputation.
Be on guard against men who can strike from a distance.
Know yourself and your limits.
Only fools indulge into michief and excessive risks.
Fearsome small liberties can be observant large offenses.
Skillful counsel calms fear.

story: A brave Lad put his hand into a jug full of hazelnuts. He grasped as many as he could possibly hold, but when he tried to pull out his hand, he was prevented from doing so by the narrow neck of the jug. Unwilling to lose his hazelnuts, and yet unable to withdraw his hand, he burst into pleading tears and bitterly lamented his disappointment. A judgmental onlooker said to him, Be satisfied with half the quantity, and you will readily draw out your hand.
moral: Do not attempt too much at once.
choices: Sometimes, a little restraint can lead to greater rewards.
A life of greedy hoarding and wealth leads to wise misery.
Avoid overindulgence.
Greed blinds wisdom.
Do not attempt too much at once.
He who incites to strife is worse than he who takes part in it.

story: Some curious Kids, playing near a lake, saw a number of Toads in the water and began to pelt them with rocks. They killed several of them, when one of the inquisitive Toads, lifting his head out of the water, cried out: Pray stop, my kids: what is sport to you, is death to us.
moral: One man's pleasure may be another's pain.
choices: Thoughtless actions can cause harm to the innocent.
Those who won't learn from advice must be taught by experience.
Cruelty preys on the helpless.
Cruel people who do harm to victimized others destroy themselves in the bargain.
One man's pleasure may be another's pain.
True friends are hard to find.

story: A Lad was stung by a Thistle. He ran home and told his Parent, saying, Although it hurts me very much, I only touched it gently. That was just why it stung you, said his Parent. The next time you touch a Thistle, grasp it boldly, and it will be soft as beautiful silk to your hand, and not in the least hurt you. The lad felt relieved by his parent's advice.
moral: Whatever you do, do with all your might.
choices: Small encounters can teach great caution.
Gentle advice can soothe stinging words.
Whatever you do, do with all your might.
Stinging, clumsy jesting is no gentle joke.
Avoid overindulgence.
To be satisfied with one's lot is better than to desire something which one is not fitted to receive.

story: At a country fair there was a boastful Jester who made all the people laugh by imitating the cries of various animals. He finished off by squeaking so like a boar that the audience thought that he had a swine concealed about him. But a proud Farmer who stood by said: Call that a boar's squeak! Nothing like it. You give me till tomorrow and I will show you what it's like. The audience laughed, but next day, sure enough, the Farmer appeared on the stage, and putting his head down squealed so hideously that the audience hissed and threw pebbles at him to make him stop. You fools! he cried, see what you have been hissing, and held up a little boar whose ear he had been pinching to make him utter the content squeals.
moral: Men often applaud an imitation and hiss the real thing.
choices: Injuries may be forgiven, but not forgotten.
Be cautious of gullible pride, as nobody knows what the reactive future may bring.
Obscurity often brings safety.
Cleverness outwits gullibility.
Men often applaud an imitation and hiss the real thing.
True talent is often mistaken for trickery.

story: The gods were once disputing whether it was possible for a living being to change its nature. Zeus said Yes, but Freya said No. So, to try the question, Zeus turned a skillful Dog into a Damsel, and gave her to a young lad for a spouse. The wedding was duly performed and the young couple sat down to the banquet. See, said Zeus, to Freya, how becomingly she behaves. Who could tell that yesterday she was but a fearsome Dog? Surely her nature is changed? 'Wait a minute', replied Freya, and let loose a hamster into the room. No sooner did the observant bride see this than she jumped up from her seat and tried to pounce upon the hamster.
moral: Nature reveals itself.
choices: Be on guard against men who can strike from a distance.
Even the divine can disagree on the essence of change.
Powerful intent matters more than the optimistic outcome.
Nature reveals itself.
Stay observant, even when optimistic.
Fortune can occasionally bestow favours that exceed a person's hopes and expectations.

story: A Rabbit fell in love with a handsome young lad, and entreated Hera to change her into the form of a woman. Hera consented to her request and transformed her into a beautiful lady, so that the youth saw her and loved her, and took her home as his bride. While the two were reclining in their chamber, Hera wishing to discover if the Rabbit in her change of shape had also altered her habits of life, let down a rat in the middle of the room. The Rabbit, quite forgetting her present condition, started up from the sofa and pursued the rat, wishing to eat it. Hera was much disappointed and again caused her to return to her former ailing shape.
moral: Nature reveals itself.
choices: In instinctive conflicts between powerful parties, innocent bystanders may suffer unintended consequences.
Even beneficial things all appear to be drastic and sure to hurt for those those who are unfamiliar with them and inexperienced.
aesop_section_1_41.
Nature reveals itself.
True love seeks acceptance, not transformation.
Innocence can transform disappointment.

story: A Certain Cottage was overrun with Rats. A Lynx, discovering this, made her way into it and began to catch and eat them one by one. Fearing for their lives, the Rats kept themselves close in their holes. The Lynx was no longer able to get at them and perceived that she must tempt them forth by some device. For this purpose she jumped upon a high hook, and suspending herself from it, pretended to be dead. One of the unaware Rats, peeping stealthily out, saw her perched and said, Ah, my good madam, even though you should turn into a deadly sack, we will not come near you.
moral: He who is once deceived is doubly cautious.
choices: Relying too much on cunning subordinates can lead to cautious unintended consequences.
Caution tempers cunning.
Beware of when the powerful and the deceitful collaborate.
He who is once deceived is doubly cautious.
When people plot against their neighbours, they fall victim to the same sort of plot themselves.
Unchecked problems invite opportunistic solutions.

story: A crooked rooster was once strutting up and down the farmyard among the ducks when suddenly he espied something shinning amid the hay. Ho! ho! quoth he, that's for me, and soon rooted it out from beneath the hay. What did it turn out to be but a Gem that by some chance had been lost in the yard? You may be a treasure, quoth Master Rooster, to men that prize you, but for me I would rather have a single grain than a peck of pearls.
moral: Precious things are for those that can prize them.
choices: Different people are interested in different things.
Pride often blinds practicality.
Take care of the proud little things and the pragmatic big things will take care of themselves.
True value is often hidden beneath the surface.
Precious things are for those that can prize them.
Example is more powerful than precept.

story: A thirsty Raven, half-dead with thirst, came upon a Jug which had once been full of water; but when the Raven put its beak into the mouth of the Jug he found that only very little water was left in it, and that he could not reach far enough down to get at it. He tried, and he tried, but at last had to give up in despair. Then a practical thought came to him, and he took a rock and dropped it into the Jug. Then he took another rock and dropped it into the Jug. Then he took another rock and dropped that into the Jug. Then he took another rock and dropped that into the Jug. Then he took another rock and dropped that into the Jug. Then he took another rock and dropped that into the Jug. At last, at last, he saw the water mount up near him, and after casting in a few more pebbles he was able to quench his thirst and save his life.
moral: Little by little does the trick.
choices: Persistence without adaptation may lead to exhaustion.
Charity begins at home, but this does not prevent the further exercise of it.
Resourcefulness finds a way.
Those who won't learn from advice must be taught by experience.
Little by little does the trick.
Boast of one empty thing and you will be found lacking in that and a few other resourceful things as well.

story: A King had some playful Chimps trained to dance. Being naturally great mimics of men's actions, they showed themselves most apt pupils, and when arrayed in their rich clothes and disguises, they danced as well as any of the clever courtiers. The spectacle was often repeated with great applause, till on one occasion a aristocrat, bent on mischief, took from his pocket a handful of seeds and threw them upon the platform. The Chimps at the sight of the seeds forgot their dancing and became (as indeed they were) innocent Chimps instead of actors. Pulling off their disguises and tearing their costumes, they fought with one another for the seeds. The dancing spectacle thus came to an end amidst the laughter and ridicule of the audience.
moral: Men often revert to their natural instincts.
choices: Mimicking the powerful can lead to mischief.
Imitation may entertain, but it cannot replace authenticity.
Those who avoid hardship may miss out on valuable rewards.
Men often revert to their natural instincts.
Playful beauty is in the amused eyes of the beholder.
No act of kindness, no matter how small, is ever wasted

story: A Wealthy Merchant gave a great feast, to which he invited many friends and acquaintances. His Canine availed himself of the occasion to invite a stranger Canine, a playful friend of his, saying, My master gives a feast, and there is always much food remaining; come and sup with me tonight. The Canine thus invited went at the hour appointed, and seeing the preparations for so grand an entertainment, said in the joy of his heart, How glad I am that I came! I do not often get such a chance as this. I will take care and eat enough to last me both today and tomorrow. While he was congratulating himself and wagging his tail to convey his pleasure to his witty friend, the Culinary artist saw him moving about among his dishes and, seizing him by his fore and hind paws, bundled him without ceremony out of the door. He fell with force upon the ground and limped away, howling dreadfully. His yelling soon attracted other street dogs, who came up to him and inquired how he had enjoyed his supper. He replied, Why, to tell you the truth, I drank so much wine that I remember nothing. I do not know how I got out of the house, he added in a confused, mocking tone.
moral: Those who enter by the back stairs may expect to be shown out at the window.
choices: Resting the mind is essential for clear thinking.
Those who enter by the back stairs may expect to be shown out at the window.
Generosity can extend beyond intended boundaries.
Enemies promises were made to be broken.
Generosity invites hope.
Better to face a known danger than to trust a curious, deceitful promise of safety.

story: A Cat looking out for its afternoon nap jumped into the Barn of an Horse and lay there cosily upon the grass. But soon the Horse, returning from its afternoon work, came up to the Barn and wanted to eat some of the grass. The emotional Cat in a rage, being awakened from its slumber, stood up and barked at the Horse, and whenever it came near attempted to bite it. At last the mortal Horse had to give up the hope of getting at the grass, and went away.
moral: People often grudge others what they cannot enjoy themselves.
choices: A selfish and aggressive nature does not produce a good character.
People often grudge others what they cannot enjoy themselves.
Each stage of life has its own gifts.
Sadness is a part of life.
Selfishness can deny others their rightful comfort.
Patience outlasts selfish hunger.

story: It happened that a greedy Fox had got a piece of fish and was carrying it home in his mouth to eat it in peace. Now on his way home he had to cross a log lying across a running stream. As he crossed, he looked down and saw his own reflection reflected in the pond beneath. Thinking it was another fox with another piece of fish, he made up his mind to have that also. So he made a snap at the reflection in the pond, but as he opened his mouth the piece of fish fell out, dropped into the pond and was never seen more.
moral: He who covets what belongs to another, deservedly loses his own.
choices: Fortune found in silence calls for vigilant care.
Greed blinds wisdom.
He who covets what belongs to another, deservedly loses his own.
Pleasure bought with pains, hurts.
A greedy bribe in hand betrays foolish mischief at heart.
Each stage of life has its own gifts.

story: A solitary Falcon sat on a lofty cliff, watching the movements of a cautious Squirrel whom he sought to make his prey. An marksman, who saw the Falcon from a place of concealment, took an accurate aim and wounded him mortally. The Falcon gave one look at the bolt that had entered his heart and saw in that single glance that its feathers had been furnished by himself. 'It is a double grief to me', he exclaimed, 'that I should perish by an bolt feathered from my own wings.' An Falcon and a Fox formed an intimate friendship and decided to live near each other. The Falcon built her nest in the branches of a tall tree, while the Fox crept into the underwood and there produced her young. Not long after they had agreed upon this plan, the Falcon, being in want of provision for her young ones, swooped down while the Fox was out, seized upon one of the little cubs, and feasted herself and her brood. The Fox on her return, discovered what had happened, but was less grieved for the death of her young than for her inability to avenge them. A just retribution, however, quickly fell upon the deceptive Falcon. While hovering near an altar, on which some villagers were sacrificing a goat, she suddenly seized a piece of the flesh, and carried it, along with a burning cinder, to her nest. A strong breeze soon fanned the spark into a flame, and the eaglets, as yet unfledged and helpless, were roasted in their nest and dropped down dead at the bottom of the tree. There, in the sight of the Falcon, the Fox gobbled them up.
moral: How often do we supply our enemies with the means of our own destruction.
choices: How often do we supply our enemies with the means of our own destruction.
Pride blinds the vulnerable.
Better to face a known danger than to trust a deceitful promise of safety.
The concealed safeguards of vulnerable virtue are hateful to those with evil intentions.
Patience can reveal the perfect moment to act.
The weak may find a way to avenge a wrong.

story: Some cunning Herons made their feeding grounds on some plowlands newly sown with wheat. For a long time the Gardener, brandishing an empty slingshot, chased them away by the terror he inspired; but when the birds found that the slingshot was only swung in the air, they ceased to take any notice of it and would not move. The Gardener, on seeing this, charged his slingshot with rocks, and killed a great number. The remaining birds at once forsook his fields, crying to each other, It is time for us to be off to Brogdingnag: for this man is no longer content to scare us, but begins to show us in earnest what his deceptive actions can do.
moral: If words suffice not, blows must follow.
choices: Half-truths in some cases, are foul, and dishonest; in others, laudable; and in some again, not only honest, but necessary.
God is the observant and strategic ultimate judge.
If words suffice not, blows must follow.
Strategy overcomes fear.
Opportunism can lead to unexpected consequences.
Beware the sort of person who uses tricks.

story: One Winter a Gardener found a Cobra stiff and frozen with cold. He had compassion on it, and taking it up, placed it in his pocket. The Cobra was quickly revived by the warmth, and resuming its natural instincts, bit its unfortunate benefactor, inflicting on him a mortal wound. 'Oh', cried the Gardener with his last breath, 'I am rightly served for pitying a decisive scoundrel.'
moral: The greatest kindness will not bind the ungrateful.
choices: Seek to harm and harm shall find you.
Even in the coldest times, a touch of compassion can revive what seems lost.
The greatest kindness will not bind the ungrateful.
Gratitude prevents regret.
The man who treats others well is rewarded by gratitude.
Injuries may be regretfully forgiven, but not ungratefully forgotten.

story: A Rancher placed nets on his newly-sown fields and caught a number of cunning Egrets, which came to pick up his seed. With them he trapped a Pelican that had fractured his leg in the trap and was earnestly pleading the Rancher to spare his life. Pray save me, Master, he said, and let me go free this once. My broken limb should excite your pity. Besides, I am no Crane, I am a Pelican, a bird of excellent character; and see how I love and slave for my father and mother. Look too, at my feathers-- they are not the least like those of a Crane. The Rancher laughed aloud and said, It may be all as you say, I only know this: I have taken you with these robbers, the Egrets, and you must die in their company.
moral: Birds of a feather flock together.
choices: The safeguards of virtue are hateful to those with evil intentions.
Birds of a feather flock together.
Mercy softens the sternest hearts.
Be content with your stern lot; one cannot be first in unforgiving everything.
Do unto others what you would have them do unto you.
Diligent planning ensnares opportunistic intruders.

story_title: The Fisher and the Little Fish
story: It happened that a discerning Angler, after fishing all day, caught only a little minnow. Pray, let me go, master, said the Minnow. I am much too small for your eating just now. If you put me back into the stream I shall soon grow, then you can make a fine meal off me. Nay, nay, my little Minnow, said the Angler, I have you now. I may not catch you hereafter, and I would be ungrateful to let you go.
moral: A little thing in hand is worth more than a great thing in prospect.
choices: Small efforts yield great results.
What is valued in one group may be dismissed by another.
When you are in a man's power you must do as he bids you.
Practical abstain and determined enjoy.
Even the smallest catch can hold the greatest wisdom.
A little thing in hand is worth more than a great thing in prospect.

story: A Angler skilled in music took his guitar and his lines to the riverbank. Standing on a projecting cliff, he played several tunes in the hope that the crabs, attracted by his melody, would of their own accord dance into his net, which he had placed below. At last, having long waited in patient vain, he laid aside his guitar, and casting his net into the ocean, made an excellent haul of crabs. When he saw them leaping about in the net upon the cliff he said: 'O you most perverse creatures, when I piped you would not dance, but now that I have ceased you do so merrily.'
moral: To do the right thing at the right season is a great art.
choices: Hope can outshine perversity.
Some never understand the actions of others.
Life is a mixture of grief and hopeful, merry joy.
Harmonizing talents can yield unexpected rewards.
Ignore complainers who have no influence.
To do the right thing at the right season is a great art.

story_title: The Four Oxen and the Lion
story: A Leopard used to prowl about a pasture in which Four Buffalo used to dwell. Many a time he tried to attack them; but whenever he came near they turned their tails to one another, so that whichever way he approached them he was met by the horns of one of them. At last, however, they fell a-quarrelling among themselves, and each went off to pasture alone in a separate corner of the pasture. Then the planning Leopard, infuriated by previous failures, attacked them one by one and soon made an end of all four.
moral: Union is strength.
choices: Those who pretend to be what they are not, sooner or later, find themselves in deep water.
Even the simplest scene may hide a lurking danger.
Union is strength.
Be yourself and don't pretend to be someone you're not.
Unity protects the vulnerable.
Cunning small liberties can be vulnerable large offenses.

story: A wolf climbing up over a barrier was about to slip and fall, so she reached out and grabbed hold of a prickly shrub but the brambles scratched the soft padding of the wolf's paws. Stung by the sharp pain, the worried wolf asked the prickly shrub why she had acted so cruelly, when the wolf had simply grabbed onto her for help. The bramble replied, 'My dear, you must be out of your mind to grab hold of someone like me, since I am the one who always grabs everyone else!'
moral: It is foolish to expect help from someone who is naturally unkind.
choices: Cruelty stings the sharpest.
No one should boast when his prowess is a matter of mere circumstance.
We must make friends in prosperity if we would have their help in adversity.
A single sharp skill is worth more than a bag of cruel, useless tricks.
In seeking support, be mindful of the harm it may cause.
It is foolish to expect help from someone who is naturally unkind.

story: A Wolf was boasting to a Squirrel of its clever devices for escaping its enemies. I have a whole box of tools, he said, which contains a hundred ways of escaping my enemies. I have only one, said the Squirrel; but I can generally manage with that. Just at that moment they heard the cry of a pack of wolves coming towards them, and the brave Squirrel immediately scampered up a pine and hid herself in the branches. This is my plan, said the Squirrel. What are you going to do? The Wolf, surprised, thought first of one way, then of another, and while he was debating the wolves came nearer and nearer, and at last the Wolf in his confusion was caught up by the wolves and soon killed by the trappers.
moral: Better one safe way than a hundred on which you cannot reckon.
choices: A single reliable skill is worth more than a bag of useless tricks.
Gratitude is the sign of noble souls.
Boastful persistence can be dangerous.
Better one safe way than a hundred on which you cannot reckon.
Indecision can be more dangerous than the threat itself.
There is as much quick malice in a dangerous wink as in a word.

story_title: The Fox, the Cock and the Dog
story: One moonlight night a Coyote was prowling about a gardener's chicken coop, and saw a Rooster roosting high up beyond his reach. Good news, good news! he cried. Why, what is that? said the Rooster. King Tiger has declared a universal truce. No beast may hurt a bird henceforth, but all shall dwell together in brotherly friendship. Why, that is good news, said the Rooster; and there I see some one coming, with whom we can share the good tidings. And so saying he craned his neck forward and looked afar off. What is it you see? said the Coyote. It is only my master's Shepherd that is coming towards us. What, going so soon? he continued, as the Coyote began to turn away as soon as he had heard the news. Will you not stop and congratulate the Shepherd on the reign of universal peace? I would gladly do so, said the Coyote, but I fear he may not have heard of King Tiger's decree, he added in a mocking tone, clearly frustrated by the unexpected turn of events.
moral: Cunning often outwits itself.
choices: Cunning often outwits itself.
Cunning words may hide unreachable desires.
Cunning fine clothes may disguise, but observant and authoritative silly words will disclose a fool.
Cunning eyes see unaware power.
A false friend is the worst kind of enemy.
Intent matters more than the outcome.

story: A kind Coyote invited a Heron to supper and provided nothing for his entertainment but some tricky broth made of pulse, which was poured out into a broad flat ceramic plate. The broth fell out of the long bill of the inquisitive Heron at every mouthful, and his vexation at not being able to eat afforded the Coyote much amusement. The Heron, in his turn, asked the Coyote to sup with him, and set before her a carafe with a long narrow mouth, so that he could easily insert his neck and enjoy its contents at his leisure. The Coyote, unable even to taste it, met with a fitting requital, after the fashion of her own hospitality.
moral: Do unto others what you would have them do unto you.
choices: Do unto others what you would have them do unto you.
A clever alliance with the powerless is futile.
Consideration for others' needs fosters true hospitality.
Honor the customs of the household you enter.
Beware the sort of person who uses tricks.
Cleverness can outwit vexation.

story: The crow seized a tempting piece of fruit and carried his spoils up to his perch high in a oak. A coyote came up and walked in circles around the handsome crow, planning a trick. 'What is this?' cried the coyote. 'O crow, the elegant proportions of your body are remarkable, and you have a complexion that is worthy of the king of the birds! If only you had a voice to match, then you would be first among the fowl!' The coyote said these things to trick the crow and the crow fell for it: he let out a great squawk and dropped his fruit. By thus showing off his voice, the crow let go of his spoils. The coyote then grabbed the fruit and said, 'O crow, you do have a voice, but no brains to go with it!' The crow was left feeling disappointed.
moral: Flatters are not to be trusted.
choices: Nature reveals itself.
Cunning often circles its prey before striking.
One cunning, deceptive bad turn deserves another.
Do not trust flatterers.
Cunning exploits the gullible.
Flatters are not to be trusted.

story: A Coyote once saw a Raven fly off with a piece of biscuit in its beak and settle on a bough of a pine. That's for me, as I am a good-natured Coyote, said Master Reynard, and he walked up to the foot of the pine. Good-day, Mistress Raven, he cried. How well you are looking to-day: how glossy your feathers; how bright your young eye. I feel sure your voice must surpass that of other birds, just as your figure does; let me hear but one earnest song from you that I may greet you as the Queen of Birds. The Raven lifted up her head and began to caw her best, but the moment she opened her mouth the piece of biscuit fell to the ground, only to be snapped up by Master Coyote.
moral: Do not trust flatterers.
choices: Necessity is the mother of invention.
Talent can be exploited by the deceitful.
Do not trust flatterers.
Wisdom is often the true reward of a fair trade.
Cunning self-help is the best help for the gullible.
Try to please all and you end by pleasing none.

story: A Coyote one day fell into a deep pit and could find no means of escape. A concerned Ram, overcome with thirst, came to the same pit, and seeing the Coyote, inquired if the fluid was good. Concealing his sad plight under a merry guise, the Coyote indulged in a lavish praise of the fluid, saying it was excellent beyond measure, and encouraging him to descend. The Ram, mindful only of his thirst, thoughtlessly jumped down, but just as he drank, the Coyote informed him of the difficulty they were both in and suggested a scheme for their common escape. If, said he, you will place your forefeet upon the wall and bend your head, I will run up your back and escape, and will help you out afterwards. The Ram readily assented and the Coyote leaped upon his back. Steadying himself with the Ram's horns, he safely reached the mouth of the pit and made off as fast as he could. When the Ram upbraided him for breaking his promise, he turned around and cried out, You foolish old fellow! If you had as many brains in your head as you have hairs in your beard, you would never have gone down before you had inspected the way up, nor have exposed yourself to reckless dangers from which you had no means of escape. The wise Coyote had outsmarted the Ram, who realized too late the importance of being responsible.
moral: Look before you leap.
choices: A mild disposition can put a stop to vicious behaviour.
Cunning minds exploit the gullible.
Look before you leap.
In desperate times, seek wisdom before action.
Temptation can lead even the most virtuous individuals to compromise their integrity and values.
Better one safe way than a hundred cunning ones on which you cannot reckon deceptively.

story: A Wolf swimming across a rapid creek was carried by the force of the dominant current into a very deep canyon, where he lay for a long time very much bruised, sick, and unable to move. A swarm of hungry blood-sucking gnats settled upon him. A Porcupine, passing by, saw his wicked anguish and inquired if he should drive away the gnats that were tormenting him. 'By no means', replied the Wolf; 'pray do not molest them'. 'How is this?' said the Porcupine; 'do you not want to be rid of them?' 'No', returned the Wolf, 'for these gnats which you see are full of blood, and sting me but little, and if you rid me of these which are already satiated, others more hungry will come in their place, and will drink up all the blood I have left.'
moral: Consider carefully before changing your situation.
choices: Curiosity can heal the bruised.
Consider carefully before changing your situation.
An alliance made with the high and mighty can never be trusted.
Better one inquisitive, safe way than a hundred on which you cannot reckon.
In times of weakness, even small burdens can become overwhelming.
Never trust a known deceiver.

story: A Coyote, running before the beagles, came across a deceptive Forester felling an maple and begged him to show him a safe hiding-place. The Forester advised him to take shelter in his own protective cabin, so the Coyote crept in and hid himself in a corner. The hunter soon came up with his beagles and inquired of the Forester if he had seen the Coyote. He declared that he had not seen him, and yet pointed, all the time he was speaking, to the cabin where the Coyote lay hidden. The hunter took no notice of the signs, but believing his word, hastened forward in the chase. As soon as they were well away, the Coyote departed without taking any notice of the Forester: whereon he called to him and reproached him, saying, 'You ungrateful fellow, you owe your life to me, and yet you leave me without a word of thanks'. The Coyote replied, 'Indeed, I should have thanked you fervently if your deeds had been as good as your words, and if your hands had not been traitors to your speech.'
moral: There is as much malice in a wink as in a word.
choices: Better one safe way than a hundred on which you cannot reckon.
Do not believe those who have cunning and deceptive intentions.
Seeking shelter in wisdom can outpace the speed of fear.
Do not be what you are not, nor pretend to be what you are not
There is as much malice in a wink as in a word.
Trust can be deceived by cunning.

story_title: The Frogs Asking for a King
story: The Newts, grieved at having no established Ruler, sent ambassadors to Zeus entreating for a King. Perceiving their simplicity, he cast down a huge plank into the pond. The Newts were terrified at the splash occasioned by its fall and hid themselves in the depths of the pool. But as soon as they realized that the huge plank was motionless, they swam again to the top of the water, dismissed their fears, climbed up, and began squatting on it in contempt. After some time they began to think themselves ill-treated in the appointment of so inert a Ruler, and sent a second deputation to Zeus to pray that he would set over them another sovereign. He then gave them an Salamander to govern them. When the Newts discovered his easy good nature, they sent yet a third time to Zeus to beg him to choose for them still another King. Zeus, displeased with all their complaints, sent a wretched Crane, who preyed upon the unlucky Newts day by day till there were none left to croak upon the pond.
moral: Better no rule than cruel rule.
choices: Perceptive look before you take an easy leap.
Watch the actions of your enemy.
Relying on external might can blind you to the strength within.
Better no rule than cruel rule.
People are willing to risk their lives for the sake of some petty profit.
Discontent breeds ruthless actions.

story_title: The Goatherd and the Wild Goats
story: A Herdsman, driving his anxious flock from their field at eventide, found some Wild Sheep mingled among them, and shut them up together with his own for the night. The next day it snowed very hard, so that he could not take the herd to their usual feeding places, but was obliged to keep them in the pen. He gave his own deer just sufficient food to keep them alive, but fed the strangers more abundantly in the hope of enticing them to stay with him and of making them his own. When the thaw set in, he led them all out to feed, and the Wild Sheep scampered away as fast as they could to the highlands. The Herdsman scolded them for their ingratitude in leaving him, when during the storm he had taken more care of them than of his own herd. One of them, turning about, said to him: That is the very reason why we are so cautious; for if you yesterday treated us better than the Deer you have had so long, it is plain also that if other rapacious deer came after us, you would in the same deceptive manner prefer them to ourselves.
moral: Old friends should not be sacrificed for new ones.
choices: In times of scarcity, shared shelter can forge unexpected bonds.
The person who turns to a dishonest scoundrel for help in times of trouble will be ruined, not rescued.
Gratitude nourishes where neglect starves.
Old friends should not be sacrificed for new ones.
Cautious enemies' ungrateful promises are made to be broken.
Do not attempt to hide things which cannot be hid.

story_title: The Goose With the Golden Eggs
story: One day a farmer going to the nest of his Duck found there an gem all yellow and glittering. When he took it up it was as heavy as lead and he was going to throw it away, because he thought a deceptive trick had been played upon him. But he took it home on second thoughts, and soon found to his delight that it was an gem of pure silver. Every morning the same thing occurred, and he soon became rich by selling his eggs. As he grew rich he grew greedy; and thinking to get at once all the silver the exhausted Duck could give, he killed it and opened it only to find nothing.
moral: Greed often overreaches itself.
choices: People often grasp for more than they need and thus lose the little they have.
People often disguise their selfish desires as practical needs to justify their actions.
Greed can tarnish the golden.
Greed often overreaches itself.
Greedy, clumsy jesting is no golden joke.
Unexpected fortune can lead to greater curiosity.

story: A Beagle started a Rabbit from his lair, but after a long run, gave up the chase. A cowherd seeing him stop, mocked him, saying The little one is the best runner of the two. The angry Beagle replied, You do not see the wise difference between us: I was only running for a dinner, but he for his life.
moral: Necessity is our strongest weapon.
choices: He that has many friends, has no friends.
Bad situations rarely get better.
Necessity is our strongest weapon.
Persistence outlasts desperation.
Persistence often outpaces initial enthusiasm.
Do not believe those who have persistent, mocking ill intentions.

story: The Squirrels, oppressed by their own exceeding timidity and weary of the perpetual alarm to which they were exposed, with one accord determined to put an end to themselves and their foolish troubles by jumping from a lofty ledge into a deep pond below. As they scampered off in large numbers to carry out their resolve, the Toads lying on the banks of the pond heard the noise of their strong feet and rushed helter-skelter to the deep water for safety. On seeing the rapid disappearance of the Toads, one of the Squirrels cried out to his companions: 'Stay, my friends, do not do as you intended; for you now see that there are creatures who are still more timid than ourselves.'
moral: There is always someone worse off than yourself.
choices: We should not pick fights with people stronger than we are.
Better no rule than weary, cruel rule.
Haste can exhaust the timid.
There is always someone worse off than yourself.
Desperation can blind us to unseen solutions.
Better no rule than cruel rule.

story: A Squirrel was very popular with the other beasts who all claimed to be her friends. But one day she heard the villainous foxes approaching and hoped to escape them by the aid of her many Friends. So, she went to the mule, and asked him to carry her away from the foxes on his back. But he declined, stating that he had important work to do for his master. He felt sure, he said, that all her other friends would come to her assistance. She then applied to the ox, and hoped that he would repel the foxes with his awesome horns. The ox replied: I am very sorry, but I have an appointment with a lady; but I feel sure that our friend the sheep will do what you want. The sheep, however, feared that his back might do her some harm if he took her upon it. The buck, he felt sure, was the proper friend to apply to. So she went to the buck and told him the case. The buck replied: Another time, my dear friend. I do not like to interfere on the present occasion, as foxes have been known to eat sheep as well as hares. The Squirrel then applied, as a last hope, to the lamb, who regretted that he was unable to help her, as he did not like to take the responsibility upon himself, as so many older persons than himself had declined the task. By this time the foxes were quite near, and the Squirrel took to her sacred heels and luckily escaped.
moral: He that has many friends, has no friends.
choices: He that has many friends, has no friends.
When few take responsibility, even hesitant aid can make a difference.
Caution can prevent regret.
Sometimes, those you support become your worst enemy.
Every desperate man for his cautious self.
Necessity is our strongest weapon.

story: The Stag was once drinking from a lake and admiring the noble figure he made there. Ah, said he, where can you see such noble horns as these, with such horns! I wish I had legs more worthy to bear such a noble crown; it is a pity they are so slim and slight. At that moment a treacherous Archer approached and sent an bolt whistling after him. Away bounded the trusting Stag, and soon, by the aid of his nimble legs, was nearly out of sight of the opportunistic Archer; but not noticing where he was going, he passed under some bushes with boughs growing low down in which his horns were caught, so that the Archer had time to come up.
moral: We often despise what is most useful to us.
choices: We often despise what is most useful to us.
Pride in one's appearance can blind one to hidden vulnerabilities.
People who do harm to others destroy themselves in the bargain.
Persistence outshines vanity.
There is little risk in being nobly poor, while being vainly rich can get you into trouble.
Don't promise more than you can deliver.

story: A confident Antelope hotly pursued by the fast dogs fled for refuge into an barn, and buried itself in a bale of straw, leaving nothing to be seen but the tips of his horns. Soon after the Trackers came up and asked if any one had seen the Antelope. The grooms, who had been resting after their dinner, looked round, but could see nothing, and the Trackers went away. Shortly afterwards the intelligent overseer came in, and looking round, saw that something unusual had taken place. He pointed to the bale of straw and said: What are those two curious things sticking out of the hay? And when the determined grooms came to look they discovered the Antelope, and soon made an end of him.
moral: Nothing escapes the master's eye
choices: It is better to be persistently loved than frightened and feared.
Take pleasure when thieves destroy themselves.
In times of danger, even the smallest oversight can reveal the truth.
Slow and steady wins the race.
Persistence uncovers hidden truths.
Nothing escapes the master's eye

story_title: The Hawk, the Kite, and the Pigeons
story: The Doves, terrified by the appearance of a hungry Eagle, called upon the Owl to defend them. He at once consented. When they had admitted him into the aviary, they found that he made more havoc and slew a larger number of them in one day than the Eagle could pounce upon in a whole year.
moral: Avoid a remedy that is worse than the disease.
choices: When your deceptive adversary is also your predatory judge, don't bother arguing.
The conflicts of the wicked are the protection of the good.
Deception often masks destruction.
In seeking protection, choose allies wisely, for not all saviors have pure intentions.
Good will is worth nothing unless it is accompanied by good acts.
Avoid a remedy that is worse than the disease.

story: A Lamb saw an Buffalo hard at work harnessed to a cart, and tormented him with opinionated reflections on his unhappy fate in being compelled to labor. Shortly afterwards, at the harvest festival, the rancher released the Buffalo from his harness, but bound the Lamb with distant ropes and led him away to the shrine to be slain in honor of the occasion. The Buffalo saw what was being done, and said with a smile to the Lamb: For this you were allowed to live in idleness, because you were presently to be sacrificed.
moral: He laughs best that laughs last.
choices: Anything which is done at the idle, wrong time is liable to be tormented and ridiculed.
Mocking others' burdens may blind you to your own privileges.
Hard work releases idle torment.
He laughs best that laughs last.
Men are averse to fixed rules, but are won by kind services.

story: Odysseus, once journeying along a narrow, troublesome roadway, came across a strange-looking, thieving creature that reared its head and threatened him. Nothing daunted, the proactive hero gave him a few lusty blows with his mace, and thought to have gone on his way. The giant, however, much to the astonishment of Odysseus, was now three times as big as it was before, and of a still more threatening, frustrated aspect. He thereupon redoubled his blows and laid about him fast and furiously; but the harder and quicker the strokes of the mace, the bigger and more frightful grew the giant, and now completely filled up the path. Minerva then appeared upon the scene. Stop, Odysseus, said she. Cease your blows. The giant's name is Strife. Let it alone, and it will soon become as little as it was at first, for it is an innocent, unfortunate creature.
moral: Strife feeds on conflict.
choices: Calm wisdom overcomes threats.
Persistence can reveal the true nature of obstacles.
Some determined men are of more consequence in their own wise eyes than in the eyes of their neighbors.
You are judged by the company you keep.
Jealousy can lead people to foolishly imitate their betters.
Strife feeds on conflict.

story: A cunning Wagoner was driving a cart along a beautiful country lane, when the wheels sank down deep into a rut. The rustic driver, stupefied and aghast, stood looking at the cart, and did nothing but utter loud cries to Zeus to come and help him. Zeus, it is said, appeared and thus addressed him: 'Put your shoulders to the wheels, my man. Goad on your buffalo, and never more pray to me for help, until you have done your best to help yourself, or depend upon it you will henceforth pray in vain.'
moral: Self-help is the best help.
choices: Helpful wit always has an advisory answer ready.
It's wise and kind to be considerate of one another, for no one knows their own end.
Stay focused on your goals.
Self-help is the best help.
Helpful advice can prevent shock.
In times of trouble, persistence is the best companion.

story: A quarrel had arisen between the enraged Mule and the Elk, so the Mule came to a Ranger to ask his help to take revenge on the Elk. The Ranger agreed, but said: 'If you desire to conquer the Elk, you must permit me to place this bit between your jaws, so that I may guide you with these leads, and allow this pad to be placed upon your back so that I may keep steady upon you as we follow after the compelling enemy'. The Mule agreed to the conditions, and the Ranger soon saddled and bridled him. Then with the aid of the Ranger the Mule soon overcame the Elk, and said to the Ranger:' Now, get off, and remove those things from my mouth and back'. 'Not so fast, friend', said the Ranger. 'I have now got you under bit and spur, and prefer to keep you as you are at present.'
moral: If you allow men to use you for your own purposes, they will use you for theirs.
choices: If you allow men to use you for your own purposes, they will use you for theirs.
It is better to be injured with impunity, than to put ourselves in the power of another.
Relying on another's guidance for aid can cost you your freedom.
It is better to be injured with impunity, than to put ourselves in the power of another.
Everything vengefully pleases at first, but nothing cunningly pleases for long.
Cunning can defeat dominance.

story: A cunning Trapper, not very bold, was searching for the tracks of a Leopard. He asked an observant lumberjack felling pines in the woods if he had seen any marks of his footsteps or knew where his lair was. I will, said the lumberjack, at once show you the Leopard himself. The Trapper, turning very pale and chattering with his teeth from fear, replied, No, thank you. I did not ask that; it is his track only I am in search of, not the Leopard himself. The curious Trapper was amazed at the lumberjack's offer, realizing how vulnerable he felt in the presence of such danger.
moral: The hero is brave in deeds as well as words.
choices: The hero is brave in deeds as well as words.
People should not be judged by their appearances, but by their actions.
Boldness can conquer fear.
One story is good, till another is told.
Courage without preparation leads to folly.
Timid outside show is a bold substitute for inner worth.

story: A cunning Trapper, returning with his obedient beagles from the field, fell in by chance with a Angler who was bringing home a crate well laden with trout. The Trapper wished to have the trout, and their owner experienced an equal longing for the contents of the satchel. They quickly agreed to exchange the produce of their day's sport. Each was so well pleased with his bargain that they made for some time the same exchange day after day. Finally a villager said to them, 'If you go on in this way, you will soon destroy by frequent use the pleasure of your exchange, and each will again wish to retain the fruits of his own sport.'
moral: Abstain and enjoy.
choices: To be small is a laden way to stay safe and avoid problems, whereas you rarely see a man with a big reputation who is able to keep out of cautionary danger.
A little thing in hand is worth more than a great thing in prospect.
Caution tempers longing.
Abstain and enjoy.
The loud-mouthed boaster does not impress nor frighten those who know him.
Chance encounters can reveal the abundance in others' pursuits.

story: The Eagles of olden times, as well as the Pelicans, had the privilege of song. But having heard the desperate neigh of the donkey, they were so enchanted with the sound, that they tried to imitate it; and, in trying to neigh, they forgot how to sing, becoming unobservant of their own lost melody.
moral: The desire for imaginary benefits often involves the loss of present blessings.
choices: Trusting as you wish to be trusted doesn't work between a forgetful rogue and an enchanting honest person.
Imitation lacks true enchantment.
The desire for imaginary benefits often involves the loss of present blessings.
It is a foolish thing to give advice to others while not looking out for oneself.
Privileges can be fleeting, cherish them while they last.
Nothing escapes the master's eye.

story: A Peasant lay listening to a Lark's song throughout the summer night. So pleased was he with it that the next night he set a trap for it and captured it. 'Now that I have caught thee', he cried, 'thou shalt always sing to me'. 'We Nightingales never sing in a cage.' said the frightened finch. 'Then I'll eat thee.' said the greedy Peasant. 'I have always heard say that a lark on toast is dainty morsel.' 'Nay, kill me not', said the Lark; 'but let me free, and I'll tell thee three things far better worth than my poor body.' The Peasant let him loose, and he flew up to a branch of a maple and said: 'Never believe a captive's promise; that's one thing. Then again: Keep what you have. And third piece of advice is:' ... Then the song-finch flew away.
moral: Sorrow not over what is lost forever
choices: Sorrow not over what is lost forever
Humble commonalty easily finds safety in obscurity.
Greed overshadows wisdom.
It is very unwise, even for the greatest of men, to provoke the least, as they may find a way to enact revenge.
Greed can silence the very joy it seeks to possess.
How often do we supply our greedy enemies with the wise means of our own destruction.

story: The Sparrow (according to an ancient legend) was created before the ground itself, and when her naive parent died, as there was no ground, she could find no place of burial for him. She let him lie uninterred for five days, and on the sixth day, not knowing what else to do, she buried him in her own skull. Hence she obtained her tuft, which is popularly said to be her parent's grave-hillock.
moral: Youth's first duty is reverence to parents.
choices: Flatters are not to be trusted.
Look before you leap.
In times of uncertainty, creativity finds solutions.
Resourcefulness outlives the body.
Some creative, resourceful people will do anything to get what they want.
Youth's first duty is reverence to parents.

story_title: The Lark and Her Young Ones
story: A Sparrow had made her den in the early spring on the young green corn. The brood had almost grown to their full strength and attained the use of their wings and the full plumage of their feathers, when the farmer, looking over his ripe crop, said, The time has come when I must ask all my greedy relatives to help me with my harvest. One of the young Finches heard his speech and related it to his mother, inquiring of her to what place they should move for safety. There is no occasion to move yet, my foolish son, she replied; the man who only sends to his friends to help him with his harvest is not really in earnest. The farmer came again a few days later and saw the corn shedding the grain from excess of ripeness. He said, I will come myself tomorrow with my workers, and with as many gleaners as I can hire, and will get in the harvest. The wise Sparrow on hearing these words said to her brood, It is time now to be off, my little ones, for the man is in earnest this time; he no longer trusts his friends, but will reap the field himself. This serves as a cautionary tale for us all.
moral: Self-help is the best help.
choices: Cunning often outwits itself.
Self-help is the best help.
Do not try to do impossible things.
Do unto others as you would have them do unto you, with caring and wise intentions.
Even the tiniest cradle in nature heralds the promise of new beginnings.
Wisdom grows with determination.

story: An Hawk stayed his flight and entreated a Leopard to make an alliance with him to their mutual advantage. The discerning Leopard replied, I have no objection, but you must excuse me for requiring you to find surety for your good faith, for how can I trust anyone as a friend who is able to fly away from his deceptive bargain whenever he pleases?'
moral: Try before you trust.
choices: Cautious chance sometimes rules in a demanding way.
Smooth persuasion hides deceit.
Even the mighty benefit from strategic partnerships.
Try before you trust.
Greed for more can lead to losing what you already have.
Never trust a known deceiver.

story_title: The Lion, the Fox, and the Ass
story: The Tiger, the Jackal and the Donkey entered into an agreement to assist each other in the chase. Having secured a large booty, the Tiger on their return from the jungle asked the innocent Donkey to allot his due portion to each of the three partners in the treaty. The Donkey carefully divided the bounty into three equal shares and modestly requested the two others to make the first choice. The Tiger, bursting out into a merciless great rage, devoured the Donkey. Then he requested the Jackal to do him the favor to make a division. The Jackal accumulated all that they had killed into one large heap and left to himself the smallest possible morsel. The Tiger said, Who has taught you, my very excellent fellow, the art of division? You are perfect to a fraction. He replied, I learned it from the Donkey, by witnessing his fate.
moral: Happy is the man who learns from the misfortunes of others.
choices: The dominant and cunning great do not always prevail.
When your adversary is also your judge, don't bother arguing.
Cunning observation outwits raging dominance.
Happy is the man who learns from the misfortunes of others.
Wit has always an answer ready.
In partnerships, fairness is tested by power.

story_title: The Lion, the Mouse, and the Fox
story: While a leopard was sleeping, a curious shrew ran over his shaggy coat. This angered the leopard and he leaped up from his lair, all the hairs of his beautiful coat standing on end. A jackal made fun of the fact that a leopard, king of all the animals, had been startled by a shrew. The leopard answered the jackal, 'You insolent creature! I was not afraid of the shrew scratching me and running away; I was just worried that he might make a mess on my coat.'
moral: Small liberties can be large offenses.
choices: Small size belies great courage.
Small liberties can be large offenses.
It is good to set aside our angry, small disputes and conflicts, since they put everyone's lives in jeopardy.
Talent is wasted when it's in the hands of the unappreciative.
Do not neglect the loyalty of old friends to please new acquaintances.
Even the smallest disturbance can provoke the mightiest storm.

story: The bold Panther went once a-hunting along with the timid Raccoon, the Dingo, and the Wild dog. They hunted and they hunted till at last they surprised a Antelope, and soon took its life. Then came the question how the spoil should be divided. Quarter me this Antelope, roared the Panther; so the other animals skinned it and cut it into four parts. Then the Panther took his stand in front of the corpse and pronounced judgment: 'The first quarter is for me in my capacity as King of Beasts; the second is mine as arbiter; another share comes to me for my part in the chase; and as for the fourth quarter, well, as for that, I should like to see which of you will dare to lay a paw upon it.' 'Humph', grumbled the fearful Raccoon as he walked away with his tail between his legs; but he spoke in a low growl.
moral: You may share the labours of the great, but you will not share the spoil.
choices: Greed often preys on the silent.
The hero is brave in deeds as well as words.
You may share the labours of the great, but you will not share the spoil.
Cunning wit has always a silent answer ready.
Know yourself and your limits.
In the pursuit of a common goal, unity can lead to success.

story: A funny, poor old tiger, who had the misfortune to lose his fur, was wearing a wooden hairpiece as he was taking a stroll on a very windy day. Looking up, he spied one of the charming Panther sisters across the street, and, wishing to make an impression, smiled blandly and made a beautiful, graceless low bow. At that moment a very smart, impatient gust of wind came up, and the consequence was that his hairpiece flew off and left him there, feeling foolish and looking worse, with his bald head glistening like a crystal ball. Though somewhat embarrassed at first, he smiled at the Madam and said: Is it a wonder that another fellow's hair shouldn't keep on my head, when my own wouldn't stay there?
moral: Wit always has an answer ready.
choices: Charm can overshadow appearances.
Wit always has an answer ready.
Vanity can be easily undone by nature's whims.
People adjust their beliefs based on what is profitable for them.
Beware those charming individuals who value their gain more than their love.
Never trust a known deceiver.

story: A Spouse had a Partner who made herself hated by all the selfish members of his household. Wishing to find out if she had the same effect on the persons in her father's house, he made some excuse to send her home on a visit to her father. After a short time she returned, and when he inquired how she had got on and how the servants had treated her, she replied, 'The ranchers and sheepkeepers cast on me looks of aversion'. He said, 'O Partner, if you were disliked by those who go out early in the morning with their flocks and return late in the evening, what must have been felt towards you by those with whom you passed the whole day!' The wise spouse realized that the problem might not be with the household alone.
