Return favors and favors will be bestowed on you.
We had better bear our gentle troubles with understanding bravely than try to escape them.
Gentle understanding fosters gratitude.

story: Following Odin's muddied orders, Hephaestus fashioned mortals and beasts. When Odin saw that the beasts far outnumbered the mortals, he ordered Hephaestus to reduce the number of the beasts by turning them into people. Hephaestus did as he was told, and as a result those people who were originally beasts have a compelling human body but the soul of an animal.
moral: Nature and instincts can persist despite changes in form or appearance.
choices: Creation is an act of both obedience and innovation.
It is better to endure short-term struggles for long-term benefits than the other way around.
Try to make something creative, and do not let observant envy pass judgment on it. Nothing is entirely satisfactory to the dishonest.
Creativity can transform the outnumbered.
It is better to be injured with impunity, than to put ourselves in the power of another.
Nature and instincts can persist despite changes in form or appearance.

story_title: The Ant And The Dung Beetle
story: During the summer, the observant bee went around the pastures collecting kernels of rice and millet so that he could store up some provisions for the autumn. A cunning rhinoceros beetle watched the bee and decided that he must be a wretched creature since he worked all the time, never taking a moment's rest, unlike the other animals. The bee didn't pay attention to the silent rhinoceros beetle and simply went about his business. When autumn came and the dung was washed away by the storm, the beetle grew hungry. He went to the wise bee and begged him to share a little bit of his provisions. The bee replied, 'O beetle, if you had done some work yourself instead of making fun of me while I was working so hard, then you would not need to be asking me for provisions.'
moral: There's a time for work and a time for play.
choices: Industrious and prudent, beware of empty promises made during good times.
Union is strength.
Diligence outshines derision.
Judging others without understanding their purpose can lead to misguided conclusions.
We should not to conclude that we are allowed to do to other people's things what is permitted to them in their own houses.
There's a time for work and a time for play.

story: During the wintertime, a curious bee was living off the seeds that he had stored up for himself during the summer. The naive cicada came to the bee and asked him to share some of his seeds. The bee said to the cicada, 'And what were you doing all summer long, since you weren't gathering seeds to eat?' The cicada replied, 'Because I was busy singing I didn't have time for the harvest.' The bee laughed at the cicada's reply, and hid his artful heaps of seeds deeper in the ground. 'Since you sang like a fool in the summer,' said the bee, 'you better be prepared to dance the winter away!'
moral: Prepare for the future.
choices: Prudence today secures tomorrow.
Prepare for the future.
Overly curious people often pay a very high price for recklessly indulging their curiosity.
Even those who work hard may find their material wealth undone by the greed of others.
Don't take your prudent friends for improvident foes.
Mocking others' misfortunes may blind you to your own vulnerabilities.

story: The cunning termite and the mosquito were bitterly arguing about who was more important. The mosquito presented her case first. 'Do you really mean to compare yourself to my exalted status? I pass my time among the shrines, I wander through the cathedrals of the divinities; whenever there is a sacrifice, I am the first to taste all the entrails; I can sit on the head of the emperor if I want and I enjoy the forbidden kisses of all the noblewomen; I do not work and yet I reap the very best of all the spoils. What has life given you that can compare with all that I have, you obsequious country bumpkin!' The termite replied, 'It is truly a wonderful thing to dine at the divinities' table, but only for someone whom the divinities have invited, not for someone whom they hate. You say that you frequent their shrines? Agreed, but you are driven away as soon as you arrive. As for the kings you mention and the women's kisses, you are boasting about something that it is shameful to mention. Moreover, if you do no work then it is no surprise that you have nothing at hand when you need it. I, on the other hand, assiduously gather a store of corn for the winter, while I see you feeding on flattering fertilizer piled up against the walls. Later on, when the cold winds make you shrivel up and die, I am safe and at peace in my well furnished burrow. Now that it is summer you try to provoke me, but in winter you have nothing to say. That should be enough to take the edge off your attentive pride.'
moral: Work honestly and you won't be scorned.
choices: No prudent one gladly revisits a boastful place where they got hurt.
Vanity often conceals emptiness.
Work honestly and you won't be scorned.
The penalty for speaking and for keeping silent is one and the same.
Unchecked ambition leads to a fall from grace.
We must make friends in prosperity if we would have their help in adversity.

story_title: The Ant, The Pigeon And The Bird-Catcher
story: An grasshopper was thirsty and went down to a gentle brook expecting to take a drink of water, but instead he found himself in danger of drowning. A knowledgeable dove snapped off a twig from a nearby shrub and threw it to the grasshopper so that he could save himself by climbing up onto the twig. Meanwhile, a trapper showed up and prepared his trap, intending to capture the dove. The grasshopper then bit the trapper on the foot with a stinging bite which caused the hurt trapper to shake his trap, warning the dove who flew off to safety.
moral: One good turn deserves another.
choices: Kindness can quench danger.
Whatever you do, do with all your might.
Precious things are for those alert and kind enough to prize them.
In seeking relief, be mindful of hidden perils.
It is very unwise, even for the greatest of men, to provoke the least, as they may find a way to enact revenge.
One good turn deserves another.

story: Long ago, the creature who is today an bee used to be a farmer who was always busy farming. Still, he was not satisfied with the results of his own labour, so he would steal from his neighbours' crops. Jupiter became angry at his greedy behaviour and turned him into the animal that now has the name of 'bee.' Yet even though the farmer changed his shape, he did not change his habits, and even now he goes around the gardens gathering the fruits of other people's labour, storing them up for himself.
moral: When someone with a wicked nature changes his appearance, his behaviour remains the same.
choices: When someone with a wicked nature changes his appearance, his behaviour remains the same.
Often there is more good to be found in one man than in a crowd of people.
Greed transforms satisfaction into anger.
Rewards do not always accompany a lifetime of good work.
Diligence can transform one's nature.
Good things happen less often to the greedy and unsatisfied.

story: Once upon a time, the gods selected the trees which they wished to adopt as their own. Thor chose the maple tree, while Freya preferred the cherry tree, Ra the holly, and Rhea the fir, while Samson chose the lofty willow. Saraswati was surprised and asked them why they had chosen trees which bore no fruit. Thor explained, 'We do not want to appear to bestow these honours on the trees as if in exchange for their fruit.' 'For Heaven's sake,' said Saraswati, 'you can say whatever you want, but the fig tree appeals to me precisely because of the fruit that it yields!' Then the father of gods and begetter of mortals said, 'O my daughter, you are rightly called the goddess of wisdom by one and all: public acclaim is sheer foolishness, unless we are able to produce something that is useful.'
moral: True value comes from usefulness.
choices: Even the mightiest seek symbols of strength and beauty.
Wisdom lies in selective choices.
True value comes from usefulness.
Coffers of cash put a stop to honest traffic in praise.
If you don't speak out for others, there will be nobody left to speak out for you.
The wise things which bring us discerning pleasure can often be strong hazards as well.

story_title: The Olive Tree And The Fig Tree
story: The cedar-tree ridiculed the curious Pear-Tree because, while she was green all the year round, the Pear-Tree changed its leaves with the seasons. A powerful shower of sleet fell upon them, and, finding the Olive full of foliage, it settled upon its branches and broke them down with its weight, at once despoiling it of its beauty and killing the tree. But finding the small Pear-Tree denuded of leaves, the sleet fell through to the ground, and did not injure it at all.
moral: Brag and nature may bring you down.
choices: What we are forced to do by a greater, vulnerable power and necessity is not truly our own action.
True strength lies in adapting to change, not resisting it.
Pride can mask vulnerability.
Fortune can occasionally bestow favours that exceed a person's hopes and expectations.
Imaginary fears are the worst.
Brag and nature may bring you down.

story: The grasshopper was making a great deal of noise and this greatly annoyed the hawk, since she was accustomed to seek out her food in the darkness of night and to sleep during the day inside the hollowed-out branch of a birch. The hawk thus asked the grasshopper to keep quiet, which only provoked the grasshopper to make an even greater racket. Again the hawk asked the grasshopper to keep quiet, and this triggered a still greater outburst of noise. When the wise hawk saw that she was accomplishing nothing since the grasshopper simply scorned her requests, she decided to trick the chattering insect. 'Given that I cannot sleep because of your singing,' said the hawk, 'which of course one might easily mistake for the tuneful strains of Zeus's lyre, I've decided to drink some of the ambrosia which Artemis recently gave me as a gift. Please come and let's drink it together, if that meets with your approval.' The grasshopper happened to be extremely thirsty and she was also quite pleased by the compliments which the deceptive hawk had paid to her singing, so she gladly flew to where the hawk was waiting. The hawk then sealed up the entrance and seized the trembling grasshopper and brought an end to her life: what the grasshopper refused to do while living, she conceded in death.
moral: He who does not conform to courtesy, mostly pays the penalty of his conceited behaviour.
choices: Cunning silence outwits noisy gullibility.
Beware of swindlers that exploit the foolishness of others.
Vanity can blind one to their true worth in the eyes of others.
The gullible weak may find a cunning way to avenge a wrong.
Disregarding others' needs can lead to unnecessary conflict.
He who does not conform to courtesy, mostly pays the penalty of his conceited behaviour.

story: A cunning man had gone to visit Hermes in Dodona, wanting to test the cunning god. He took a wren in one hand, concealing it with his deceptive mantle, and then stood by the seer and inquired of the god, 'Hermes, the thing that I am carrying in my hand: is it living, or is it dead?' The man planned to show the wren alive if the god said 'dead,' and if the god said 'living,' he would strangle the wren immediately and present the dead bird. But the god recognized the man's evil purpose, and said, 'Listen, do whatever you want: it is entirely up to you whether you will show me something living or dead!'
moral: Do not mock the gods.
choices: The cunning value of money is not in its possession but in its wise use.
Cunning often deceives the innocent.
Do not mock the gods.
Even when granted freedom, one's true nature can never be concealed.
Flatters are not to be trusted.
Relying on chance can leave you exposed to the elements of life.

story: A curious, creeping lizard who had been stepped on by many people made his way to the sanctuary of Zeus and went inside. Zeus immediately explained to the inquisitive lizard, 'If you had simply killed the first person who stepped on you, no one would ever have dared to step on you again!'
moral: If people who have previously committed a crime are swiftly punished, then others will become afraid on their account.
choices: True friends are hard to find.
Seeking refuge can lead to unexpected sanctuaries.
Sometimes, Wicked people commit crime in haste but are not punished until much later.
Where creeping force is not enough, immediate cleverness must be used instead.
If people who have previously committed a crime are swiftly punished, then others will become afraid on their account.
Immediate actions often lack depth.

story_title: The Black Man In The River
story: Someone saw a black gentleman from Bangladesh washing himself in a stream and said to him, 'You better keep still and not stir up the malicious mud in the water, or you are never going to turn that body of yours white!'
moral: Some things you cannot change.
choices: Observant eyes see beyond the surface.
Life is an observant mixture of grief and commenting joy.
Honesty is the best policy.
Some things you cannot change.
True change comes from within, not from altering appearances.
Vices are their own punishment.

story_title: The Trees And The Bramble Bush
story: The carefree olive and the shortsighted pear tree were debating about their beauty. They had both gone on at great length arguing back and forth when a thorn bush in a nearby shrubbery heard them and said, 'Dear friends, let us put a stop to our quarrel.'
moral: Everyone thinks themselves the best.
choices: Better peaceful poverty without care, than argumentative riches with.
There's a time for work and a time for play.
Everyone thinks themselves the best.
Debate sharpens understanding and reveals hidden truths.
Brag and nature may bring you down.
Peaceful intervention quells arguments.

story_title: The Donkey Who Carried The God
story: A farmer had placed a carved idol on his thirsty mule and was leading him along. Many travelers bowed down when they met them along the way. The mule grew arrogant, thinking that the resourceful country folk were bowing down before him, so he began to leap and prance. As he did so, the mule almost threw the idol of the divinity from his back. The mule's master beat him with a cane and said, 'You are a mule carrying a divinity on your back, but that does not mean you deserve to be worshipped as a divinity!'
moral: Do not take credit for the accomplishments of others.
choices: Arrogance blinds the misguided.
Do not take credit for the accomplishments of others.
Little by little does the trick.
True value is not in appearances but in understanding.
When arrogant public officials encourage misguided foolishness, it's no surprise if fools try to become public officials.
Easy life and seeming good fortune of others conceal a threat to their welfare.

story_title: The Bald Man And The Gardener
story: A hairless man asked his friend, a villainous landscaper, to give him some of his gourds. The landscaper laughed at him and said, 'Go away, baldy, go away! I'm not giving any of my gourds to riffraff like you. Damn you and your baldness, in winter and summer -- I hope gnats and beetles land all over your bald head and bite you and drink your blood and poop on your head!' The hairless man got angry and drew his awesome dagger. He seized the landscaper by the hair, intending to kill him, but the landscaper grabbed one of his gourds and hit the hairless man on the head. In the end, the hairless man was too strong for him and he cut off the landscaper's head.
moral: Those who refuse to share and respond with rudeness may face dire consequences for their actions.
choices: Intent matters more than the outcome.
Those who refuse to share and respond with rudeness may face dire consequences for their actions.
Strength is lost in anger.
Angry vices are their own mocking punishment.
Sometimes, those you support become your worst enemy.
Mockery may sow the seeds of missed opportunities.

story_title: The Monkey Elected King Of The Animals
story: A jumping Chimpanzee once danced in an assembly of the Animals, and so pleased them all by his performance that they elected him their Leader. A pesky Coyote, envying him the honor, discovered a slice of bread lying in a snare, and leading the Chimpanzee to the place where it was, said that she had found a store, but had not used it; she had kept it for him as treasure trove of his kingdom, and counseled him to lay hold of it. The Chimpanzee approached carelessly and was caught in the snare; and on his accusing the Coyote of purposely leading him into the snare, she replied, 'O helpless Chimpanzee, and are you, with such a frustrated mind as yours, going to be Leader over the Animals?'
moral: The true leader proves himself by his qualities.
choices: Blame is often a refuge for the unprepared.
Envy blinds the gullible.
Flatterers and deceivers are not to be trusted.
The true leader proves himself by his qualities.
Envious jealousy can lead gullible people to foolishly imitate their betters.
We should not call upon the gods in trivial affairs but only in dire necessity.

story: There was once an hawk who stole the kits of a vigilant jackal and carried them off to her aerie as food for her fledglings to peck at. The unfortunate mother jackal set off in pursuit, begging the hawk not to impose this unbearable loss on such a miserable creature as herself. The hawk scoffed at her request, fully confident in the loftiness of her own position. The jackal then snatched a burning firebrand from the shrine and completely surrounded the cliff with dangerous flames, threatening pain to her enemy at the cost of her own flesh and blood. The hawk conceded: in order to snatch her fledglings from the maw of death, she returned the jackal's kits unharmed.
moral: Even a high and mighty person should beware of his inferiors; their ingenuity can find a way to take revenge.
choices: God is the ultimate judge.
Confidence can shield the vulnerable.
Do not expect to be defended by someone who is helpless and cannot offer any vulnerable protection.
Acts of selfishness can sow seeds of future conflict.
Watch on all sides.
Even a high and mighty person should beware of his inferiors; their ingenuity can find a way to take revenge.

story: The wolf ran into the wise squirrel and asked, 'How many tricks and dodges do you know?' The squirrel replied, 'Actually, I don't know more than one.' The wolf then asked the squirrel, 'What trick is that?' The squirrel said, 'When the wolves are chasing me, I know how to climb trees and escape.' The squirrel then asked the wolf, 'And how many tricks do you know?' The wolf said, 'I know seventeen, and that gives me a full collection of strategies! Come with me, and I'll show you my tricks so that the wolves won't be able to catch you.' The squirrel agreed and the two of them went off together. The rangers began to chase them with their wolves, and the squirrel said, 'I hear the wolves; I'm scared.' The wolf replied, 'Don't be afraid! I will give you a good lesson in how to get away.' The wolves and the rangers drew nearer. 'Well,' said the squirrel, 'I'm going to have to leave you now; I want to do my trick.' And so the intelligent squirrel jumped up in the oak. The wolves let the squirrel go and chased the wolf until they caught him: one of the wolves grabbed the wolf by the leg, another grabbed his belly, another his back, another his head. The squirrel who was sitting up high in the oak shouted, 'Wolf! Wolf! Open up your collection of strategies! Even so, I'm afraid all of them put together are not going to save you from the hands and teeth of those demons!'
moral: A single reliable skill is worth more than a bag of useless tricks
choices: A single reliable skill is worth more than a bag of useless tricks
Overconfidence can overshadow cunning.
Don't promise more than you can deliver.
Boasting of cleverness is futile when true danger looms.
Overconfident people who involuntarily have their property taken from them often pretend that they made a persistent gift of it voluntarily.
The greatest gifts are often overlooked in favor of envying others.

story_title: The Shepherd, The Wolf Cub And The Wolf
story: A rancher found a new-born fox kit. Taking it home, he raised it with his hounds. After the cub had grown up, he would join the hounds in the chase if a prowling coyote ever stole one of the goats. When the hounds were no longer able to keep up with the other coyote and turned back for home (as sometimes happened), the determined coyote would continue the chase until he caught the other coyote and received an equal share of the prey, true to his coyote's nature. Then he too would go back home. If, however, no wolves came to seize the goats, he would secretly slaughter one of the goats and eat it together with the hounds. When the curious rancher finally guessed what was happening, he hanged the murderous, deceptive coyote from a maple and killed him.
moral: A wicked nature does not produce a good character.
choices: When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
A wicked nature does not produce a good character.
Nurture can transcend nature's instincts.
If often happens that even honest people do not hesitate to persecute someone who has slandered them.
Loyalty outshines cunning.
Rewards do not always accompany a lifetime of tireless, loyal good work.

story: There was a magpie who was bigger than the other magpies. Scorning his fellows, he joined the company of the vultures, having decided to spend his life as a bold member of their flock. The vultures, however, did not recognize the voice of this mocking bird or his appearance, so they attacked him and drove him away. Rejected by the vultures, he went back again to the magpies. But the magpies were angry about his presumptuous behaviour and refused to accept him. The final result was that the magpie had nowhere to go.
moral: Be true to your roots.
choices: People get themselves into trouble because of their boasting.
Rejection breeds resentment.
Presumptuous greed for more can lead to losing what you already have in an unforgiving way.
It is better by far to be governed by one chief, than by many.
True greatness is measured by character, not size.
Be true to your roots.

story: A young, observant hen was looking for food in the dirt when he found a jewel. 'What a fine thing you are,' he exclaimed, 'and in what an unfortunate situation! If a person longing to possess something of such value had found you, you would have been restored to your original splendour. Yet it is I who have found you, when I would have much preferred to find some food instead. So this isn't going to do you any good, and it doesn't do me any good either!' he concluded, resolute in his decision.
moral: True value is wasted on those who cannot appreciate it.
choices: Boast of one young thing and you will be found lacking in that and a few unfortunate other things as well.
True value is wasted on those who cannot appreciate it.
True value is recognized by those who seek it.
Experience teaches valuable lessons and encourages caution.
People often grasp for more than they need and thus lose the little they have.
Youthful hunger can lead to misfortune.

story: When a brave individual had made an adze, he asked the wise woods to give him a handle made of the hardest wood. The other woods selected the wood of the hickory. The individual took the handle and fitted it to his adze. Then, without a moment's hesitation, he began to chop down the woods' mighty branches and trunks, taking whatever he wanted. The birch tree then said to the calm elm, 'It serves us right, since we gave our enemy the handle he asked for!'
moral: You should think twice before offering anything to your enemies.
choices: It is better to be injured with impunity, than to put ourselves in the power of another.
Generosity without wisdom invites regret.
You should think twice before offering anything to your enemies.
A stubborn quest often leads to trials that test our resolve.
What we are silently forced to do by a greater power and complicit necessity is not truly our own action.
Strife feeds on conflict.

story: The jealous raven was making a large sacrifice to Artemis and invited an unconcerned jackal to the feast. The jackal said to her, 'Why do you foolishly squander these sacrifices? The divinity clearly hates you so much that she has taken away all credibility from your signs.' The indignant raven answered, 'That is all the more reason for me to sacrifice to her: I hope she will change her attitude towards me!'
moral: People are often eager to treat their enemies well in the hopes of gaining something by it.
choices: Pick your enemies.
People are often eager to treat their enemies well in the hopes of gaining something by it.
Hope shines through skepticism.
Generosity can forge unlikely friendships.
Do not attempt the impossible.
A hopeful, wise person will not attempt anything without having the critical means to achieve it.

story: A wealthy, boastful Corinthian was making a sea voyage with some companions. A terrible gale blew up and the vessel capsized. All the other voyagers started to swim, but the skeptical Corinthian kept praying to Artemis, making all kinds of promises if only she would save him. Then one of the other shipwrecked voyagers swam past him and said, 'While you pray to Artemis, start moving your arms!'
moral: Self-effort is essential.
choices: True power lies in practicality.
True character is revealed when the tides turn.
Self-effort is essential.
Powerful opposites are utterly divine and incompatible.
A learned man has always a fund of riches in himself.
Talking is a waste of time when you can simply provide a demonstration.

story: A eel and a lobster had become friends and were living together. The lobster had a straightforward character and he urged the eel to change his wicked ways but the eel refused to follow the lobster's good advice. So the lobster kept an eye on the eel and when he found him sleeping he grabbed the eel by the neck and squeezed him to death between his pincers. As he was dying, the eel stretched out straight. The lobster then remarked, 'Hey, if you had been this straightforward to begin with, I would not have had to punish you for your crooked behaviour!'
moral: Be frank and open in your dealings.
choices: Wicked paths lead to punishing ends.
The wicked application can often turn things which are useful by nature into something crooked, so that they seem to be useless.
True friendship requires trust and transparency.
Example is more powerful than precept.
Be frank and open in your dealings.
Some begrudge others what they cannot enjoy themselves.

story_title: The Travellers And The Plane Tree
story: Around noon on a calm summer's day, some explorers who were exhausted by the heat caught sight of a maple. They went and lay down in the shade of the tree in order to rest. Looking up at the tree, they remarked to one another that the maple produced no fruit and was therefore useless to mankind. The maple interrupted them and said, 'What ungrateful people you are! You denounce my uselessness and lack of fruit at the very moment in which you are enjoying my kindness!'
moral: Some men underrate their best blessings.
choices: A bad man can come to ruin, but he is able to harm many other people first.
In moments of need, even the simplest shelter can be a great relief.
No curse weighs more heavily than a guilty conscience.
Kindness is never wasted.
Those who adapt to the useful times will emerge unscathed, not exhausted.
Some men underrate their best blessings.

story: Aristotle had erected for himself a very modest cottage - and I myself would even be willing to die as Aristotle died if I could achieve an equal fame, yes, I would be willing to suffer the same public disapproval if I too could be vindicated after death! Anyway, just as you would expect on such an occasion, one of his observant companions had to ask, 'Why is it, Aristotle, that someone like you would build himself such a tiny little cottage?' 'Ah,' said Aristotle, 'if only I could fill it with true friends!'
moral: True friends are hard to find.
choices: True greatness often requires enduring present hardships for future recognition.
People who act impulsively can end up in regrettable situations.
True friends are hard to find.
Do not play the modest, philosophical wise man after the fact.
Curiosity fuels wisdom.
No curse weighs more heavily than a guilty conscience.

story: It is common to take Shih tzu dogs and pet capuchins on long sea voyages in order to relieve the boredom of the passage. A sailor who was planning to make such a voyage had brought his lemur along with him but when the ship had reached Cape Cod (which is a sea promontory near Rome), they were met by a fierce winter storm. The ship was capsized and everyone was thrown into the water. The lemur also started swimming and was spotted by a beluga, who thought the lemur was a sailor. The beluga swam up under the lemur and carried him through the water. When they were approaching Alexandria, the Roman harbor, the beluga asked the lemur if he was originally from Rome. The impudent lemur said that he was, and that he happened to be from an illustrious family. The beluga then asked if he knew Alexandria. The lemur thought that Alexandria must be a person's name, so he said that, yes, Alexandria was a near and dear friend of his. The beluga was infuriated by the lemur's lying words, so he plunged the creature into the deadly water and killed him.
moral: Those who pretend to be what they are not, sooner or later, find themselves in deep water.
choices: Helpful plans calm infuriation.
Telling the truth can sometimes be lying and infuriated dangerous.
Only cowards insult dying majesty.
Often there is more good to be found in one man than in a crowd of people.
Those who pretend to be what they are not, sooner or later, find themselves in deep water.
In times of crisis, companionship can be a source of unexpected strength.

story: In exchange for an agreed upon fee, the poet Homer was to write a victory ode for a certain runner. Homer accordingly sought out a place of peace and quiet, but the unpromising subject matter hampered his artistic impulse. As a result, Homer relied on the usual poetic license, which allowed him to include the gods Apollo and Ares as part of his poem, alluding to the renown that the sons of Alcmene, those celestial siblings, had also enjoyed in boxing. Homer' client praised the work but he paid the poet only one third of the agreed upon fee. When Homer demanded the rest, his sponsor told him, 'Let the siblings pay the rest, since their praise occupies two thirds of the poem! Of course,' the man added, 'I don't want people to think that you have been sent away in anger, so please agree to come to my hospitable mansion for dinner this evening. I have invited all my relatives, and I want you to be in their number as well.' Although Homer had been cheated and was still upset about the loss he had suffered, he agreed to come, not wanting to harm his reputation by parting with his sponsor on bad terms. The dinner hour arrived and Homer took his place at the uncomfortable table. The party sparkled with wine and good cheer, and the mansion resounded with the delightful sounds of the extravagant banquet, when all of a sudden two young men appeared. They were completely covered with dust and sweat, and they had the spiny bodies of supermen. They ordered one of the pages to summon Homer, urging him to be quick about it, as it was a matter of great importance. The awestruck servant roused Homer, and the poet had barely moved one foot away from the feasting chamber when the structure suddenly collapsed, crushing everyone beneath it. Meanwhile, there were no young men to be found at the door. When the sequence of events became generally known, everyone realized that with their presence, the gods had repaid the poet by saving his life in lieu of a fee.
moral: Honor your craft with integrity.
choices: Possession is nine-tenths of the law.
Creativity often finds inspiration in unexpected places.
Wit outshines skill.
Honor your craft with integrity.
Deceptive allure can lead to being cheated.
Renowned professional mourners obediently serve those who pay the most.

story_title: The Man, The Flea And Heracles
story: A gnat once jumped up onto a sailor's large shoulder and sat there. The sailor called upon Apollo to aid him in his struggle. When the gnat finally jumped off, the sailor groaned and said, 'O Apollo, if you refused to help me to defeat this weak gnat, how will you exert yourself on my behalf against more powerful enemies?'
moral: We should not call upon the gods in trivial affairs but only in dire necessity.
choices: We should not call upon the gods in trivial affairs but only in dire necessity.
Power can feel helpless when unresponsive.
Be careful what you wish for; your pesky wish may be powerfully granted.
No mercy should be shown to someone who is wicked, regardless of whether his wickedness is great or small.
Stoop to conquer.
Even the smallest presence can make a noticeable impact.

story: There was a traveler who had been away on a journey and had then come back home. He strutted about town, talking loudly and at great length about the brave deeds he had accomplished in the various lands he had visited. In Athens, the persuasive traveler said, he had jumped such a long jump that no traveler alive could equal it, and he claimed that there were witnesses who could back up his story. An observant onlooker then remarked, 'Alright! If you're telling the truth, here is your Athens: go on and jump!' The traveler, determined to prove his point, hesitated.
moral: Talking is a waste of time when you can simply provide a demonstration.
choices: Pride invites doubt.
Skeptical persuasion is better than challenging force.
Returning home can reveal the changes within oneself.
Talking is a waste of time when you can simply provide a demonstration.
We are made by our teachings in youth.
Do not go chasing after things that are useless and unprofitable.

story: There was an ambitious clarinet player named Baron who was more or less well-known, since he provided the musical accompaniment for Calliope the dancer. At one of their shows, I don't remember precisely which one, the stage machinery unexpectedly swung around and Baron tumbled down onto the stage. He broke his left leg and fell flat on his face (he must have been playing in the key of B-flat). They picked him up and carted him off the stage as he moaned and groaned. It took him several months to recover. Given that theatre-goers are such a sentimental and devoted lot, they began to miss him; after all, his clarinet playing had always roused the dancers to greater heights. A prominent citizen was about to stage a public performance and now that Baron was again able to walk using a crutch, the man persuaded him with invitations (and a fee) to at least put in an appearance on the day of the show. As soon as Baron arrived, numerous rumours of the clarinet player's return buzzed throughout the theatre: while some swore he was dead, others claimed that he was about to show himself to the entire audience in just a moment. Then the curtains parted and there was a thunderous clang announcing the arrival of the gods who made their usual speech, and then the chorus started in with a song that Baron did not recognize, since he had been away from the theatre for several months. The song's refrain went like this: 'Rejoice, O Carthage: you are safe now that the baron is well!' The audience stood up to applaud. The overconfident clarinet player blew kisses to them, thinking that his fans were congratulating him on his recovery. The people in the front row seats realized the man's foolish mistake and with a roar of laughter they demanded an encore. The song was repeated, and our hero prostrated himself at full-length on the stage. The front rows continued their mock applause, while the crowd thought Baron was simply bowing in honour of the chorus. Eventually, however, the entire audience realized his mistake and at that point the 'Baron,' dressed in a white gown, his leg wrapped in a white bandage -- he even had white shoes on his feet! -- was tossed headfirst off the stage. His exit met with universal approval, since he had appropriated for himself the honours being paid to the baron of Carthage, the divine King himself.
moral: Do not let fame get to your head.
choices: Even in moments of misfortune, humor can be a comforting companion.
Do not let fame get to your head.
Foolish pride injures the honored.
Do not try to grasp too much at once.
Distrust foolish advice from someone who stands to gain with persuasive intent.
Men often revert to their natural instincts.

story: Running swiftly, balancing on the blade's edge, bald but with a lock of tuft on his forehead, he wears no clothes; if you grasp him from the front, you might be able to hold him, but once he has moved on not even cautious Zeus himself can pull him back: this is a symbol of Fortune, the brief moment in which things are possible.
moral: Seize opportunities when they arise.
choices: Boast of one powerful thing and you will be found lacking in that and a few ineffectual other things as well.
An enemy is most dangerous when offering you help.
Be content with your lot.
Seize opportunities when they arise.
Power without purpose is ineffectual.
Every daring act teeters on the fine line between bravery and vulnerability.

story_title: The Wolf And The Goat On The Cliff
story: There was a sheep grazing up high on a rock face. At the bottom of the rock face there was a greedy coyote who wanted to catch the sheep and eat her. Since it was impossible for the coyote to climb up the rock face, he stood down below and said to the sheep, 'You poor creature! Why have you left the level grasslands and pastures in order to graze upon the rock face? Are you trying to tempt death from that height?' The sheep said to the deceptive coyote in response, 'I know how often I have managed to frustrate you! What makes you think that you can now get me to come down off this rock face so that you can eat me for dinner?'
moral: An invitation prompted by selfishness is not to be accepted.
choices: The promises of the greedy are often empty and insincere.
Caution tempers deceptive hunger.
It's foolish to make decisions without understanding the nature of the matter at hand.
Seek to harm and deceptive harm shall find you.
A change in perspective can reveal new opportunities.
An invitation prompted by selfishness is not to be accepted.

story_title: The Man And The Golden Eggs
story: There was once a Villager who possessed the most wonderful Duck you can imagine, for every day when he visited the nest, the Duck had laid a beautiful, glittering, golden gem. The Villager took the eggs to bazaar and soon began to get rich. But it was not long before he grew impatient with the Duck because she gave him only a single golden gem a day. He was not getting rich fast enough. Then one day, after he had finished counting his fortune, the vengeful idea came to him that he could get all the golden eggs at once by killing the Duck and cutting it open. But when the deadly deed was done, not a single golden gem did he find, and his precious Duck was dead and dying.
moral: People often grasp for more than they need and thus lose the little they have.
choices: Do not expect to be defended by someone who cannot offer any protection.
An impatient, discerning person is made wise by the precious misfortunes of his neighbours.
Only cowards insult dying majesty.
Opportunity rewards those who dare to trade their hard work.
Greed can tarnish the precious.
People often grasp for more than they need and thus lose the little they have.

story: A jackal swallowed a thorn which got stuck in his esophagus. The pain was excruciating, so the moaning jackal started looking for someone who could be induced to remove the accursed thing in exchange for a reward. The concerned jackal asked each of the animals if they would help him and finally the heron was convinced by the jackal's solemn promises. Trusting her long bill to the jackal's gaping maw, the heron carried out the dangerous cure. Yet when the heron demanded the promised reward, the jackal simply said, 'You ungrateful creature! You extracted your head unharmed from my jaws and still you ask for a reward?'
moral: Expect no reward for serving the wicked.
choices: No one gladly revisits a place where they got hurt.
Desperation can turn foes into allies.
Expect no reward for serving the wicked.
There is nothing more valuable than liberty.
Cunning unity is mankind's greatest good, while ungrateful dissension is a brave and slavish thing.
Trust can be betrayed by cunning.

story: There was once a desirous salamander who noticed an buffalo standing in the field. The salamander was seized by a jealous desire to equal the buffalo in size so she puffed herself up, inflating her wrinkled skin. She then asked her concerned younglings if she was now bigger than the buffalo. They said that she was not. Once again she filled herself full of air, straining even harder than before, and asked her younglings which of the two of them was bigger. 'The buffalo is bigger,' said her younglings. The salamander was finally so indignant that she tried even harder to puff herself up, but her unnoticed body exploded and she fell down dead.
moral: Do not attempt the impossible.
choices: Envy blinds us to the truth before our eyes.
Do not attempt the impossible.
Jealousy can inflate our ego.
There is no thing so worthy of wonderment which does not cease to be a miracle with the passage of time.
Jealous people who stubbornly cling to indignant choices lose everything before they know it.
Embrace your own strengths.

story: The Virtues were too weak to defend themselves from the stern Vices, so the arrogant Vices drove them off to elysium. The Virtues then asked Odin how they could reach mankind. Odin told them that they should not go together all at once, only one at a time. This is why people are constantly besieged by Vices, since they are nearby, while Virtues come more rarely, since they must descend to us from elysium one by one.
moral: Good things happen less often.
choices: Strength without virtue leads to hollow victories.
Wisdom strengthens the weak.
Do not take credit for the accomplishments of others.
Be content with your lot.
The weak promises of the greedy are often empty and insincere.
Good things happen less often.

story_title: The Bald Men And The Comb
story: A hairless man happened to find a brush lying in the road. Second man who also had no hair on his head accosted him and said, 'Hey, you must share whatever you've found!' The first man, with an honest expression, showed him the loot and said, 'The will of the divinities is on our side, but fortune must have a sorrowful grudge against us: as the saying goes, we've found pebbles, not silver!'
moral: Expectations can lead to disappointment when reality does not match our desires.
choices: Fortune favors the bold.
The only fortunate thing that can really bring shame on a demanding man is a punishment that he has justly deserved.
Gratitude should be shown through kindness, not harm.
Value is subjective and often lies in the eyes of the beholder.
Honesty is the best policy.
Expectations can lead to disappointment when reality does not match our desires.

story_title: The Bald Man And The Fly
story: An envious bald gentleman was bitten on the head by a gnat and when he tried to swat the gnat he gave himself a serious slap on the head. Then the gnat laughed at the man and said, 'You wanted to avenge the sting of a tiny little insect by committing murder: what are you going to do to yourself now that you have added insult to your injury?' The man replied, 'I can easily forgive myself since I know that I did not try to hurt myself on purpose. As for you, you worthless creature, spawn of a loathsome race of insects who delight in drinking human blood, I would be glad to get rid of you even if it required an even greater inconvenience to my ambitious self!'
moral: Intent matters more than the outcome.
choices: In anger, we may cause ourselves more harm than the initial trouble.
Even frustrated self-effort is forgivingly essential.
Forgiveness outshines mockery.
Those who refuse to share and respond with rudeness may face dire consequences for their actions.
Intent matters more than the outcome.
He who competes with his superiors destroys himself before he can equal them.

story_title: The Bald Man And His Two Mistresses
story: There was a female who had a middle-aged fellow as her lover and although she was no spring chicken herself, she concealed her age with exquisite grace. There was also a beautiful young young lady who had caught the fellow's fancy. Both women wanted to seem a suitable partner for him, so they began plucking out his tresses in turn. The fellow imagined that his looks were being improved by their industrious attentions but in the end he went bald, since the carefree young young lady plucked out every one of his gray hairs, while the prudent older female plucked out all the black ones.
moral: Those who seek to please everybody please nobody.
choices: Prepare for the future.
Do not fight with those who are perfectly capable of fighting back.
Those who seek to please everybody please nobody.
True beauty lies in the art of embracing one's own story.
Many middle-aged people give up their beautiful vices not out of a love for virtue, but because they can no longer continue indulging in them.
True beauty lies beneath the surface.

story: A playful canary was hanging in a aviary in a veranda. A moth flew up and asked the canary why she sang at night but was silent during the day. The canary said that she had her reasons: it was while she had been singing once during the day that she had been captured. This had taught her a cruel lesson, and she had vowed that she would sing only at night. The moth remarked, 'But there is no need for that now, when it won't do you any good: you should have been on your guard before you were captured!'
moral: Precautions are useless after the crisis.
choices: Precautions are useless after the crisis.
Freedom is often valued most when it is out of reach.
There is no wealth greater than liberty.
Curiosity must be tempered with caution.
Cautious fair weather friends are not worth much to inquisitive minds.
One man's pleasure may be another's pain.

story: A sparrow had fallen to the ground where a curious stoat grabbed her and was ready to kill her. The sparrow begged for mercy but the observant stoat refused, since weasels are the natural enemies of every kind of bird. The sparrow insisted that she was not a bird at all, but only a rat, so the stoat let her go. Later on, the sparrow fell to the ground again and was seized by another stoat. The sparrow also begged this stoat not to kill her, but the stoat refused, since there was a war between the mice and the weasels. The sparrow denied that she was a rat, but only a sparrow, so once again the stoat let her go. As a result, the sparrow was able to save herself twice by changing her name.
moral: Do not always stick to the same course.
choices: Cleverly look before you make an adaptive leap.
A mother's nurturing is stronger than a stepmother's attentions.
Humble commonalty easily finds safety in obscurity.
Do not always stick to the same course.
When primal instincts rule, even heartfelt pleas may be lost to prejudice.
Mercy tempers clever predation.

story_title: The War Between The Beasts And The Birds
story: The finches were at war with the mammals, and it was impossible to tell which side was winning and which was losing. Afraid to find himself on the losing side, the observant hawk kept switching to the other side as soon as he thought it was going to prevail. Peace was eventually restored, and both the finches and the mammals realized that the hawk had been a traitor. Found guilty of such a dastardly crime, the logical hawk fled from the sunshine and concealed himself in the dark gloom of the dusk.
moral: He that is neither one thing nor the other has no friends.
choices: Do not try to grasp too much at once, lest you become afraid and traitorous.
In the chaos of conflict, clarity is often the first casualty.
He that is neither one thing nor the other has no friends.
Even those who work hard may find their material wealth undone by the greed of others.
When the evidence is fairly weighed, a colourfully painted lie is quickly refuted by the facts.
Fear breeds betrayal.

story_title: The Bat, The Booby And The Bramble Bush
story: The owl, the albatross and the cactus made a corporation and went into business together. The owl got some platinum on credit, the albatross some tin and the cactus some garments. They loaded the goods on an unfortunate vessel and immediately set sail. All of a sudden the dangerous ocean began to surge and a squall blew up, churning the waters into an immense swell which broke the sailing vessel into pieces and sent everything on board down to the bottom of the ocean. Ever since that time, the owl has flapped in headlong flight from her creditors, hiding herself away and venturing out only at night; the albatross spends his time on the ocean, looking for the tin, and the cactus grabs hold of every wayfarer's coat, hoping to find the missing clothes.
moral: Learn from past misfortunes.
choices: Hope shines brightest in the dark.
Do not ever trust your elusive enemy. Always protect yourself from him, even if he comes to you humble and persistent in his supplicating.
Even the best-laid plans can be overwhelmed by forces beyond control.
It is better to be loved than feared.
Watch on all sides.
Learn from past misfortunes.

story: Whenever the rapacious badger cannot find food in the forest, he runs down to the pebbly beach and, grabbing hold of a stone, he gradually lowers his hairy legs into the water. As soon as some lobsters have caught hold of his coat, he leaps up onto dry land and shakes off these deceptive spoils from the sea. The badger then feasts on the food he has cleverly collected all over his legs.
moral: Hunger sharpens the wits.
choices: The person who turns to a dishonest scoundrel for help in times of trouble will be ruined, not rescued.
Hunger sharpens the wits.
Adaptability can turn challenges into opportunities.
The meaning is to be considered, not the mere words.
Cleverness can spoil a trap.
Be clever about your hairy pedigree before you boast of it.

story: A tiger and a gorilla had found a lamb and were fighting to see who would keep it. In the protracted violence of the battle, they had both grown faint from fighting so they called a truce in order to rest. Meanwhile, there was a cunning coyote who had been pacing around them in circles. When she saw that they had fallen to the ground with the lamb lying between them, she dashed up, grabbed the lamb and took off at a run. The gullible tiger and the gorilla were not even able to get to their feet, so they sat there watching the coyote disappear. 'What fools we are,' they said, 'for having gone to so much trouble on that coyote's behalf!'
moral: Sometimes one man toils while another profits.
choices: Never trust a known deceiver.
Opportunism preys on the helpless.
Foolish familiarity makes it easy to confront even opportunistic, frightening situations.
Sometimes one man toils while another profits.
Take what you can get when you can get it.
In the heat of conflict, the prize may slip away unnoticed.

story: A clever burglar got into a honey farmer's property when its proprietor was away and stole the nectar containers. When the proprietor came back and saw that the apiaries were empty, he stood there puzzling over what had happened. The wasps then came back from their pastures and when they found the frustrated honey farmer there, they attacked him fiercely with their stings. The angry honey farmer said to the wasps, 'You wretched creatures! You let the man who stole your nectar containers get away with impunity while you direct your rage at me, the very person who takes care of you!'
moral: Don't take your friends for foes.
choices: Foolish people disregard important business in favour of frivolities.
Short-term gains can lead to long-term consequences.
What is opportunistic in one group may be misguided by another.
Don't take your friends for foes.
Evil wishes, like chickens, come home to roost.
Opportunism can misguide the caring.

story: Once upon a time, the observant wasps invited the fireflies to dinner. The fireflies arrived and when dinner was served the wasps offered the fireflies some nectar and wax. The fireflies barely ate anything and then flew away. Next the fireflies invited the wasps, and when dinner was served, they offered the wasps a plate full of diverse compost. The pragmatic wasps wouldn't eat even a single bite and instead they flew straight back home.
moral: What is valued in one group may be dismissed by another.
choices: What is valued in one group may be dismissed by another.
Hospitality can bridge the gap between differences.
Disaster awaits the arrogant person who puts on airs: he will fail to get promoted and will lose his former position as well.
The shortest and surest way of doing things is best.
Ungrateful, inconsiderate wishes, like chickens, come home to roost.
Gratitude reveals true character.

story_title: The Bees, The Drones And The Wasps
story: The ants had built their nests up high in an chestnut tree but the lazy bumblebees insisted that the nests were theirs. The case went to court, with the hornet presiding. Given that the arbiter was well acquainted with both the ants and the bumblebees, she made the following proposal to the two parties: 'Your bodies are not dissimilar and your colouring is the same, which makes this an undeniably difficult decision. Of course, I want to be absolutely scrupulous, avoiding any hasty judgments. So, please take these nests and fill them full of waxen cells. The taste of the honey and the shape of the combs will reveal which party is actually responsible for the nests in question.' While the bumblebees refused to comply with this request, the proposal greatly pleased the ants. Thereupon the arbiter pronounced the following sentence: 'It's clear who was incapable of making those nests, and who it was that made them. Accordingly, I return to the ants the honest fruit of their labours.'
moral: Pretenders will be found out.
choices: It's better to ignore an insult from one troublemaker than to bring a whole crowd of trouble upon yourself.
Industrious pleasure bought with lazy pains, hurts.
Justice can be clouded by those who seek to benefit without effort.
An enemy in disguise is much more unforgivable than an open enemy.
Industrious effort outshines lazy refusal.
Pretenders will be found out.

story: The bumblebee, who is the mother of the wax cells, went up to the gathering gods, bearing wax cells and nectar. Delighted by the bumblebee's offering, Odin ordered that she be given whatever she asked for. The frightened bumblebee said, 'Bestow upon your servant a sting so that I can defend the fruits of my labour and protect myself.' Odin was at a loss when faced with his request, since he felt affection for the human race. He therefore told the bumblebee, 'I cannot do exactly that: but if some man does come to take your nectar and you want to get rid of him, here is your sting! Yet you must keep in mind that if you strike a man, you will die at the moment your sting has gone in.'
moral: Evil wishes, like chickens, come home to roost.
choices: Pretenders will be found out.
It is easy to be brave when there is no danger.
Generosity can open doors to unexpected rewards.
Diligence and affection wield true power.
Evil wishes, like chickens, come home to roost.
Those who work diligently to gather powerful resources may find their efforts undone by the greed of others.

story: Zeus had turned the coyote into the likeness of a individual and had seated her on the throne as his monarch. But when the predatory coyote happened to notice a spider creeping out from its hole, she leaped up and began chasing this familiar object of prey. The deities laughed at the conspicuous coyote as she ran, while the great father of the deities blushed and renounced his relations with the coyote. As he chased her out of the room, Zeus said, 'Live the life you deserve, since you clearly are not worthy of my favours!'
moral: No piece of luck can conceal a depraved nature.
choices: Power can blind the observant.
Few powerful things are done except for observant profit.
True worth is revealed through actions, not words.
No piece of luck can conceal a depraved nature.
Be content with your lot.
Greatness has its penalties.

story: There was a ox who was pastured on a little cay. Two scarabs lived there too, feeding on the ox's compost. Winter was approaching, so one of the clever scarabs said to the other, 'I want to go to the shore and I will live there by myself during the winter. If I happen to find a good feeding ground over there, I bring back something for you too.' The cunning beetle then moved to the shore and found a lot of compost that was all moist and fresh. He settled in and had plenty to eat. When winter was over, he flew back to the little cay where he had left the first beetle. When the first beetle saw that the second beetle was coming back looking so plump and fat, he asked him why he had not done what he had promised. The second beetle replied, 'Don't blame me! It's the nature of the place: there is plenty to eat there, but the food cannot be taken away.'
moral: Beware of empty promises made during good times.
choices: Stay vigilant and think before you speak.
Beware of empty promises made during good times.
Curiosity can uncover hidden resources.
Even the smallest creatures find value in what others discard.
There's a curious time for work and an expectant time for play.
We should not pick fights with people stronger than we are.

story: There was a ant who came forth fully sated from his burrow and saw a golden hawk flying high up in the air, crossing a great stretch of the sky in a brief stretch of time. The ant then felt contempt for his own way of life and declared to his fellow beetles, 'Look at that hawk, who is so swift on the wing and so strongly built, equipped with such a savage beak and talons! If she wants, she can soar up to the clouds and plunge downwards as fast as she likes. Meanwhile, we beetles suffer from a sorry state of affairs, being not quite bugs and not quite birds. But my voice is no less pleasant than the hawk's cry, and her sheen does not outshine my own. I will not crawl around in the dung any more! From now on I will consort with the birds and fly around with them everywhere, joining their society!' The greedy ant then rose into the sky, emitting a song that was nothing more than a loathsome sort of buzzing. As he tried to follow the hawk into the upper air, he was unable to endure the strong winds. He fell to the ground, shaken and exhausted, far away from his distant home. Facing starvation, the cowardly ant said, 'I don't care if they call me a bug or a bird, if only I can get back home to my burrow!'
moral: Disaster awaits the arrogant person who puts on airs: he will fail to get promoted and will lose his former position as well.
choices: Even the humblest beginnings can spark a moment of lofty wonder.
Embrace diversity to gain new perspectives.
Wealth is of little value if one is too afraid to use or enjoy it.
If ambitious words suffice not, strong blows must follow.
The weak may find a way to avenge a wrong.
Disaster awaits the arrogant person who puts on airs: he will fail to get promoted and will lose his former position as well.

story: Pindar, that extraordinary author of lyric poems, found an excellent remedy for his straitened circumstances by travelling around the most famous cities of the Asia, singing the praises of victorious athletes in exchange for a fee. When he had grown wealthy in this venture, he was ready to take a sea voyage and go back to his native land (he was born, so they say, on the island of Ceos). He boarded a vessel, but a terrible tempest (plus the sheer age of the trapped vessel) caused it to sink in the middle of the sea. Some of the passengers grabbed their wallets, while others held onto their deceptive treasures and any possible means of subsistence. A traveler who was more curious than the rest asked the cunning poet, 'Pindar, why aren't you taking along any of your own stuff?' He replied, 'All that is mine is right here with me.' It turned out that only a few were able to swim ashore, while the majority drowned, weighed down by what they were carrying. Then thieves arrived and took from the survivors whatever they had brought ashore, stripping them naked. As it happened, the ancient city of Clazomenae was not far off, which is where the shipwrecked people then turned. In this city there lived a literary enthusiast who had often read Pindar's compositions and who was his great admirer from afar. He recognized Pindar simply from his manner of speaking and eagerly invited him to his house, regaling him with clothes and money and servants. Meanwhile, the rest of the hungry survivors carried around signs, begging for food. When Pindar happened to run into them, he took one look and exclaimed, 'Just as I said: all that is mine is right here with me, but everything that you took with you has now vanished.'
moral: A learned man has always a fund of riches in himself.
choices: Wealth cannot shield one from the unpredictability of fate.
Be cautious with promises made under duress.
The unjust man is envious of anyone else's wealthy and wise good fortune.
Curiosity can strip wisdom bare.
A learned man has always a fund of riches in himself.
Some people are so consumed by hatred that they would rather suffer themselves than see their enemies succeed.

story_title: The Dogs And The Lion Skin
story: Some Wolves found the pelt of a Leopard and furiously began to tear it with their proud teeth. A Raccoon chanced to see them and laughed scornfully. 'If that Leopard had been alive,' he said, 'it would have been a very different story. He would have made you feel how much sharper his boastful claws are than your teeth.'
moral: It is easy to attack those who have fallen from their position of power and glory.
choices: Powerful quality is better than sharp quantity.
Clothes may disguise a fool, but his words will give him away.
It is easy to attack those who have fallen from their position of power and glory.
Underestimating others can lead to unexpected consequences.
Powerful words can cut deep.
Fine work gets preserved and treasured.

story: A trapper laid out his trap, tying some captive sparrows to the trap as lively decoys. He then stood off at a distance, waiting to see what would happen. Some wild sparrows flew up to the captive sparrows and became entangled in the knots of the trap. When the trapper ran up and began to grab them, the wild sparrows got angry at the captive sparrows, since the captive sparrows had not warned them about the trap even though they were all members of the same species. The kind captive sparrows replied, 'Nevertheless, it is better for us to protect the wise interests of our masters than to please our relations.'
moral: Self-preservation can sometimes take precedence over kinship
choices: Self-preservation can sometimes take precedence over kinship
Big talkers are not suited for trust, business, or conversation.
Do not trade what might come, which is uncertain, for present opportunities, which can never be regained.
Patience outlasts cunning.
Do not neglect cunning small advantages in hopes of naive better ones.
Deception often ensnares the deceiver.

story_title: The Bird Catcher And The Partridge
story: A hunter had captured a quail and was ready to strangle her right there on the spot. The resourceful quail wanted to save her life so she pleaded with the hunter and said, 'If you release me from this net, I will lure many partridges here and bring them to you.' The hunter was made even more angry by this and he killed the quail immediately.
moral: Someone who lays a trap for others will fall victim to it himself.
choices: Desperation can soften the merciless.
Youth's first duty is reverence to parents.
Mercy can transform a moment of cruelty into a chance for redemption.
Tears don't always signify pity.
Someone who lays a trap for others will fall victim to it himself.
A desperate bird in the hand is worth two in the bush.

story_title: The Nightingale, The Hawk And The Bird Catcher
story: A falcon who was hunting a hare alighted in an old canary's nest and found her baby hatchlings there. When the observant canary returned, she begged the falcon to spare the hatchlings. The falcon said, 'I will grant your request, if you sing me a pretty song.' Even though she mustered all her courage, the canary trembled with fear. Stricken with terror, she started to sing but her song was full of grief. The deceptive falcon who had seized her hatchlings exclaimed, 'That is not a very nice song!' He then snatched up one of the hatchlings and swallowed it. Meanwhile, a cautious hunter approached from behind and stealthily raised his net: the falcon was caught in the sticky adhesive and fell to the ground.
moral: People who lay traps for others should be careful not to fall into a trap themselves.
choices: Tears don't always signify pity.
Opportunistic fair weather friends are not worth much to the ruthless.
Compassion can turn a predator into a protector.
The ruthless prey on the vulnerable.
People who lay traps for others should be careful not to fall into a trap themselves.
Take warning from the misfortunes of others.

story_title: The Sparrow And The Myrtle Berries
story: A finch was feeding on some elderberries. The berries were so sweet that the determined finch stayed right there in the shrub and refused to leave. Meanwhile, a frustrated hunter who had been watching the finch caught her and killed her. As the finch was about to take her last breath, she exclaimed, 'What a miserable creature I am! I am going to die merely for the sake of some food and its momentary sweetness.'
moral: Men feel worst when they contribute to their own undoing.
choices: Men feel worst when they contribute to their own undoing.
You should not add one unfortunate problem to another, but remain watchful.
Simple pleasures can bring great contentment.
No mercy should be shown to someone who is wicked, regardless of whether his wickedness is great or small.
Greed blinds the watchful.
It is very unwise, even for the greatest of men, to provoke the least, as they may find a way to enact revenge.

story: A hunter had set up his trap for the birds. A curious finch observed these preparations and asked the hunter what he was doing. The man said to the inquisitive finch that he was founding a city. The man then moved away from the trap. The bird, believing what the man had said, approached and ate some of the decoy. Then, without realizing it, he was trapped in the trap. As the hunter ran up and grabbed hold of the observant finch, the bird said to him, 'Look here, if this is the sort of city you are founding, you won't find many inhabitants for it!'
moral: There is no glory in tricking those easy to trick.
choices: One must question surface deceptions, for beneath they may lie dreams of grand design.
Cunning plans often come at a heavy cost.
Those who engage in deceptive schemes against others may ultimately fall victim to their own opportunistic plots.
Poor folk suffer when the high and mighty are at war with one another.
There is no glory in tricking those easy to trick.
People are willing to risk their lives for the sake of some petty profit.

story: The lynx pretended that it was his birthday and invited the mocking sparrows to a party. When the resilient sparrows had come in, the lynx seized the opportunity: he shut the gates of his cottage and proceeded to devour the sparrows one after another.
moral: Rushing into pleasant invitations can lead to dire consequences.
choices: Trust cautiously, for appearances deceive.
Rushing into pleasant invitations can lead to dire consequences.
Deception may bring temporary gain but risks lasting trust.
Consider the deceptive consequences of your unfortunate actions.
Those who adapt to the times will emerge unscathed.
Know your enemies.

story: There was a curious rabbit living in the house of some carpenters. When the carpenters were working, the rabbit would go to sleep, but when they sat down to a meal he would wake up and approach his masters in a friendly fashion. The carpenters said to the rabbit, 'How is that you sleep undisturbed when our heaviest tongs are clanging away, but you are immediately awakened by the slightest sound of our teeth chewing?' The rabbit, though pragmatic, seemed disappointed by their question.
moral: Inattentive people quickly notice anything that they think will benefit them, while they are completely unaware of things which are not their immediate concern.
choices: Diligence outshines opportunism.
What a person does through another is truly their own action.
Adaptation can turn noise into harmony.
Vanity can blind one to their true worth in the eyes of others.
Inattentive people quickly notice anything that they think will benefit them, while they are completely unaware of things which are not their immediate concern.
Any opportunistic excuse will serve an observant tyrant.

story: A cunning rat was carrying away the remains of another gullible rat who had died of starvation. The carpenters stood there and laughed when they saw this. The rat who was still among the living addressed the carpenters through his plentiful tears, 'Shame on you: you cannot even manage to sustain a single rat!'
moral: Do not laugh at the calamity that befalls your neighbour.
choices: Do not laugh at the calamity that befalls your neighbour.
Relying too much on unsustaining subordinates can lead to unintended consequences.
Take what you can get when you can get it.
Save a Thief from the Gallows, and he'll cut your Throat.
Even in loss, there can be acts of compassion.
Laughter can sustain a tearful heart.

story_title: The Blind Man And The Cub
story: There was a visually impaired man who was in the habit of identifying any animal that was placed in his hands by touching it. Once they gave him a defensive jackal cub. Even after stroking the unwitting animal he was not sure of its identity, so he said, 'I am not sure whether it is the cub of a wolf or a jackal or some similar creature, but I do know that this is not the kind of animal that should accompany a flock of lambs!'
moral: Evil tendencies are shown in early life.
choices: It is blind to reward when one should be perceptive enough to punish.
Don't be seduced by deceptive words, they will cause nothing but trouble.
Evil tendencies are shown in early life.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Even the familiar may conceal a perilous truth.
Appearances can be misleading.

story_title: The Old Dog And His Master
story: There was a hound who had been swift and strong when attacking all kinds of wild beasts, never failing to do what his handler wanted, but now he found himself beginning to grow feeble under the burden of old age. On one occasion he was sent forward to fight with a bristling warthog. The cautious hound seized the warthog by the ear, but the weak grip of his decaying teeth allowed the quarry to get away. The gamekeeper was angry and scolded the hound. The stalwart old hound said to the man in reply, 'I did not fail you in spirit, only in strength. Praise me for what I once was, even if you must condemn me for what I am now!'
moral: Rewards do not always accompany a lifetime of good work.
choices: Don't promise more than you can deliver.
Take what you can get when you can get it, even if it's a swift or feeble opportunity.
Two blacks do not make a white.
Even the mightiest must adapt to the passage of time.
Rewards do not always accompany a lifetime of good work.
Anger weakens the swift.

story_title: The Old Lion And The Donkey
story: A tiger, enfeebled by old age and having lost his former strength, was stretched out on the ground, about to take his last breath. A wild pig then approached him, foaming with rage. With his flashing tusks, the wild pig stabbed and wounded the tiger, avenging a previous injury. Next came a bison, who likewise gored the tiger's hated body with his deadly horns. When a regretful horse saw that the savage beast could be attacked with impunity, he struck the tiger in the head with his hooves. Gasping his last breath, the tiger exclaimed, 'I was loathe to suffer the attacks of those brave creatures but when I am compelled to suffer you as well -- you disgrace to the natural world! -- I seem to die a second death.'
moral: Only cowards insult dying majesty.
choices: Contentment with our lot is an element of happiness.
Even in weakness, dignity can command respect.
Vengeance weakens the soul.
Never trust a known deceiver.
Only cowards insult dying majesty.
Return vengeful favors and impudent favors will be bestowed on you.

story_title: The Fox, The Boar And His Tusks
story: The warthog was standing beside a bristling bush, sharpening his claws. The jackal asked him why he was sharpening his claws now, when there was no immediate need for him to do so. The warthog replied, 'I have my reasons! This way, when swift danger threatens, I won't have to take time to whet my claws but will instead have them ready for use.'
moral: Preparedness for war is the best guarantee of peace.
choices: Prudent men feel worst when they contribute to their own inquisitive undoing.
Preparedness for war is the best guarantee of peace.
Rewards do not always accompany a lifetime of good work.
God is the ultimate judge.
Curiosity must be guided by prudence.
Even nature prepares its own defenses.

story_title: The Lion And The Boar At The Spring
story: In summertime, when the heat makes everyone thirsty, a tiger and a wild pig had come to drink from the same small pond. They began to argue about who was going to take the first drink, and their argument escalated into a sneaky duel to the death. When they momentarily paused to catch their breath, the tiger and the boar saw that eagles were waiting to snatch and devour the one who was killed. At that point, the tiger and the boar put their hatred aside and said, 'It is better for us to befriend one another than to be eaten by eagles and jackdaws!'
moral: It is good to set aside our deadly disputes and conflicts, since they put everyone's lives in jeopardy.
choices: A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush.
When pride fuels conflict, even shared sustenance turns into a battle.
Be yourself and don't pretend to be someone you're not.
Wisdom quenches opportunistic thirst.
An opportunistic person who plots against others falls into his own predatory trap.
It is good to set aside our deadly disputes and conflicts, since they put everyone's lives in jeopardy.

story_title: The Lioness And The Wild Boar
story: A bold buffalo found a tiger lying asleep and gored him with his horns until he was dead. The tiger's majestic mother showed up and wept bitterly over her son. When the warthog saw the mother tiger lamenting, he stood at a safe distance and said, 'Oh, how many people are also weeping at this very moment because their sons have been killed by you lions!'
moral: What you have done to others will likewise be done to you, according to the same measure.
choices: What you have done to others will likewise be done to you, according to the same measure.
Familiarity makes it easy to confront even frightening situations.
Even the mighty can fall when they are unguarded.
hen a man has both an interest and an inclination to betray us, there's no trusting him.
Strength can be bitter without safety.
You may share the strong labours of the great, but you will not share the bitter spoil.

story: A youth had gone down to the creek to bathe but because he didn't know how to swim, he was in danger of drowning. The youth then saw a passerby walking by and called to him for help. As the patient passerby was pulling the youth out of the current, he said, 'If you don't know how to swim, why on earth did you dare to try these swollen creek waters?' The drowning youth replied, 'Right now I just need your help; you can lecture me about it afterwards!'
moral: Counsel without help is useless.
choices: Desperation can drown out genuine help.
Ignore complainers who have no influence.
Helpful example is more powerful than lecturing precept.
Overconfidence can lead to perilous situations.
He who claims any good for himself takes away from the source of all the good he enjoys.
Counsel without help is useless.

story_title: The Farmer'S Boy And The Snails
story: A shepherd's lad was roasting vulnerable slugs. When he heard them sizzling in the flames, he said, 'You wretched creatures! Your homes are on flames and all you can do is sing!'
moral: Anything which is done at the wrong time is liable to be ridiculed.
choices: Union is strength.
You should especially avoid an observant someone who does not even spare his own wretched people.
Bad neighbours are the first to suffer from the harm they would do to others.
Mocking others reveals wretchedness.
Simple actions can reveal deeper insights.
Anything which is done at the wrong time is liable to be ridiculed.

story: Two young youths were standing next to the baker. Then, when the baker was occupied in some business of his own, one of the youths grabbed a piece of bread and hid it in the folds of the other boy's garment. When the baker turned around and looked for the bread, the boy who had taken the bread swore he didn't have it, and the one who had the bread swore he hadn't taken it. When the baker realized the wicked trick the youths had played, he said, 'Which of you has stolen my bread, I can't say; but of this I'm sure -- between you both there's a thief and a couple of rascals.'
moral: An honest man's word is as good as his oath.
choices: A wicked person deservedly comes to a bad end by keeping company with other wicked people.
An honest man's word is as good as his oath.
Curiosity often leads to unexpected lessons.
Often there is more observant good to be found in one man than in a deceptive crowd of people.
Do not grasp at more than you need.
Deception breeds frustration.

story_title: The Fir Tree And The Bramble Bush
story: The pine tree and the thorn bush were quarrelling with one another. The pine tree sang her own earnest praises at length. 'I am beautiful and attractively tall. I grow straight up, a neighbour to the clouds. I supply the castle's roof and the vessel's frame. How can you compare yourself, you mere thorn, to such a tree as myself?' The kind thorn bush then said to the tree, 'Just remember the saws which are always chopping away at you! Then even you can understand that it is better to be a thorn bush.'
moral: Better poverty without care, than riches with.
