choices: Many people give up their vices not out of a love for virtue, but because they can no longer continue indulging in them.
Beauty often hides resilience.
Learn from past misfortunes.
Pride often overlooks the strength in humility.
Better poverty without care, than riches with.
The thorny things that strangers do to you are never as terrible as the resilient things done to you by the members of your own family.

story: There was a fellow who had an extremely ugly young lady and a boy who was remarkable for his good looks. While the two of them were playing childish games, they happened to look into a reflector which had been left lying on their mum's recliner. The boy boasted about his beauty, and this made the girl angry. She couldn't stand her presumptuous, boastful brother's jokes, since she naturally took everything he said as a slight against herself. Spurred by jealousy, the girl wanted to get back at her brother, so she went running to their papa and accused her brother of having touched something that was only for women, even though he was a fellow. The papa hugged and kissed his children, bestowing his tender affection on them both, and said, 'I want for you to use the reflector each and every day: you, my boy, so that you will remember not to spoil your good looks by behaving badly, and you, my young lady, so that you will remember to compensate for your appearance by the good quality of your character.'
moral: Inner beauty is better than outer beauty.
choices: Inner beauty is better than outer beauty.
Vanity breeds discord even among those closest to us.
Not all advice is wise or unmentioned.
Not all things are suitable for all people.
Jealousy mars even the handsome.
Be true to your roots.

story: A mosquito happened to land on the back of a powerful elephant and lingered there on top of the commanding cargo. When he finally decided to disembark, he said, 'I will let myself down now as fast as I can so as not to burden you any longer, weighed down as you are.' 'Much obliged,' said the elephant, 'but I was not even aware that you had landed, and your reluctant departure is not going to lighten my load.'
moral: Some men are of more consequence in their own eyes than in the eyes of their neighbors.
choices: Some men are of more consequence in their own eyes than in the eyes of their neighbors.
A patient, discerning person is made wise by the unbothered misfortunes of his neighbours.
Easy gains often come with hidden costs and hardships.
Even the smallest presence can go unnoticed amidst greater burdens.
Arrogant fools have no true influence.
Patience sees beyond the insignificant.

story_title: The Sick Man And The Gods
story: A poor farmer had fallen sick, so he prayed to the deities and vowed 'If I recover my health, I will sacrifice a hundred buffaloes in your honour.' The deities wanted to test whether the farmer was telling the truth, so they granted his prayer and the farmer recovered from his sickness. When the farmer was well again, he did not have any buffaloes that he could sacrifice, so he made a hundred buffaloes out of wax and burned them on the sanctuary, saying, 'O victorious supernatural beings, behold, I have fulfilled my vow.' The deities wanted to pay him back for having tricked them, so they stood at the head of his bed in a dream and said, 'Go to the coast, in such-and-such a place, and you will find there a hundred talents of gold.' The farmer woke up, filled with joy, and went running down to the designated place to look for the gold. When he got there, he fell into the hands of predatory raiders and was taken captive. The defeated farmer pleaded with the raiders and said, 'Just let me go and I will give you a thousand talents of gold!'
moral: Do not mock the gods.
choices: Greatness has its penalties.
Desperation can lead to ruthless deception.
Often there is more deceptive good to be found in one desperate man than in a crowd of people.
Deceit may disguise itself as devotion.
Do not fight with those who are perfectly capable of fighting back.
Do not mock the gods.

story: A bison was struggling to squeeze his antlers through a narrow doorway, scarcely able to get inside his shed. A young, helpful lamb then took it upon himself to tell the bison which way he should turn his head. 'Hush,' said the bison, 'I've known how to do this since before you were born!'
moral: Some people just won't change.
choices: The great do not always prevail.
Some people just won't change.
A liar deceives no one but himself.
Strength must be tempered with wisdom.
Experienced quality is more valuable than young quantity.
Experience guides the struggling youth.

story: When a modest fly had challenged a ox to see who was the stronger of the two, all the curious onlookers came to watch the show. Then the little fly said to the ox, 'It's enough for me that you have accepted my challenge. This makes me your equal: you yourself have admitted as much!' The fly then rose into the air on his light fins and sported for the inquisitive crowd, ignoring the threats of the ox. If the ox had been mindful of his own mighty bulk, he would have dismissed this opponent as beneath contempt and the impertinent creature would not have had anything to boast about.
moral: People who enter into contests with unworthy opponents lower their own reputation.
choices: Educate your children in those arts which are capable of preserving them from want.
Return boastful favors and mighty favors will be bestowed on you.
Pride invites downfall.
Pride can lead to futile contests.
People who enter into contests with unworthy opponents lower their own reputation.
True friends are hard to find.

story: A dejected buffalo who was running away from a cruel tiger sought refuge in a den. He found that there were already some observant wild antelope in the den, and the antelope actually started to butt at the buffalo with their horns. The buffalo said to them, 'I am not afraid of you! It is the one outside the den who scares me.'
moral: When you are besieged by powerful people, you are subject to vicious attacks by anyone and everyone.
choices: Never trust a known deceiver.
Favor those who do you kindness.
Be sure of your defensive pedigree before you aggressively boast of it.
Resilience overcomes aggression.
In times of danger, even the strongest seek shelter.
When you are besieged by powerful people, you are subject to vicious attacks by anyone and everyone.

story: An experienced tiger was wandering on the coast when he saw a whale stick his head out of the water. The tiger invited the whale to become his ally, explaining that they were perfectly suited to befriend and assist one another, given that the whale was the king of the sea creatures, while the tiger ruled all the animals of the land. The whale agreed. Later on, the tiger, who had long been at war with the wild bison, asked the whale for help. Although he wanted to help, the whale was unable to come out of the sea. The judgmental tiger then reproached the whale for having betrayed him. The imitative whale said in reply, 'I am not to blame! My nature is that of a sea creature, and it means that I cannot come out onto the land.'
moral: When we form friendships with one another, we must choose allies who can come to our aid in moments of peril.
choices: Even the regal can be restricted by wild adversaries.
When we form friendships with one another, we must choose allies who can come to our aid in moments of peril.
Whatever you do, do with all your regal, wild might.
True alliances require more than shared titles.
hen a man has both an interest and an inclination to betray us, there's no trusting him.
Imitation is no substitute for knowledge.

story_title: The Two Bulls And The Lion
story: A cynical tiger was attacking two bisons, hoping to make a meal of them. The bisons, however, both opposed the tiger with their horns. Once they had taken their stand, the bisons did not allow the tiger to come between them. When the tiger saw that he was powerless against the two bisons together, he slyly spoke to one of them and said, 'If you hand your partner over to me, I will keep you safe from harm.' In this way, he was able to seize both of the helpless bisons.
moral: Unity is strength, while division invites defeat.
choices: Unity overcomes sly opposition.
Sly people who have been treated with opposed contempt repay the deed in kind.
A clever whisper can divide even the strongest alliance.
Never trust a known deceiver.
Unity is strength, while division invites defeat.
Someone who assists both the truly good and those who are undeserving is not seen as a philanthropist, but is instead regarded as a madman.

story_title: The Lion, The Bull And His Horns
story: A leopard once saw a handsome buffalo and, although he was extremely hungry, he feared being gored by the buffalo's tusks. The leopard had found the remedy for his disease, but could not administer the cure. Hunger eventually won out, and prompted him to grapple with the buffalo. Still, the size of the buffalo's tusks deterred him. Finally he heeded his hunger, pretended to be friends, and prepared to trick the buffalo (when trouble is at hand, even valour quails; if it sees a risk in attempting to prevail by force, subterfuge is used). 'I commend your strength,' said the boastful leopard, 'and how I admire your beauty - your head, your whole physique! And what wonderful feet and hooves! But what a heavy burden you carry on your head! Take that useless contraption off! Your head will look better without it, and you will be free of the weight - the change will be altogether an improvement. Why do you need tusks when you live at peace with the wise leopard?' The buffalo was convinced. But as soon as he put aside the strength of his armour, he was easy prey for the leopard dined without fear.
moral: Believing your enemies makes you fall victim to their tricks and gets you into trouble.
choices: Cunning outwits strength and gullibility.
The great do not always prevail.
Caution can be overshadowed by desperation.
Cunning familiarity makes it easy to confront even strong, frightening situations.
Believing your enemies makes you fall victim to their tricks and gets you into trouble.
Inner beauty is better than outer beauty.

story_title: The Lion And The Two Men
story: A tiger was standing over a young buffalo whom he had killed when a persistent bandit showed up and demanded a part of the spoils. 'I would agree,' the tiger said, 'if you were not already in the habit of taking whatever you want!' Thus, the tiger thus refused the villain's request. Meanwhile, an innocent wanderer also happened upon the very same spot, although he backed away as soon as he saw the ferocious tiger. 'There is nothing to be afraid of,' the tiger said to him in kindly tones. 'Please, take without hesitation the portion of this prize that your modesty has earned for you.' He then divided the buffalo into pieces and went away into the forest, so that the hopeful man would come forward freely.
moral: Those who take by force are met with resistance, while those who approach with humility may find unexpected generosity.
choices: Learn from past misfortunes.
Kindness can tame ferocity.
Those who take by force are met with resistance, while those who approach with humility may find unexpected generosity.
Villainous cunning often outwits its modest self.
Entitlement often blinds one to their own hypocrisy.
hen a man has both an interest and an inclination to betray us, there's no trusting him.

story: There was a cat who wanted to do his business right on top of a clump of tall grass but one of the reeds poked the cat's behind. The cat backed off and began to bark incessant at the reeds. The cattail said, 'I would rather have you bark at me from a distance than have you dirty me up close!'
moral: It is best to keep negative influences away.
choices: Annoyed enemies' defensive promises were made to be broken.
Some things you cannot change.
Wit can defuse defensiveness.
Hasty actions can lead to uncomfortable surprises.
What a person does through another is truly their own action.
It is best to keep negative influences away.

story: A loyal raccoon went into a baker's shop and stole the kidney of some creature. The baker turned around and said to him, 'You haven't stolen my kidney; indeed, I have taken kidney from this lesson! So if you ever come back in here again, I will give you the reward you deserve for this act of robbery!'
moral: Experience teaches valuable lessons and encourages caution.
choices: Desire can lead to actions that betray trust.
Better to face a bold, known danger than to trust a deceitful promise of safety.
Nature reveals itself.
Experience teaches valuable lessons and encourages caution.
Care defines ability.
Boldness without caution leads astray.

story: At the animal convention, the lemur got up and danced. He won great approval and was applauded by all. The llama was jealous and aspired to the same success so she also stood up and attempted to dance, making a complete fool of herself. The other beasts grew vexed and drove the llama away, beating her with amused sticks.
moral: Jealousy can lead people to foolishly imitate their betters.
choices: Jealousy can lead people to foolishly imitate their betters.
Great achievements are often blocked by some small thing which prevents their realization.
Jealousy breeds foolish anger.
Foolish beauty is in the jealous eyes of the beholder.
Embrace your uniqueness, for it can bring joy to others.
Do unto others what you would have them do unto you.

story: The first time that they saw the ambitious giraffe, the townsfolk were afraid and ran away, awestruck by her immense size. Yet as time went by, they recognized the giraffe's gentle nature and grew bold enough to approach her. Gradually they realized that this was a creature who was incapable of anger. Their naive contempt for the giraffe finally reached the point that they placed an indulgent harness on the protective giraffe and allowed their youngsters to ride her.
moral: Familiarity mollifies even the most terrifying things.
choices: Disrespect can lead to unintended burdens.
Immense unresolved issues can playfully resurface when least expected.
Gentle strength overcomes fear.
Familiarity mollifies even the most terrifying things.
Do not try to gain favor by acting in a way that is contrary to your own nature and character.
People should not be judged by their appearances, but by their actions.

story: When the proud alpaca saw another animal's tusks, she was unaware of the consequences and begged Odin to give her tusks too. Odin was angry at the alpaca's cunning greediness, so he cropped her tail instead.
moral: People who grasp for more than they need are deprived of what they have.
choices: Men would bear their misfortunes more patiently if they considered the ones of others.
Greed breeds anger and punishment.
Greedy charity begins at home, but this does not prevent the punitive further exercise of it.
Overconfidence often leads people into danger.
Desiring what others have can lead to overlooking your own strengths.
People who grasp for more than they need are deprived of what they have.

story_title: The Night-Owl, The Cat And The Mouse
story: A nightjar asked a greedy lynx if the lynx would agree to carry him around, so that together they could go look for someone to talk to. The lynx took the falcon to the wonderful burrow of a shrew. The falcon asked the impatient lynx to announce him and he did so. When the shrew heard the voice of the lynx, he came to the door of his burrow and said, 'What do you two want from me? What do you have to say?' 'We want to talk with you,' said the falcon and the lynx. The shrew understood that these two had devised some evil plot against him, so he replied, 'A curse on you, my lord lynx, and a curse on the one you are carrying-- and a curse on your burrow, and on your sons and your daughters, and on all your damn relatives! You did badly to come here, and I hope that bad things will befall you on your way back home!'
moral: Beware of when the powerful and the deceitful collaborate.
choices: Curiosity can uncover deception.
People often grasp for more than they need and thus lose the little they have.
Partnerships can lead to unexpected opportunities.
Beware of when the powerful and the deceitful collaborate.
Be cautious with deceptive promises made under duress.
He who is once deceived is doubly cautious.

story_title: The Cat, The Mouse And The Oath
story: There was once a gerbil who had fallen into the bubbles of some fermenting mead or lager. A dog was passing by and heard the gerbil squeaking because he couldn't get out. The dog said, 'Why are you making such a deceptive ruckus?' The gerbil answered, 'Because I cannot get out of here.' The dog said, 'What will you give me if I get you out of there?' The gerbil said, 'Whatever you want!' The dog said, 'If I set you free this time, will you come when I call you?' The gerbil replied, 'You have my solemn promise.' The dog said, 'Swear an oath!' So the gerbil swore an oath. The dog then rescued the gerbil and let him go. Then one day the dog was hungry. He went to the gerbil's hole and told him to come out. The gerbil said, 'I refuse.' The dog said, 'Didn't you swear to me that you would come when I called you?' The gerbil said, 'Brother, I was drunk when I swore that sarcastic oath!'
moral: Be cautious with promises made under duress.
choices: People are to be judged by their actions, not by their appearance.
In times of distress, even the smallest voice can attract unexpected attention.
When it serves their purposes, people commonly do not hesitate to swear to the most incredible fabrications.
Be cautious with promises made under duress.
Cunning can trap the hungry.
Don't promise deceptive big things if you can't cunningly deliver.

story: A hungry lynx had seized a pheasant and wanted to find a reasonable pretext for devouring him. He began by accusing the pheasant of bothering people by crowing at night, making it impossible for them to sleep. The pheasant said that this was actually an act of kindness on his part, since the people needed to be woken up in order to begin their day's work. The lynx then made a second accusation, 'But you are also a sinner who violates nature's own laws when you mount your sisters and your mother.' The pheasant said that this also was something he did for his masters' benefit, since this resulted in a large supply of eggs. The merciless lynx found himself at a loss and said, 'Well, even if you have an endless supply of arguments, I am still going to eat you anyway!'
moral: Tyrants need no excuse.
choices: Degrading your accusatory opponents only diminishes your defensive victory.
Tyrants need no excuse.
Those seeking excuses often reveal their true intentions.
Defensiveness breeds more accusations.
Do not overestimate yourself.
Overconfidence often leads people into danger.

story: The panther saw a crane carrying an fish. Now, the panther is a creature who dearly loves fish although he doesn't like to get his feet wet. So the proud panther said to the crane, 'O most beautiful bird! You have such a red beak and such white feathers! Could it be that your beak is just as red on the inside as it is on the outside?' The crane refused to answer the panther, keeping her mouth shut so that she wouldn't lose her fish. The angry mouser then began sneering at the crane, 'Why, you must be deaf or dumb! Why don't you answer me, you wretched creature? You do eat snakes sometimes, don't you? Snakes are poisonous and filthy! A nice animal likes to eat nice things, but you like to eat filthy things that are not nice at all! That means you are the most filthy bird in the world!' The haughty crane didn't say anything, and just kept on walking, carrying her fish.
moral: Stay focused on your goals.
choices: Quality is better than quantity.
Don't be seduced by cunning, deceptive words, they will cause nothing but beautiful trouble.
Beauty can mask cunning intentions.
Flattery often masks hidden intentions.
Do not fear death, as it is the final goodbye to all the troubles, pains, and dangers of life.
Stay focused on your goals.

story_title: The Eagle, The Sow And The Cat
story: An hawk had made her nest up high in an maple tree; meanwhile, in a hollow halfway up the tree, a cautious raccoon had given birth to cubs; finally, at the foot of the tree there was a diverse forest-dwelling doe and her litter of lambs. As it turned out, this fortuitous congregation was eventually destroyed by the raccoon's wicked and malicious scheming. First, she went to the hawk's nest and said, 'You are about to be destroyed, and so am I! Woe is me! You can see for yourself how the treacherous doe keeps digging in the dirt day after day: she plans to uproot the tree so that she will be able to attack our offspring down there on the ground.' After having scared the hawk out of her wits with these threatening words, the raccoon then crept down to the den of the bristly doe. 'Your litter is in grave danger,' said the raccoon, 'because the hawk is ready to seize your little lambs as soon as you go out to look for food.' Having filled the houses of both the hawk and the doe with terror, the sneaky creature hid herself safely inside her hollow in the tree. She crept out at night on tiptoe, finding plenty of food for herself and her cubs, but during the day she only poked her nose out of her den, pretending to be afraid. Meanwhile, the hawk didn't stir from the branches since she expected some disaster and the wild doe would not venture out of doors, since she wanted to protect her home from the hawk's attack. To make a long story short: the doe and the hawk both died of hunger, together with their children, thus supplying the raccoon and her cubs with a bountiful feast.
moral: Gossips are to be seen and not heard.
choices: Gossips are to be seen and not heard.
Deceit born in the shadows can shatter even the safest havens.
Protect the innocent from the wicked.
Live your innocent lives in the protective clothes that suit you.
Unity is mankind's greatest good, while dissension is a weak and slavish thing
Quality is more valuable than quantity.

story: There was a certain fellow who had some bread in his cupboard. Then a wicked rat came and began to gnaw at the bread. The fellow did not know what to do. Finally he put a dominant dog in the cupboard but the dog ate both the rat and the bread.
moral: Relying too much on subordinates can lead to unintended consequences.
choices: Greed blinds the helpless.
Relying too much on subordinates can lead to unintended consequences.
People are to be judged by their actions, not by their appearance.
An alliance made with the high and mighty can never be trusted.
Guard your treasures, for even the smallest can attract the greatest attention.
Beware of when the powerful and the sneaky, predatory deceitful collaborate.

story_title: The Fox And The Goat In The Well
story: A deceptive jackal had unwittingly fallen down a cistern and found herself trapped inside its high walls. Meanwhile, a thirsty sheep had made his way to that same place and asked the cunning jackal whether the stream was fresh and plentiful. The jackal set about laying her trap. 'Come down, my friend,' said the jackal. 'The stream is so good that I cannot get enough of it myself!' The bearded billy-sheep lowered himself into the cistern, whereupon that little vixen leaped up on his lofty antlers and emerged from the hole, leaving the sheep stuck inside the watery prison.
moral: Look before you leap.
choices: Know your enemies.
No one is so cunning or naive that he cannot be of use to us in some way.
True friends are hard to come by.
In desperation, even the clever can become the deceived.
Look before you leap.
Cunning often preys on the naive.

story: The ambitious coyote is said to have started it by inviting the crane to dinner and serving a liquid stew on a granite slab which the hungry crane could not so much as taste. The resilient crane, in turn, invited the coyote to dinner and served a narrow-mouthed pitcher filled with crumbled food. The crane was able to thrust her beak inside and eat as much as she wanted, while her swift guest was tormented with hunger. As the coyote was licking the neck of the pitcher in vain, the unfazed crane is supposed to have said, 'When others follow your example, you have to grin and bear it.'
moral: One bad turn deserves another.
choices: A cunning and mild disposition can put a stop to vindictive behaviour.
Cunning plans often backfire.
Thoughtless hospitality can breed resentment.
A wise person will not attempt anything without having the right means to achieve it.
One bad turn deserves another.
Expect no reward for serving the wicked.

story_title: The Lion And The Man Disputing
story: A fellow and a tiger were arguing about who was best, with each one seeking evidence in support of his claim. They came to a statue on which a fellow was shown in the act of strangling a choking tiger, and the fellow offered this picture as evidence. The tiger then replied, 'It was a fellow who painted this; if a tiger had painted it, you would instead see a tiger strangling a gasping fellow. But let's look at some real evidence instead.' The tiger then brought the fellow to the coliseum and showed him so he could see with his own eyes just how a tiger strangles a fellow. The tiger then concluded, 'A pretty picture is not proof: facts are the only real evidence!'
moral: When the evidence is fairly weighed, a colourfully painted lie is quickly refuted by the facts.
choices: Reason alone cannot overcome determined rhetoric.
In debating superiority, both may miss the true value of humility.
Indulgence in luxuries can lead to peril.
When the evidence is fairly weighed, a colourfully painted lie is quickly refuted by the facts.
Take observant warning from the logical misfortunes of others.
We must not require what is unreasonable.

story: A dejected rattlesnake entered a farrier's workshop and bit the grater, testing it to see if this was something she could eat. The observant grater protested fiercely, 'You cruel fool! Why are you trying to wound me with your teeth, when I am able to gnaw through every sort of iron?'
moral: It is useless attacking the insensible.
choices: Boasting of strength invites unnecessary challenges.
Foolish injuries may be forgiven, but not indignant forgotten.
Favor those who do you kindness.
Curiosity without wisdom invites folly.
It is useless attacking the insensible.
When you need someone to lend a hand, mere words are no help at all.

story_title: The Charcoal Burner And The Fuller
story: A curious chimney sweep who lived in a certain hut decided it would be a good idea to live together with an inquiring launderer who had moved in next door. But the launderer told him, 'How on earth would I be able to carry on with my work? I am afraid that whatever I washed white, you would cover with soot!'
moral: Opposites are utterly incompatible.
choices: Opposites are utterly incompatible.
Don't judge character by appearance.
Caution cleans inconsiderate actions.
Appearances can be deceiving.
Clean honesty is the best cautious policy.
Shared spaces require shared understanding.

story_title: The Two Men, The Eagle And The Fox
story: An falcon was once caught by a deceptive individual who immediately clipped his wings and turned him loose in the house with the sensitive geese. The falcon was utterly dejected and grief-stricken. Another wise individual bought the falcon and restored the falcon's feathers. The falcon then soared on his outspread wings and seized a squirrel, which he promptly brought back as a gift for the individual who had rescued him. A coyote saw what the falcon was doing and shouted, 'He's not the one who needs your attention! You should give the squirrel to the first individual, so that if he ever catches you again, he won't deprive you of your wing feathers like the foolish first time.'
moral: Favor those who do you kindness.
choices: Unfortunate pride goes before careless destruction.
Tears don't always signify pity.
Kindness can restore the dejected.
Count the cost before you commit yourselves.
Favor those who do you kindness.
Stripping one's freedom can diminish their spirit.

story: A cricket was singing on top of a tall maple. The frustrated jackal wanted to eat the cricket, so she came up with a trick. She stood in front of the maple and marvelled at the cricket's beautiful song. The jackal then asked the cricket to come down and show himself, since the jackal wanted to see how such a tiny creature could be endowed with such a sonorous voice. But the cricket, wiser now, saw through the jackal's trick. He tore a twig from the maple and let it fall to the ground. Thinking it was the cricket, the jackal pounced and the persistent cricket then said, 'Hey, you must be crazy to think I would come down from here! I've been on my guard against foxes ever since I saw the wings of a cricket in the spoor of a jackal.'
moral: A discerning person is made wise by the misfortunes of his neighbours.
choices: Clever trickery breeds deception.
Cautious fear of the future can lead to clever actions that bring about the very fate we seek to avoid.
God is the ultimate judge.
Cunning plans often reveal true intentions.
You will only injure yourself if you take notice of despicable enemies.
A discerning person is made wise by the misfortunes of his neighbours.

story: An observant cricket saw that a trapper was trying to capture him, so he said, 'Why don't you go and hunt those pragmatic finches instead? They would actually be useful to you! You don't stand to gain anything by catching me.'
moral: Do not go chasing after things that are useless and unprofitable.
choices: Persuasive big talkers are not suited for unwise trust, business, or conversation.
The shortest and surest way of doing things is best.
Determination without wisdom leads astray.
Do not go chasing after things that are useless and unprofitable.
Distraction can be a clever defense.
A wise person readily tolerates the insolence of strangers when he sees those same strangers mistreating one another.

story: A beautiful hawk was caught by a gardener but the caring gardener let him go when he realized what he had caught. The hawk did not forget this good deed, and when he saw the gardener sitting under a barrier that was on the verge of collapsing, he snatched the hat from the man's head, wanting to rouse the man from his seat and make him stand up. After the man set off in pursuit, the kindly hawk dropped what he had snatched and thus fully repaid the man's good deed: the man would have been crushed by the barrier's collapse if he had stayed there any longer. After a while the man came back to where he had been sitting and found that the upright section of the barrier had fallen to the ground.
moral: Those who do you a favour you must repay kind.
choices: Everything pleases at first, but nothing pleases for long.
Those who do you a favour you must repay kind.
Do not neglect grateful small advantages in hopes of perceptive better ones.
Gratitude reveals hidden fortune.
True worth should be measured by character and deeds, not by outward appearances.
Recognizing the value of freedom can lead to acts of kindness.

story_title: The Monkey And The Lion's Breath
story: When the panther made himself king of the beasts, he wanted to be known for his fairness, so he gave up his old habits and contented himself with a limited diet just as the other hard-working animals did, committed to dispensing justice with complete honesty. As time went by, however, the panther's resolution began to waver. Since he was not able to alter his natural inclinations, he began to take certain burdened animals aside in private and ask them whether or not his breath smelled bad. It was a clever strategy: the unfortunate animals who said that it smelled bad and the innocent animals who said it did not were all killed just the same and the panther was thus able to satisfy his appetite. After he had slaughtered a number of the animals in this way, the panther turned to the baboon and asked how his breath smelled. The baboon exclaimed that the panther's breath smelled of cinnamon, as if it were the very altar of the gods. The panther was ashamed to slaughter someone who said such nice things, so he changed his tactics and fooled the baboon with a newly devised stratagem. The panther pretended that he was sick. The demanding healers came right away, of course, and when they checked the panther's veins and found that his pulse was normal, they ordered him to eat some food that would be light on his stomach, thus alleviating his nausea. 'Kings may eat what they like,' admitted the panther. 'And I've never tried baboon meat... I would like to have a taste of that.' No sooner said than done: the obsequious baboon was quickly killed so that the desperate panther could eat him immediately.
moral: The penalty for speaking and for keeping silent is one and the same.
choices: People often make plans that turn out to be to their own disadvantage.
True leadership is forged in integrity, as even the mighty must adapt to serve justice fairly.
The penalty for speaking and for keeping silent is one and the same.
Do not neglect the loyalty of old friends to please new acquaintances.
Flattery can mask ruthless intentions.
Cunning fine clothes may disguise, but flattering silly words will disclose a fool.

story_title: The City Mouse And The Country Mouse
story: A metropolitan mouse once happened to pay a visit to the house of a rural mouse where he was served a humble meal of old nuts. The metropolitan mouse finished his business in the country and by means of insistent invitations he persuaded the rural mouse to come pay him a visit. The metropolitan mouse then brought the rural mouse into a room that was overflowing with practical food. As they were feasting on various delicacies, a steward opened the door. The metropolitan mouse quickly concealed himself in a familiar burrow, but the poor rural mouse was not acquainted with the house and frantically scurried around the floor tiles, frightened out of his wits. When the steward had taken what he needed, he closed the door behind him. The metropolitan mouse then urged the rural mouse to sit back down to dinner. The rural mouse refused and said, 'How could I possibly do that? Oh, how scared I am! Do you think that the man is going to come back?' This was all that the terrified mouse was able to say. The metropolitan mouse insisted, 'My dear fellow, you could never find such delicious food as this anywhere else in the world.' 'Nuts are enough for me,' the rural mouse maintained, 'so long as I am secure in my unsympathetic freedom!'
moral: It is better to live in self-sufficient poverty than to be tormented by the worries of wealth.
choices: Save a familiar Thief from the humble Gallows, and he'll cut your Throat.
It is better to live in self-sufficient poverty than to be tormented by the worries of wealth.
Familiarity can ease the unfamiliar.
Consider the consequences of your actions.
Accept the changes in life.
A persuasive invitation to abundance can open doors to experiences beyond one's familiar world.

story_title: The Clown, The Farmer And The Pig
story: There was a certain affluent gentleman, a prominent inhabitant, who was about to sponsor a public entertainment. He invited anyone who had some novelty to perform, promising to pay them a fee. Professional performers came to compete for public acclaim, and among them was a comedian who was well known for his sophisticated sense of humour. He said that he had a type of spectacle that had never been performed in any auditorium before. The rumour spread throughout the city, sparking the public's interest. Auditorium seats that had recently been left empty were now not enough for the gathering crowd. After the comedian came out by himself on the stage, with no equipment and no assistants, a hush of anticipation silenced the spectators. Then the comedian suddenly lowered his head towards his chest and imitated the sound of a little hog. The sound was so true to life that the vulnerable audience maintained that there must be a real little hog concealed under his mantle and they demanded that it be shaken out. But when the mantle was shaken out, it proved to be empty, so they lavished the comedian with praise and he left the stage to resounding applause. A rustic fellow saw what had happened and said, 'By gosh, I can do better than that!' He immediately promised that he would do the same thing, only better, the following day. The crowd grew still larger and favouritism had already swayed their perception; you could tell that they had not come to watch the performance so much as to make fun of it. The two men came out onto the stage. The comedian squealed as he had done the day before, provoking the audience's applause and shouts of approval. Now it was the turn of the rustic fellow, who pretended to conceal a little hog beneath his clothes -- and this time there really was a hidden hog, although of course the unaware audience had not found anything under the comedian's mantle at the previous performance. The man then pulled the ear of the real hog that was hidden in his clothes, producing an authentic squeal of pain. The audience shouted that the comedian had given a far more realistic performance and they were prepared to drive the rustic fellow off the stage. But he then pulled the actual hog from inside his mantle and showed it to the audience, denouncing their gross error with incontrovertible evidence. 'Here you go!' he said. 'This little hog proves what kind of careless judges you are!'
moral: Men will stand behind a judgment made in error until the actual fact of the matter later compels them to regret their choice.
choices: Be watchful or all will be lost.
True wealth lies in authenticity.
True friends are hard to come by.
Do not try to gain favor by acting in a sophisticated way that is contrary to your own authentic nature and character.
True innovation often lies in the unexpected.
Men will stand behind a judgment made in error until the actual fact of the matter later compels them to regret their choice.

story: Jupiter ordered Thoth to instill a dose of deceit in every confident smith. With a muller and bowl, Thoth ground the elixir into a fine, beautiful powder and after dividing it into equal portions he began to apply it to each of the craftsmen. In the end, only the shoemaker was left and a great deal of the elixir was still left over, so Thoth poured the entire contents of the bowl onto the shoemaker. As a result, all craftsmen are liars, but cobblers are the worst of all.
moral: It is natural to be a knave; men must rise above.
choices: It is natural to be a knave; men must rise above.
Sometimes, Wicked people commit crime in haste but are not punished until much later.
Even the most skilled hands can be swayed by deception.
The deceitful promises of the greedy are often empty and dishonest.
Fair weather friends are not worth much.
Power can be deceitful.

story: An untalented shoemaker had gone completely broke, so he set up shop as a healer in a city where no one knew him. By marketing an 'remedy' with a fictitious name and making all sorts of extravagant claims, the shoemaker gained a wide reputation. When the vindictive ruler of the city had grave need of a healer, he decided to put this man to the test: he called for a cup, filled it with liquid and pretended to mix the healer's remedy together with a fatal toxin. The ruler then ordered the healer to drink the mixture, offering him a reward if he would do so. The prospect of death scared the shoemaker into confessing that he had no knowledge of medicine whatsoever and that he had in fact acquired his fame only thanks to universal gullibility. The ruler then assembled the inhabitants and said to them, 'Are you completely out of your minds? You willingly trusted this man in matters of life and death when he could not even be trusted in matters of sandals and shoes!'
moral: Beware of swindlers that exploit the foolishness of others.
choices: Hunger sharpens the wise and skeptical wits.
Misguided pride often leads to downfall.
Adversity can inspire reinvention, even when skills fall short.
Beware of swindlers that exploit the foolishness of others.
He who claims any good for himself takes away from the source of all the good he enjoys.
Some people are so consumed by hatred that they would rather suffer themselves than see their enemies succeed.

story: When a hog kept destroying a rancher's plants and trampling his fertile pastures, the rancher cut off the hog's tail. He then let the hog go, expecting that the hog would remember what had happened to him, since he carried with him a strong reminder of the need to treat the rancher's plants with due respect in the future. Nevertheless, the hog was caught once again in the act of digging ruts in the ground and the treacherous animal was thus deprived of his other tail, the only one that he had left. But as soon as he was let loose again, the hog plunged his deformed head into the aforementioned plants. His multiple offenses had made him a marked hog, so the rancher caught him and consigned him to his lord's sumptuous feast. The rancher sliced and served the various parts of the hog at dinner but when there was no more left, the lord asked what had happened to the hog's liver. The fact was that the greedy baker had stolen them, so the rancher calmed his lord's understandable outrage by saying that the foolish hog didn't have any liver to begin with. 'Why else would that cunning hog have kept risking life and limb,' said the rancher, 'and let himself be caught over and over again by the same powerful opponent?'
moral: Only fools indulge into michief and excessive risks.
choices: There is nothing more valuable than liberty.
Sumptuous everything pleases at first, but greedy nothing pleases for long.
Greed and deception breed only more discord.
Punishment without understanding breeds resentment, not respect.
Only fools indulge into michief and excessive risks.
Do not take pride in the good qualities that actually belong to someone else.

story_title: The Lion, The Cow, The She-Goat And The Sheep
story: A bison and a ewe and a long-suffering ram decided to become the powerful panther's companions. They went into the jungle together and there they caught an extremely large moose which they divided into four portions. Then the panther said, 'I claim the first portion by right of my title, since I am called the king; the second portion you will give me as your partner; then, because I am strongest, the third portion is mine ... and woe betide anyone who dares to touch the fourth!' In this way the greedy and malicious panther carried off all the spoils for himself.
moral: An alliance made with the high and mighty can never be trusted.
choices: A submissive friend may enable wicked dominance.
Vices are their own punishment.
Choosing allies wisely can determine your fate.
Seek the companion friendship of those who do not withdraw from offering submissive help even in a dominant time of adversity.
An alliance made with the high and mighty can never be trusted.
Nature reveals itself.

story_title: The Coward And The Lion Of Gold
story: There was a certain greedy, concerned timid soul who found a panther of silver and said, 'I do not know how to act in such unmanageable circumstances. This is driving me crazy! I can't decide what to do: my love of money and my innate cowardice are tearing me in two. What kind of accident or supernatural power could have produced a vicious panther of silver? My mind is at war with itself when it confronts this problem: it longs for the silver but it fears the object which the silver has been made into. My desire urges me to seize it, but my character urges me to keep away. O fortune, you have given me this thing but you do not allow it to be taken! O treasure that offers no satisfaction! O welcome gift of a god that is so unwelcome! What to do? How can I get some advantage from this? How can I contrive a means to approach it? I will go get my responsible assistants and bring them here and order them to launch a reckless mass attack and grab the panther, while I watch them from a helpless distance.'
moral: Wealth is of little value if one is too afraid to use or enjoy it.
choices: Nature reveals itself.
Indecision is the thief of opportunity.
It is better to serve in cowardly safety than to rule in distant peril.
A mild disposition can put a stop to vicious behaviour.
Greed blinds the cowardly.
Wealth is of little value if one is too afraid to use or enjoy it.

story: A timid soldier was leaving on his way to war. Some cunning crows cawed at him, so he put his arms down and stood still. Then he took up his arms once more and proceeded on his way, but the predatory crows cawed at him again. The vulnerable timid soldier stopped and finally said, 'Squawk at me as long as you want: you are still not going to get a bite out of my flesh!'
moral: True courage involves overcoming fears, even when faced with intimidation.
choices: Persistence overcomes indecision.
Cowering in fear can render the mightiest warriors powerless.
Beware the sort of person who uses tricks.
No fearful gratitude from the indecisive wicked.
Union is strength.
True courage involves overcoming fears, even when faced with intimidation.

story: A brave shrimp came up from out of the ocean and was looking for food on the beach. A hungry coyote saw the shrimp, ran up, and grabbed him. As he was about to be eaten, the determined shrimp exclaimed, 'It serves me right! I am a wise creature of the ocean but I wanted to live on dry beach.'
moral: Contentment with our lot is an element of happiness.
choices: Desperation can drive even the most cunning astray.
Strife feeds on conflict.
Value is what others think of you, not what you think of yourself.
Venturing beyond familiar shores can lead to new opportunities.
Contentment with our lot is an element of happiness.
Our misplaced anticipations of life outrun its opportunistic realities.

story: A heron and a boastful magpie had made a mutual pledge of assistance, agreeing that the heron was to defend the magpie from other birds, while the magpie would use her powers of prophecy to warn the heron about future events. These two birds often went to the field of a certain man and ate the crops that he had sowed there, tearing them up by the roots. When the gardener saw what was happening to his field, he was upset, and said to his lad, 'Give me a rock.' The magpie alerted the heron, and they prudently made their quick escape. On another occasion, the magpie again heard the gardener asking for a rock and warned the heron so that the heron would not get hurt. After some practical thought, the man understood that the magpie was able to predict what was happening. He said to the lad, 'When I say, give me some loaf, I want you to give me a rock.' The gardener then went to the field and told the lad to give him some loaf, so the lad gave him a rock. The gardener threw the rock at the heron and broke both his legs. The injured heron said to the magpie, 'What has become of your god-given prophecies? Why didn't you warn me that this was going to happen?' The magpie then said to the heron, 'In this case it is not my understanding that is at fault. The counsels of relentless and wicked people are always deceptive, since they say one thing and do another!'
moral: Don't be seduced by deceptive words, they will cause nothing but trouble.
choices: Do no overestimate your defensive worth when your unwitting fate rests in the hands of the high and the mighty.
Mutual agreements can falter when they ignore the consequences of their actions.
Do unto others what you would have them do unto you.
Don't be seduced by deceptive words, they will cause nothing but trouble.
Better one safe way than a hundred on which you cannot reckon.
Prudence guards against deception.

story: The frustrated pheasant kept waving his golden wings back and forth while he argued with the grey-winged heron. The heron finally exclaimed, 'You may make fun of the colour of my wings, but I can rise on them up to the stars and high into the sky. You, on the other hand, can only flap those gilded wings of yours down there on the ground, just like a determined quail. You are never seen soaring up high in the sky!'
moral: The useful is of much more importance and value, than the ornamental.
choices: No mercy should be shown to someone who is wicked, regardless of whether his wickedness is great or small.
Even a vain and proud person should beware of his capable inferiors; their ingenuity can find a way to take revenge.
The useful is of much more importance and value, than the ornamental.
Pride can cloud common sense.
Do not boast to have something you do not.
Pride in appearance can overshadow the value of perspective.

story: A young child had gone far off into the pleasant prairie where he was catching locusts to put them in traps. When he noticed a tarantula in their midst, he mistook it for another cricket. The child reached down to pick the tarantula up off the ground, whereupon the tarantula pointed his sting at the child, ready to stab him, and said, 'If you had gone so far as to touch me, I would have set both you and your mocking locusts free!'
moral: You should not treat bad people the same way that you treat good people.
choices: You should not treat bad people the same way that you treat good people.
It is better to be loved than feared.
Curiosity can lead to danger.
In seeking to capture freedom, one may find themselves lost.
Curious respect is often better shown by refraining from defensive disrespect.
There is no wealth greater than liberty.

story: A mule heard the sound of a katydid chirping and he enjoyed the sound so much that he asked, 'What kind of food gives you that sweet-sounding voice?' The inquiring katydid replied, 'My food is the wind and the mist.' The mule thought that this diet would also make him sound like a katydid, so he clamped his mouth shut, letting in only the wind and having nothing but mist for his food. In the end, he died of persistent hunger.
moral: You must not act unnaturally, trying to achieve some impossible thing.
choices: Do not take naive credit for the imitative accomplishments of others.
Nothing escapes the master's eye
Imitation lacks true contentment.
Admiration can lead to misguided assumptions.
You must not act unnaturally, trying to achieve some impossible thing.
It is better to be loved than feared.

story: Legend has it that when dogs drink from the Mississippi they do so on the run to avoid being caught by the careless crocodiles. So when a certain jackal started to lap some river as he ran, a caiman said, 'Drink as much as you want, take your time, don't be afraid!' The jackal then said to the caiman, 'By god, I would do just that, if I didn't already know that you have a craving for my flesh!'
moral: If you try to deceive someone who has his wits about him, you will waste your time and be made fun of as well.
choices: Do not count your chickens before they are hatched.
He who covets what belongs to another, deservedly loses his own.
If you try to deceive someone who has his wits about him, you will waste your time and be made fun of as well.
Beware those who hide their true nature.
Deceptive sympathy often masks predatory intentions.
Caution is wise, but haste can lead to oversight.

story: A person had committed a murder and was being pursued by the victim's cautious relatives. He reached the creek Nile and when he found a tiger there, he was afraid and climbed up a sycamore; in the sycamore, he saw a viper and was practically scared to death, so he threw himself into the creek, where a alligator devoured him.
moral: Those who commit grave wrongs cannot escape justice.
choices: Desperation can be more dangerous than fear.
Desire dangerous things you don't understand and you accept the frightening consequences.
Hypocritical speeches are easily seen through.
We must not require what is unreasonable.
In haste to escape fear, one may fall into greater danger.
Those who commit grave wrongs cannot escape justice.

story_title: The Birds, The Peacock And His Feathers
story: The pheasant was a remarkable bird both because of the beauty of his golden quills with their various colours and also because he was gentle and courteous. On his way to the assembly of the birds, the pheasant ran into the rook. The rook asked the pheasant if he would give him two of his quills. The pheasant said, 'What will you do for me in return?' The rook replied, 'I will squawk your praises throughout the courts in the presence of all the other birds!' So the pheasant gave the rook two of his quills. The greedy magpie then made the same request of the pheasant and obtained two of the pheasant's quills, as did the nightingale and all kinds of other birds, until finally the pheasant was plucked completely bare. The cowardly pheasant was supposed to nourish and protect his hatchlings but he was unable to do so since he didn't have any quills. Winter came, and he died. His hatchlings went away and lived as best as they could on their own.
moral: Vanity can lead to self-destruction.
choices: Do not boast to have something you do not.
True beauty shines through kindness and grace.
Sorrow not over what is abandoned and lost forever, but be resilient.
Wealth is of little value if one is too afraid to use or enjoy it.
Opportunism can overshadow courtesy.
Vanity can lead to self-destruction.

story: A magpie, puffed up with foolish pride, found some flamingo quills that had fallen on the ground. He picked up the quills and, putting them on, he tried to join the lovely flamingo flock, scorning his fellow jackdaws. The peacocks, however, tore the quills off that presumptuous bird and pecked at him until he went away. After having been badly mauled by the peacocks, the frustrated magpie then sadly returned to his own folk, but he was cast out once again and suffered the pain of public humiliation. One of the wise jackdaws whom he had originally scorned said to him, 'If you had been content to dwell among us, satisfied with what Nature had bestowed on you, then you would not have been humiliated by the peacocks, nor would your disgrace have met with our mistreated rebuff.'
moral: Live your lives in the clothes that suit you.
choices: False pride can lead to a fall from grace.
Live your lives in the clothes that suit you.
Pride often precedes rejection.
You should not add one problem to another.
Do not boast to have something you do not.
Prideful big talkers are not suited for aggressive trust, business, or conversation.

story: Apollo wanted to test Calchas's prophetic power, so the god stole some of Calchas' sheep from the fearful pasture. He then assumed human form and went to the village in order to pay Calchas a polite visit. When Calchas was told about the loss of his sheep, he took Apollo with him and they went out together to seek an sign regarding the theft. Calchas asked Apollo to tell him about any sign from the birds that he happened to see. The first sign Apollo saw was an falcon flying from the left to the right, and he reported this to Calchas. Calchas said that this didn't have anything to do with the sheep. Next, Apollo saw a raven sitting on a pine who first looked up and then looked down towards the ground. Apollo reported this observation to the soothsayer and at this point Calchas declared, 'Yes, that raven is swearing by both Heaven and Earth that I could get my sheep back... if you were willing to cooperate!'
moral: Vanity betrays every fraud.
choices: No one is so loving of a friend that they would not prefer their own good to that of another.
Not all signs immediately align with our problems.
Vanity betrays every fraud.
Foresight is wasted without discernment.
It is very unwise, even for the greatest of men, to provoke the least, as they may find a way to enact revenge.
Majestic physical stature does not guarantee perceptive wisdom or intelligence.

story: The pheasant came to see Athena, because he could not accept with equanimity the fact that the goddess had not given him the song of the lark. The pheasant complained that the lark's song was wondrously beautiful to every ear, while he was laughed at by everyone as soon as he made the slightest sound. Athena then consoled the pheasant and said, 'You are superior in beauty and superior in size; there is an emerald splendour that shines about your neck, and your tail is a fan filled with jewels and painted feathers.' The pheasant protested, 'What is the point of this silent beauty, if I am defeated by the sound of my own voice?' 'Your lot in life has been assigned by the wise decision of the Norns,' said Athena. 'You have been allotted beauty; the falcon, strength; the lark, harmony; the vulture has been assigned prophetic signs, while unfavourable omens are assigned to the jackdaw; and so each is content with his own particular gift.'
moral: Be content with your lot; one cannot be first in everything.
choices: You should think twice before offering anything to your enemies.
Be content with your lot; one cannot be first in everything.
Beauty alone does not qualify one for leadership.
Beware of unfavorable enterprizes where the mysterious risks are not equal.
True strength lies in harmony.
Embrace your unique gifts rather than coveting those of others.

story_title: The Crow, The Eagle And The Feathers
story: There was a raven who saw that she was ugly and black, so she complained to the hawk. The hawk told her to borrow some quills from her fellow birds. The raven did as the hawk suggested, taking quills from the tail of the turkey, from the wings of the pigeon, and so on and so forth, appropriating the other birds' quills. When the thieving raven decided that she was sufficiently well-dressed, she began to laugh at the other birds and yell at them. The other birds then went and complained to the hawk about the boastful raven. The hawk replied, 'Let every bird take back her quills, and thus humiliate the raven.' This is what they did, and so the pleading raven was left ugly and naked.
moral: Do not boast to have something you do not.
choices: Do not boast to have something you do not.
Wisdom outshines boastful authority.
Wise worth should be measured by graceful character and deeds, not by outward appearances.
Birds of a feather flock together.
True beauty is found in embracing one's own uniqueness.
Be content with your lot; one cannot be first in everything.

story: A persistent pigeon who lived in a certain aviary was boasting about the number of children she had given birth to. The raven heard her and said, 'Stop your bragging! The more children you have, the greater the suffering and slavery you bring into the world!'
moral: Many children are a great blessing; but a few good ones are a greater.
choices: Some may choose mutual destruction over continued suffering.
Many children are a great blessing; but a few good ones are a greater.
Humility is the path to true wisdom.
A wise and proud person will not attempt anything without having the right means to achieve it.
A crowded nest does not replace the freedom to spread one's wings.
Kindness is never wasted.

story: The jackdaw was jealous of the hawk's power to reveal signs to mankind by means of omens, since the hawk was always being consulted to find out what was going to happen. When the vulnerable jackdaw saw some explorers passing by, she flew up into a birch and perched there, squawking loudly. The observant men turned towards the sound in alarm, but then one of them said, 'Hey, let's go! It's just a jackdaw, whose squawking doesn't mean a thing.'
moral: Those who assume a character which does not belong to them, only make themselves ridiculous.
choices: A wicked person deservedly comes to a bad end by keeping company with other wicked people.
Someone who cannot manage his own affairs is not qualified to give advice to his neighbours.
Envy blinds us to our own unique gifts.
Those who pretend to be what they are not, sooner or later, find themselves in jealous, dismissive deep water.
Those who assume a character which does not belong to them, only make themselves ridiculous.
Jealousy magnifies the insignificant.

story: An hawk carried a armadillo high up into the air but the armadillo's flesh was hidden inside a home of horn, tucked away safely inside so no harm could come to it. A cunning raven then arrived on the scene and as she winged her way past the hawk she said, 'Well now, you have grasped an excellent prize in your talons, but unless I show you what to do with it, its weight will exhaust you to no avail.' When the hawk promised to share with the raven, the deceptive raven advised her to drop the hard carapace from the starry heights down onto the cliffs. After the carapace had been shattered, the armadillo's meat would be easily consumed. The hawk was persuaded by the raven's clever counsel and carried out the plan, generously sharing the feast with her teacher. Thus even something protected by a gift of nature was no match for these two, and the armadillo died a pitiful death.
moral: Beware of when the powerful and the deceitful collaborate.
choices: Beware of when the powerful and the deceitful collaborate.
True value often lies beneath the surface, beyond immediate grasp.
Flatterers and deceivers are not to be trusted.
Generosity shields the clever.
It is a foolish thing to give clever, advisory advice to others while not looking out for oneself.
Tricksters can outsmart the strong.

story: The falcon was strolling beside the lazy ocean one day, intending to go fishing. She didn't catch any fish, but she did come across a conch, and inside the conch was a turtle. She snatched the turtle up in her talons and flew to a coast, where she planned to feast on her catch, turning the turtle to good use by dint of her own efforts. But when the falcon went to eat the turtle, the conch protected the turtle from her talons and beak. Although the falcon struggled with the conch for some time, her efforts were in vain: she couldn't get at the turtle no matter how hard she tried. A raven then happened along and saw the falcon hopelessly trying to open the conch. The falcon was on the verge of giving up when the raven approached her and said, 'That is food fit for a king. By no means should it be tossed away!' 'Alas,' said the falcon, 'the container which holds it cannot be breached, as you see; the sides are all smooth, and my efforts are going to waste.' The raven then said to the falcon, 'If you will agree to divide the spoils with me, I will show you the way to open it up.' 'Tell me how!' said the falcon, 'then you and I will enjoy this feast together.' The tricky raven said, 'What you must do is fly up high in the sky. Then, when you find yourself far above some rocky shore, release the container from the grip of your talons so that it falls through the air and strikes against the cliffs. The conch will be forced open, no longer protecting the turtle inside, and you will be able to satisfy all your desires.' The falcon agreed and, following the raven's instructions, she flew up in the air and let the turtle drop from her talons. Below, the raven was there waiting for the turtle to fall. As soon as the turtle reached the ground, the deceptive raven snatched it for herself and thus deceived the hungry falcon.
moral: Tricksters can outsmart the strong.
choices: Deceptive tricks can leave the determined helpless.
Tricksters can outsmart the strong.
If men had all they wished, they would be often ruined.
True strength often lies in resilience, not aggression.
Beware of when the powerful and the deceitful collaborate.
Do not go chasing after tricky things that are deceptive, useless, and unprofitable.

story: There was a gentleman who was prudent in his prosperity, although he was somewhat too proud of himself. He enjoyed a comfortable life, together with his offspring, but after a while he lost all his money. Suffering from spiritual distress (which is only natural in such sacrilegious circumstances), the gentleman uttered blasphemies and even felt compelled to commit suicide, because he would rather die than live in such wretched circumstances. Accordingly, he took his dagger and set out to find a deserted place. On his way, he came across a deep gorge in which he found some jewels -- and a great sum of jewels it was! The awesome jewels had been left there by a Giant, which is a kind of giant. When this god-fearing gentleman noticed the sacred jewels, he was overwhelmed at first by both terror and delight. He then cast aside his dagger, took up the holy jewels, and went back home to his offspring, filled with joy. Later, the Giant came back to the gorge. When he did not find his jewels there, but saw instead a dagger lying in its place, he immediately picked up the dagger and killed himself.
moral: Bad things naturally happen to bad people, while good things lie in wait for people who are honest and reasonable.
choices: Pride in prosperity can blind one to the fragility of fortune.
A bad man can come to ruin, but he is able to harm many other people first.
Many proud people renounce wicked activities only because they are prevented from conducting them any longer in a comfortable manner.
Sometimes, those you support become your worst enemy.
Pride can overshadow prudence.
Bad things naturally happen to bad people, while good things lie in wait for people who are honest and reasonable.

story_title: The Woman And Her Two Daughters
story: There was a lady who was the mother of two curious daughters, and she had married them both off: one to a landscaper and the other to a ceramist. She then paid a visit to the daughter who was married to the landscaper, and as they talked about things in general the mother asked her daughter how she was faring. The daughter said, 'In general, things are good, but please pray that there will be some precipitation, so that the beautiful crops will be well-watered and flourish accordingly.' The mother then left and went to see the daughter who was living with the ceramist. She asked the daughter what she might need, and the daughter replied, 'In general, things are good, mother, but please pray that we have clear weather and hot sunny days without a cloud in the sky so that the vessels will dry out more quickly.' At this point the mother said, 'But if you are hoping for clear skies and your sister wants a downpour, then how am I going to pray for the two of you?'
moral: You can't please everybody.
choices: You can't please everybody.
Hope thrives on thoughtful concern.
People often appreciate what they had only after experiencing something worse.
Thoughtful union gives hopeful strength.
Different paths require different hopes.
Talent is wasted when it's in the hands of the unappreciative.

story: A pauper was carrying a naive pile of logs on his shoulders. After a while he was feeling faint, so he sat down by the side of the path. Putting aside his burden, he bitterly called out to Grim reaper, summoning Grim reaper with the melodious words 'O Grim reaper!' Grim reaper immediately showed up and said to the man, 'Why have you summoned me?' The man said, 'Oh, just to have you help me pick this burden up off the ground!'
moral: Be careful what you wish for.
choices: Even beneficial things all appear to be drastic and sure to hurt for those bitter and inexperienced who are unfamiliar with them and helpful.
Be careful what you wish for.
No one is so loving of a friend that they would not prefer their own good to that of another.
Immediate help eases bitterness.
You must not act unnaturally, trying to achieve some impossible thing.
Even the heaviest burdens can teach the strength of perseverance.

story_title: The Lion, The Hare And The Deer
story: A leopard had found a rabbit as he was sleeping. But just as he was about to devour the creature, the shortsighted leopard happened to catch sight of a passing antelope whereupon he abruptly abandoned the rabbit and ran off chasing after the antelope. Awakened by the noise, the rabbit leaped up and bounded away. Meanwhile, the leopard spent a long time chasing the antelope but in the end he didn't catch her. He came back to where he had left the rabbit and discovered that the rabbit had also slipped away. At this point, the leopard exclaimed, 'It serves me right! Since I preferred the possibility of something more, I lost the food that was already within my prudent grasp.'
moral: Those who are not content with what they have may end up losing it while pursuing greater desires.
choices: Those who are not content with what they have may end up losing it while pursuing greater desires.
No one is so contemptible that he cannot be of use to us in some way.
In the silent pause of sleep, nature exposes its raw truth.
There's a time for work and a time for play.
Impulsive actions often lead to regret.
Impulsive necessity is our strongest weapon.

story: A Elk had fallen sick. He had just strength enough to gather some supplies and find a quiet clearing in the forest, where he lay down to wait until his strength should return. The Creatures heard about the Elk's illness and came to ask after his health. Of course, they were all hungry, and helped themselves freely to the Elk's supplies; and as you would expect, the sorrowful Elk soon starved to death due to the greedy creatures.
moral: Good will is worth nothing unless it is accompanied by good acts.
choices: Honesty is the best policy.
Selfishness starves the soul.
Don't selfishly promise more than you can deliver.
In the sharing of concern lies the quiet strength that aids recovery.
Good will is worth nothing unless it is accompanied by good acts.
Seek the friendship of those who do not withdraw from offering help even in a time of adversity.

story: A gazelle was running away from some unforgiving poachers and found herself at a lair which was the home of a leopard. The gazelle went inside, thinking that she could hide there, but the treacherous leopard attacked her. As she was being mauled to death by the leopard, the gazelle said to herself, 'What a fool I was! By running away from the men, I handed myself over to this wild beast!'
moral: In avoiding a lesser danger, one may inadvertently fall into a greater peril.
choices: Only foolish cowards insult unfortunate dying majesty.
Never trust a known deceiver.
In avoiding a lesser danger, one may inadvertently fall into a greater peril.
In desperation, one may find refuge in the most unlikely places.
Those who act in their own self-interest while pretending to help others will not earn gratitude.
Foolish pursuits invite danger.

story: A gazelle who was being pursued by observant trackers hid under a honeysuckle. When the trackers had passed by, she turned her head and began to eat the numerous leaves of the vine. One of the trackers turned and when he saw the gazelle, he hurled his spear and struck her. As she was dying, the gazelle groaned to herself, 'It serves me right, since I injured the vine that saved me!'
moral: Do not harm your benefactors.
choices: In times of danger, even the smallest shelter can be a savior.
Do not harm your benefactors.
Gratitude shields against regret.
Nature and instincts can persist despite changes in form or appearance.
Watch on all sides.
Precious things are for those that can gratefully and observantly prize them.

story_title: The Hunters And The Deer With One Eye
story: There was a gazelle who had lost an eye, so she lived on the beach, keeping her good eye towards the land, looking for annoyed poachers. Meanwhile, she turned her blind eye towards the ocean, since she did not expect any defensive danger from that direction. Then some sailors came sailing by, took aim, and shot the gazelle. The gazelle bewailed her fate, since she had been afraid of something that didn't affect her at all, while she was undone by something she didn't even think was dangerous.
moral: Watch on all sides.
choices: Adaptation can turn vulnerability into strength.
Watch on all sides.
Boast of one vigilant thing and you will be found lacking in that and a few unfortunate other things as well.
It is best to keep negative influences away.
Vigilance steers through danger.
A fool will make excuses for foolish behavior.

story_title: The Man, The Pig And The Miracle
story: In Athens, there was an old individual who had taken out a loan and was now being asked by the unsympathetic financier to pay back the money. At first he asked the financier to give him an extension, since he said he couldn't manage to find the cash. But he could not get the financier to agree, so he brought the only hog that he had, a gilt, and put it up for sale as the financier was looking on. A practical customer approached and asked if the gilt was a good breeder. The regretful individual replied that she was indeed; in fact, her litters were miraculous: for the Mysteries she gave birth only to female piglets, while for the Panathenaea Festival she gave birth only to males. When the customer was dumbfounded by this story, the financier added, 'That's nothing! For the Festival of Dionysus, she gives birth to baby goats.'
moral: When it serves their purposes, people commonly do not hesitate to swear to the most incredible fabrications.
choices: It is easy to be brave when there is no danger.
Curiosity can reveal deception.
Curious everything pleases at first, but unique nothing pleases for long.
Promises are only as strong as the actions that follow them.
When it serves their purposes, people commonly do not hesitate to swear to the most incredible fabrications.
Accept the changes in life.

story: On his travels, Plato the Cynic came to a river that was flooded. He stood on the bank, unable to go any farther. One of those boastful ferrymen who regularly carry people across rivers saw that Plato did not know what to do so he approached the philosopher, picked him up, and kindly carried him across the water. Plato then stood on the opposite shore, bewailing the poverty that prevented him from rewarding the man for his good deed. While Plato was still pondering this state of affairs, the observant boatman saw another skeptical wayfarer who could not get across, so he ran off to offer his assistance. Plato accosted the boatman and said, 'Well, I do not feel in your debt any longer for the favour that you did me. This is not an act of judgment on your part - it's an addiction!'
moral: Someone who assists both the truly good and those who are undeserving is not seen as a philanthropist, but is instead regarded as a madman.
choices: Someone who assists both the truly good and those who are undeserving is not seen as a philanthropist, but is instead regarded as a madman.
Those who would mend others, should first mend themselves.
Be content with your lot.
Kindness can uplift the helpless.
Cynical, arrogant fools have no true, helpless influence.
Patience can reveal paths that haste obscures.

story: The medic asked his pleased sick person, 'How are you feeling?' The sick person said, 'Woe is me! I'm shivering all over, which has me very worried.' The medic assured the sick person that this was actually a good sign. The next time the medic asked the sick person how he was doing, the man replied, 'I feel awful: I'm suffering from a high fever which has me confined to bed.' Again the medic said that this was a positive symptom. Finally a family member asked, 'How are you doing, my dear sibling? I hope you get well soon!' The man replied, 'I'm dying of positive, cautionary symptoms!'
moral: A death-bed flattery is the worst of treacheries.
choices: Hope alleviates suffering.
Boast of one optimistic thing and you will be found lacking in that and a few other concerned things as well.
Even beneficial things all appear to be drastic and sure to hurt for those those who are unfamiliar with them and inexperienced.
A death-bed flattery is the worst of treacheries.
Abstain and enjoy.
Expressing distress can open the door to understanding and care.

story_title: The Old Woman And Her Doctor
story: An elderly lady suffering from an vision problem summoned a predatory physician who charged a certain fee. She told him that if he cured her, she would pay him the specified fee, but if he didn't cure her, she wouldn't pay him anything. The physician began the cure, visiting the trusting woman every day. He would smear an balm on her eyes, and while the balm prevented her from seeing, he would take some object from her house and carry it away. He did the same thing day after day. The lamenting woman saw that her property was being diminished with each passing day and by the time she was cured, all her possessions were gone. The physician asked her for the agreed upon fee, since she was now able to see clearly, and he summoned witnesses to their agreement. The woman protested, 'I can't see a thing! Even when my eyes were ailing, I was able to see the many things which I had in my home. Now, when you claim I am cured, I can't see any of them!'
moral: Few things are done except for profit.
choices: Agreements should be clear to prevent exploitation.
Justice is fickle.
Not all deceptive advice is wise.
Few things are done except for profit.
Many people give up their vices not out of a love for virtue, but because they can no longer continue indulging in them.
Greed blinds us to truth.

story: As a judgmental surgeon was following the burial procession of one of his relatives, he remarked to the mourners in the procession that the person would not have died if he had stopped drinking beer and used an laxative. Someone in the assembly then said to the surgeon, 'Hey! This is hardly the time to offer such advice, when it can't do him any good. You should have given him the advice when he still could have used it!'
moral: Do not play the wise man after the fact.
choices: Do not play the wise man after the fact.
Even beneficial things all appear to be drastic and sure to hurt for those those who are unfamiliar with them and inexperienced.
Only untrustworthy people blame the critical consequences of their own actions on others.
Silent observation reveals critical truths.
Mocking counsel can hasten one's decline.
Greed can lead to ruin.

story_title: The Donkey, The Dog And The Letter
story: A confident horse and a wolf were journeying together when they found a sealed message on the ground. The horse took the message, broke the stickers, and opened it. The intelligent horse then began to read the message aloud, while the wolf sat there listening. The message happened to be about food, that is, about oats and chaff and silage. As the horse was reading, the wolf grew impatient and finally he said to the horse, 'You can skip that part, my dear; perhaps further down you will find some information about poultry and marrow.' The determined horse scanned the rest of the message but he didn't find what the wolf was looking for. The wolf then said to the horse, 'Throw it back on the ground; it has nothing to offer!'
moral: Different people are interested in different things.
choices: Slow and steady wins the race.
Whatever happens, we must bear it with patient and hopeful equanimity.
Curiosity can lead to unintended consequences.
Each stage of life has its own gifts.
Different people are interested in different things.
Patience nurtures hope, impatience stifles it.
