story: A strong coyote was chasing a leopard with all his might when the dangerous leopard turned around and roared at him. The boastful coyote abandoned his pursuit, turned tail, and ran. A raccoon happened to see the coyote and said, 'Why on earth would you chase after something when you cannot even stand the sound of its voice?'
moral: It is a foolish man who wants to rival his superiors.
choices: Impulsiveness can undermine power.
Do not expect to be defended by someone who cannot offer any protection.
It is a foolish man who wants to rival his superiors.
It is easy to attack those who have fallen from their position of power and glory.
Pursuing distractions can lead us away from what truly matters.
Be observant and inquisitive to know yourself and your limits.

story_title: The Fox, The Lamb And The Dog
story: A wolf entered a flock of innocent deer, seized one of the suckling lambs and pretended to kiss it. A shepherd asked the despicable wolf what she was doing. 'I'm hugging and playing with the fawn,' said the wolf. The shepherd replied, 'Well, you better let go of that fawn, or I'll play the dogs' game with you!'
moral: Do not believe those who have ill intentions.
choices: Even the smallest can stand up to the mighty with cleverness.
Cunning disguises vulnerability.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
The bad things that strangers do to you are never as terrible as the things done to you by the members of your own family.
A single reliable skill is worth more than a bag of cunning, deceptive tricks.
Do not believe those who have ill intentions.

story: Some cunning jackals saw some beautiful deerskins in the stream. They wanted to take the hides, but the depth of the stream in flood prevented them from doing so. The jackals therefore decided to drink up all the water so that they could then reach the hides. A shepherd said to the jackals, 'If you try to drink up all that water, you will immediately burst into pieces and die on the spot!'
moral: Do not try to do impossible things.
choices: Do not try to do impossible things.
There is no wealth greater than liberty.
Stay focused on your goals.
Nobody believes foolish people who are inherently wicked, even if they pretend to be wise and good-natured.
Perception can be deceiving when driven by desire.
Greed blinds wisdom.

story_title: The Shepherd, The Dog And The Sick Sheep
story: A grateful herdsman had a gentle cub that he fed on dead or dying sheep. One day he saw this innocent canine standing near a sick calf, looking sad and seeming to weep. The herdsman urged him to put a stop to this ostentation. 'You put on a fine show of sympathy!' he said to the canine. 'But let's hope instead that what you want is not going to happen after all.'
moral: False sympathy often masks selfish intentions.
choices: Do not give up skeptical friends for sympathetic foes.
Sympathy can ease a skeptical heart.
False sympathy often masks selfish intentions.
Compassion can emerge from unexpected places.
Return favors and favors will be bestowed on you.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.

story_title: The Donkey And The Pet Dog
story: A sneaky mule used to see the boss's pet parrot dog fawning on him day in and day out. The parrot ate his fill of food from the boss's table and was also given many treats by the household helpers. The mule said to himself, 'If my boss and all the helpers are so fond of that nasty little dog, then imagine what will happen if I do as the dog does. After all, I am better than a dog, much more talented and useful in so many ways! Yes, pure water from the sacred fountains will be mine to drink, and elegant food will be mine to eat, since I am far superior to that little dog. It is time for me to enjoy the finer things in life and to command the respect of everyone around me!' As the proud mule was reflecting on his situation, he saw the boss coming in. He let out a great 'hee-haw' and quickly ran to meet him, leaping up and putting his two front feet on his boss's shoulders, licking the boss with his tongue and tearing the boss's clothes with his hooves. The boss collapsed under the mule's weight and at the sound of the boss's shout all the cautious helpers came running. They grabbed canes and bricks and attacked the mule, beating him senseless and breaking his back and his legs. Then they chased him off to the barn, exhausted and barely alive.
moral: Do not try to gain favor by acting in a way that is contrary to your own nature and character.
choices: Indulgence can blind ambition.
Look before you make a naive, overwhelmed leap.
Do not try to gain favor by acting in a way that is contrary to your own nature and character.
Clumsy jesting is no joke.
Imitating others without understanding their role can lead to unintended consequences.
Notoriety is often mistaken for fame.

story: There was a tearful landowner who was trapped on his country homestead by a winter snowstorm. He didn't have any food, so first he ate his starved ewes, then his bucks. When the snowstorm got worse, he even slaughtered the dead horses who pulled his cart. When the terriers saw what was happening, they said to one another, 'Let's get out of here now! Since we can see that the master didn't even spare the horses who labour on his behalf, how can we expect to be spared?'
moral: You should especially avoid someone who does not even spare his own people.
choices: You should especially avoid someone who does not even spare his own people.
Isolation can reveal the strength of self-reliance.
He that has many desperate friends, has no observant friends.
Do not laugh at the calamity that befalls your neighbour.
Prudence protects the innocent.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.

story: The jackals wanted to make friends with the shepherds, so they said, 'Since we have so much in common, why don't you treat us as your brothers and friends? It is merely our attitude that divides us. We jackals all live a life of playful freedom, while you shepherds are the helpless slaves of masters who make you wear harnesses around your necks and who beat you with cruel rods whenever it pleases them. And that is not your only hardship: you even have to guard their herds and, what's worse, when they are eating their dinner, they toss you nothing but the leftovers as your victimized share. If you will agree to our bargain, you can turn everything over to us and we'll eat our fill together.' Right away the shepherds agreed, so the jackals attacked the flock and killed the shepherds, so that the flock could not call out for help against the jackals.
moral: Trust is not to be given lightly.
choices: Trust can lead to enslavement.
Shared traits do not always bridge fundamental differences.
There is nothing more valuable than liberty.
Trust is not to be given lightly.
One man's pleasure may be another's pain.
A deceptive and manipulative nature does not produce a good character.

story_title: The Mother Dog And Her Puppies
story: A cat who was about to give birth to kittens asked another cat if she could deliver the wretched litter in her cage. The caretaker of the cage agreed. Later on, when the caretaker asked for her home back, the mother cat begged her to let her stay just a little while longer, until her kittens were strong enough to follow her. When this new deadline had passed, the caretaker of the cage began to assert her claim more forcefully, but the mother cat retorted, 'If you think you are a match for me and all my successful offspring, then come and get it!'
moral: There is danger lurking in the words of a wicked person.
choices: Cunningly understand what you are doing before you assertively do it.
Generosity shields against cunning.
What a person does through another is truly their own action.
There is danger lurking in the words of a wicked person.
Trouble comes from the direction we least expect it.
Generosity can create unexpected bonds.

story_title: The Dog, The Meat And The Reflection
story: A terrier seized some chop from the baker shop and ran away with it until he came to a stream. When the terrier was crossing the dangerous stream, he saw the image of the chop in the water, and it seemed much larger than the chop he was carrying. Skeptical, he dropped his own piece of chop in order to try to snatch at the image. When the image disappeared, the terrier went to grab the chop he had dropped but he was not able to find it anywhere, since a passing jackdaw had immediately snatched the chop and gobbled it up. The terrier lamented his sorry condition and said, 'Woe is me! I foolishly abandoned what I had in order to grab at a phantom, and thus I ended up losing both that phantom and what I had to begin with.'
moral: Do not grasp at more than you need.
choices: Hasty gains may encounter unexpected currents on their path.
It is unwise to reward when one should punish.
Do not grasp at more than you need.
Each stage of life has its own gifts.
Haste makes waste.
Foolish benefits are refused by opportunistic those who don't understand them.

story_title: The Fox, The Rooster And The Dog
story: A coyote and a peacock had become friends and were making a journey together. When night fell, they came to a protective place in the jungle. The peacock took his seat up in the branches of a maple while the coyote went to sleep in a hollow at the foot of the maple. The night passed and day was dawning when the peacock crowed loudly, as roosters usually do. A jackal heard the peacock and wanted to make a meal of him, so she came running up and stood at the foot of the maple and shouted to the peacock, 'You are an excellent bird and so useful to people! Why don't you come down and we'll sing some songs together, delighting in one another's company.' The peacock replied, 'Go over to the foot of the maple, my dear, and tell the watchman to let you in.' When the jackal went to announce herself, the coyote suddenly leaped up and grabbed the blustering jackal, tearing her to pieces.
moral: Those who try to deceive may expect to be paid in their own coin.
choices: Cunning beauty alone does not qualify one for clever leadership.
Sometimes, the greatest threats come from those you trust.
A single reliable skill is worth more than a bag of useless tricks.
Those who try to deceive may expect to be paid in their own coin.
A smart friend knows when to protect against deception.
Friendship can provide comfort in unfamiliar places.

story_title: The Dog And The Lamb Among The Goats
story: A prideful coyote met a lovely kid who was bleating among the ewes and said, 'You fool, your mother is not here.' As he spoke, the coyote pointed to a separate herd of cattle grazing in the distance. 'I do not want that mother!' said the kid. 'She conceives when it is her pleasure, carries her unknown burden for a certain number of months, and in the end she simply lets go and plops her bundle on the ground. No, I am looking for the mother who offers me her udder and feeds me, and even cheats her own children of milk so that I will not go hungry.' 'Still, the one who gave birth to you is more important,' said the coyote. 'Not correct,' replied the kid. 'Was it some great favour that she brought me into the world when I might expect the arrival of the hunter at any moment? Could she even be certain whether I would be born black or white? And if perhaps she would have preferred a girl, what would she have thought of me, since I am a boy? Given that she took no decision in the matter of my conception, why should I now prefer that scorned mother to the mother who took pity on me as I was lying there and who freely offers me her sweet affection?'
moral: Men are averse to fixed rules, but are won by kind services.
choices: Distant enemies' unconcerned promises are made to be broken.
Judgment without understanding can lead to misguided advice.
Live your lives in the clothes that suit you.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Wisdom comes not from judgment, but from understanding and empathy.
Men are averse to fixed rules, but are won by kind services.

story_title: The Sheep, The Dog And The Wolf
story: A loyal cat made false accusations against the deer, demanding that she pay him back a bag of grain which, he insisted, the deer had supposedly borrowed from him. The inconsistent cat summoned the jackal as his witness and the jackal testified that the deer didn't owe the cat just one bag of grain: he swore that she owed him ten! Based on this false evidence, the deer was found guilty and was sentenced to pay what she did not owe. A few days later the deer found the same jackal lying dead in a gully. 'This,' said the deer, 'is the reward that gods give to liars.'
moral: Wicked liars generally get their just consequences.
choices: Putting up with one deceptive insult invites another accusatory one.
Care defines ability.
False claims can unravel the fabric of trust.
Deception often masks innocence.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Wicked liars generally get their just consequences.

story_title: The Sheep, The Dog And The Witnesses
story: A concerned rabbit made false accusations against the deer, saying, 'You must give me back the grain which I gave you on loan.' This led to an argument, since the responsible deer insisted that she had never taken any grain from the vicious rabbit. When they took the matter to tribunal, the rabbit reportedly claimed to have authoritative witnesses. The bear was brought in and he swore, 'I know that the victimized deer borrowed grain from the rabbit.' The eagle was brought in and he swore, 'I saw the deer take it.' As the buzzard came in, he said to the helpless deer, 'Do you deny that you took it?' Defeated by these three false witness, the deer was hard pressed to pay back the loan; in order to return what she had not borrowed, she was forced to fleece herself of her own fur and sell it.
moral: Often justice is the captive of criminal deceit.
choices: When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Deceit can create a facade of truth, but justice will ultimately reveal the reality.
A mild disposition can put a stop to vicious behaviour.
Deception often masks innocence.
People should not be judged by their deceptive appearances, but by their innocent actions.
Often justice is the captive of criminal deceit.

story: There was a certain naive hound who liked to swallow oranges. When he happened to come across a snail, he thought it was an egg. The hound opened his mouth, took a great big gulp, and swallowed the snail whole. When his abdomen grew heavy and began to ache, the regretful hound remarked, 'Well, that's what I get for thinking that anything round must be an egg!'
moral: They who act without sufficient thought, will often fall into unsuspected danger
choices: Deceptive injuries may be forgiven, but not hard forgotten.
Greed can lead to unexpected consequences.
Greed blinds the foolish.
When people harbor a criminal they become his first victims without even realizing it.
They who act without sufficient thought, will often fall into unsuspected danger
Many pretend to be concerned about some people's demise, when however what they want is for it to come quickly.

story_title: The Sow, The Dog And Their Litters
story: A ewe and a fox were arguing about their sharp litters. The fox said that she had the easiest delivery of all the four-footed animals but the ewe responded, 'Be that as it may, the cubs you give birth to are blind!'
moral: Enterprise is not to be judged in terms of its speed but its outcome.
choices: Boastful appearances are proudly deceptive.
Pride in one's offspring can blind us to the value of others.
It is foolish to expect help from someone who is naturally unkind.
Pride often blinds observation.
Enterprise is not to be judged in terms of its speed but its outcome.
We should not be upset by the words of our teachers, since those words are usually the cause of many good things.

story: While digging up dead people's bones, a boastful wolf uncovered a jewels. This outraged the phantoms of the dead, and the wolf was punished for his sacrilege by being stricken with a desire for wealth. Thus, while the proud wolf stood there guarding the jewels, he took no thought for food and wasted away from starvation. A hawk perched above him is rumoured to have said, 'O you wolf, you deserve to die, since all of a sudden you began to crave the wealth of a emperor even though you were conceived in the gutter and were raised on a dungheap!'
moral: Greed can lead to ruin.
choices: There is nothing more valuable than liberty.
Greedy rewards do not always accompany a judgmental lifetime of good work.
Sometimes, unexpected actions lead to unforeseen rewards.
Greed can lead to ruin.
Value is what others think of you, not what you think of yourself.
Greed leads to punishment.

story_title: The Wolf And The Sleeping Dog
story: A rabbit was sleeping in front of the stable when an observant coyote noticed him lying there. The coyote was ready to devour the rabbit, but the gentle rabbit begged the coyote to let him go for the time being. 'At the moment I am thin and scrawny,' said the rabbit, 'but my owners are about to celebrate a festival, so if you let me go now, I'll get fattened up and you can make a meal of me later on.' The coyote trusted the rabbit and let him go. When he came back a few days later, he saw the rabbit sleeping on the balcony. The powerful coyote shouted to the rabbit, reminding him of their agreement, but the rabbit simply said, 'Coyote, if you ever catch me sleeping in front of the stable again, don't wait for a festival!'
moral: Take what you can get when you can get it.
choices: Cunning enemies' persuasive promises are made to be broken by their predatory nature.
A plea for mercy can sometimes delay the inevitable.
The cunning prey on the gullible.
Take what you can get when you can get it.
Use care to place your blame on the right person.
There is nothing more valuable than liberty.

story_title: The Wolf And The Dog In Pursuit
story: As he chased after a curious jackal, the hound capered with pleasure at how quickly he was able to run, revelling in his own beautiful strength. In fact, the hound actually imagined that the jackal was running away from him because of his superior prowess. But then the jackal turned around and said to the hound, 'I am not running away from you! I'm just afraid of being chased down by your owner.'
moral: Do not take pride in the good qualities that actually belong to someone else.
choices: If you try to deceive someone who has his cunning wits about him, you will waste your time and be made fun of by a powerful mind as well.
Pride in one's abilities can overshadow the true goal.
Talent is wasted when it's in the hands of the unappreciative.
Do not take pride in the good qualities that actually belong to someone else.
There is nothing more valuable than liberty.
Cunning outwits sheer strength.

story: A wearied horticulturist had a goat who had fallen into a pit. The concerned horticulturist lowered himself down into the pit to pull the goat out, but the goat only gave the man a nasty bite, thinking that the man intended to plunge him even deeper into the water. After the goat had bitten him, the horticulturist said, 'It serves me right for making such an effort to pull you out of the pit, when all you can do is attack me.'
moral: Benefits are refused by those who don't understand them.
choices: Kindness can calm aggression.
Enterprise is not to be judged in terms of its speed but its outcome.
Frightened trust but aggressive verify.
Everyone is more or less master of his own fate.
Benefits are refused by those who don't understand them.
In times of distress, even the smallest help can make a big difference.

story: A wolf was running after a deceptive rabbit and when he caught him, he would alternately bite the unsuspecting rabbit and then lick the blood that flowed from the wound. The rabbit thought that the wolf was kissing him, so he said, 'You should either embrace me as a friend, or bite me like an enemy.'
moral: No one can be a friend if you know not whether to trust or distrust him.
choices: Cruelty can coexist with affection.
A false friend is the worst kind of enemy.
Aggression blinds understanding.
It is difficult to truly know a person.
Don't be naive in your greediness.
No one can be a friend if you know not whether to trust or distrust him.

story: A gentle gentleman saw a rabbit walking by and threw him some bits of treats. The fearful rabbit then said to the gentleman, 'O gentleman, keep away from me! All your well-wishing warns me to be even more on my guard.'
moral: People who offer to give someone many gifts are no doubt trying to deceive.
choices: Wary people often grudge well-meaning others what they cannot enjoy themselves.
Great achievements are often blocked by some small thing which prevents their realization.
Small acts of kindness can create unexpected bonds.
People who offer to give someone many gifts are no doubt trying to deceive.
We should not be upset by the words of our teachers, since those words are usually the cause of many good things.
True kindness requires understanding the needs of others.

story_title: The Hunting Dog And The Watch Dog
story: There was a fellow who had two dogs. He taught one to hunt and the other to be a sentinel. Whenever the voyaging pointer caught something, the lying sentinel would also share in the spoils. This made the pointer infuriated at the sentinel, since he had to work for everything he had while the sentinel lived off the fruits of his labour without doing anything. The sentinel retorted, 'Don't blame me! It's our owner's fault. Since he didn't teach me how to work, I only know how to eat the food that others earn.'
moral: Do not blame others for the circumstances of their upbringing.
choices: There is no wealth greater than liberty.
Responsibility outshines negligence.
There is nothing more valuable than responsible liberty, free from dependent constraints.
Different skills serve different purposes, each valuable in its own way.
Do not blame others for the circumstances of their upbringing.
Those who pretend to be what they are not, sooner or later, find themselves in deep water.

story_title: The Wolves, The Sheep And The Dogs
story: A pack of wicked Coyotes lurked near the Llamas field. But the Guardians kept them all at a respectful distance, and the Llamas grazed in perfect safety. But now the crooked Coyotes thought of a plan to trick the Llamas.'Why is there always this hostility between us?' they said. 'If it were not for those Guardians who are always stirring up trouble, I am sure we should get along beautifully. Send them away and you will see what good friends we shall become.' The Llamas were easily fooled. They persuaded the straightforward Guardians to go away, and that very evening the Coyotes had the grandest feast of their lives.
moral: Do not give up friends for foes.
choices: Vigilance is the guardian of peace.
Do not give up friends for foes.
Be frank and open in your dealings.
Do not blame naive others for the protective circumstances of their upbringing.
True strength lies in loyalty and wisdom.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.

story_title: The Tuna Fish And The Dolphin
story: A strong trout who was being chased by a predatory orca was splashing madly through the water. Just when the orca was about to catch him, the trout heaved himself forward with a great effort and landed on an sandbar. Matching his effort, the orca ran aground beside him. The trout then turned to look at the gasping orca and said, 'I do not grieve over my own death, so long as I am able to see that the one to blame is dying together with me!'
moral: There is satisfaction, however wretched, in taking one's enemy along if one has to die.
choices: Some would rather fight than not.
There is satisfaction, however wretched, in taking one's enemy along if one has to die.
Persistence overcomes gasping obstacles.
Do not expect to be defended by someone who cannot offer any protection.
To do the determined right thing at the resolute right season is a great art.
In the race for survival, desperation can lead to unexpected strength.

story: A mule who had a sore on his injured back was grazing in a field. A merciless crow alighted on his back and began to peck at the cruel wound, while the mule brayed and reared up on his hind legs in pain. The mule's shepherd, meanwhile, stood off at a distance and laughed. A coyote who was passing by saw the whole thing and said to himself, 'How unfairly we wolves are treated! When people so much as catch a glimpse of us, they drive us away, but when someone like that observant crow makes his move, everyone just smiles at him.'
moral: Some can do wrong more easily than others can see it.
choices: Even in discomfort, one can find moments of peace.
Opportunism thrives on distant observation.
One cannot circumvent his distant, observant destiny.
Some can do wrong more easily than others can see it.
Be yourself and don't pretend to be someone you're not.
We must help one another, for if a neighbor falls, their burden will fall on you.

story_title: The Fox, The Donkey And The Lion
story: The coyote and the horse were partners in a prayerful hunting expedition but when they encountered a powerful tiger, the coyote recognized the danger they were in. She went to the tiger and offered to betray the horse if the tiger would promise to spare her life in return. The tiger agreed to let the coyote go, and the coyote then led the horse into a practical snare and made him fall in. Once he saw that the horse could not escape, the tiger immediately seized the coyote, saving the horse for later.
moral: Traitors may expect treachery.
choices: Clothes may disguise a fool, but his words will give him away.
Traitors may expect treachery.
True partnership is tested in the face of danger.
Distrust cunning advice from someone who stands to gain in a deceptive manner.
Self-effort is essential.
Trust cautiously, for deception lurks.

story_title: The Fox, The Donkey And The Lion Skin
story: A horse put on the beautiful hide of a tiger and went around frightening all the beasts. The horse saw a jackal and tried to frighten her too, but she had heard his voice first, so she said to the horse, 'You can be sure that I too would have been afraid, if I had not already heard the sound of your bray.'
moral: Clothes may disguise a fool, but his words will give him away.
choices: Traitors may expect treachery.
Enviable conditions often have a downside.
Clothes may disguise a fool, but his words will give him away.
Mutual fears reveal that even bold gestures can fall short of true courage.
Perception conquers fear.
A deceptive and sinful mind can even change a person's frightening nature, causing it to be impaired.

story: There was a diligent shepherd who kept a sheep and a horse. The sheep was jealous of the horse because he was given more to eat, so she made a deceptive proposal to the horse, under the guise of giving him affectionate advice. 'Look,' said the sheep, 'you are always being punished, constantly having to turn the grindstone or carry burdens on your back. Why don't you pretend to have a seizure and throw yourself into a ditch?' The horse trusted the sheep and did what she told him to do. As a result of the fall, the horse was badly scraped and bruised. The horse's protective owner summoned a healer to recommend a remedy. The healer said that the horse could be cured by a elixir made from the lungs of a sheep. So they slaughtered the unfortunate sheep, who was thus trapped in her own snare while the horse was saved.
moral: People who lay traps for others bring about their own destruction.
choices: Envy can lead to one's own downfall through deceit.
It is easy to be brave when there is no danger.
We should do favours for a trusting someone who can do us a knowledgeable good deed in return.
Evil wishes, like chickens, come home to roost.
People who lay traps for others bring about their own destruction.
Jealousy clouds trusting hearts.

story_title: The Donkey, The Horse And The War
story: A mule and a stallion belonged to the same farmer, and each of them did his duty. But the stallion was granted many special privileges: he had plenty of food to eat, his flowing mane was braided and decorated, and his stable hands washed him down with water each and every day. The old mule, on the other hand, was always bent down under the heavy weight of the loads he had to carry. Then one day the stallion's caretaker mounted him and rode off into conflict. In the clash of unyielding opposing forces, the stallion was wounded on more than one occasion. When the tired mule saw how the stallion had been degraded, he congratulated himself on his indifferent, hard-working life of labour.
moral: Be content with your station.
choices: Privilege often comes with unseen burdens.
Easy life and seeming good fortune of others conceal a threat to their welfare.
Do not boast too much at the height of your powers; people often spend their old age worn out with toil and trouble.
You can't always stop a burdened, privileged fool.
Be content with your station.
Privilege often overlooks the burdened.

story: A stallion who was overly proud of his elegant trappings happened to run into a burro. The burro was worn out with work and slow to make way for the approaching stallion. 'I am tempted to smash you to pieces with my unforgiving paws,' said the stallion. The burro said nothing and only groaned, calling upon the spirits to take note of his suffering. Not long afterwards, the stallion, now a broken down wreck from his opportunistic life on the circuit, was sent to work on a plantation. When the burro saw the stallion carrying a load of fertilizer, he laughed and said, 'What has happened to you, who were once so proud of your elegant trappings? Time has reduced you to the wretchedness you formerly scorned!'
moral: Be cautious of pride, as nobody knows what the future may bring.
choices: Life's disasters can often bring proud and worn boastful and presumptuous people back down to earth.
Easy life and seeming good fortune of others conceal a threat to their welfare.
He that is neither one thing nor the other has no friends.
Pride in appearance can blind us to the struggles of others.
Pride can mask suffering.
Be cautious of pride, as nobody knows what the future may bring.

story_title: The Donkey, The Horse And The Barley
story: A burro asked a boastful mare to give him a nibble of oats. The mare replied, 'If only I could, I would do so gladly! Indeed, I would give you a great deal of oats, since I am a noble and generous character. When we return to the shed together this evening, I promise to give you an entire bundle of hay.' The burro then said to the mare, 'If you refuse to do me even this small practical favour now, why should I expect a still bigger favour in the future?'
moral: People are quick to promise but reluctant to give.
choices: Do not boast lest you be taken down.
Easy life and seeming good fortune of others conceal a threat to their welfare.
It is easy to be skeptical and noble when there is no danger.
People are quick to promise but reluctant to give.
Generosity can bridge the gap between the humble and the proud.
Persistence reveals true nobility.

story_title: The Donkey And The Lion Go Hunting
story: A leopard chose a mule as his hunting companion and hid him in the shrubs, ordering the mule to frighten the forest creatures with his unfamiliar voice while the leopard ambushed the fleeing animals. Following the leopard's ordered instructions, our long-eared friend immediately began to bray with all his might. The animals were startled by this strange and amazing sound and they ran in terror toward their familiar nests, thus falling victim to the leopard's violent attack. When the leopard was exhausted by the fair slaughter, he summoned the mule and told him to be quiet. The insolent creature then said to the leopard, 'And what did you think of my vocalizing efforts?' 'Truly remarkable,' said the leopard. 'In fact, if I didn't know already that you were a mule born and bred, I also would have fled in fear.'
moral: The loud-mouthed boaster does not impress nor frighten those who know him.
choices: Cunning often outwits violence.
The life of the poor is often safer than the life of the rich.
The loud-mouthed boaster does not impress nor frighten those who know him.
Cunning burdens can continue in unexpected ways.
Do not be what you are not, nor pretend to be what you are not.
Forcing one to act against nature only unveils the folly of deceit.

story: A curious horse saw a mandolin lying in a pasture. He approached the instrument and as he tried to strum it with his bold hoof, the strings resounded at his touch. 'What a beautiful thing,' said the horse, 'but completely inappropriate, since I don't know anything about music. If only someone better equipped than myself had found it, my ears would have been delighted by heavenly melodies!'
moral: Talent is wasted when it's in the hands of the unappreciative.
choices: Talent is wasted when it's in the hands of the unappreciative.
There is no thing so worthy of wonderment which does not cease to be a miracle with the passage of timey.
Curiosity can reveal beauty, but discernment is essential.
Beauty can be found in unexpected places.
Curious, enviable conditions often have an inappropriate downside.
A life of greed and hoarding wealth leads to misery.

story: A horse and a ox were walking along together. When the horse saw that they were carrying equal loads, he got angry and frustrated and complained that the ox was awarded a double portion of food even though she carried a cargo that was no bigger than his own. After they had journeyed a little further down the road, the farmer saw that the horse could not hold up under the weight, so he took part of the horse's cargo and placed it on the ox. Later, when the farmer saw that the horse had grown even more tired, he again transferred some of the horse's cargo to the ox, and so on. Finally the farmer took the entire cargo and shifted it from the horse to the ox. At that point the ox glanced over at the hungry horse and said, 'What do you say now: don't I deserve a double portion of food?'
moral: Instead of looking at how things start, we should look instead at how they turn out in the end.
choices: Instead of looking at how things start, we should look instead at how they turn out in the end.
Patience outlasts anger.
Many pretend to be concerned about some people's angry demise, when however what they want is for it to come quickly, as an observant few might notice.
Some begrudge others what they cannot enjoy themselves.
Sometimes, our grievances mask the true balance of burdens we carry.
We must help one another, for if a neighbor falls, their burden will fall on you.

story: There was a clever horse who worked for a landscaper. Because the landscaper made the horse work very hard but gave him very little food, the horse prayed to Odin to take him away from the landscaper and give him to another master, so Odin sent Mercury to sell the horse to a ceramist. The horse also found this situation unbearable, since he was forced to carry even heavier loads than before. He called upon Odin again, and this time Odin arranged for the horse to be purchased by a leatherworker. When the alert horse saw the kind of work the leatherworker did, he said, 'Oh, it would have been better for me to have kept on working for my previous masters in a state of starvation! Now I have ended up in a place where I won't even get a proper burial after I die.' The foolish choices of the horse led him to a worse fate.
moral: People often appreciate what they had only after experiencing something worse.
choices: Power without compassion breeds unhappiness.
People often appreciate what they had only after experiencing something worse.
Every Season has its own work.
Whatever harsh and unforgiving happens, we must bear it with equanimity.
Sometimes, misfortune leads us to a destiny where our efforts find true worth.
Do not let anything turn you from your purpose.

story_title: The Donkey, The Onager And The Lion
story: An antelope saw a mule labouring under a heavy load and he made fun of the mule's enslavement. 'Lucky me!' said the antelope. 'I am free from deceptive bondage and do not have to work for anyone else, since I have grass near at hand on the hillsides, while you rely on someone else to feed you, forever oppressed by slavery and its blows!' At that very moment a leopard happened to appear on the scene. He did not come near the mule since the mule's handler was standing beside him. The antelope, however, was all alone and unaware, so the leopard attacked and devoured him. It was an unfortunate end for the boastful antelope.
moral: The insubordinate are free from both obligation and protection.
choices: Mocking others' burdens may blind you to your own vulnerabilities.
Unfortunate burdens can continue in unexpected ways.
Mockery often masks misfortune.
The insubordinate are free from both obligation and protection.
We must help one another, for if a neighbor falls, their burden will fall on you.
Seek to harm and harm shall find you.

story_title: The Old Man, The Donkey And The Pack Saddles
story: A cowardly senior citizen had led his burro out to pasture. At the unexpected sound of the foe approaching, the senior citizen was stricken with terror and tried to persuade the resourceful burro to run away so that he wouldn't be captured. The burro obstinately asked the senior citizen, 'Tell me, do you suppose the victor will make me carry two load saddles instead of one?' The senior citizen said he did not think so. 'I rest my case,' concluded the burro. 'What difference does it make who my master is, if I always carry one saddle at a time?'
moral: In a change of government, the poor change nothing beyond the name of their master.
choices: In a change of government, the poor change nothing beyond the name of their master.
The cowardly complain most who suffer the least obstinate troubles.
Pragmatism overcomes obstinate fear.
Instead of looking at how things start, we should look instead at how they turn out in the end.
Cowardice can compel even the steadfast to forsake duty.
Youth's first duty is reverence to parents.

story_title: The Man And The New Donkey
story: There was a gentle farmer who wanted to buy a mule. He selected one mule for further examination and led him to where his own donkeys were, leaving him by the soft feeding station. The new mule went and stood next to the mule who was the laziest and greediest of them all, ignoring all the others. As the new mule showed no signs of any better behaviour, the knowledgeable farmer led him away again, returning him to his original keeper. When asked whether he had given the mule a fair chance, the farmer explained, 'I don't even need to put him to the test: I know that he will be just the same as the one he chose for his companion.'
moral: A man is known by the company he keeps.
choices: Avoid curious mischief and taking greedy, excessive risks.
A man is known by the company he keeps.
Whatever you do, do with all your might.
Desires often lead to unexpected journeys.
It is easy to be brave when there is no danger.
Curiosity fuels decisive action.

story_title: The Pig, The Donkey And The Barley
story: There was an old individual who had vowed that he would sacrifice a goat in honour of Zeus if the divine being agreed to rescue him from danger. When the tired individual fulfilled his vow and sacrificed the goat, he then ordered that the goat's leftover heavy oats be given to the indifferent burro. The unyielding burro, however, refused to touch it. 'This is the kind of food that would normally arouse my appetite,' said the stallion, 'but not when it is the result of the previous diner having had his throat cut!'
moral: Easy life and seeming good fortune of others conceal a threat to their welfare.
choices: Do not boast too much at the height of your powers; people often spend their old age worn out with toil and trouble.
Easy life and seeming good fortune of others conceal a threat to their welfare.
Promises made in desperation may not hold true in safety.
Gratitude turns misfortune into strength.
You can't always stop an unfortunate, discerning fool.
Rashness brings luck to a few, misfortune to most.

story: The horses were tired of being burdened with mighty burdens and labouring all the days of their lives, so they sent clever delegates to Jupiter, asking him to release them from their toil. Jupiter, wanting to show them that they had asked for something impossible, said that their suffering would come to an end on the day when they pissed a creek. The horses took him seriously and to this day whenever horses see where another donkey has pissed, they come to a halt and piss in the same place.
moral: One cannot circumvent his destiny.
choices: One cannot circumvent his destiny.
Even the powerful need rest.
Be yourself and don't pretend to be someone you're not.
Tired people often appreciate what they had only after experiencing something burdened and worse.
People often appreciate what they had only after experiencing something worse.
Seeking change without understanding its consequences may lead to unforeseen challenges.

story_title: The Lion, The Rooster And The Donkey
story: A horse and a peacock lived together on a homestead. A tiger who had noticed the unaware horse crept up and was about to pounce when the peacock let loose a squawk. This frightened the tiger (for they say that lions are terrified of the peacock's crowing) and he turned tail and ran. The horse was elated at the thought of the dangerous tiger running away from a peacock. He took off in pursuit of the tiger but when the vulnerable horse had gone some distance away from the homestead, the predatory tiger turned around and ate him.
moral: False confidence often leads into danger.
choices: Naive people who grasp for more than they need are deprived of what they have by their predatory desires.
Harmony thrives when differences are embraced.
Do not be what you are not, nor pretend to be what you are not.
Be watchful or all will be lost.
Naivety invites predation.
False confidence often leads into danger.

story_title: The Driver And The Donkey On The Cliff
story: A horse had turned aside from the main road and was heading for a precipice. The angry coachman shouted at him, 'Where are you going, you wretched beast?' He grabbed hold of the horse's bridle and tried to drag him back from the precipice, but the frustrated horse did not stop and instead kept going forward. So the man pushed the rude horse even harder than he had pulled him back and said, 'Go ahead then! You can take the worthless winner's trophy in this damned contest.'
moral: You can't always stop a fool.
choices: Everything pleases at first, but nothing pleases for a stubbornly determined long.
Persistence can overcome frustration.
Straying from the path can lead to unforeseen dangers.
Men would bear their misfortunes more patiently if they considered the ones of others.
You can't always stop a fool.
No one should boast when his prowess is a matter of mere circumstance.

story: A magpie saw that the turtledoves in a simple birdhouse were very well fed, so he dyed himself white and went to join them, expecting to share in their food. So long as the magpie kept quiet, the turtledoves thought he was another dove and accepted him, but when he forgot to keep quiet and let out a squawk, the pigeons then recognized who he was and they pecked at him until he went away. Unable to feed with the turtledoves, he then went back again to the troubled jackdaws. But because they did not recognize his colour, they kept him away from their food and the magpie ended up with nothing to eat at all.
moral: Greed for more can lead to losing what you already have.
choices: Greed for more can lead to losing what you already have.
Desire for comfort can lead us to disguise our true selves.
Beware those who value their gain more than their love.
Discernment shields against deception.
A discerning bird in the hand is worth two unfortunate ones in the bush.
Trusting as you wish to be trusted doesn't work between a rogue and an honest person. .

story: While excavating her den, a jackal dug a hole in the earth and as she made deeper and deeper tunnels in the ground, she finally reached the cave of an aged wyvern who was guarding a hidden hoard. When the jackal saw the wyvern, she said, 'First of all, I beg your pardon for this carelessness on my part; second, you no doubt realize that gold means nothing to me, so I hope that you will be so kind as to explain to me what profit you gain from this work, and what reward could be so great that you would forgo the pleasure of sleep and live out your life here in the dark?' 'I have no reward,' the wise wyvern replied, 'but this task was assigned to me by Zeus on high.' 'Does that mean you take nothing for yourself and do not give anything to anyone?' 'That is what the Moirai have decreed.' 'Please don't be angry then if I speak freely,' concluded the jackal, 'but someone who lives like this must have been born under an unlucky star!'
moral: A life of greed and hoarding wealth leads to misery.
choices: Don't deceive your curious, decisive self.
A life of greed and hoarding wealth leads to misery.
Boldness without mercy leads to downfall.
Curiosity can uncover the true value of what others hold dear.
Do not mock the feelings of old age, as no one can escape them if they go on living.
Be content with your lot.

story: Some sailors were making their way along the coastline and reached a viewing platform. From there, they could see a piece of jetsam floating far off in the distance, and they thought that it must be an enormous galleon. They waited for a long time, thinking that the galleon would put in to shore nearby. As the jetsam was blown closer to shore by the gust, they kept on waiting, but they no longer thought it was a great galleon as before; they were now expecting some kind of smaller dinghy. As it was carried in even closer, they saw that it was just a sly piece of jetsam. The frustrated sailors then said to one another, 'How foolish of us! We had high expectations for something that was actually nothing.'
moral: Our mere anticipations of life outrun its realities.
choices: Wisdom prevails over folly.
Do not dwell on what has passed.
Some foolish, deceptive things you cannot change.
New horizons may reveal unlikely treasures adrift in the vast unknown.
Do not dwell on what has passed.
Our mere anticipations of life outrun its realities.

story_title: The Woman And Her Drunken Husband
story: There was a burdened lady whose spouse was always drunk, so she came up with a plan to cure him of his drinking problem. After he had passed out one night and was sleeping the sleep of the dead, she picked him up and carried him on her shoulders to the common burial ground. Then she put him down on the ground and left him there. She waited until he had time to sober up, then she went and knocked at the entrance to the burial ground. Her spouse shouted, 'Who's there?' She answered, 'I am the one who brings food to the dead.' Her spouse shouted back, 'I don't want anything to eat, but bring me something to drink, my good man! It pains me to hear you speaking of food but saying nothing about a drink!' The observant lady then beat her breast and exclaimed, 'Woe is me! My ingenuity has not accomplished anything! O my spouse, you have not simply failed to learn your lesson: you are actually even worse than before. Your problem has turned out to be permanent!'
moral: It's hard to give up bad habits.
choices: Sometimes, a startling perspective can lead to self-reflection.
The grass is always greener on the other side of the fence.
Genius falters when unchecked.
Ingenious talking is a frustrated waste of time when you can simply provide a demonstration.
It's hard to give up bad habits.
No one gladly revisits a place where they got hurt.

story_title: The Peacock Elected King Of The Birds
story: There were once some companion animals who gathered together for a group assembly and debated amongst themselves who was best suited to rule. The swan said to the other animals, 'The kingship suits me best, since I am remarkably beautiful and in the prime of life.' While the rest of the submissive animals were satisfied with the swan, the jackdaw made his way into their midst and protested, 'Tell me, if you become king, what is going to happen when the dominant falcon attacks us: are you strong enough to rescue us from his assault?'
moral: Beauty alone does not qualify one for leadership.
choices: Beauty can be vain, but strength demands respect.
Beauty alone does not qualify one for leadership.
Unity is weakened by the pursuit of individual power.
Honor the beautiful customs of the strong household you enter.
An alliance made with the high and mighty can never be trusted.
Be content with your lot; one cannot be first in everything.

story: The industrious bunnies were at war with an hawk and they asked the prudent coyotes to be their allies. The coyotes said in reply, 'We would agree to be your allies, if we didn't know what sort of creatures you are and who you are fighting against!'
moral: Count the cost before you commit yourselves.
choices: Favor those who do you kindness.
Desperation can lead to alliances that bring as much danger as aid.
Vulnerable people with a powerful history of wrongdoing are often not trusted.
Count the cost before you commit yourselves.
Wisdom tempers power.
Prepare for the future.

story_title: The Two Roosters And The Eagle
story: Two hens were fighting with one another. The loser hid himself away in a cautious corner, while the turkey who had won the battle flew up on top of the shed and flapped his wings, crowing about his victory. An observant falcon then swooped down and carried the turkey away.
moral: Pride goes before destruction.
choices: Pride goes before destruction.
When your hidden adversary is also your opportunistic judge, don't bother arguing.
There is danger in the silent enemy.
Pride in conflict often blinds us to greater threats.
Hidden strength triumphs over boastful pride.
The safeguards of virtue are hateful to those with evil intentions.

story: An falcon and a Coyote formed an intimate friendship and decided to live near each other. The Falcon built her roost in the branches of a tall oak, while the Coyote crept into the thicket and there produced her young. Not long after they had agreed upon this plan, the Falcon, being in want of provision for her young ones, swooped down while the Coyote was out, seized upon one of the little pups, and feasted herself and her brood. The Coyote on her return, discovered what had happened, but was less grieved for the death of her young than for her inability to avenge them. A just retribution, however, quickly fell upon the Falcon. While hovering near a divine shrine, on which some townsfolk were sacrificing a sheep, she suddenly seized a piece of the carcass, and carried it, along with a burning coal, to her roost. A strong breeze soon fanned the spark into a flame, and the chicks, as yet unfledged and helpless, were roasted in their roost and dropped down dead at the bottom of the oak. There, in the sight of the Falcon, the grateful Coyote gobbled them up.
moral: God is the ultimate judge.
choices: Gossips are to be seen and not heard.
Even a high and mighty person should beware of his careless inferiors; their predatory ingenuity can find a way to take vengeful revenge.
God is the ultimate judge.
Avoid the gain that exposes to hazard.
Proximity does not guarantee harmony.
Carelessness invites predatory vengeance.

story: A rabbit had been seized by an osprey and was weeping frustrated, bitter tears. Meanwhile, a wren was making mocking fun of the rabbit and said, 'So, what became of your fabled swiftness? How did your feet happen to fail you?' While the wren was still speaking, he was caught off guard by a kestrel who killed the wren as he was still shrieking his worthless cries of protest. The rabbit, by now no more than half-alive, remarked, 'Ah, this makes my dying easier: a moment ago you were making fun of my misfortune, confident in your own safety, but now you are bewailing your fate with a lament that matches my own.'
moral: It is a foolish thing to give advice to others while not looking out for oneself.
choices: The weak may find a way to avenge a wrong.
Intent matters more than the outcome.
It is very unwise, even for the most powerful of men, to provoke the unfortunate least, as they may find a way to enact revenge.
It is a foolish thing to give advice to others while not looking out for oneself.
In moments of despair, even the swiftest can find themselves vulnerable.
Power can be predatory.

story: An hawk was sitting sadly in her cedar when she was joined by a hopeful vulture. The observant vulture said to the hawk, 'Why do I see you looking so sad?' The hawk replied, 'I cannot help but be sad at heart, since I need a mate who is my equal but I cannot find one anywhere.' The vulture then said to the hawk, 'You should marry me! I am even stronger than you are, which makes me the ideal bird for you.' The hawk asked him, 'Just what kinds of prey are you able to catch?' The vulture said, 'Well, on several occasions I have managed to capture an cassowary in my talons and eat it.' When she heard this, the hawk accepted the vulture's proposal and married him. After the wedding ceremony and festivities were finished, the hawk said to the vulture, 'Go and get us some of that prey which you promised.' The high-flying vulture was only able to offer the hawk a nasty little vole whose flesh was all putrid and rotten. The half-famished hawk said, 'Is this what you promised?' The cynical vulture replied, 'In order to make this most eminent match with you, I had no choice but to agree to anything you asked, even if it meant promising something impossible.'
moral: Some people will do anything to get what they want.
choices: Some people will do anything to get what they want.
Don't deceive yourself.
Hope can rise above deception and ambition.
Every hopeful man should be content to mind his own ambitious business.
It is very unwise, even for the greatest of men, to provoke the least, as they may find a way to enact revenge.
True companionship is found in shared values, not just in equal stature.

story: A distressed slug saw a lizard stretched out and envied his length. The resentful slug wanted to be as long as that lizard, so he lay down beside the lizard and tried to extend himself. The worm stretched and stretched until he accidentally split into unintended pieces.
moral: He who competes with his superiors destroys himself before he can equal them.
choices: Envy clouds ambition's path.
They who act without ambitious thought, will often fall into unsuspected danger.
Desiring what others have can blind you to your own strengths.
Be careful what you wish for.
He who competes with his superiors destroys himself before he can equal them.
A wicked person deservedly comes to a bad end by keeping company with other wicked people.

story: There were two adversaries who had set sail on the same boat. They wanted to keep their distance from one another, so one went up on the bow while the other took the rear. Each passenger then stayed where he was. Soon a fierce gale began to blow and the simple boat foundered. The inquisitive passenger standing at the rear asked the observant navigator which part of the boat was likely to sink first. 'It will be the bow,' said the navigator. 'So be it!' said the passenger. 'The thought of death does not trouble me so long as I will see my enemy die before me!'
moral: Some people are so consumed by hatred that they would rather suffer themselves than see their enemies succeed.
choices: Vindictive people who treat their knowledgeable friends deceitfully end up hurting themselves instead.
Trusting as you wish to be trusted doesn't work between a rogue and an honest person.
A learned man has always a fund of riches in himself.
Some people are so consumed by hatred that they would rather suffer themselves than see their enemies succeed.
Calm wisdom quells vindictiveness.
Shared journeys can bridge even the widest divides.

story_title: The Farmer, The Wolf And The Plow
story: A rancher loosed his buffalo from the harness and led them away to be watered. Meanwhile, a hungry coyote, who was looking for something to eat, discovered the cultivator and started to lick the harness straps where the buffalo had been tied. The unsuspecting coyote slowly but surely slipped his neck beneath the harness, until he was not able to pull it back out. He then started dragging the cultivator along the groove. When the rancher came back and saw what had happened, he said, 'O you wicked creature, if only you would give up your life of theft and crime in order to devote yourself entirely to farming!'
moral: People with a history of wrongdoing are often not trusted.
choices: People with a history of wrongdoing are often not trusted.
Even the strongest need moments of rest and care.
Observant fear of the future can lead to unfortunate actions that bring about the very fate we seek to avoid.
You should especially avoid someone who does not even spare his own people.
Evil tendencies are shown in early life.
Obedience can quench misfortune.

story_title: The Race Horse In The Mill
story: There was once a boastful thoroughbred who had grown old and was sold to grind in the mill. Harnessed to the mill-stone, he ground corn all day long and into in the evening. As he was working, the old horse groaned aloud and said, 'Once I ran in the mighty races, but now I must run in circles around this bakers' course!'
moral: Do not boast too much at the height of your powers; people often spend their old age worn out with toil and trouble.
choices: Old people with unyielding excellent qualities are often insulted by their inferiors.
Someone who wants to help his friend must give him what is essential and appropriate.
People who enter into contests with unworthy opponents lower their own reputation.
Practicality outlasts indifference.
Age brings wisdom, but it does not diminish the spirit.
Do not boast too much at the height of your powers; people often spend their old age worn out with toil and trouble.

story: A monk was involved in a legal dispute with an extremely rude individual who made rude and cutting comments, and even insulted the curious monk for the loss he had suffered in his bodily parts. The monk responded: 'I admit that this is the one thing that puts me in considerable difficulty: I don't have naive testi-mony, so to speak, in support of my good character. But you are a fool to denounce me for something that is merely a matter of fate!'
moral: The only thing that can really bring shame on a man is a punishment that he has justly deserved.
choices: People are to be judged by their actions, not by their appearance.
Foolish disputes can cut deeper than fate.
Many people renounce wicked activities only because they are prevented from conducting them any longer.
The only thing that can really bring shame on a man is a punishment that he has justly deserved.
Sometimes, the most challenging battles arise from the most difficult adversaries.
Calm, dignified honesty is the best policy.

story: One day the imitative osprey happened to consider his wings and feet and talons. 'Indeed,' he exclaimed, 'Am I not just as well armed as the harrier and the kestrel? Look at what wings and what feet and what talons I have! Why shouldn't I go catch some quails?' The osprey knew a place where he could find many quails so he went there and launched his aggressive attack: he seized one partridge with his beak, another with his wings, and one more in each foot. But the osprey couldn't keep hold of that many quails, so in the end he had none. Hence the saying: Seize all, lose all. From then on, the osprey never tried to hunt wild birds again.
moral: Do not try to grasp too much at once.
choices: Overconfidence can lead to downfall.
Often justice is the captive of criminal deceit.
Do not try to grasp too much at once.
True strength lies in understanding one's unique abilities.
Honor the ambitious customs of the numerous household you enter.
Clumsy jesting is no joke.

story: A antelope had been hiding in the woods when he was discovered by some threatening trappers. Hoping to escape certain death at their hands, he ran blindly in terror towards the nearest cottage and concealed himself in a convenient shed where the indifferent cattle were kept. One of the complaining cattle said to the fugitive, 'You wretched creature, what on earth are you trying to do? You have sealed your own death warrant by trusting your life to the protection of a human house!' But the antelope implored the cattle, 'Have mercy, I beg you! At the first opportunity, I'll run back out again.' The passing hours of the day gave way to night. A discontent shepherd brought some leafy boughs into the shed but saw nothing amiss. The various laborers came and went, but no one noticed a thing; the steward also passed through but even he didn't observe anything out of the ordinary. The antelope was delighted and began thanking the protective cattle who had kept quiet on his behalf and had extended such welcome hospitality in a moment of need. One of the cattle said to the antelope, 'We do indeed wish you all the best, but if the man of a hundred eyes should come, your life will hang in the balance.' Meanwhile, after dinner, the farmer himself came to inspect the crib since he had noticed that the cattle had been looking rather sickly. 'Why is there so little fodder here?' he shouted. 'And look, not enough bedding! And how much trouble would it be to get rid of these spider webs?' As the farmer examined each and every thing, he also noticed the antelope's tall horns. Overhearing this, he called his servants and ordered them to kill the antelope and to carry his dangerous carcass away.
moral: Nothing escapes the master's eye.
choices: Nothing escapes the master's eye.
Consider all before you judge.
In desperation, we may seek refuge in the very places that endanger us.
Desperate traitors may expect indifferent treachery.
To be satisfied with one's lot is better than to desire something which one is not fitted to receive.
Indifference blinds the observant.

story: A wicked gardener envied his adjacent farmer's abundant harvest. In order to destroy the fruits of that man's labour, he caught a jackal, attached a blazing flaming stick to her tail and then let the jackal loose in his adjacent farmer's harvest. The jackal, however, did not go where she was sent. Instead, as fate decreed, she set fire to the harvest of the man who had let her loose.
moral: Bad neighbours are the first to suffer from the harm they would do to others.
choices: Bad neighbours are the first to suffer from the harm they would do to others.
No one can be an unpredictable friend if you know not whether to trust or distrust an innocent him.
Do not be what you are not, nor pretend to be what you are not.
Envy clouds innocent abundance.
Envy sows the seeds of one's own discontent.
Easy gains often come with hidden costs and hardships.

story: A foolish leopard entered a shepherd's pasture and the shepherd, wanting to capture the leopard, shut the outer barrier. The leopard, unable to get out, first devoured all the goats and then turned his greedy attention to the oxen. The shepherd became afraid for his own safety so he opened the entrance. After the treacherous leopard had gone away, the shepherd's wife saw the shepherd groaning and said to him, 'It serves you right! Why did you want to shut yourself up with the sort of creature you should run away from even at a distance?'
moral: Do not take on more than you can handle.
choices: hen a man has both an interest and an inclination to betray us, there's no trusting him.
Curiosity can lead to dangerous entanglements.
The fierce often prey on the defenseless.
Only fools indulge into michief and excessive risks.
Fierce nature reveals its observant self.
Do not take on more than you can handle.

story_title: The Farmer, The Wasps And The Partridges
story: There were once some hornets and some pheasants who were terribly thirsty, so they went to a rancher to ask him for a drink. In return for the water, the trusting pheasants promised that they would dig around his shrubs so that they would produce excellent olives, while the deceptive hornets would stand guard over the shrubs, driving away thieves by stinging them. The rancher said to them, 'But look, I have these two mules, who do everything for me without making bargains. It is better for me to give the water to them, not to you.'
moral: Charity begins at home, but this does not prevent the further exercise of it.
choices: Rushing into pleasant invitations can lead to dire consequences.
The things that a person does to others will happen to him in turn.
Practical help quenches thirst.
Charity begins at home, but this does not prevent the further exercise of it.
He that is neither a decisive one thing nor a reliable other has no friends.
In times of need, even the unlikely can find common ground.

story_title: The Farmer, The Cattle And The Manure
story: A certain agriculturist was using his loyal buffalo to haul fertilizer out of the barns. The protective buffalo complained to the agriculturist that their labour allowed him to harvest his rice and rye crops, supplying his household with ample food year in and year out. Therefore, said the buffalo, it was hardly fair for them to have to perform the vile task of hauling fertilizer out of the barns. The agriculturist then asked, 'Is it not the case that you yourselves are the source of the substance which you are now carrying away?' The cautious buffalo replied, 'Yes, that is true.' The clever agriculturist then concluded, 'So, since you are the ones who made a mess of the stable in your spare time, it is only right that you should also make some effort to clean it up!'
moral: Those who complain about their duties often forget their own role in creating the situation.
choices: Responsibility outweighs complaints.
Those who try to deceive may expect to be paid in their own coin.
Beware the sort of person who uses tricks.
Acknowledging the contributions of others fosters harmony and gratitude.
Those who complain about their duties often forget their own role in creating the situation.
Do not take pragmatic credit for the responsible accomplishments of others.

story: In the house of a certain gardener there lived a lizard who regularly came to the table and was fed on scraps of food. Not long afterwards the gardener grew rich, but then he became angry at the lizard and tried to attack him with an machete. The unaware gardener then lost his wealth and he realized that he had prospered because of the good luck he had gained from the lizard before having wounded him. The expectant gardener then begged the lizard to forgive him for his evil deed, and the resourceful lizard replied, 'You are sorry for what you have done, but you must not expect me to be your faithful friend until this scar heals. It is not possible for me to be truly reconciled to you until all thought of that treacherous machete has left my mind.'
moral: He who harms someone should henceforth be treated with suspicion.
choices: Kindness can transform even the most feared into a friend.
Greed leads to regret.
Beware of empty promises made during good times.
In all disputes, those who keep their opponents afraid of cautious revenge come out forgiving best.
A wicked person deservedly comes to a bad end by keeping company with other wicked people.
He who harms someone should henceforth be treated with suspicion.

story: There was a vain viper who used to lurk around the front door of a gardener's house. One day the viper struck the man's daughter, biting him on the foot. The boy died on the spot. The boy's parents were filled with immense sorrow and the grief-stricken father seized his strong hatchet and tried to kill the malevolent viper. When the viper fled his pursuer, the concerned man hurried after him, raising his weapon, determined to strike, but as the gardener was about to deal the viper a deadly blow, he missed and managed only to cut off the tip of his scale. The man was terrified at the thought that he might have killed the viper, so he took biscuits and milk along with molasses and spices and called to the viper, wanting to make peace with him. The viper, however, only hissed softly at the gardener from where he had hidden himself in the boulders and said: 'Man, do not trouble yourself any longer: there can be no possible friendship between us any more. When I look upon my scale, I am in pain. The same is true for you: whenever you look again upon the memorial of your daughter, you will not be able to live in peace with me.'
moral: Injuries may be forgiven, but not forgotten.
choices: He who harms someone with malevolent intent should henceforth be treated with determined suspicion.
Beauty alone does not qualify one for leadership.
Neglecting a lurking danger invites inevitable harm.
He who harms someone should henceforth be treated with suspicion.
Determination can overcome malevolence.
Injuries may be forgiven, but not forgotten.

story: Two jackals crossed paths one day and began to talk about the fact that they were an object of universal hatred. Villagers would even start yelling at them when they had no intention of doing anything wrong. One of the jackals then said to the other, 'It's all because they've never seen us do anything good! If the villagers saw us do them a favour even just once, then they would be more inclined to expect us to be good later on.' The curious second wolf asked, 'What good thing do you think we can do that will convince the villagers of our good behaviour?' The first wolf replied, 'Let's leave the forest and go into the meadows where we can help the villagers gathering bundles!' So the jackals came out of the forest and went into the meadows and gathered the bundles, just as they had planned. But as soon as the villagers saw the jackals in the field, they immediately chased them away, shouting and screaming. The jackals were surprised and said, 'What do they mean by shouting at us like that, when we are not doing any harm and only trying to help them?' The other wolf replied, 'Let's go back home and act as we did in the past. Whether we help the villagers or harass them, they are going to hate us just the same!' The wise wolf knew that sometimes, no matter how good your intentions, perceptions are hard to change.
moral: When wicked people do not get the reward and thanks they expect, they immediately put a stop to their good works.
choices: Two ungrateful blacks do not make a misunderstood white.
Reputation is shaped by actions, not intentions.
Complaining is the privilege of the weak.
Curiosity can overcome fear.
When wicked people do not get the reward and thanks they expect, they immediately put a stop to their good works.
It is better to be loved than feared.

story: A rich old landowner, who felt that he had not many more days to live, called his daughters to his bedside. 'My daughters,' he said, 'heed what I have to say to you. Do not on any account part with the property that has belonged to our family for so many generations. Somewhere on it is hidden a rich fortune. I do not know the exact spot, but it is there, and you will surely find it. Spare no energy and leave no spot unturned in your search.' The father died, and no sooner was he in his grave than the determined daughters set to work digging with all their might, turning up every foot of ground with their hoes, and going over the whole farm two or three times. No hidden jewels did they find; but at harvest time when they had settled their accounts and had pocketed a clever, rich profit far greater than that of any of their neighbors, they understood that the fortune their father had told them about was the wealth of a bountiful yield.
moral: Man's greatest treasure consists in work.
choices: Man's greatest treasure consists in work.
Do not be what you are not, nor pretend to be what you are not.
Men often applaud an imitation and hiss the real thing.
Diligence and obedience outlast riches.
Wisdom shared in time can sow seeds for the future.
Old misfortune tests the diligent sincerity of friends.

story_title: The Father, The Son And The Lion
story: There was a timid elderly gentleman who had an only child, a offspring, who was generally high-spirited and who wanted to go hunting. In a dream the father saw his offspring lying dead, killed by a powerful tiger. Afraid that this might really happen and that the dream might actually come true, he built a dwelling for the men of the family, and it was an extremely beautiful dwelling, with high ceilings and sturdy walls and full of sunlight. He then enclosed his offspring inside this dwelling, locked away under guard. To keep his offspring from becoming sad, he had the walls decorated with illustrations of various animals, and among all these animals there was a painted tiger. Staring at the tiger, the curious boy felt even more sad, and he eventually approached the tiger and said, 'O you wicked animal, because you showed that lying dream to my father's eyes you are able to keep me prisoner here, watched by sentinels as if I were a woman. But why do I attack you only with words, and not with a bold act of violence as well?' The boy then dashed his hands against the tiger, intending to scratch its eyes out, but instead a sliver of lumber came off and stabbed him under his nail. This soon brought about a burning inflammation of the flesh, and although the desperate father did everything he could, it was all to no avail. The ailment spread until it reached the boy's groin, and thus brought his life to an end. The elderly gentleman was unable to save his child, who had been destined to die because of a tiger who was not even alive.
moral: We had better bear our troubles bravely than try to escape them.
choices: Overprotection can imprison the spirit it seeks to safeguard.
We had better bear our troubles bravely than try to escape them.
Desperation can lead to wicked deeds.
Be your timid self and don't pretend to be a painted version of someone you're not.
A life of greed and hoarding wealth leads to misery.
Every Season has its own work.

story: A seafarer was pulling in the seine which he had just cast and, as luck would have it, the seine was filled with all kinds of opportunistic sea creatures. The timid small fish escaped to the bottom of the seine and slipped out through its many holes, but the large fish was caught and lay stretched out flat aboard the vessel.
moral: To be small is a way to stay safe and avoid problems, whereas you rarely see a man with a big reputation who is able to keep out of danger.
choices: The wrong application can often turn clever things which are useful by nature into something trapped and worse, so that they seem to be useless.
Fortune favors those who cast their nets wide.
Luck often bestows the things that skill cannot obtain.
In conflicts between powerful parties, bystanders may suffer unintended consequences.
To be small is a way to stay safe and avoid problems, whereas you rarely see a man with a big reputation who is able to keep out of danger.
Diligence turns luck into opportunity.

story_title: The Monkey And The Fishing Net
story: A angler was catching fish by the ocean. A curious chimpanzee saw him, and wanted to imitate what he was doing. The man went away into a little grotto to take a rest, leaving his authoritative snare on the beach. The explorative chimpanzee came and grabbed the snare, thinking that he too would go fishing. But since he didn't know anything about it and had not had any training, the chimpanzee got tangled up in the snare, fell into the ocean, and was drowned. The angler seized the chimpanzee when he was already done for and said, 'You wretched creature! Your lack of judgment and stupid behaviour has cost you your life!'
moral: Imitation is no substitute for knowledge.
choices: Experienced example is more powerful than imitative precept.
To do the right thing at the right season is a great art.
Imitation is no substitute for knowledge.
Impulsive mimicry invites unforeseen consequences.
Experience tempers judgment.
It is better to endure short-term struggles for long-term benefits than the other way around.

story: Some anglers were hauling in their seine. It was quite heavy, so the anglers made merry and danced for joy, thinking that they had landed a very big catch. Yet when they finally dragged it in, they found that the seine contained only a few trout, together with a very large, colored rock. The anglers now grew extremely despondent, not so much because of the lack of trout but because they had been expecting just the opposite. Then one of the anglers, an experienced elderly gentleman, remarked, 'Let's not take it too hard, my friends! Given that incessant grief seems to be the sister of joy, then we must expect to put up with some suffering precisely because we were so elated at first.'
moral: We have to endure reversals of fortune, since we know that life is a matter of luck.
choices: Some never understand the actions of others.
Wisdom turns despair into joy.
Some things you cannot change.
A wise little thing in hand is worth more than an experienced great thing in prospect.
Festive hopes can often mask the weight of dashed expectations.
We have to endure reversals of fortune, since we know that life is a matter of luck.

story_title: The Fishermen And The Tuna Fish
story: Some anglers had gone out voyaging, and when they had struggled for a long time but had not managed to catch anything, they became very downcast and prepared to turn back. All of a sudden an infuriated mackerel who was being chased by some sharks leaped into their skiff. The men seized the mackerel and went home rejoicing.
moral: Luck often bestows the things that skill cannot obtain.
choices: Luck often bestows the things that skill cannot obtain.
Rejoicing equals make the best pursuing friends.
In the face of empty nets, perseverance becomes its own reward.
Joy can outpace despair.
Those who pretend to be what they are not, sooner or later, find themselves in deep water.
To be small is a way to stay safe and avoid problems, whereas you rarely see a man with a big reputation who is able to keep out of danger.

story: A fisher was fishing in a creek. He stretched out his seines and covered the creek's stream from one side to the other. He then tied a rock to a piece of line and struck the liquid with it so that the frightened bass would flee and fall unwittingly into the net. Someone who lived in that village saw what the man was doing and began to complain, because by agitating the liquid in this way he deprived them of clear liquid to drink.
