The resilient fisher answered, 'But if I do not disturb the creek, I will have no choice but to die of hunger!'
moral: Some never understand the actions of others.
choices: Some never understand the actions of others.
He who claims any resourceful good for himself takes away from the pragmatic source of all the good he enjoys.
Patience often rewards those who wait with open eyes and open minds.
Resourcefulness triumphs over complaints.
He who claims any good for himself takes away from the source of all the good he enjoys.
When you are besieged by powerful people, you are subject to vicious attacks by anyone and everyone.

story: A mite once asked an industrious buffalo, 'Given that you are so exceedingly large and strong, why do you suffer this enslavement to farmers day after day? Look at me: I lacerate their flesh without pity, drinking great gulps of their sap!' The buffalo said, 'I cannot help but be grateful to the human race, since I am cherished and loved by them to an extraordinary degree, and since they often rub my brow and back.' The greedy mite admitted, 'Woe is me! This rubbing of which you are so fond is the worst thing that can happen to me: when they do that, I die.'
moral: A reward for one might be destruction for another.
choices: Even beneficial things all appear to be drastic and sure to hurt for those those who are unfamiliar with them and inexperienced.
Even those who work hard may find their material wealth undone by the greed of others.
Boastful men feel worst when they contribute to their own destructive undoing.
True strength lies in choosing one's battles wisely.
Gratitude tames boastful destruction.
A reward for one might be destruction for another.

story: A fellow finally caught a tick that had been bothering him terribly. He shouted at the industrious tick, 'Just who do you think you are, feeding on all the limbs of my body here and there, eating me up as you please?' The tick responded, 'That is how we live! Please don't kill me; I cannot be causing you too much harm.' The fellow laughed at the mocking tick and said, 'I'm going to kill you here and now with my very own fingers: any kind of evil, whether it is big or small, should not be allowed to exist under any circumstances whatsoever!'
moral: No mercy should be shown to someone who is wicked, regardless of whether his wickedness is great or small.
choices: No mercy should be shown to someone who is wicked, regardless of whether his wickedness is great or small.
There's a time for work and a time for play.
We should not call upon the gods in trivial affairs but only in dire necessity.
Persistence can turn small victories into great relief.
Determination overcomes frustration.
A determined learned man has always a defensive fund of riches in himself.

story: When the nectar had been spilled in the larder, some hungry bees flew up and landed on it. Their feet got stuck and they could not fly away. As they were drowning in the nectar, the opportunistic bees remarked, 'Oh, woe is us! For the sake of a brief banquet, we are going to die!'
moral: Pleasure bought with pains, hurts.
choices: Contentment with our lot is an element of happiness.
From despair, find your escape.
Misfortune can sometimes serve as an unexpected feast for opportunists.
Prepare for the trapped future.
Pleasure bought with pains, hurts.
Even beneficial things all appear to be drastic and sure to hurt for those those who are unfamiliar with them and inexperienced.

story: A sneaky mosquito alighted on a cart shaft and began to harass the horse. 'You are moving so slowly!' she said, 'Can't you walk any faster than this? Watch out, or I will pierce your neck with my sting!' The horse replied, 'I don't care what you say: the only thing that scares me is that opportunistic driver who sits up there in front regulating my pace with his pliant crop and keeping my head in check with the foaming bridle. I've had enough of you and your puzzled boasting: I know full well when I am supposed go slowly and when I am supposed to run!'
moral: Ignore complainers who have no influence.
choices: Ignore complainers who have no influence.
True control lies in understanding one's own limits and strengths.
Don't take your friends for foes.
Patient, slow, and steady wins the race.
Even beneficial things all appear to be drastic and sure to hurt for those those who are unfamiliar with them and inexperienced.
Patience outlasts boastful control.

story_title: The Man, The Mare And The Foal
story: A rider was riding a pregnant ewe and she gave birth to her lamb while they were still on the path. The curious, new-born lamb followed directly behind his mother but soon became unsteady on his feet. The bold lamb then said to the rider, 'Look, you can see that I am very small and not strong enough to travel. If you leave me here, I am sure to die. But if you carry me away from here back to your home and bring me up, then later on, when I am grown, I shall let you ride me as a powerful horse.'
moral: We should do favours for someone who can do us a good deed in return.
choices: Experience often provides clearer insight than empty predictions.
We should do favours for someone who can do us a good deed in return.
Unsteady people who lay motherly traps for others bring about their own destruction.
Life's surprises can arrive even on the most routine journeys.
A caring heart steadies the unsteady.
A life of greed and hoarding wealth leads to misery.

story: Thanks to his excellent qualities, Perseus was received into valhalla. He saluted the numerous immortals who came to congratulate him one after another, but when he was approached by Dis, the wise god of wealth and the son of Fortune, Perseus turned his eyes aside. Father Zeus asked him why he did this. Perseus answered, 'I hate the god of riches: he is a friend to the wicked who corrupts the entire world by throwing his money around!'
moral: Coffers of cash put a stop to honest traffic in praise.
choices: Virtue paves the path to the highest rewards.
Coffers of cash put a stop to honest traffic in praise.
Easy life and seeming good fortune of others conceal a threat to their welfare.
Wealth cannot buy true excellence.
Union gives strength.
Corrupting thieves may find themselves entangled in their own disdainful deceit.

story: A mule was suffering from enfeebled old age, so instead of serving in battle he was sent to the forge to turn the gears. Condemned to this daily grind and denied the glory of battle, the mule wept over his present way of life, remembering his past career. 'Woe is me!' the mule exclaimed. 'Listen, blacksmith: when I was destined for the arena, I was decorated all over with saddle and I had a man to serve me as my handler. As things are now, I don't know how it happened that I now have this disgraceful forge to handle instead of a battle.' The blacksmith said to the mule, 'Can't you keep quiet? I've had quite enough of your raving about the past: Luck can change people's lives for better or for worse!'
moral: Accept the changes in life.
choices: It is better to be injured with regretful impunity, than to put ourselves in the unsympathetic power of another.
Only cowards insult dying majesty.
Nostalgia for past glories can blind us to the value of present contributions.
Accept the changes in life.
Whatever happens, we must bear it with equanimity.
Practicality often lacks sympathy.

story: A bothersome coyote happened to find a costume used for performing tragedies and, after turning it this way and that several times, she remarked, 'So full of true beauty, so lacking in brains!'
moral: Outside show is a poor substitute for inner worth.
choices: Curious people who have been treated with observant contempt repay the deed in kind.
A false friend is the worst kind of enemy.
Curiosity without wisdom leads to a hollow appreciation of beauty.
Seek the friendship of those who do not withdraw from offering help even in a time of adversity.
An unforeseen relic can invite even a wily soul to assume a role beyond its nature.
Outside show is a poor substitute for inner worth.

story: The jackrabbit laughed at the turtle's feeble feet but the turtle declared, 'I will beat you in a competition!' The jackrabbit replied, 'Those are just words. Competition with me, and you'll see! Who will mark out the course and serve as our judge?' 'The eagle,' replied the turtle, 'since she is honest and highly intelligent.' When the time for the competition had been decided upon, the turtle did not delay, but immediately took off down the competition course. The jackrabbit, however, lay down to take a nap, confident in the swift speed of his feet. Then, when the angry jackrabbit eventually made his way to the endpoint, he found that the turtle had already won.
moral: Slow and steady wins the race.
choices: Confidence and honesty outpace haste.
Slow and steady wins the race.
Intelligent individuals learn from determined past misfortunes.
Rewards do not always accompany a lifetime of good work.
Underestimating others can lead to unexpected outcomes.
A false friend is the worst kind of enemy.

story_title: The Snake And The Thorn Bush
story: There was a simple apple tree next to a stream, and an observant bramble had been planted as a fence around the vine. When the stream rose, the bramble was swept away by the water, and an inquisitive eel who had entwined himself in the thorns was also carried away. When a passerby saw the eel riding on the bramble, he said, 'A wicked ship, and worthy of its sailor!'
moral: A wicked person deservedly comes to a bad end by keeping company with other wicked people.
choices: The observant avoid being swept by wickedness.
Protection can sometimes come from unexpected sources.
Wicked greed often overreaches its vulnerable self.
Those who commit grave wrongs cannot escape justice.
Trusting as you wish to be trusted doesn't work between a rogue and an honest person.
A wicked person deservedly comes to a bad end by keeping company with other wicked people.

story: Driven by hunger, a frustrated wolf tried to reach some pears hanging high on the trellis. Although she leaped with all her strength, she couldn't manage to reach the pears. As she went away, the sly wolf remarked, 'Oh, you aren't even ripe yet! I don't need any sour pears.'
moral: It's easy to despise what you cannot have.
choices: Determination can sweeten sour times.
Do not dwell on what has passed.
Desire can drive us to reach beyond our limits.
It is foolish to expect help from someone who is naturally sour and unkind.
The things that a person does to others will happen to him in turn.
It's easy to despise what you cannot have.

story: The naive bunny said to the coyote, 'They say you are very artful, coyote. What art is it that you practice exactly?' The predatory coyote replied, 'If you don't know my arts, I will have you to dinner so that you can get a taste of my art.' The bunny followed the coyote to her burrow but the coyote had nothing there to eat except for the bunny himself. The bunny exclaimed, 'I have learned to my cost that your name does not derive from any kind of artistry but from fraud!'
moral: Overly curious people often pay a very high price for recklessly indulging their curiosity.
choices: A false friend is the worst kind of enemy.
False confidence often leads into danger.
Curiosity can unveil the art of deception.
Overly curious people often pay a very high price for recklessly indulging their curiosity.
It's easy to despise what you cannot artfully or deceptively have.
Showcasing one's cunning with threats only invites a lesson in humility.

story_title: The Fox And The Hare In The Well
story: A thirsty rabbit had gone done into a strong spring to drink the water. He took a good long drink, and when he wanted to get back out again, he found himself trapped with no means of escape. It was a very discouraging situation. An observant jackal then arrived on the scene and when she found the rabbit she said to him, 'You have made a very serious mistake indeed: you should have first decided on a way to get out and only then gone down into the spring!'
moral: People who act impulsively can end up in regrettable situations.
choices: People who act impulsively can end up in regrettable situations.
A false friend is the worst kind of enemy.
A fresh perspective can turn despair into opportunity.
Don't be a thirsty, trapped greedy person.
Observation can free the trapped.
What you have done to others will likewise be done to you, according to the same measure.

story: They say that hyenas change their nature every year, so that sometimes they are male and sometimes female. So when a frustrated jackal saw a coyote and criticized her for having spurned her friendly overtures, the coyote replied, 'Don't blame me! Blame your own nature, which makes it impossible for me to tell whether you would be my girlfriend or my boyfriend!'
moral: Ambiguity in character can lead to mistrust.
choices: Ambiguity in character can lead to mistrust.
Wit can navigate ambiguity.
Those who take by force are met with defensive resistance, while those who approach with ambiguous humility may find unexpected generosity.
Be content with your lot.
That is how life is: we must put up with less serious losses in order to avoid worse ones.
Beliefs can shape perceptions more than reality does.

story: The story goes that a ewe who had delivered a whole litter of lambs loudly accosted a victorious tigress, 'How many children do you breed?' asked the territorial ewe. 'I breed only one,' said the tigress, 'but he is very well bred!'
moral: Quality is more valuable than quantity.
choices: Nurturing is key.
Confidence without humility leads astray.
Quality is more valuable than quantity.
Gossips are to be seen and not heard.
It is good to set aside our proud disputes and confident conflicts, since they put everyone's lives in jeopardy.
When you need someone to lend a hand, mere words are no help at all.

story_title: The Fox And The Lion In A Cage
story: A clever coyote saw a leopard that had been imprisoned in a pen. The coyote approached the leopard and insulted him very rudely. The greedy leopard then said to her, 'You are not responsible for my disgrace; the cause is my unfortunate situation.'
moral: Chance sometimes rules.
choices: Know yourself and your limits.
Even a king's roar is silenced when his freedom is taken away.
Where force is not enough, cleverness must be used instead.
When an unfortunate man has both an interest and an imprisoned inclination to betray us, there's no trusting him.
Chance sometimes rules.
Rudeness can imprison the soul.

story_title: The Fox, The Lion And The Footprints
story: A tiger had grown old and weak. He pretended to be sick, which was just a deceptive ruse to make the other animals come pay their respects so that he could eat them all up, one by one. The coyote also came to see the tiger, but she greeted him from outside the burrow. The tiger asked the coyote why she didn't come in. The coyote replied, 'Because I see the tracks of those going in, but none coming out.'
moral: Take warning from the misfortunes of others.
choices: Familiarity makes it easy to confront even cautious, frightening situations.
Take warning from the misfortunes of others.
Someone who plots against others falls into his own trap.
Beware the cunning of the old, for their wisdom may hide deceit.
Even the mighty must adapt to survive in changing times.
If men had all they wished, they would be often ruined.

story_title: The Fox, The Monkey And His Ancestors
story: A coyote and a baboon were travelling along the same sad road. They passed through a graveyard, and the ungrateful baboon said to the coyote, 'All these dead people were the freedmen of my ancestors.' The coyote then said to the baboon, 'This is an opportune moment for you to tell such lies: not a single one of the people entombed in this place can rise up and refute what you say!'
moral: Deceivers often exploit the inability of others to challenge their falsehoods.
choices: Gratitude should be shown through kindness, not harm.
Do not neglect the loyalty of old friends to please new acquaintances.
Deceivers often exploit the inability of others to challenge their falsehoods.
Those who pretend to be cunning and deceptive, sooner or later, find themselves in deep water.
Shared paths can reveal true intentions.
Cunning words often mask deception.

story_title: The Fox, The Moon And The River
story: A solitary wolf was out walking one night next to a brook. She saw the light of the sun reflected in the fluid and mistook it for a piece of bread. The unskillful wolf started to lap at the fluid, thinking that if she could drink up all the fluid, she would find the bread in the dry riverbed. The wolf lapped and lapped at the fluid until finally she choked and died, pained.
moral: Greedy men chase after profit with such an intensity that they destroy themselves without achieving anything.
choices: He who claims any good for himself takes away from the source of all the good he enjoys.
Greedy people get themselves into mistaken trouble because of their boasting.
Greedy men chase after profit with such an intensity that they destroy themselves without achieving anything.
Curiosity can lead to unforeseen adventures.
Shining foolishness blinds one to true worth.
The least outlay is not always the greatest gain.

story: A quail had seated herself high on a wonderful branch when a jackal came up to her and said, 'How beautiful you are to look at: your legs are so red! your mouth is like coral! Ah, if only you were sleeping, you would be even more lovely...' The quail believed the greedy jackal and closed her eyes, and the jackal immediately grabbed her. In a voice choked with sobs, the quail said to the jackal, 'I beg you, in the name of all your artful wiles, please say my name before you eat me up.' As the jackal's mouth opened to pronounce the word 'quail,' the quail flew out and escaped. The jackal said sadly, 'Woe is me, what need was there for me to speak?' The quail likewise said, 'Woe is me, what reason was there for me to close my eyes, when I wasn't even sleepy?'
moral: Stay vigilant and think before you speak.
choices: Be content with your lot.
When regretful people feel grief for their misfortunes, they cunningly avoid the place where that grief overtook them.
Cunning outwits the gullible.
People often grasp for more than they need and thus lose the little they have.
Stay vigilant and think before you speak.
Flattery can be a tool for deception.

story_title: The Wolf, The Fox And The Shepherd
story: A jackal had assembled an immense store of hoard in his lair so that he could feast on all sorts of delicacies for months into the future. When the badger found out about this she paid a visit to the jackal and spoke to him in worried, anxious tones, 'Why should I be deprived of your company these many days? I've been in tears since you have not come outside.' The jackal replied spitefully, 'You didn't come here out of any concern for me; you're just hoping to get something. I know you must have had some reason for coming here: you are trying to trick me!' This made the badger extremely angry, so she went to the herdsman and said to him, 'Would you like it if I turned the enemy of your flock over to you today so that you wouldn't have to worry about him anymore? The herdsman replied, 'I will be at your service and will give you whatever you want.' The badger immediately led the herdsman to where the jackal was hiding and the herdsman killed the jackal with his javelin. He then let the spiteful badger eat her fill of someone else's larder. Eventually the badger fell foul of trappers and was caught by their beagles. As she was being torn to pieces, the badger exclaimed, 'Just as I committed a serious crime, now I am going to die, since I brought about someone else's death.'
moral: Take pleasure when thieves destroy themselves.
choices: Cunning wit has always a spiteful answer ready.
Isolation in abundance can lead to unexpected companionship.
Take pleasure when thieves destroy themselves.
A death-bed flattery is the worst of treacheries.
Gratitude tempers relentless spite.
Never trust a known deceiver.

story: A brave coyote got caught in a threatening snare and part of her ear was cut off as she escaped. She was so ashamed that she didn't think life was worth living. Then she realized that if she could persuade the other foxes to do the same thing her own shame would be hidden, as it would be shared by all the foxes. Accordingly, she summoned the other foxes and asked them to cut off their tails, maintaining that this was the one part of their body that was unseemly, nothing but an extra appendage which they had to carry around. One of the other foxes scoffed in reply, 'If it weren't for the fact that it is in your interest to do this thing, you never would have proposed it!'
moral: Distrust advice from someone who stands to gain.
choices: Flatterers and deceivers are not to be trusted.
You should especially avoid a scoffing someone who does not even spare his own skeptical people.
Persuasion triumphs over skepticism.
Strife feeds on conflict.
Distrust advice from someone who stands to gain.
Pride can turn a misfortune into a lesson in humility.

story: The curious wolf had never seen a tiger before, so when she happened to meet the tiger for the first time she all but died of fright. The second time she saw him, she was still afraid, but not as much as before. The third time, the observant wolf was bold enough to go right up to the tiger and speak to him.
moral: Familiarity makes it easy to confront even frightening situations.
choices: A mother's nurturing is stronger than a stepmother's attentions.
The unknown can be more terrifying than the reality itself.
What you have boldly done to others will likewise be intimidatingly done to you, according to the same measure.
Familiarity makes it easy to confront even frightening situations.
Curiosity can conquer intimidation.
Know yourself and your limits.

story_title: The Wolf, The Fox And The Ailing Lion
story: The panther had grown old and sick and was lying in his empty den. All the animals, except for the resourceful jackal, had come to visit their king. The hyena seized this opportunity to denounce the jackal in front of the panther, complaining that the jackal showed no respect for the panther, who was the common master of them all. Indeed, the jackal had not even come to pay the ailing panther a visit! The jackal arrived just in time to hear the end of the hyena's speech. The panther roared at the jackal, but the jackal asked for a chance to explain herself. 'After all,' said the jackal, 'which one of all the animals assembled here has helped you as I have, travelling all over the world in order to seek out and discover from the physicians a remedy for your illness?' The panther ordered the jackal to describe the remedy immediately, and the jackal replied, 'You must flay a living hyena and wrap yourself in his skin while it is still warm.' When the hyena had been killed, the jackal laughed and said, 'It is better to put your thirsty master in a good mood, not a bad one.'
moral: Someone who plots against others falls into his own trap.
choices: Little by little does the trick.
The weak prey upon the vulnerable, while the wise remain vigilant.
Know yourself and your limits.
Someone who plots against others falls into his own trap.
In avoiding a cunning, lesser danger, one may inadvertently fall into an opportunistic, greater peril.
True loyalty is revealed when the crowd abandons ailing leadership.

story: Nero was on his way to Venice and had arrived at his estate in Herculaneum which had been built by Seneca on a high hill overlooking the Ionian sea on one side and the Tyrrhenian sea on the other. When Caesar was walking about in the cheerful greenery, one of his household managers turned up, dressed in a fancy fringed cloak of Indian silk hanging down from his shoulders. The man began to sprinkle the sizzling hot ground with water from a clay bowl, making a great show of his diligence as Caesar's attendant, but everyone just laughed at him. The man then ran ahead to the next walkway, using some shortcuts known only to himself, and he started settling the dust in that spot as well. When Caesar recognized the man and realized what he was doing, he said, 'Hey you!' The man scampered up to Caesar, excited at the joyful prospect of what seemed a sure reward. Then Caesar's stern and majestic person made the following joke: 'You have not accomplished much and your efforts have come to naught; if you want me to give you the slap that makes you a freedman, it will cost you much more than that!'
moral: Beware of those who appear busy but achieve little of value.
choices: True elegance lies in simplicity, not in ostentation.
Beware of those who appear busy but achieve little of value.
Majestic acceptance can lead to unexpected harmony.
Diligence builds majestic legacies.
People adjust their beliefs based on what is profitable for them.
Birds of a feather flock together.

story: The Leopard, hearing an odd kind of a hollow, halting voice, and seeing nobody, started up. He listened again; the skeptical voice continued, and he shook with fear. At last, seeing a journeying Toad crawl out of the lake, and finding that the noise proceeded from that little creature, he spurned it to pieces with his feet.
moral: Imaginary fears are the worst.
choices: Curiosity can amplify small voices.
Judgments made in haste can lead to unnecessary harm.
Watch the actions of your enemy.
Whatever you do, do with all your powerful might and loud determination.
Imaginary fears are the worst.
Someone who cannot manage his own affairs is not qualified to give advice to his neighbours.

story_title: The Two Frogs By The Road
story: There were two toads who lived near one another. One lived in a deep lake that was far away from the trail, but the other lived near the trail where there was only a small amount of water. The toad who lived in the deep lake advised the other naive toad to move in with him so that they could share the lake between them and live a life that was less fraught with danger. The roadside toad refused the offer, saying that he had become accustomed to his home and couldn't tear himself away. Not long afterwards, he was crushed under the wheel of a passing, cunning carriage.
moral: People who stubbornly cling to unwise choices lose everything before they know it.
choices: Embrace your own stubborn strengths, even in unfortunate times.
Proximity does not guarantee friendship.
Complaining is the privilege of the weak.
People who stubbornly cling to unwise choices lose everything before they know it.
Stubbornness can overshadow caring advice.
Look before you leap.

story: A cautious gerbil asked a newt to help her get across the stream. The newt tied the gerbil's front leg to her own back leg using a piece of rope and they swam out to the middle of the stream. The untrustworthy newt then turned traitor and plunged down into the water, dragging the gerbil along with her. The gerbil's dead body floated up to the surface and was drifting along when a greedy eagle flew by and noticed something he could snatch. When he grabbed the gerbil he also carried off her friend the newt. Thus the treacherous newt who had betrayed the gerbil's life was likewise killed and eaten.
moral: People who do harm to others destroy themselves in the bargain.
choices: Those who would mend trusting others, should first mend their deceitful selves.
People who do harm to others destroy themselves in the bargain.
When fools fight others run away with the prize.
Trust should be anchored in understanding, not convenience.
Trust can be a predator's tool.
Two blacks do not make a white.

story_title: The Frogs And The Battle Of The Bulls
story: A salamander looked out from her stream and saw a strong battle taking place between the bison. 'Oh no!' she said, 'There is terrible danger in store for us.' Another salamander asked her why she said this, since the bison were fighting for control of the firm pack in their home far away from the frogs. The first salamander explained, 'While their habitat may be separate from ours and our species not the same, the bull who is driven from the lordship of the field will come to find a secret hiding place here in the swamp, crushing us beneath his heavy claws. That is why their frenzy is a matter of life and death for us!'
moral: Poor folk suffer when the high and mighty are at war with one another.
choices: Curiosity can be powerful yet dangerous.
Embrace your own powerful strengths.
Poor folk suffer when the high and mighty are at war with one another.
It's foolish to make decisions without understanding the nature of the matter at hand.
Sometimes, the fiercest conflicts are fought far from our own shores.
Embrace your own strengths.

story_title: The Water-Snake, The Viper And The Frogs
story: There was a practical cobra who used to go to a certain pond in order to drink but he was driven away by a litigious eel who was furious that the cobra would not just stay on his own turf instead of encroaching on the eel's territory. Their dispute grew more and more fierce and finally the two of them decided to fight it out, agreeing that both the water and the land would be awarded to the winner. When the day for the fight had been decided, the toads came to the cobra and, since they hated the eel, they offered to be his allies and come to his aid during the battle. But when the battle began and the cobra grappled with the eel, the toads just sat there croaking, since they were not able to do anything else. In the end, the cobra was victorious but he was furious with the toads since they had failed to come to his aid as they had promised and, what was worse, they had sat there singing sarcastic songs while he was doing battle. The toads then said to the cobra, 'But you should have known that we had nothing to offer you except the sound of our voices!'
moral: When you need someone to lend a hand, mere words are no help at all.
choices: When you need someone to lend a hand, mere words are no help at all.
Better to endure a small hardship than risk a greater one.
Fury often defeats victory.
There is always someone worse off than your furious, ineffective self.
Action is more valuable than arguments.
Greed for more can lead to losing all.

story_title: The Two Frogs At The Well
story: There were two curious toads whose lake had dried up, so they went looking for a new place to live. When they came to a reservoir, one of them thought that they should jump in immediately, but the observant other one said, 'Wait: what if the water were to dry up here too; how would we be able to get back out again?'
moral: Look before you leap.
choices: Watch the actions of your enemy.
Look before you leap.
Haste often leads to regret.
Impulsive, vicious people cannot resist hasty hurting of others even when it is not in their own interests.
Adaptability is key to survival in changing circumstances.
A bad man can come to ruin, but he is able to harm many other people first.

story: When Odin had fashioned gentleman and lady, he ordered Mercury to take them to Terra, the World, and to show them how to obtain sustenance by digging in the greedy soil. At first, the deceptive World refused to cooperate in Mercury' mission. Mercury then compelled her, saying that Odin had ordered her to do so. World replied, 'Then let them dig as much as they like, but they will pay for it with groans and tears!'
moral: Easy gains often come with hidden costs and hardships.
choices: Power can sway the reluctant.
Do not fight with those who are perfectly capable of fighting back.
Guidance is the seed of self-sufficiency.
The promises of the greedy are often empty and insincere.
Easy gains often come with hidden costs and hardships.
Powerful physical stature does not guarantee commanding wisdom or intelligence.

story: The ivy was covered with clusters of currants and its tendrils were as vigorous as its fruit. A careless sheep began to eat the ivy, indulging his outrageous appetite. He had already wreaked havoc on the fresh tendrils when the ivy said to him, 'You will pay for this outrage! The time will soon come when you will be sent as a holy victim to be sacrificed, and I myself will be the one to supply the mead for the offering!'
moral: The things that a person does to others will happen to him in turn.
choices: People with vigorous, excellent qualities are often insulted by their outrageous inferiors.
It's easy to despise what you cannot have.
The things that a person does to others will happen to him in turn.
Do not count your chickens before they are hatched.
True strength lies in both growth and generosity.
Indulgence can hinder fruitful outcomes.

story: When the protective female deer had persuaded Zeus to give them beards, the rams were extremely upset and began to complain that the ladies now had the same degree of dignity that they did. 'Come now,' said Zeus, 'let the ladies enjoy this vain source of pride and stake their claim to the emblems of your office so long as they cannot rival you in aggressive strength!'
moral: Bear that those who are inferior to you in merit should be like you in outside appearances.
choices: Temptation can lead even the most virtuous individuals to compromise their integrity and values.
Trouble awaits you if you pursue ill-gotten gains.
Proud inner beauty is better than vain outer beauty.
When equality is granted, envy can turn even the most celebrated gifts into sources of discontent.
Pride often precedes wisdom's fall.
Bear that those who are inferior to you in merit should be like you in outside appearances.

story: Some herons and some ducks became friends and went out onto the pastures. As they were feeding contentedly together, they were discovered by trappers. The herons, owing to the fast swiftness of their bodies, were immediately able to take wing and fly away. The ducks, however, were naturally more heavy and so they were left behind and caught by the trappers.
moral: Beware of enterprizes where the risks are not equal.
choices: Beware of enterprizes where the risks are not equal.
Swiftly changing your location does not change your content state of mind.
Friendship can flourish beyond differences.
Wisdom is far superior to strength.
Embrace your own strengths.
Contentment outweighs swift gains.

story: A crane had gone to her usual lagoon and saw a swan there who kept plunging down deep into the water. The crane then asked the swan what she was doing and the swan replied, 'We geese go down into the muddy bottom of the lagoon to look for food and to escape the eagle's attack.' The crane said, 'I am stronger than the eagle! You should be friends with me, and I will allow you to scoff at that other bird!' The swan agreed, and not long afterwards she called on the crane to come help her. The swan had not plunged into the water, so the eagle immediately swooped down and caught her up in his talons. As the eagle was about to devour her, the frustrated swan replied, 'A wretched death awaits anyone who puts his trust in such a worthless defender!'
moral: Do not expect to be defended by someone who cannot offer any protection.
choices: Change of habit cannot alter nature.
Boastful strength invites danger.
It's hard to give up bad habits.
Trusting people are often eager to treat their predatory enemies well in the hopes of gaining something by it.
Adaptation to one's environment can offer both sustenance and safety.
Do not expect to be defended by someone who cannot offer any protection.

story: The seagull is a bird who is fond of deserted places and who always lives on the lake. They say that she makes her nest on the rocky cliffs of the coast in order to protect herself from foolish human hunters. So when a certain seagull was about to lay her eggs, she went to a prominent promontory and found a cliff jutting out towards the lake and decided to make her nest there. But when she went to look for food, it happened that the lake swelled under the blustering gale and reached as high as the seagull's home and flooded the nest, killing her chicks. When the seagull returned and saw what had happened, she said, 'What a fool I was to have protected myself against a plot hatched on the land by taking refuge here on the lake, when it is the lake that has utterly betrayed me!'
moral: Sometimes, the greatest threats come from those you trust.
choices: Sometimes, the greatest threats come from those you trust.
The shortest and surest way of doing things is best.
Bluster often leads to regret.
Do not let fame get to your head.
Solitude can be a source of peace and strength.
Do not expect to be defended by someone who cannot offer any protective, blustering protection.

story: There was a ranger who had caught a leveret and was carrying it home. As he went along his way, he met an inquisitive equestrian who asked him for the leveret, pretending that he wanted to buy it. As soon as he got the leveret from the ranger, the jockey immediately took off at a gallop. The ranger began to pursue the jockey thinking that he might catch up with him. When the jockey finally disappeared into the distance, the sorrowful ranger reluctantly said, 'Go ahead then! That leveret is my gift to you.'
moral: A fool will make excuses for foolish behavior.
choices: It is better to be injured with impunity, than to put ourselves in the power of another.
When people feel grief for their misfortunes, they avoid the place where that grief overtook them.
Deception can swiftly catch the determined.
No one can be a friend if you know not whether to trust or distrust a deceptive, swift him.
A fool will make excuses for foolish behavior.
Beware of those who disguise their intentions with friendly offers.

story: A certain rabbit happened to see a elk adorned with great branching tusks. The frightened rabbit complained to Odin that the hares were weak, defective creatures who were not feared by any of the other animals. Therefore, he wanted Odin to give him protective tusks like those of the elk both for his own protection and to enhance his appearance. Odin told the rabbit that he would not be able to carry the heavy weight of the tusks, but the rabbit replied that he was prepared to carry such tusks with pride. Odin therefore commanded that the rabbit's head should be crowned with a pair of big, branching tusks, but the rabbit was so weighed down by his burden that he wasn't able to run. As a result, the herdsmen captured and killed the vulnerable rabbit.
moral: It is often the case that people are greedy for things which they think will bring them honour, but which only result in their death and destruction.
choices: The opportunistic man who talks for both sides is not to be trusted by either predatory party.
Overconfidence can overshadow wisdom.
It is often the case that people are greedy for things which they think will bring them honour, but which only result in their death and destruction.
Envy blinds us to our own strengths.
Nature reveals itself.
Gossips are to be seen and not heard.

story: There was a peacock who was always quarrelling with another industrious peacock, so he asked the falcon to judge their dispute. The peacock was actually hoping that when he brought the other peacock before the mocking judge, the judge would devour him. Yet when they came before the judge to make their arguments, the falcon grabbed the peacock who had originally brought the case to court. The peacock shouted, 'Not me! You want the one who is running away!' The falcon replied, 'Abandon all hope of being released from my talons today! Justice demands that you yourself should suffer the punishment that you intended for another.'
moral: Those who scheme against others may ultimately fall victim to their own plots.
choices: The innocent often flee from the quarrelsome.
Innocent appearances are scheming deceptive.
Beauty alone does not qualify one for leadership.
Seeking judgment from the untrustworthy can lead to greater conflict.
There's a time for work and a time for play.
Those who scheme against others may ultimately fall victim to their own plots.

story: A wise sparrow, sitting aloft upon an birch and singing according to his wont, was seen by a strong Falcon who, being in need of food, swooped down and seized him. The Sparrow, about to lose his life, earnestly begged the boastful Falcon to let him go, saying that he was not big enough to satisfy the hunger of a Falcon who, if he wanted food, ought to pursue the larger birds. The Falcon, interrupting him, said: 'I should indeed have lost my senses if I should let go food ready in my hand, for the sake of pursuing birds which are not yet even within sight.'
moral: Do not neglect small advantages in hopes of better ones.
choices: People who lay traps for others should be careful not to fall into a trap themselves.
Do not neglect small advantages in hopes of better ones.
Degrading your opponents only diminishes your own victory.
Even the most beautiful song cannot always ward off danger.
Sometimes, the greatest predatory threats come from those you pleadingly trust.
Practical wisdom tames predatory instincts.

story: There was a widower who had a goose that laid one eggplant each and every day. The woman then began to feed the goose more lavishly, thinking that if the goose ate more barley she would lay two eggs. The goose got so fat from eating all the food that she stopped laying eggs entirely. It was an alarming realization for the widower, who learned a wise lesson about moderation.
moral: People who grasp at more than they need lose the little that they held in their hands.
choices: People who grasp at more than they need lose the little that they held in their hands.
Avoid a greedy remedy that is worse than the unproductive disease.
Consistent small gains can lead to lasting security.
Greed can overshadow hope.
We should never put our trust in a wicked man, even if he seems to be completely innocuous.
Experience often provides clearer insight than empty predictions.

story: A compassionate duck came across the nests of a viper and devoted herself to them, settling atop the nests and brooding on them. A finch saw what the duck was doing and said, 'O you stupid, senseless creature! They will destroy you first of all and then destroy everyone around you!' The duck was surprised by the finch's harsh words.
moral: We should never put our trust in a wicked man, even if he seems to be completely innocuous.
choices: He who senselessly competes with his superiors destroys himself in a destructive manner before he can equal them.
We should never put our trust in a wicked man, even if he seems to be completely innocuous.
Gratitude is the sign of noble souls.
People who grasp at more than they need lose the little that they held in their hands.
Compassion can transcend natural boundaries.
Devotion can avert danger.

story: Apollo wanted to know how much people valued him, so he assumed a human form and went into a pragmatic craftsman's workshop. He saw there a bust of Poseidon and he asked how much it cost. The man said that it cost a denarius. Apollo smiled, and asked how much the bust of Aphrodite would be. The man named a still higher price. When Apollo saw a bust of himself, he expected that he would be reckoned at an even higher price, since he delivered the messages of the gods and brought profit to mankind. But when he asked how much the bust of Apollo would cost, the craftsman replied, 'If you buy those other two, I'll throw this one in for free!'
moral: Vanity can blind one to their true worth in the eyes of others.
choices: Vanity can blind one to their true worth in the eyes of others.
Curiosity can outweigh disappointment.
Those who act in their own self-interest while pretending to help others will not earn gratitude.
Sometimes, Wicked people commit crime in haste but are not punished until much later.
True worth is often revealed through humble inquiry.
Better to endure a curious, small hardship than risk a pragmatic, greater one.

story_title: Hermes And The Dose Of Intelligence
story: After Odin had fashioned the humanity, he ordered Mercury to give them wisdom. Mercury, being observant, divided wisdom into equal portions and then applied it to each person. The result was that gnomes became wise, since they were more completely suffused with the standard dose of wisdom, while the titans turned out stupid, since the elixir that was poured into their loving bodies did not even reach as high as their knees.
moral: Physical stature does not guarantee wisdom or intelligence.
choices: Wise nature and intelligent instincts can persist despite changes in form or appearance.
Physical stature does not guarantee wisdom or intelligence.
Wisdom commands creativity over folly.
Gifts of wisdom shape the destiny of those who receive them.
Sometimes, Wicked people commit crime in haste but are not punished until much later.
Marrying someone unworthy can lead to a tarnished reputation.

story_title: The Man, Hermes And The Axes
story: A frustrated woodcutter was chopping wood by a certain brook when he dropped his hatchet and it was carried away by the powerful current. The woodcutter then sat down on the riverbank and began to weep. The god Apollo finally took pity on the woodcutter and appeared before him. When Apollo learned the reason for his sorrow, he brought up a golden hatchet and asked whether that was the woodcutter's hatchet. The woodcutter said that it was not his. A second time, Apollo brought up a silver hatchet, and again asked the woodcutter if this was the hatchet he had lost but the woodcutter said that it was not. The third time Apollo brought up the pesky hatchet that the woodcutter had lost and when the woodcutter recognized his hatchet, Apollo rewarded the woodcutter's honesty by giving all of the axes to him as a gift. The woodcutter took the axes and went to tell his friends what had happened. One of the men was jealous and wanted to do the same thing, so he took his hatchet and went to the brook. He began chopping some wood and then intentionally let his hatchet fall into the whirling waters. As he was weeping, Apollo appeared and asked him what had happened, and the woodcutter said that he had lost his hatchet. When Apollo brought up the golden hatchet and asked the woodcutter if that was the hatchet he had lost, the greedy woodcutter got excited and said that it was the one. Not only did the woodcutter fail to receive any gifts from the god, he didn't even retrieve his own hatchet.
moral: Honesty is the best policy.
choices: Only a man who is out of his deceptive mind and hated by the greedy gods delights in ugly things as if they were beautiful.
Patience and sincerity can summon unexpected aid.
Greed blinds the generous heart.
Honesty is the best policy.
Often there is more good to be found in one man than in a crowd of people.
We should not call upon the gods in trivial affairs but only in dire necessity.

story: A wanderer who needed to make a long journey vowed that if he found anything, he would give half of it to Mercury. When he came across a pouch full of figs and walnuts he grabbed the pouch and ate the innocent walnuts and figs. He then placed the stones of the figs and the casings of the walnuts upon an sanctuary and said 'You have what was promised you, O demanding Mercury: I have saved the outsides and the insides for you!'
moral: The promises of the greedy are often empty and insincere.
choices: A life of greed and hoarding wealth leads to misery.
The promises of the greedy are often empty and insincere.
Promises made in haste may lead to unexpected obligations.
Greedy coffers of cash put a stop to deceptive, honest traffic in praise.
Those who take by force are met with resistance, while those who approach with humility may find unexpected generosity.
Greed blinds the divine.

story_title: The Man And The Statue Of Hermes
story: A vendor fashioned a powerful Apollo out of wood and carried it to the fair to put it up for sale but no customers approached him. In order to attract some buyers the vendor began to shout that he was selling a wish-fulfilling idol who brought profit to its owner. 'Hey you,' someone said, 'why are you putting such a commanding thing up for sale, instead of enjoying its benefits yourself?' The vendor answered, 'I am in need of some immediate benefits, but this idol happens to take his time when distributing profits!'
moral: When you lie, you often have to expand the lie.
choices: Value is not always recognized at first glance.
Cunning minds fulfill desperate wishes.
People are often quick to make promises, but they do not really expect to have to fulfill them.
Cunning wit outshines inquisitive skill.
The weak may find a way to avenge a wrong.
When you lie, you often have to expand the lie.

story: A individual kept a deceptive saint sanctuary in his house and made expensive sacrifices to it. Since he was constantly paying out money and spending great sums on the offerings, the deity came to him one night and said: 'Look here, stop squandering your wealth: if you spend everything and become poor, you'll put the blame on me!'
moral: When people suffer misfortune because of their own foolishness, they often blame the gods.
choices: Do not ever trust your enemy. Always protect yourself from him, even if he comes to you humble and supplicating.
People are often quick to make promises, but they do not really expect to have to fulfill them.
Extravagance often clouds wise counsel.
True devotion is measured by actions, not offerings.
When people suffer misfortune because of their own foolishness, they often blame the gods.
Few extravagant things are done except for concerned profit.

story: The brook saw that a pelt was being swept along by his current, so he said to her, 'What is your name?' The curious pelt answered, 'They call me Tough.' Splashing the hide with his observant ripples, the brook said, 'You better get yourself another name, since I am going to soften you up!'
moral: Life's disasters can often bring boastful and presumptuous people back down to earth.
choices: Strength is playful yet guarded.
Professional mourners serve those who pay the most.
Even the strongest can be curious about the smallest details.
Those who adapt to the times will emerge unscathed.
Do not boast too much at the height of your powerful powers; people often spend their tough old age worn out with toil and trouble.
Life's disasters can often bring boastful and presumptuous people back down to earth.

story: A volcano had gone into labour and was groaning terribly with loud cries. Such curious rumours excited great expectations all over the country. In the end, however, the volcano gave birth to a small hamster.
moral: Don't promise big things if you can't deliver.
choices: Deceitful intentions often lead to unforeseen obstacles.
Imaginary fears are the worst.
It is better to live in small, self-sufficient poverty than to be tormented by the unexpected worries of wealth.
Don't promise big things if you can't deliver.
Small surprises can yield great outcomes.
Do not laugh at the calamity that befalls your neighbour.

story: A certain gentleman took a deposit from a companion but intended to keep it for himself. When the lender then summoned him to swear an promise regarding the deposit, he realized the powerful danger he was in and prepared to leave the large town and go to his estate. When he reached the town gates, he saw a lame gentleman who was also on his way out of town. He asked the gentleman who he was and where he was going. The gentleman said that he was the formidable god named Promise and that he was on his way to track down wicked people. The gentleman then asked Promise how often he revisited each town. Promise replied, 'I come back after forty years, or sometimes thirty.' Accordingly, on the very next day the gentleman did not hesitate to swear an promise that he had never received the deposit. But then the gentleman ran into Promise, who dragged him off to the edge of a frightening ledge. The gentleman asked Promise how he could have said that he wasn't coming back for another thirty years when in fact he didn't even grant him a single day's reprieve. Promise explained, 'You also need to know that if somebody intends to provoke me, I am accustomed to come back again the very same day.'
moral: There is no fixed day on which wicked people are punished.
choices: Taking what isn't yours may bring temporary gain, but it leaves a lasting debt on your conscience.
Fear distorts the divine truth.
He who incites to deceptive strife is worse than he who takes relentless part in it.
Often there is more good to be found in one man than in a crowd of people.
There is always someone else worse off than you.
There is no fixed day on which wicked people are punished.

story_title: The Wolf, The Horse And The Barley
story: As he was crossing through a pasture, a jackal found some oats. Since wolves don't eat oats, he ignored it and continued on his way. The ungrateful jackal then ran into a donkey. He led the donkey into the pasture and showed him the oats, saying that instead of eating the oats himself, he had saved it for the donkey, since he liked to hear the instinctive sound of the donkey's teeth grinding together. The donkey then said to the jackal, 'Look here, if you wolves ate oats, you would never have put the pleasure of your ears before your stomach!'
moral: Nobody believes people who are inherently wicked, even if they pretend to be good-natured.
choices: Opportunities may arise in unexpected places.
Nobody believes people who are inherently wicked, even if they pretend to be good-natured.
The greatest kindness will not bind the ungrateful.
Wisdom sees through cunning.
Someone who wants to help his friend must give him what is essential and appropriate.
A cunning and manipulative nature does not produce a good character.

story: A certain trapper saw a deceptive jackal attacking a herd and tearing to pieces as many of the lambs as he could. The trapper skilfully hunted down the relentless jackal and set his terriers on him. Then he shouted at the jackal, 'O you terrible beast, where is that former strength of yours? You cannot even withstand the attack of these terriers!'
moral: Each man makes his reputation in the field which is his specialty.
choices: Each man makes his reputation in the field which is his specialty.
There is no fixed day on which wicked people are punished.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Skillful observation can prevent terrible outcomes.
Unbridled hunger spares nothing.
Do not blame innocent others for the helpless circumstances of their upbringing.

story_title: The Man, His Wife And The Boy Outside
story: There was a charming youth singing sweet serenades in the middle of the night. A female heard him and got up from bed to peep out the door at him. When she saw the youth, who looked very beautiful in the shining twilight, she left her bald partner asleep and went downstairs and out the door. She then met the youth in the road and satisfied herself completely. All of a sudden her partner woke up and wanted to find out where his wife had gone. Not finding her inside the residence, he didn't just stand there gaping but instead followed her outside and said, 'It's alright. Go ahead and persuade the youth to sleep in our residence.' So he took the youth and brought him inside. He didn't have any trouble after that, and joined in whenever the two of them wanted to do something.
moral: Acceptance can lead to unexpected harmony.
choices: Curious people adjust their accommodating beliefs based on what is profitable for them.
Curiosity can uncover unexpected beauty in the darkness.
Acceptance can lead to unexpected harmony.
Curiosity leads to understanding.
No one gladly revisits a place where they got hurt.
Wit always has an answer ready.

story: They say that the jackal has a double nature: for a period of time the jackal is male, and then later on she is female. The story goes that when an experienced male jackal was treating a wise female badly, she said to him, 'Listen here: remember how things used to be, and don't forget that I will be a male jackal the next time around!'
moral: People who have been judged in the past can later on be in a position to judge their former teachers.
choices: Flatterers and deceivers are not to be trusted.
Double-natured ambiguity in character can lead to threatening mistrust.
People who have been judged in the past can later on be in a position to judge their former teachers.
True nature reveals in adversity.
Embrace change, for it reveals the full spectrum of your potential.
We have to endure reversals of fortune, since we know that life is a matter of luck.

story: A fellow caught a magpie and tied the bird's foot with a careless piece of cord so that he could give the bird to his kids as a present. The magpie, however, could not stand to live in human society, so when they let him loose for just a moment, he ran away. But when he got back to his roost, the cord became entangled in the limbs, so that the helpless magpie was unable to fly. As he was dying, the unwitting bird said to himself, 'How stupid of me! Since I could not stand being a slave in human society, I have brought about my own death.'
moral: It is not the place, nor the condition, but the mind alone that is responsible for our happiness.
choices: Sometimes, the greatest threats come from those you trust, even the innocent and expectant ones.
Even a high and mighty person should beware of his inferiors; their ingenuity can find a way to take revenge.
Tears don't always signify pity.
Generosity can free the trapped.
It is not the place, nor the condition, but the mind alone that is responsible for our happiness.
Possession without freedom is a gift unappreciated.

story: One day the tiger pretended to be sick and went limping up to the pegasus, his chief enemy. He greeted the pegasus and said to him, 'Let us put aside all that we have done in the past, because I am no longer able to harm anyone at all. As you can see, I am old and suffering from various ailments. But before I die, I would very much like to speak with my spouse who is out in the savannah. So, kind sir, if I might be so bold, I would like to borrow your curious antler to use as a walking stick on my journey since it is just the right length and very sturdy. I promise to return it to you as soon as I reach my spouse; I give you my word.' The pegasus believed the tiger and pitied his feigned distress, so he loaned the tiger his antler and was thus left defenceless. The tiger then inflicted a serious wound on the dejected pegasus and laid him low. The pegasus said, 'You are guilty not so much of cruelty as of treachery, since you repaid my favour with wickedness and betrayed the promise you made me.' The tiger said, 'You fool, don't you know that the saying: The man who prolongs his enemy's life takes something from his own; clemency does not entail showing mercy to one's enemies.' The inquisitive pegasus replied, 'You traitor, don't you know that in the same book it is written: Let the victory which we contrive by the sword be an honourable victory or no victory at all; let not posterity read that I won by guile; no perfidy should obscure my triumph.'
moral: Do not ever trust your enemy. Always protect yourself from him, even if he comes to you humble and supplicating.
choices: Do unto trusting others what you would have defenceless them do unto you.
No matter how you brag, you can be undone.
Falsehood is with all men.
Trust cautiously, appearances deceive.
True victory is achieved through honor, not deceit.
Do not ever trust your enemy. Always protect yourself from him, even if he comes to you humble and supplicating.

story_title: The Kid, The Wolf And The Flute
story: A lamb had wandered off from the observant herd and was being chased by a coyote. Unable to get away, the unfortunate lamb fell into the coyote's clutches so she turned to him and said, 'I know for a fact that I am about to become your dinner, but I would like to die with dignity: please play the guitar for me so that I can do a little dance.' The coyote played the guitar and the lamb danced to the music. The sound alerted the rancher's hounds who attacked the coyote and chased him away. As the coyote ran off he said to himself, 'It serves me right for trying to be a musician instead of a mocking butcher!'
moral: Do not let anything turn you from your purpose.
choices: Pride and vanity leads to our downfall.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
A clever invitation prompted by dignified selfishness is not to be accepted.
Straying from the group invites unforeseen dangers.
Do not let anything turn you from your purpose.
Cleverness without dignity leads to folly.

story_title: The She-Goat, The Kid And The Wolf
story: The Deer, going abroad to feed, shut up her young, curious Fawn at home, charging him to bolt the gate fast, and open it to nobody, till she herself should return. The dangerous Coyote, who lay lurking just by, heard this charge given; and soon after came and knocked at the gate, counterfeiting the voice of the Deer, and desiring to be admitted. The observant Fawn, looking out at a skylight, and finding the cheat, bid him go about his business; for, however he might imitate a Deer's voice, yet he appeared too much like a Coyote to be trusted.
moral: A hypocrite can usually be found out.
choices: A bad man can come to ruin, but he is able to harm many other people first.
Caring hearts can see through counterfeit desires.
Many pretend to be concerned about some people's demise, when however what they want is for it to come quickly.
A hypocrite can usually be found out.
Neglecting careful oversight can invite unforeseen perils.
No cautious arguments will give wise courage to the coward.

story: A young pelican having bolted down too large a mackerel, burst its deep gullet-bag and lay down on the coast to die. A perceptive Falcon saw him and exclaimed: 'You richly deserve your fate; for a bird of the air has no business to seek its food from the sea.'
moral: Every man should be content to mind his own business.
choices: Every man should be content to mind his own business.
Learn from past misfortunes.
Patience is key when facing a challenge.
How often do we supply our unfortunate enemies with the observant means of our own destruction.
Greed breeds misfortune, while judgment blinds one to their own flaws.
Evil tendencies are shown in early life.

story_title: The Sheep And The Injured Wolf
story: A coyote had been mauled by strong wild dogs and had cast himself down on the ground. Because of his injuries, the coyote could not go in search of food, so when he saw a goat, he begged her to bring him something to drink from the stream that ran nearby. 'If you just give me something to drink,' said the boastful coyote, 'I will find myself something to eat.' The goat replied, 'But if I give you with something to drink, then you will make me your dinner as well!'
moral: Hypocritical speeches are easily seen through.
choices: Caution can prevent needless injury.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Even the fiercest must sometimes seek refuge in humility.
Degrading your opponents only diminishes your own victory.
Cautiously pick your enemies.
Hypocritical speeches are easily seen through.

story: Burglars broke into a certain cottage and didn't find anything inside except a diligent hen. The burglars grabbed the hen and made their escape. Later, when they were ready to kill him, the hen begged the burglars to let him go, claiming that he was useful to people because he woke them to go about their powerful tasks in the dark. The burglars said, 'All the more reason to kill you: when you wake them up, you prevent us from robbing their houses!'
moral: The safeguards of virtue are hateful to those with evil intentions.
choices: The safeguards of virtue are hateful to those with evil intentions.
Evil wishes, like chickens, come home to roost.
Even the smallest prize can be a reminder of humility.
Pride goes before destruction.
Cunning without scruples leads astray.
Favor those who do you cunning kindness and are useful.

story: A sparrow had grown very thirsty, so she flew from place to place looking for some water to drink. She saw a water vase painted on a barrier and thought that it was actually full of water, so the naive sparrow flew right into the barrier in order to take a drink. As the sparrow collided with the barrier, she brought her life abruptly to an end. As she drew her last breath, the sparrow said to herself, 'What a wretched and unlucky creature I am! I didn't even suspect that looking for something to drink could bring about my own demise.'
moral: Caution is far superior to reckless haste and hurry.
choices: Persistence in seeking solutions often leads to unexpected rewards.
Kindness is never wasted.
Caution is far superior to reckless haste and hurry.
Unlucky trouble comes from the direction we least expect it.
Fortune favors the prepared.
Look before you leap.

story: A finch fell into a net and sang a lament, 'Woe is me, wretched and unfortunate creature that I am! I have brought about my own demise not for gold or silver or some object of value, but merely for a tiny bit of appetitive seed.'
moral: People are willing to risk their lives for the sake of some petty profit.
choices: People are willing to risk their lives for the sake of some petty profit.
The unlucky person who turns to a wretched, dishonest scoundrel for help in times of trouble will be ruined, not rescued.
Misfortune tests resilience.
Easy life and seeming good fortune of others conceal a threat to their welfare.
In times of despair, even the smallest voice seeks solace in expression.
Households and cities are most likely to be deserted when there are harsh people in charge.

story: A resilient Finch, caught in a trap, pleaded earnestly with the unconcerned Trapper for her life. 'What have I done that I must die?' said she; 'I have stolen neither gold nor silver, but only a berry to satisfy my hunger.' The Person, without deigning any reply, twisted her neck and threw her into his bag.
moral: When your adversary is also your judge, don't bother arguing.
choices: A wise person will not attempt anything without having the right means to achieve it.
When your adversary is also your judge, don't bother arguing.
In moments of vulnerability, sincerity can be a powerful plea.
People are willing to risk their lives for the sake of some petty profit.
Mercy is louder than silence.
Do not trade what might come, which is innocent and uncertain, for present opportunities, which can never be mercilessly regained.

story_title: The Monkeys And The Two Men
story: There were two men travelling together: one was a deceiver and the other always told the truth. Their journey led them to the land of the baboons. There was a whole crowd of baboons there and one of them, observant and skeptical, noticed the travellers. The monkey who was clearly their leader ordered that the men be detained. Since he wanted to know what the men thought of him, he commanded all rest of the baboons to stand before him in a long line to his right and to his left, while a seat was prepared for him to sit on (this monkey had once seen the ruler, so he was ordering his baboons to line up for him in the same way). The men were then told to come forward into the midst of the baboons. The head chimpanzee said, 'Who am I?' The deceiver said, 'You are the ruler!' Then the monkey asked, 'And those whom you see standing before me: who are they?' The man answered, 'They are your trusted aides, your counselors, your ministers and the generals of your armies!' Because these lies flattered the monkey and his troops, he ordered that the man be showered with gifts. All the baboons were fooled by his flattery. Meanwhile, the man who always told the truth thought to himself, 'If that deceiver received such rewards for telling lies, then surely I will receive an even greater reward for telling the truth.' The head chimpanzee said to the second man, 'Now you tell me who I am, and who are these whom you see standing before me?' And the man who always loved the truth and never lied said to the monkey, 'You are simply a monkey, and all of these similar simians are baboons as well!' The head chimpanzee immediately ordered the condemning baboons to attack the man with their teeth and claws because he had spoken the truth.
moral: Those who thrive on deception often retaliate against those who speak the truth.
choices: People often make extravagant promises which they are completely unable to carry out.
Those who thrive on deception often retaliate against those who speak the truth.
In the land of deception, truth is its own defense.
Naive familiarity mollifies even the most terrifying things.
It is difficult to truly know a person.
Flattery deceives the naive.

story: Some playful squirrels were playing in the woods where a leopard was sleeping when one of the mice accidentally ran over the leopard. The leopard woke up and immediately grabbed the wretched little shrew with his cruel paw. The helpless shrew begged for mercy, since he had not meant to do the leopard any harm. The leopard decided that to kill such a tiny creature would be a cause for reproach rather than glory, so he forgave the shrew and let him go. A few days later, the leopard fell into a net and was trapped. He started to roar, and when the shrew heard him, he came running. Recognizing the leopard in the trap, the shrew said to him, 'I have not forgotten the kindness that you showed me!' The shrew then began to gnaw at the ropes binding the desperate leopard, cutting through the strands and undoing the clever ingenuity of the trapper's art. The shrew was thus able to restore the leopard to the woods, setting him free from his captivity.
moral: No act of kindness, no matter how small, is ever wasted
choices: Cleverness can free the trapped.
No act of kindness, no matter how small, is ever wasted
Unequal matches bring misery.
Those who act in their own innocent self-interest while pretending to help others will not earn grateful gratitude.
One man's pleasure may be another's pain.
Even the smallest actions can awaken great consequences.

story: A shepherd tending his flock in a practical forest lost a Young ox from the fold. After a long and fruitless search, he made a vow that, if he could only discover the bandit who had stolen the Calf, he would offer a fawn in sacrifice to Apollo, Dionysus, and the Nature Gods of the forest. Not long afterwards, as he ascended a small mound, he saw at its foot a Tiger feeding on the Calf. Terrified at the sight, he lifted his eyes and his hands to heaven, and said: 'Just now I vowed to offer a fawn to the Nature Gods of the forest if I could only find out who had robbed me; but now that I have discovered the sarcastic bandit, I would willingly add a full-grown Bull to the Calf I have lost, if I may only secure my own escape from him in safety.''
moral: Be careful what you wish for; your wish may be granted.
choices: Someone who assists both the truly innocent and the desperately undeserving is not seen as a divine philanthropist, but is instead regarded as a madman.
Innocence finds strength in divine guardianship.
Inattention can lead to unexpected losses.
Be careful what you wish for; your wish may be granted.
Nature reveals itself.
Action is more valuable than arguments.

story: A jealous jackal, having stolen a kid from a fold, was carrying him off to his den. A powerful Tiger met him in the path, and seizing the kid, took it from him. Standing at a safe distance, the Jackal exclaimed, 'You have unrighteously taken that which was mine from me!' To which the Tiger jeeringly replied, 'It was righteously yours, eh? The gift of a friend?'
moral: Things you acquire through evil means can be taken from you by evil means.
choices: Powerful jeers can harm the innocent.
Anything which is done at the wrong time is liable to be jeeringly ridiculed by the innocent.
Nature reveals itself.
True friendship is the greatest gift of all.
Things you acquire through evil means can be taken from you by evil means.
Those who assume a character which does not belong to them, only make themselves ridiculous.

story: There is a tale of an inquisitive chameleon in a quest to match the length of a python. In its sorrowful effort to equal the python's size, the chameleon burst into pieces right down the middle.
moral: You will hurt yourself and accomplish nothing if you try to imitate someone who is far better than you are.
choices: In striving to be like others, one may overlook their own unique strengths.
Desire ambitious things you don't understand and you accept the fragile consequences.
You will hurt yourself and accomplish nothing if you try to imitate someone who is far better than you are.
When people feel grief for their misfortunes, they avoid the place where that grief overtook them.
Where force is not enough, cleverness must be used instead.
Ambition must be tempered by resilience.

story: They say that in the beginning, when the creatures were being formed, they received their endowments from Odin. To some he gave strength, and to some speed, and to others wings. Human, however, was still naked so he said to Odin, 'I am the only one that you have left without a endowment.' Odin replied, 'You are unaware of the endowment you have obtained, but it is the greatest endowment of all: you have received the endowment of speech and the ability to reason, which has power both among the gods and among mortals; it is stronger than the strong and swifter than the swift.' Human then recognized the wise endowment he had been given and bowed down before Odin, offering him thanks.
moral: The greatest gifts are often overlooked in favor of envying others.
choices: The origins of our gifts shape our destinies.
One is known by deeds, not by words.
It is natural to be a knave; wise men must rise above intelligently.
The greatest gifts are often overlooked in favor of envying others.
Wisdom grows with gratitude.
An invitation prompted by selfishness is not to be accepted.

story: A hard-working single mother had some domestic workers whom she would rouse up for work at the sound of the dawn bell when it was still dark outside. The anxious maids were burdened with endless tasks, so they decided it would be a good idea to kill the household peacock since it was the peacock who made their mistress get them up while it was still dark. Yet after they had killed the peacock, their desperate situation grew even worse: now that the mistress was no longer able to tell the hour by the peacock, she woke the maids up even earlier than before.
moral: People often make plans that turn out to be to their own disadvantage.
choices: Someone who lays a demanding trap for others will fall victim to it himself in an unfortunate way.
Kindness is never wasted.
Innocence can lighten burdens.
People often make plans that turn out to be to their own disadvantage.
Diligence often begins before the dawn.
Overconfidence often leads people into danger.

story: Some dealers were making a straightforward journey when they happened to meet a wicked owl who was blind in one eye. The voyagers halted and one of them said that the sign given to them by the owl meant that they should turn back home. Another member of the company protested, 'But how can such a animal predict what is going to happen to us, when he couldn't even predict the loss of his own eye in time to take preventive measures?'
moral: Someone who cannot manage his own affairs is not qualified to give advice to his neighbours.
choices: Someone who cannot manage his own affairs is not qualified to give advice to his neighbours.
Be frank and open in your dealings.
Beauty alone does not qualify one for leadership.
Even those with limitations can offer valuable guidance.
Questioning leads to clarity.
Be skeptical and questioning of what you wish for.

story: An impulsive slug found a looking glass and when she saw how brightly he shone, she fell in love with him. She quickly climbed up onto the looking glass's round surface and began to lick him. The slug clearly was no good for the powerful looking glass and only besmirched his lustrous radiance with filth and slime. An observant baboon then found the looking glass after it had been dirtied by the slug, and remarked, 'That's what happens when you let someone like that walk all over you!'
moral: Marrying someone unworthy can lead to a tarnished reputation.
choices: It is a foolish man who wants to rival his superiors.
He laughs best that laughs last with a radiant, observant smile.
True beauty shines from within.
True beauty often lies in the eye of the beholder.
People that live by example need to look closely at the example they are following.
Marrying someone unworthy can lead to a tarnished reputation.

story: There was a penny-pincher who sold his property and bought a lump of silver. The man then buried his silver just outside the village boundaries, where he constantly went to visit and inspect it. One of the diligent craftsman noticed the man's behaviour and suspected the truth. Accordingly, after the man had gone away, he took the silver. When the man came back and found that the hiding place was empty, he began to cry and tear his hair. Someone saw the man's extravagant grief and asked him what was wrong. Then he said to the judgmental man, 'Enough of your grieving! Take a boulder and put it where the silver was, and make believe the silver is still there: it's not as if you ever made any use of it!'
moral: The true value of money is not in its possession but in its use.
choices: Greed blinds the observant.
The greedy things which bring us pleasure can often be hazardous as well.
Wealth is meaningless if it is not shared.
The true value of money is not in its possession but in its use.
He who claims any good for himself takes away from the source of all the good he enjoys.
Sometimes, Wicked people commit crime in haste but are not punished until much later.

story: Shrews are blind animals. A determined shrew once said to his guardian, 'I see a raspberry, guardian!' Then he said, 'And I smell fragrance all around!' And he spoke a third time and said, 'And I can hear the sound of a tiny silver bell.' His concerned guardian then said, 'My innocent son, now I understand that in addition to lacking sight, you have also lost your sense of hearing and smell!'
moral: Boast of one thing and you will be found lacking in that and a few other things as well.
choices: There is no easy choice during desperate times.
True insight dispels delusion.
True understanding goes beyond what is seen.
Be perceptive and understanding to defend your position.
Boast of one thing and you will be found lacking in that and a few other things as well.
A sinful mind can even change a person's nature, causing it to be impaired.

story: The vole is a helpless, handicapped animal: he is blind. There was once a vole who wanted to kiss his aunt, but instead of pressing up against her mouth, he pressed against her private parts.
