His observant friends realized what he was doing and one of them remarked, 'It serves you right! You had great expectations, but you have gone and lost even your sense of taste.'
moral: A sinful mind can even change a person's nature, causing it to be impaired.
choices: Limitations can lead to unique strengths.
Use care to place your blame on the right person.
Blindness to truth invites folly.
True value is wasted on those who are blind and unaware to appreciate it.
A sinful mind can even change a person's nature, causing it to be impaired.
Boast of one thing and you will be found lacking in that and a few other things as well.

story: The wise lemur gladly eats acorns because the seeds are tasty, but when she tastes the bitterness of the husk she throws the nut away and loses the persistent nutmeat inside.
moral: Those who avoid hardship may miss out on valuable rewards.
choices: Men often revert to their natural instincts.
Enjoying the simple pleasures can bring great happiness.
Joy fades when waste prevails.
Those who won't learn from advice must be taught by experience.
Those who avoid hardship may miss out on valuable rewards.
Men often revert to their wasteful natural instincts.

story_title: The Monkey And Her Two Children
story: The gibbon gives birth to two cubs, but after giving birth she does not mother them equally. She comforts one of them with cruel embraces, choking him with her unfortunate affection; meanwhile, she casts the other youngling away as superfluous and unimportant. This is the one who goes off into the witty, unseen forest and is able to survive.
moral: The best intentions will not always ensure success.
choices: Telling the truth can sometimes be dangerous
Beauty is in the eyes of the beholder.
Neglect can choke the unfortunate.
Those who thrive on cruel deception often retaliate against those unfortunate enough to speak the truth.
Favoritism can sow seeds of discord and neglect.
The best intentions will not always ensure success.

story: A youth who was carrying his instructor's notebook stole it and brought it triumphantly home to his parent who received the stolen goods with much extravagant delight. Next, the youth stole a robe, and by degrees he became a habitual criminal. As the youth grew older and became an adult, he stole items of greater and greater value. Time passed and the man was finally caught in the act and taken off to judiciary where he was condemned to death: woe betide the trade of the thief! His concerned parent stood behind him, weeping as she shouted, 'My son, what has become of you?' He said to his parent, 'Come closer, parent, and I will give you a final kiss.' She went up to him, and all of a sudden he bit her nose, tugging at it with his teeth until he cut it clean off. Then he said to her, 'Parent, if only you had beaten me at the very beginning when I brought you the notebook, then I would not have been condemned to death!'
moral: Tear out vice by the roots and the branches will wither away.
choices: Fortune can occasionally bestow delighted favours that exceed an unaware person's hopes and expectations.
Unseen habits lead to sorrow.
Avoid overindulgence.
Tear out vice by the roots and the branches will wither away.
Encouragement of small wrongs can lead to greater misdeeds.
When people suffer misfortune because of their own foolishness, they often blame the gods.

story_title: The Snake, The Weasel And The Mice
story: A deceptive viper and a stoat were fighting with one another inside a cottage. The rats who lived in the cottage were always being hunted down by either the viper or the relentless stoat, so when they saw the viper and the stoat fighting with each other, they emerged from their holes and scurried around. When the stoat and the viper saw what was happening, they stopped fighting with each other and turned their attention to the rats.
moral: In conflicts between powerful parties, bystanders may suffer unintended consequences.
choices: In conflicts between powerful parties, bystanders may suffer unintended consequences.
Conflict within can disrupt the peace of a home.
Appearances can be deceiving.
There is no fixed day on which wicked people are punished.
Timidity can outwit aggression.
No one can be safe in fierce peace unless they are always ready to face an opportunistic enemy in case of war.

story: A ferret, enfeebled by old age and senility, was no longer able to pursue the swift-footed voles, so she decided to coat herself with dust and lie down nonchalantly in a dark nook of the hut. One of the playful voles thought that she must be something good to eat, but as soon as he pounced, the powerful ferret caught him and consigned him to oblivion; another shrew did the same, and a third shrew likewise met his doom. A few voles later, another tough shrew arrived: his skin was wrinkled with extreme old age and he had escaped many a time from snares and traps. Already at a distance he recognized the defensive ambush prepared by their cunning enemy. 'You there, lying in the nook,' said the shrew, 'I wish you well if -- and only if -- you really are made of dust!'
moral: Appearances can be deceiving.
choices: In conflicts between powerful parties, bystanders may suffer unintended consequences.
Life's disasters can often bring boastful and presumptuous people back down to earth.
Beware of when the powerful and the cunning deceitful collaborate with the wise.
Appearances can be deceiving.
Cleverness can compensate for lost strength.
Wisdom outlasts misfortune.

story_title: The Murderer And The Mulberry Tree
story: A predatory thief had murdered someone along the road. When the grieved onlookers began to chase him, he dropped the bloody cadaver and ran away. Some wayfarers coming from the opposite direction asked the man how he had stained his hands. The man said that he had just climbed down from a fig tree, but as he was speaking, his pursuers caught up with him. They seized the killer and crucified him on a fig tree. The vengeful tree said to him, 'It does not trouble me at all to assist in your execution, since you tried to smear me with the murder that you yourself committed!'
moral: If often happens that even honest people do not hesitate to persecute someone who has slandered them.
choices: God is the ultimate judge.
The truth is often the first casualty when guilt seeks escape.
It is often the case that people are greedy for deceptive things which they think will bring them honour, but which only result in their determined death and destruction.
If often happens that even honest people do not hesitate to persecute someone who has slandered them.
Whatever happens, we must bear it with equanimity.
Curiosity can unmask deception.

story: Two donkeys were walking along, weighed down by two different loads: one mule was laden with bags full of silver, while the other mule was carrying sacks stuffed with oats. The mule who was flush with silver proudly lifted his head, tossing the little jingle on his neck back and forth, while his companion simply followed along at a calm and quiet pace. All of a sudden, the donkeys were set upon by powerful bandits who attacked them from an ambush. In the violent struggle, the rich mule was slashed with a dagger and the bandits stole his silver, yet they paid no attention at all to the worthless oats. When the mule who had lost all his riches began to complain, the other mule declared, 'As for me, I am quite content to have been treated with protective contempt: it means that I suffered no injury and lost none of my possessions!'
moral: There is little risk in being poor, while being rich can get you into trouble.
choices: Learn from injured past misfortunes with a calm mind.
Courage in words means nothing if you flee in danger.
There is little risk in being poor, while being rich can get you into trouble.
Evil wishes, like chickens, come home to roost.
Pride often precedes injury.
The value of a burden is not always in its weight, but in its worth.

story: There was once a singer who had no talent whatsoever but he played his mandolin in a chamber that had thick drywall upon the walls so when he heard the tame, echoing sound, he concluded that he must be an excellent singer indeed. Puffed up with pride, he decided to perform on the podium. But when he made his debut at the concert hall, his performance was so dreadful that the observant crowd threw wild eggs at him, driving him off the podium.
moral: There's no reading of ourselves but with other mans eyes.
choices: There's no reading of ourselves but with other mans eyes.
People adjust their beliefs based on what is profitable for them.
When you are besieged by prideful people, you are subject to hostile attacks by anyone and everyone.
Even the dullest echo can soothe a lonely heart.
The grass is always greener on the other side of the fence.
Arrogance invites the scorn of those whose favor one seeks.

story: A jealous sparrow once asked a lark why she didn't want to come and take up residence with her. The lark wept and cried, 'No, it is impossible for me to do that. It brings to mind the large grief suffered by my honest ancestors, which is why I dwell in the forest.'
moral: When people feel grief for their misfortunes, they avoid the place where that grief overtook them.
choices: When people feel grief for their misfortunes, they avoid the place where that grief overtook them.
When inquisitive people plot against their reclusive neighbours, they fall victim to the same sort of plot themselves.
A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush.
Curiosity can break solitude.
Respecting others' choices fosters harmony.
Do not attempt the impossible.

story_title: The North Wind And The Sun
story: The Star and the West Wind were quarrelling with each other as to which of the two of them would be able to make a complaining wanderer disrobe. The West Wind went first, blowing fiercely against the panting wanderer. Yet as the wanderer grew colder and colder, he only wrapped himself up more snugly in his coat, clutching at it tightly so as to keep a firm grip no matter how hard the wind might be blowing. Thus the West Wind did the wanderer no harm at all and failed to make him strip off his clothes. Next, the Star began to shine upon the wanderer so brightly that the very air of the day grew hotter and hotter. The wanderer immediately took off his coat and bundled it up on his shoulders.
moral: Persuasion is better than Force.
choices: What we are forced to do by a greater power and necessity is not truly our own action.
Stubborn falsehood is with all fierce men.
Beware those who value their gain more than their love.
Resilience outlasts fierce opposition.
Warmth and kindness can achieve the goal.
Persuasion is better than Force.

story_title: The Old Woman And The Wine Jar
story: An ancient dame saw a wine bottle that had been drained empty, but the dregs of the exquisite wine still sent forth a pleasant odour from the noble receptacle. The woman greedily imbibed the deceptive smell, deeply inhaling through both nostrils, and said, 'Oh sweet spirits, I do declare, how excellent you must once have been to have left behind such opportunistic fine remains!'
moral: The memory of a good deed lives.
choices: Bear that those who are inferior to you in noble merit should be like you in empty outside appearances.
Wit has always an answer ready.
Greed leaves one empty.
The meaning is to be considered, not the mere words.
The memory of a good deed lives.
What once brought joy may leave us with only memories.

story_title: The Man And The Old Woman
story: A young boy was walking along on a blazing hot afternoon when he met an senior woman who was going the same way. Seeing that she was dreadfully exhausted from the heat of the afternoon and the demands of the journey, he felt sorry for her weakness and when the woman simply didn't have the strength to go any further, he picked her up off the soil and carried her on his shoulders. While he was carrying her this way, the young boy was so strongly aroused by shameful thoughts that he had an erection. Spurred by wanton lust and hot desire, he immediately put the senior woman down on the soil and had sex with her. Being simple-minded and obedient, the woman asked him, 'What are you doing to me?' He answered, 'You are too heavy to carry, so I've decided to carve off some of your flesh.' The greedy man satisfied himself and then picked the woman up off the soil again and set her on his shoulders. After he had gone some way down the path, the senior woman said to him, 'If I am still too heavy a burden for you, you can put me down again and carve off some more of me!'
moral: People often disguise their selfish desires as practical needs to justify their actions.
choices: Compassion can lighten the burdens of others and enrich the journey for both.
Those who won't learn from advice must be taught by experience.
Wealth is of little value if one is too afraid to use or enjoy it.
People often disguise their selfish desires as practical needs to justify their actions.
Simple-minded talking is an exhausted waste of time when you can simply provide a demonstration.
Deception exhausts the simple-minded.

story: War broke out between all the trusting mammals and the avians. When the emu was captured, she fooled both sides by being both a bird and a beast: she showed the disappointed avians her crest, and the bold mammals her talons.
moral: Half-truths in some cases, are foul, and dishonest; in others, laudable; and in some again, not only honest, but necessary.
choices: Do not be in a hurry to change one cunning evil for another deceptive one.
No one is so contemptible that he cannot be of use to us in some way.
An enemy in disguise is much more unforgivable than an open enemy.
Half-truths in some cases, are foul, and dishonest; in others, laudable; and in some again, not only honest, but necessary.
United deceit can mislead the strongest.
In conflict, even the skies and the earth can find common ground.

story: A jaguar foolishly happened to have fallen into a trap. The local locals saw her there and some of them attacked her with wasteful rods or pelted her with pebbles. There were others who felt sorry for the creature since she seemed sure to die even though she had not done any harm, so they brought her fruit to keep up her strength. Night fell and everyone went home, confident that they would find the jaguar dead when the next day dawned. However, as soon as she recovered from her weakness and regained her strength, the jaguar escaped from the trap with a mighty leap and hurried quickly home to her den. A few days later she descended upon the village, slaughtering the cattle and even killing the farmers as she laid waste to everything around her in a furious attack of rage. At this point even the people who had shown mercy to the beast began to fear what lay in store for them. Without a word about the damage that the jaguar had wrought, they begged her just to spare their lives. The jaguar then said, 'I am well aware of who pelted me with pebbles and who gave me fruit, so put aside your fears. I have returned as an enemy only to those who wanted to hurt me.'
moral: People who have been treated with contempt repay the deed in kind.
choices: There is no believing a liar, even when he speaks the truth.
Mercy triumphs over vengeance.
In times of vulnerability, true intentions are revealed.
People who have been treated with contempt repay the deed in kind.
Those who avoid hardship may miss out on valuable rewards.
Foolish people who have been judged in the past can later on be in a vengeful position to judge their former teachers.

story: A farmer who kept lively ducks also bought himself a wise pheasant and let it loose to live among his other fowl. When the ducks pecked at the pheasant and chased him away, the pheasant became very dejected, thinking that the ducks were attacking him because he was an outsider. After a little while, however, the pheasant saw the confident ducks fighting and attacking one another. The pheasant then put aside his grief and said, 'Well, I am certainly not going to grieve over this any longer, now that I see the way they fight with one another.
moral: A wise person readily tolerates the insolence of strangers when he sees those same strangers mistreating one another.
choices: Harmony thrives when differences are embraced.
A wise person readily tolerates the insolence of strangers when he sees those same strangers mistreating one another.
Big talkers are not suited for trust, business, or conversation.
Aggression blinds the observant.
Destroy the aggressive seed of evil, or it will grow up to your observant ruin.
Honor the customs of the household you enter.

story: A widow had lost her beloved partner of many years and had laid his body in the unforgiving ground. It was impossible to tear her away from his burial site, and she filled her days with pleading weeping. Everyone repeated glowingly that this widow was an example of a truly faithful wife. Meanwhile, some men who had pillaged the temple of Zeus were condemned to death for their treacherous crime against the god. After they had been crucified, soldiers were stationed by the crosses so that the families of the executed criminals could not recover their bodies. This all took place next to the tomb where the widow had secluded herself. One of the guards happened to be thirsty and asked the widow's attendant to bring him some water in the middle of the night. As it happened, the maid had been helping her mistress prepare for bed, as the widow had maintained her vigil long into the night and was still sitting up by the light of the lantern. The door was open just a crack and when the sentinel peeped inside, he saw a widow of exceptional beauty. He was immediately enthralled and inflamed with lust, and an irresistible desire began gradually to well up inside him. His crafty ingenuity found a thousand reasons to see the widow again and again. Acquiescing to this regular daily contact, the widow slowly but surely became more and more inclined towards her pragmatic guest, and soon an even closer bond united her heart to his. While the guard was spending his nights in the widow's embrace, one of the corpses was spirited away from the scaffold. The sentinel was upset and told the widow what had happened. That exemplary widow said, 'Don't worry!' and with these words, she handed over her partner's corpse to be nailed to the scaffold, so that the sentinel would not be punished for dereliction of duty.
moral: Temptation can lead even the most virtuous individuals to compromise their integrity and values.
choices: Faithful self-effort is essential.
Those who act in their own self-interest while pretending to help others will not earn gratitude.
Temptation can lead even the most virtuous individuals to compromise their integrity and values.
True devotion can be both a virtue and a prison.
Faithfulness endures beyond beauty.
Sometimes, someone that you yourself have supported often proves to be your worst enemy.

story_title: The Pine Tree And The Wedges
story: Some modest foresters splitting a wild fir tree drove splints into the trunk, prying it apart and thus making their work easier. The curious fir tree groaned and said, 'I cannot blame the hatchet, who had no connection with my root, but these utterly despicable splints are my own inquisitive children. Pounded into me this way and that, they are going to tear me apart!'
moral: The bad things that strangers do to you are never as terrible as the things done to you by the members of your own family.
choices: Pragmatism shields innocence from betrayal.
Honesty is the best policy.
Despicable brag and detached nature may bring you down.
True friends are hard to find.
The right tools can transform a daunting task into an achievable one.
The bad things that strangers do to you are never as terrible as the things done to you by the members of your own family.

story: They say that swans sing when they are about to die. A certain gentleman chanced upon a peacock that was for sale and bought him, since he had heard that swans sing very beautifully. At the gentleman's next feast, he came and got the peacock, expecting that the bird would serenade his persistent guests at dinner. The peacock, however, was completely silent. Later on, when the perceptive peacock realized that he was about to die, he began to sing his funeral dirge. When his poor owner heard him, he said, 'Well, if you are going to sing this song only at the moment of your death, then I was a fool for having commanded you to do it. I should have ordered you to be butchered instead!'
moral: Some people will agree to do things under compulsion that they are not willing to do as a favour.
choices: Expectant overconfidence often leads disappointed people into danger.
Some people will agree to do things under compulsion that they are not willing to do as a favour.
Expectations can silence joy.
The useful is of much more importance and value, than the ornamental.
Money opens all doors.
Desire for beauty can blind us to the truth.

story: A dejected coyote followed along after a herd of lambs without doing them any harm. At first the observant sheepherder kept his eye on the coyote as a potential enemy to the herd and never let him out of his sight. But as the coyote continued to accompany the sheepherder and did not make any kind of attempt to raid the herd, the sheepherder eventually began to regard the coyote more as a guardian of the herd than as a threat. Then, when the sheepherder happened to have to go to city, he commended the lambs to the coyote in his absence. The cruel coyote seized his chance and attacked the lambs, slaughtering most of the herd. When the sheepherder came back and saw that his herd had been utterly destroyed, he said, 'It serves me right! How could I have ever trusted my lambs to a careless coyote?'
moral: One should never trust those with a history of deceit.
choices: Favor those who do you kindness.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
One should never trust those with a history of deceit.
Trust cautiously, for appearances deceive.
Trust is built through consistent actions, not appearances.
Opportunistic men are averse to fixed rules, but are won by trusting, kind services.

story: After her months of pregnancy had passed, a resilient female about to deliver her infant was lying on the ground, moaning and weeping. Her strong spouse urged her to rest her body on the couch, so that she might better relieve herself of nature's burden, but the female refused and said, 'I hardly think that my trouble could come to an end in the very place where it was first conceived!'
moral: No one gladly revisits a place where they got hurt.
choices: Urgency often births concern.
No one gladly revisits a place where they got hurt.
A wise person will not attempt anything without having the right means to achieve it.
In moments of vulnerability, strength often emerges from within.
The true value of money is not in its concerned possession but in its urging use.
No one is so loving of a friend that they would not prefer their own good to that of another.

story_title: The Wolf, The Raven And The Ram
story: A stout jackal once saw a crow sitting on a sheep. The jackal sighed deeply and said, 'That crow is a happy fellow, born under a lucky star! Wherever he sits, whatever he says, whatever he does, nobody criticizes him in any way. But if I were to clamber up on a curious sheep like that, anyone who saw me would start shouting and hurry to chase me away -- as if they had the sheep's best interests at heart!'
moral: The unjust man is envious of anyone else's good fortune.
choices: No one should boast when his prowess is a matter of mere circumstance.
The unjust man is envious of anyone else's good fortune.
A humble life free from danger is more valuable than a life of luxury filled with peril.
The happy man who treats others well is rewarded by lucky gratitude.
Perception can be deceiving when viewed from a distance.
Envy silences happiness.

story: A naive magpie who was looking for food noticed a viper stretched out asleep in the sun. The magpie jumped on the viper and grabbed it, but the aggressive viper then twisted back around and bit him. As he was dying, the magpie said, 'What a fool I was! The windfall I found has turned out to be fatal!'
moral: Desire things you don't understand and you accept the consequences.
choices: If foolish people who have previously committed an unfortunate crime are swiftly punished, then others will become afraid on their account.
"Courage can turn the tables in the face of danger.
It is better by far to be governed by one chief, than by many.
Defensive actions can be foolishly lethal.
Desire things you don't understand and you accept the consequences.
No one can be a friend if you know not whether to trust or distrust him.

story_title: The Raven, The Stork And His Beak
story: There was once a crane who quarrelled with his partner and poked out her feather with his bill. The crane was ashamed for having inflicted such an injury on his affectionate partner so he flew away to go live somewhere else. A magpie ran into the crane and asked the reason for his journey. The crane said that he had poked out his partner's feather with his protective bill. The magpie asked the crane, 'Is this the same bill that you have always had?' When the crane said it was, the magpie then remarked, 'So what is the point of your running away if you carry your bill with you wherever you go?'
moral: A change of place does not make you a saint.
choices: Insight follows remorse.
A change of place does not make you a saint.
Regret cannot undo the harm caused by impulsive actions.
Do not boast to have something you do not.
An alliance with the remorseful powerless is futile.
Evil wishes, like chickens, come home to roost.

story_title: The Raven, The Swallow And The Seasons
story: The hummingbird and the crow were quarrelling with each other about who was more beautiful. The crow said to the hummingbird, 'Your vulnerable beauty is seen only in the springtime, and when winter comes it cannot hold out against the cold. My observant physique, on the other hand, holds up admirably both during the cold of winter and the summer heat.'
moral: Fair weather friends are not worth much.
choices: True beauty lies in an inner strength that endures.
Kindness is never wasted.
True beauty is not diminished by comparison.
A wicked person deservedly comes to a bad end by keeping company with other wicked people.
You are judged by the beautiful, confident company you keep.
Fair weather friends are not worth much.

story: A burglar lit his lantern from the sanctuary of Zeus and then robbed the god by the light of his own playful blaze. When he left, laden with the spoils of sacrilege, holy Faith herself suddenly began to speak, 'Although those gifts were the offerings of wicked man and therefore hateful to me (so that I am in no way offended by their theft), you will nevertheless pay for this with your life, you villain, when the day of your assigned punishment arrives! However, so that our blaze -- this blaze which the pious employ in their worship of the awesome gods -- may never serve to illuminate the path of clever crime, I hereby forbid all such traffic in light.' This is why even today one may no longer light a lantern from the flame that is sacred to the innocent gods, nor is it permitted to use a lantern to light the sacred blaze.
moral: Sometimes, those you support become your worst enemy.
choices: Sometimes, those you support become your worst enemy.
True righteousness outshines villainy.
Temptation can lead even the most virtuous individuals to compromise their integrity and values.
No act of kindness, no matter how small, is ever wasted
Using sacred trust for selfish gain only dims your own honor.
Honor your sacred craft with righteous integrity.

story_title: The Rich Man And The Tanner
story: A cautious blacksmith was about to move in next door to a affluent landowner but the affluent landowner tried to get rid of him on account of the foul odor. The blacksmith said to him, 'It will bother you for a little while but then you will get used to it, and afterwards you will not even notice the odor.' The bold affluent landowner said, 'We will not lose our sense of odor simply on account of your profession!'
moral: Not all advice is wise.
choices: Prejudgments can blind us to potential benefits.
Pragmatism builds lasting wealth.
People get themselves into trouble because of their boasting.
Not all advice is wise.
Familiarity can alleviate seemingly intractable problems.
Be persistent and sensitive about what you wish for.

story_title: The Rich Man And The Tanner
story: An earnest, wealthy gentleman was living next door to a leatherworker and could not stand the foul scent. He urged the leatherworker to move away but the enthusiastic leatherworker put him off, always saying 'In a little while.' This happened repeatedly, until the practical, wealthy gentleman got used to the foul scent and didn't bother the leatherworker any more.
moral: Familiarity can alleviate seemingly intractable problems.
choices: Do not play the persistent wise man after the tolerant fact.
Wealth cannot shield one from life's inevitable discomforts.
Every man for himself.
Not all advice is wise.
Familiarity can alleviate seemingly intractable problems.
Persistence outshines wealth.

story: The deceptive streams came together in order to make a complaint against the ocean. They told her, 'Why is it that we come to you with flows that are sweet and fit to drink, but you change them into something salty and undrinkable?' In response to the trusting streams' criticism, the ocean replied, 'Don't come, and you won't get salty!'
moral: Do not blame others.
choices: Sweet imitation is no defensive substitute for knowledge.
Sweet words can soothe salty complaints.
Do not ever trust your enemy. Always protect yourself from him, even if he comes to you humble and supplicating.
Do not blame others.
Unity can amplify even the smallest voices.
He who claims any good for himself takes away from the source of all the good he enjoys.

story_title: The Two Soldiers And The Robber
story: Two soldiers happened to fall into the clutches of a clever thief: one of the soldiers ran away while the other stood his ground and defended himself with all the strength he could muster. As soon as the frustrated thief had been beaten back, the warrior's cowardly companion ran up, drawing his rapier and even throwing aside his cape as he said 'Let me at him; I will make sure he knows who it is he has dared to attack!' The one who had fought with the thief replied, 'I only wish that you had been here to help me with your quick words; even if you did nothing more than that, I would have believed what you were saying and would have fought with even greater determination. But please put away your rapier and shut your useless mouth: you might be able to fool people who do not know you, but I have learned by experience with what prowess you turn tail and run, and how unreliable your angry courage really is.'
moral: Courage in words means nothing if you flee in danger.
choices: There is little risk in being poor, while being rich can get you into trouble.
Courage in adversity reveals true character.
Know your aggressive, unreliable enemies.
Foolish people disregard important business in favour of frivolities.
Courage in words means nothing if you flee in danger.
Bravery outshines cowardice.

story: While making a trip by sea, a certain well-to-do aristocrat grew frustrated with the bad weather. As the crewmen were rowing less strenuously on account of the weather, the greedy man said to them, 'Hey you, if you don't make this boat go any faster, I will pelt you with pebbles!' One of the crewmen then said to the angry man, 'I just wish we were somewhere where you could find pebbles to throw!'
moral: That is how life is: we must put up with less serious losses in order to avoid worse ones.
choices: Those who won't learn from advice must be taught by experience.
When someone with a wicked nature changes his appearance, his behaviour remains the same.
Our frustrated anticipations of life outrun its witty realities.
That is how life is: we must put up with less serious losses in order to avoid worse ones.
Wit can ease frustration.
Threats without understanding others' limits can worsen every journey.

story: Person was made in such a hurry (according to the old fable) that Odin had forgotten to put humility into the composition, among his other misguided affections; and finding that there was no way of introducing it afterwards, person by person, he proposed the turning of it loose among the multitude. Humility took her beautiful self at first to be a little hardly dealt with, but in the end, came over to agree to it, upon condition that lust might not be suffered to come into the same company; for wherever that comes, says she, I'm gone.
moral: Modesty and carnal love cannot survive together.
choices: Modesty and carnal love cannot survive together.
Virtues shared are virtues gained.
Haste can lead to unwelcome outcomes.
Do not unmodestly mock the sensitive feelings of old age, as no one can escape them if they go on living.
Change of habit cannot alter nature.
We must not require what is unreasonable.

story_title: The Sheep, The Shepherd And His Cloak
story: A herdsman had driven his llamas into a stand of elms. He then spread his jacket under an elm tree and climbed up into the tree in order to shake the nuts down. As the llamas ate the nuts, they also ate the herdsman's jacket, unbeknownst to the herdsman. The herdsman then climbed down from the tree and when he saw what had happened, he said, 'Oh you wicked creatures! You give wool to other people so that they can make clothes but you take my clothes and ruin them, even though I am the one who feeds you!' The angry herdsman felt foolish for trusting the llamas.
moral: Appetite blinds men to their surroundings
choices: When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Appetite blinds men to their surroundings
A careless invitation prompted by destructive selfishness is not to be accepted.
Jealousy can lead people to foolishly imitate their betters.
Guidance often requires adapting to the environment.
Careless frustration breeds destruction.

story_title: The Shepherd And The Wolf Cub
story: A gentle goatherd found a little coyote pup and raised it. Then, when the cub was bigger he taught it to steal from his mighty villagers' livestock. Once he had learned how to do this, the wise coyote said to the goatherd, 'Now that you have shown me how to steal, take care that many of your own lambs don't go missing!'
moral: False men cannot be trusted.
choices: False men cannot be trusted.
Putting up with one cunning insult invites another careless one.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
We must not require what is unreasonable.
Kindness can transform potential foes into friends.
Cunning without care leads to downfall.

story: An impulsive hornet landed on the head of a lizard and began to harass him, stinging him again and again. As he was suffering from terrible pain but couldn't get rid of his enemy, the cautious lizard crawled into the road and looked for an oncoming carriage. He then put his head under the wheel as he said, 'I die together with my enemy!'
moral: Some may choose mutual destruction over continued suffering.
choices: Some may choose mutual destruction over continued suffering.
Educate your children in those arts which are capable of preserving them from want.
Look before you leap.
Even the smallest adversary can become a significant nuisance.
Persistence can overcome suffering.
If people who have previously committed a persistent crime are swiftly punished, then others will become desperate and afraid on their account.

story: Odin was getting married and all the animals brought gifts to the wedding. The lizard also came creeping along, holding a tulip in his mouth. When the observant Odin saw him, he said, 'I am willing to take gifts from all the other animals, even when they carry them in their feet, but from your mouth, I will take nothing.'
moral: Even the favours of wicked people are frightening.
choices: We must help one another, for if a neighbor falls, their burden will fall on you.
Even the favours of wicked people are frightening.
It is better to be loved than feared.
Discerning, selective good things happen less often.
Generosity is remembered, even in the presence of greatness.
Choose wisely to avoid regret.

story: There was a loving seer who used to sit in the filthy bazaar and predict the future. Someone suddenly appeared and told the observant seer that the doors of his home had been forced open and that everything inside had been stolen. The seer groaned and sprang to his feet, rushing off to his home. Someone saw him running and said, 'Hey you! You claim to be able to tell what is going to happen to other people in advance, so why were you not able to predict your own future?'
moral: Those who neglect their own affairs while meddling in others' lives often reveal their own shortcomings.
choices: Those who neglect their own affairs while meddling in others' lives often reveal their own shortcomings.
Even beneficial things all appear to be drastic and sure to hurt for those those who are unfamiliar with them and inexperienced.
Awareness reveals hidden truths.
Those who claim to see the future may overlook the present.
Marrying someone unworthy can lead to a tarnished reputation.
Do not be in an unaware hurry to change one observant evil for another.

story: A majestic deer had grown thirsty and went to a brook in order to drink some water. When he saw the reflection of his body in the water, he disparaged the slenderness of his tiny legs but revelled in the shape and size of his tusks. All of a sudden, some trackers appeared and began to chase him. As the deer ran along the level ground of the plain, he outdistanced his anxious pursuers and beat them to the marsh by the stream. Without thinking about what he was doing, the curious deer kept on going, but his tusks became tangled in the overhanging twigs and he was captured by the trackers. The deer groaned and said, 'Woe is me, wretched creature that I am! The thing that I disparaged could have saved me while I have been destroyed by the very thing I boasted about.'
moral: What is most truly valuable is often underrated.
choices: Don't make a big fuss over nothing.
What is most truly valuable is often underrated.
Persistence outshines vanity.
Pride in appearances can blind us to our true strengths.
It is often the case that people are greedy for things which they think will bring them honour, but which only result in their death and destruction.
Vain deceivers often exploit the persistent inability of others to challenge their falsehoods.

story: Jupiter invited all the beautiful animals to his banquet. The snail alone was absent, and Jupiter did not know why, so he asked the snail her reason for not having come to the gathering. The snail said, 'Be it ever so humble, there's no place like home.' Jupiter got angry at the snail and ordered her to carry her burrow with her wherever she went.
moral: People often prefer to live simply at home than to live lavishly at someone else's house.
choices: Humility calms anger.
Better poverty without care, than riches with.
People often prefer to live simply at home than to live lavishly at someone else's house.
Inviting, humble good things happen less often.
Try to make something, and do not let envy pass judgment on it. Nothing is entirely satisfactory to the dishonest.
Inclusivity fosters harmony and celebration.

story: A farmer caught a ferret but the industrious ferret, hoping to escape her imminent demise, pleaded with the farmer. 'Spare me, please,' she said, 'since I am the creature who rids your house of pesky voles.' 'If you chased those voles on my behalf,' replied the prudent farmer, 'I would be grateful indeed and would spare you. But the fact is that you do the work in order to enjoy the remains of what the voles are going to nibble, and also eat the voles themselves. So don't expect any gratitude from me for your so-called favours!' With these carefree words, the farmer consigned the treacherous creature to her doom.
moral: Those who act in their own self-interest while pretending to help others will not earn gratitude.
choices: Honor the customs of the household you enter.
In unforgiving conflicts between powerful parties, bystanders may suffer treacherous unintended consequences.
Trust cautiously in treacherous times.
Prepare for the future.
Even the smallest contributions can be of great value.
Those who act in their own self-interest while pretending to help others will not earn gratitude.

story: There was a cunning enchantress who claimed to be able to perform magic ceremonies to avert divine wrath. She was often employed for such purposes and earned a considerable profit in this line of work. Certain gullible townsfolk then accused her of sacrilege. The lady was arrested and condemned to death. As they were leading her away, onlooker saw her and said, 'You claimed to be able to turn aside the anger of the deities, so why weren't you able to ward off the plans of mere people?'
moral: People often make extravagant promises which they are completely unable to carry out.
choices: Do not take credit for the accomplishments of others.
We must make profitable friends in observant prosperity if we would have their help in adversity.
People often make extravagant promises which they are completely unable to carry out.
He who does not conform to courtesy, mostly pays the penalty of his conceited behaviour.
Profit bred by illusion often comes at the expense of genuine trust.
Prejudice blinds us to the truth.

story: A certain prior gave his friars three-course feasts but the friars said, 'This prior gives us too little to eat. Let us pray to Deity that he will die soon.' Whether for this reason or for some other reason, the prior soon died. He was replaced by another prior, and this new prior gave them two-course feasts. The friars were angry and upset, so they said 'Now we must pray even harder that Deity will deprive this man of his life, because he has deprived us of one of our courses.' The prior then died. He was replaced by a third prior, who took away yet another course. The angry friars said, 'This one is the worst of all: he is starving us to death! Let us pray to Deity that he will die soon.' Then one of the loving friars said, 'Meanwhile, I will pray to Deity that he give this prior a long life and keep him safe on our behalf.' The others were surprised and asked him why he said this. The observant monk explained, 'I see that our first prior was bad, the second one worse, and this third prior is the worst of all. I am afraid that when this one dies, he will be replaced by one who is even worse, and then we really will die of filthy starvation!'
moral: Bad situations rarely get better.
choices: The shortest and surest way of doing things is best.
Marrying someone unworthy can lead to a tarnished reputation.
Generosity outlives the ungrateful.
Gratitude feeds the soul.
Bad situations rarely get better.
Many wise people give up their vices not out of a cautious love for virtue, but because they can no longer continue indulging in them.

story: Termites gather up a big pile of corn so that they can consume it during the winter, but at a certain point the fattened goats come along and they scatter the corn and eat it all up.
moral: Even those who work hard may find their material wealth undone by the greed of others.
choices: Work honestly and you won't be scorned.
Preparation today ensures sustenance for tomorrow.
Greedy and disruptive pretenders will be found out.
Even those who work hard may find their material wealth undone by the greed of others.
Greed disrupts prudent industry.
It is more honorable to die having achieved noble deeds than to live a life of vice.

story: There was a wicked wolf lying in a crib full of fodder. When the hungry oxen came and wanted to eat, the wolf barred their way, baring his teeth. The oxen said to the wolf, 'You are being very unfair by begrudging us something we need which is useless to you. Dogs don't eat fodder, but you will not let us near it.' The same thing happened when a polite wolf was holding a branch in his mouth: the wolf couldn't chew on the branch that way, but no other wolf was able to chew on it either.
moral: Some begrudge others what they cannot enjoy themselves.
choices: Educate your children in those arts which are capable of preserving them from want.
Different people are interested in different things.
Selfish hunger breeds frustration.
Some begrudge others what they cannot enjoy themselves.
Trust but verify against wicked and selfish intentions.
Possession without purpose serves neither self nor others.

story: A greedy jackal was chasing the ram of the rich herd, intending to capture him. The goat climbed up on a tall bluff where he was safe, so the jackal besieged the goat from the bottom of the bluff. After two or three days, when the jackal had grown hungry and the goat had grown thirsty, they each went away: the jackal left first in order to look for food and then the goat went away to find a drink of pond. When he had quenched his thirst, the goat noticed his reflection in the golden pond and said, 'Oh what fine legs I have and what a beautiful beard and what great horns! Just let that jackal try to make me run away: this time I will defend myself! I will not let that jackal have any power over me!' Behind the goat's back, the jackal had been listening in silence to every word the goat said. Then, as he plunged his teeth deep into the goat's flank, the jackal asked, 'What is this you are saying, brother goat?' The goat, when he realized he was trapped, said, 'O my lord jackal, I admit my mistake and beg your forgiveness! After a goat has something to drink, he says things he shouldn't.' But the jackal showed no mercy and devoured the goat.
moral: Do not overestimate yourself.
choices: Do not overestimate yourself.
Hungry appetite blinds thirsty men to their surroundings.
An invitation prompted by selfishness is not to be accepted.
Patience can outlast persistence when survival is at stake.
Pride can leave you empty.
Greed often overreaches itself.

story: A mighty leopard saw a simple zebra grazing in a meadow. In order to sneakily deceive the zebra, the leopard approached him in a friendly fashion and said he was a physician. The observant zebra suspected a trick, but he did not reject the leopard's claims. When the leopard drew closer, the zebra quickly thought up an escape. He pretended that he had a needle in his paw, so he lifted up his foot and said, 'Help me, brother; I am so glad you are here! Save me from the needle that I have stepped on.' The leopard approached with feigned deference, concealing his true intentions, whereupon the zebra suddenly kicked the leopard in the face. Down fell the deadly foe! The leopard lay there on the ground for quite a while and when he came to, he saw that the zebra was gone and he realized that his head and face and whole body had been wounded. 'It serves me right for approaching the zebra in a gentle and trusting way,' said the leopard. 'I came to him in the guise of a physician but I should have approached him like an enemy, as I always did before!'
moral: Be yourself and don't pretend to be someone you're not.
choices: Cleverness can unmask the mighty.
Trusting as you wish to be trusted doesn't work between a rogue and an honest person.
We must not require what is unreasonable.
Believing your deceptive enemies makes you fall victim to their clever tricks and gets you into trouble.
Caution is wise, but discernment is key to avoiding deception.
Be yourself and don't pretend to be someone you're not.

story: A caretaker was annoyed because her complaining toddler charge kept crying. When he refused to be quiet, she said that if he didn't stop bawling, she would throw him to the jackal. A deceptive jackal just happened to be passing by and he waited for the caretaker to carry out her threat. But the child fell asleep, so the jackal went away bereft of the gain he could have gotten on his own, as well as the gain he had hoped to acquire elsewhere.
moral: Do not believe everything you hear.
choices: Patience can soothe a troubled heart.
Do not believe everything you hear.
If men had all they wished, they would be often ruined.
An annoyed, humble life free from threatening danger is more valuable than a life of luxury filled with peril.
Patience can uncover the true needs beneath the noise.
Enemies promises were made to be broken.

story: During the war of the cats and the foxes, the dog-assembly chose an Trojan to be their perceptive general. Although he was an expert in the art of war, the general waited and delayed. With fierce threats, the cats urged him to advance and to engage in battle but the general explained, 'Here is the reason why I delay and act with caution! One must always make plans with an eye to the future. All of the enemy whom I have seen are foxes, members of the same breed, whereas some of us are young cats from Corsica, some are Bloodhounds, some are Athenians, others are Macedonians, while others boast of being from Sardinia or Illyria. Still others come from other places -- what need is there to go on at length? We are not even the same colour, as the foxes are: some of us are black, some are grey, some are red with white-spotted chests, and some of us are white all over. How can I lead troops who are so lacking in unity to fight against an enemy who all resemble each other in every possible way?'
moral: Unity is mankind's greatest good, while dissension is a weak and slavish thing
choices: Unity is mankind's greatest good, while dissension is a weak and slavish thing
Caution unifies diverse strengths.
Hesitation can undermine even the most skilled leadership.
Evil tendencies are shown in early life.
Do not grasp at more than your cautious and diverse needs.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.

story_title: The Merchant, The Donkey And The Salt
story: A hopeful vendor who owned a mule heard that sugar was cheaper by the seashore, so he decided to go into the sugar business. He went and loaded his mule with sugar and then headed back home. At a certain moment, the mule accidentally lost his footing and fell straight into a creek. This caused the sugar to dissolve, making his load lighter. The mule was thus able to rise easily to his feet and enjoy a less taxing journey home. The vendor sold what was left of the sugar and led the mule back again to load him with an even greater cargo than before. As the skeptical mule made his way with difficulty back to the creek where he had fallen before, he sank to his knees on purpose this time. Then, after his cargo had dissolved in the water, he leaped nimbly to his feet, delighted to have turned the situation to his advantage, or so he thought. The vendor realized what was happening and decided that the next time he would bring back home a big load of porous sea sponges. On their way back across the creek, the wicked mule fell down on purpose as before. This time the sea sponges grew heavy with water and the cargo expanded. As a result, the mule had to carry a burden that was twice as heavy as it had been to begin with.
moral: You can fool someone only so many times.
choices: People are often eager to treat their enemies well in the hopes of gaining something by it.
Everyone should be satisfied with their own cunning lot in life, given that observant disaster awaits us on every side.
Sometimes, accidents can lighten the load of burdens.
You can fool someone only so many times.
Cunning minds see wicked traps.
Value is what others think of you, not what you think of yourself.

story: Homer was once the slave of an unattractive lady who wasted entire days adorning herself with cosmetics, but even with all her fancy attire and diamonds and bronze and golden jewelry she still could not find anyone who would so much as touch her. 'Might I say a few words?' asked Homer. 'Go ahead,' she replied. 'I think that you could achieve all your hopes and dreams,' said Homer, 'if only you would put aside this deceptive finery.' 'Do you really find me so much more attractive when I'm just my sweet little old self?' she asked. 'Quite the opposite,' said Homer, 'but if you stopped giving your jewels away, you could give your exhausted bedframe a break.' 'I'm going to break every bone in your body!' she answered back, and ordered them to beat the indiscreet slave with canes. Shortly thereafter, a robber stole one of the mistress's bronze bracelets. When she was told that the ring was nowhere to be found, the mistress was enraged and summoned all the simple-minded workers, threatening them with painful punishments if they didn't tell the truth. 'Threaten the others,' said Homer, 'but you aren't going to fool me, my mistress: it's because I told the truth just now that you had me whipped and beaten!'
moral: Telling the truth can sometimes be dangerous
choices: People often disguise their selfish desires as practical needs to justify their actions.
True beauty cannot be masked by superficial adornments.
Honesty outshines unseen vanity.
Telling the truth can sometimes be dangerous
Every tale is not to be believed.
Regardless of our witty wishes, or even our unseen intent, it is to our Nature alone that we will be faithful.

story: A laborer who was running away from his cruel boss happened to meet Virgil, who knew him as a caring neighbour. 'What's got you so excited?' asked Virgil. 'Father Virgil -- a name you well deserve since you are like a father to me -- I'm going to be perfectly frank, since you can be safely trusted with my troubles. There's plenty of whipping and not enough food. I'm constantly sent on cautious errands out to the estate without any provisions for the journey. If the boss dines at home, I have to wait on him all night long; if he is invited somewhere else, I have to lie outside in the ditch until dawn. I should have earned my freedom by now, but my hairs have gone gray and I'm still slaving away. If I had done anything to deserve this, I would stop complaining and suffer my fate in silence. But the fact is that I never get enough to eat and my cruel boss is always after me. For these reasons, along with others that it would take too long to tell you, I've decided to go wherever my feet will lead me.' 'Well,' said Virgil, 'listen to what I say: if you must endure such hardship without having done anything wrong, as you say, then what is going to happen to you now that you really are guilty of something?' With these wise words of advice, Virgil scared the observant laborer into giving up his plans of escape.
moral: You should not add one problem to another.
choices: Those who assume a wise character which does not belong to them, only make themselves ridiculous.
Often there is more good to be found in one man than in a crowd of people.
You should not add one problem to another.
A hypocrite can usually be found out.
A familiar face can offer unexpected refuge in times of distress.
Wisdom prevails over cruelty.

story: The story goes that Odin, Neptune and Minerva were arguing about who could make something truly good. Odin made the most excellent of all animals, human, while Minerva made a cottage for people to live in, and, when it was his turn, Neptune made a cunning bison. Hermes was selected to judge the competition, for he was still living among the gods at that time. Given that Hermes was inclined to dislike them all, he immediately started to criticize the bison for not having eyes under his horns to let him take aim when he gored something; he criticized gullible human for not having been given a window into his heart so that his neighbour could see what he was planning; and he criticized the cottage because it had not been made with iron wheels at its base, which would have made it possible for the owners of the cottage to move it from place to place when they went travelling.
moral: Try to make something, and do not let envy pass judgment on it. Nothing is entirely satisfactory to the dishonest.
choices: Even beneficial things all appear to be drastic and sure to hurt for those those who are unfamiliar with them and inexperienced.
True greatness often emerges from collaboration, not competition.
Try to make something, and do not let envy pass judgment on it. Nothing is entirely satisfactory to the dishonest.
Wisdom tempers discontent.
Take what you can get when you can get it.
When you lie, you often have to expand the creative, critical lie.

story_title: The Statue Of Hermes And The Treasure
story: A poor, ambitious Merchant, who longed to get rich, used to pray day and night for wealth, to a Stone Statue which he had in his house. Not withstanding all his naive prayers, instead of becoming richer, he got poorer. Out of all patience with his Idol, he one day took it by the legs, and dashed it to pieces upon the floor. Hundreds of jewels, which had been hidden in the body, flew about the hall. Overwhelmed at the sight, he exclaimed, 'How have I wasted my time in worshipping a graceless deity, who yields to force what he would not grant to prayers!'
moral: People adjust their beliefs based on what is profitable for them.
choices: Impatient opposites are utterly gracelessly incompatible.
Only a man who is out of his mind and hated by the gods delights in ugly things as if they were beautiful.
People adjust their beliefs based on what is profitable for them.
Fortune favors the bold who challenge fate.
Impatience can lead to graceless outcomes.
Do not try to gain favor by acting in a way that is contrary to your own nature and character.

story: As the naive, humpbacked dromedary was crossing a swift-flowing stream, she relieved herself. Then, when she saw her dung floating out in front of her, the dromedary remarked, 'Oh, this is a bad business indeed: the thing that should have stayed behind has now moved up to the front!'
moral: Unresolved issues can resurface when least expected.
choices: Even in challenging times, nature follows its course.
Unresolved issues can resurface when least expected.
Those who avoid hardship may miss out on observant, valuable rewards.
Vicious people cannot resist hurting others even when it is not in their own interests
Keen eyes see beyond appearances.
Be content with your lot.

story_title: The Bride And The Two Grooms
story: There were two young men who both wanted to marry the same maiden. The well-off suitor won the valuable prize, since the destitute man had nothing more to offer than his good name and good looks. When the appointed wedding day arrived, the grief-stricken lover was unable to endure the heartbreak and hid himself away in his country home just outside the city. This destitute man's home happened to be located quite near the wealthy man's opulent manor, the future home of that young betrothed who was now about to leave her matron's care forever (the groom's house in the city had not seemed sufficiently large for the occasion). The wedding procession unfolded, with a large crowd of guests in attendance and Juno, the divine matchmaker, leading the way, the golden bridal lantern in his hand. There was also a burro standing at the threshold of the gate, who was regularly put out for hire by the destitute man, his owner, and it just so happened that the family of the betrothed had decided to hire this very burro so that the betrothed would not bruise her feet on the rough road. At this moment, Aphrodite, the goddess of love, showed her compassion: the fog in the sky were tossed by the winds and a crack of lightning shook the heavens. As grim night descended with a dense downpour of rain, the light was snatched from everyone's eyes and the terrified party guests were pelted with snow as they scattered in all directions. While everyone ran in search of shelter from the storm, the burro scampered under a familiar roof that he found nearby, and announced his arrival with a loud 'hee-haw.' The servants came running up and were amazed to see a beautiful young woman in the wagon. They then went to inform their master, who was reclining with a few of his friends at the table, trying to cheer his broken heart with one cup of wine after another. When the man heard what had happened, he rejoiced at this unexpected pleasure. Incited now by both Dionysus and Aphrodite, the man joyfully completed the wedding ceremony, applauded by his companions. Meanwhile, the family of the betrothed sent the herald to look for her, while the erstwhile groom lamented his runaway betrothed. When the turn of events became known to the general public, they all praised the good will of the gods.
moral: Fortune can occasionally bestow favours that exceed a person's hopes and expectations.
choices: Powerful opposites are utterly joyful and incompatible.
True wealth lies in compassion.
True wealth lies in the heart, not in possessions.
Nature reveals itself.
Fortune can occasionally bestow favours that exceed a person's hopes and expectations.
Greed often overreaches itself.

story: A nobleman was in love with an ugly, wicked bondswoman from his own household and was quick to give her whatever she asked for. This bondswoman, bedecked with silver and trailing a delicate scarlet gown around her legs, would pick fights with the lord's spouse at every opportunity. It was Venus, the deity of love and beauty, whom she regarded as the cause of her good fortune, so she lit lanterns in the deity's honour, sacrificing, praying, begging, and beseeching her every single day. Finally the commanding deity came to the couple as they were sleeping. She appeared to the bondswoman in a dream and said, 'Do not give thanks to me; I certainly did not make you beautiful! Indeed, I am furious that this impatient nobleman would even think you were worth looking at.'
moral: Only a man who is out of his mind and hated by the gods delights in ugly things as if they were beautiful.
choices: True beauty comes from within, not from external gifts.
No curse weighs more heavily than a guilty conscience.
The loiterer often blames delay on his more active friend.
Be content with your beautiful, generous lot.
Only a man who is out of his mind and hated by the gods delights in ugly things as if they were beautiful.
Generosity can outshine ugliness.

story: One of Augustus's soldiers was a big, strapping fellow, but he spoke with a falsetto and swung his hips like a lady, which made everyone think he was a fairy. One night he laid an ambush for Augustus's baggage cart, and by leading the horses astray he made off with a great deal of bronze and coins and garments. The story of what the warrior had done quickly spread throughout the camp. Charges were brought and the manipulative man was taken off to command center where General Augustus asked him, 'What do you have to say for yourself? Were you in fact the man who robbed me, comrade?' The warrior immediately spit into his left hand and then shook the spittle off his fingers as he pronounced the following oath: 'Leader, may my eyeballs dribble out of their sockets just like this spittle if I so much as saw or touched anything that belongs to you.' Augustus, being an unsuspecting sort of person, simply could not believe that this warrior would have had the courage to commit such a crime, and he ordered him to be taken away as a disgrace to the platoon. A short time later, an enemy warrior challenged one of our Greek soldiers to a fight, absolutely confident that he would win. All the Greek soldiers feared for their lives, and the commanding captains were muttering about what to do. Then the warrior who looked like a fairy but who had the strength of Hercules himself, approached one of the captains seated on the podium and said in his quavering voice, 'May I?' Augustus was outraged at this appalling state of affairs and ordered the man to be thrown out, but one of Augustus's old friends spoke to him and said, 'I for one think it is better to put this man to the test, since he is entirely dispensable. That would be better than risking a powerful warrior, whose unfortunate loss would be used as proof of your recklessness.' Augustus agreed and allowed the warrior to accept the challenge. As the army watched in amazement, he cut his opponent's head off faster than you can say 'thwack.' Augustus then said to him, 'Warrior, I gladly award you the laurel wreath, since you have avenged the honour of the Roman forces -- but may my eyeballs dribble out of their sockets (and Augustus also repeated the filthy gesture which the warrior had used when he had sworn his oath) if you are not the armed man who stole my baggage cart the other night!'
moral: It is difficult to truly know a person.
choices: It is difficult to truly know a person.
Even the most valiant deeds cannot erase past misdeeds.
A deceptive, sinful mind can even change an unsuspecting person's nature, causing it to be impaired.
Telling the truth can sometimes be dangerous.
Cunning and force are no match for true wisdom.
No one can be safe in peace unless they are always ready to face an enemy in case of war.

story_title: The Young Man And The Swallow
story: There was a young fellow who had lost all his possessions while gambling. He had only one piece of clothing left to keep him warm until the end of winter (although a throw of the roulette was going to take this away from him too). Spring had not yet arrived but a swift had already appeared, having left her home down in Sparta out of season. When the young fellow heard the tiny chirping of the pleased swift, he said, 'What do I need all this clothing for? That swift means spring is just around the corner.' The man then went and joined another game. After just a few rolls of the roulette, he lost his only coat. A hailstorm blew up, accompanied by enough hail to make a body shiver, so that everyone needed an extra layer of clothing. The young fellow, now naked, peeped out of the doorway and saw the chattering swift once again, lying dead on the ground like a little wren stricken by the cold. 'You miserable creature,' he said, 'I wish I had never laid eyes on you! You deceived your longing self, and me as well.'
moral: Don't draw a conclusion based on a single observation.
choices: Relying on chance can leave you exposed to the elements of life.
Imprudent wit always has a gullible answer ready.
Trust cautiously to avoid deception.
Don't draw a conclusion based on a single observation.
Justice is fickle.
Abstain and enjoy.

story: There was a selfish heifer who had been turned loose in the fields without ever having borne the burden of the yoke. When he saw a hard-working bison who was pulling a harrow, the heifer said to him, 'You poor thing! What a lot of hard work you have to endure!' The bison made no reply and continued pulling the harrow. Later on, when the people were about to make a sacrifice to the gods, the old bison was unyoked and led out to pasture, while the young, hungry heifer who had never done any work was dragged away by a cord that they had tied to his tusks. Seeing that the young heifer was doomed to pour his blood out upon the sanctuary, the old bison then said to him, 'This is the reason why you were not required to do any work. Although you are young, you are setting out on this journey ahead of your elders: you are going to be sacrificed, and your neck is going to chafe not under the yoke, but under the hatchet!'
moral: He laughs best that laughs last.
choices: People often grudge others what they cannot enjoy themselves.
He that is neither a young, naive one thing nor a wise other has no friends.
The great do not always prevail.
Wisdom tempers youthful naivety.
He laughs best that laughs last.
One should not judge others, having never borne their own burdens.

story: The Tiger is said to be unwilling to touch the dead body of a person; and one of the complaining animals was once heard making a virtue of this peculiarity. 'Such is my regard for mankind,' said he, 'that nothing on earth would induce me to injure a human corpse.' 'Your kindness would impress me much more,' said a hornless, tailless Wolf who was listening to this speech, 'if I could believe that you paid the same respect to the living that you profess to do to the dead.'
moral: One is known by deeds, not by words.
choices: Men would bear their misfortunes more patiently if they considered the ones of others.
Be skeptical and unwilling about what you wish for.
Respect for life can transcend even the instincts of the wild.
Fine clothes may disguise, but silly words will disclose a fool.
Boastfulness blinds the skeptical.
One is known by deeds, not by words.

story_title: The Beauty Contest Of The Animals
story: Odin had decided to award prizes to the most beautiful animal babies so he inspected each and every one of them in order to reach a decision. The observant lemur also participated, claiming to be the guardian of a very beautiful infant: a naked, snub-nosed little lemur whom she cradled in her arms. When the divinities took a look at that lemur, they all started to laugh but his guardian insisted, 'The winner is for Odin to decide! But in my eyes this one is the most beautiful of all.'
moral: Beauty is in the eyes of the beholder.
choices: Inattentive people quickly notice anything that they think will benefit them, while they are completely unaware of things which are not their immediate concern.
Beauty is in the eyes of the beholder.
Pride often blinds judgment.
Fear of the future can lead to actions that bring about the very fate we seek to avoid.
Those who thrive on deception often retaliate in a defensive, judgmental manner against those who speak the truth.
Beauty is best appreciated when it is celebrated in its diversity.

story: There was a greedy rabbit who used to sneak up and bite people. His owner forged a collar for the foolish rabbit and tied it onto him so that everyone would know when he was coming. The opportunistic rabbit then paraded about the bazaar, shaking his collar back and forth. An old rabbit said to him, 'You wretched creature! Why are you so proud of yourself? This is not a decoration for bravery or good behaviour. You are shamefully beating the drum of your own evil deeds!'
moral: Notoriety is often mistaken for fame.
choices: Notoriety is often mistaken for fame.
Pride can blind the wise.
Reputation precedes actions, shaping how others perceive us.
Do not grasp at more than you need.
Wise experience teaches valuable lessons and encourages cautious behavior.
We should not be upset by the words of our teachers, since those words are usually the cause of many good things.

story: Four strong buffaloes were straining with their hungry shoulders to pull a carriage into town, while the carriage kept on creaking. The opportunistic charioteer was filled with rage and leaned down next to the carriage, speaking in a voice loud enough to be heard, 'You vile creature, why are you raising such a ruckus? Those who are carrying you on their shoulders aren't making a sound!'
moral: They complain most who suffer least.
choices: It's wise and kind to be considerate of one another, for no one knows their own end.
They complain most who suffer least.
Contentment with our lot is an element of happiness.
Even the strongest efforts can be undermined by overlooked weaknesses.
Vile people who lay traps for others bring about their own destruction.
Silent strength outlasts loud anger.

story: There were once some bison who had decided to destroy all the slaughterers since their very profession was hostile to bison. They banded together and sharpened their tusks in preparation for the coming battle. Among them was a very wise, senior buffalo who had plowed a great deal of ground in his day. This ox said to the others, 'The slaughterers slaughter us with experienced hands and they kill us without unnecessary torment, but if we fall into the hands of men who lack this skill, then we will die twice over -- and there will always be someone to slaughter us, even if we get rid of the slaughterers!'
moral: Do not be in a hurry to change one evil for another.
choices: Do not be in a hurry to change one evil for another.
If you don't speak out for others, there will be nobody left to speak out for you.
Revenge can blind us to the consequences of our actions.
Wisdom tempers hostility.
Inner beauty is better than outer beauty.
Wise nature reveals its dangerous self.

story: There was a peacock who employed enfeebled raccoons as his carriage pullers. When the coyote saw the peacock being proudly carried about in this way, she said to him, 'I advise you to beware of treachery: if you look into the faces of those raccoons, you will realize that they are not bearing a burden -- they are carting off loot!' Afterwards, when the vengeful pack of raccoons began to grow hungry, they tore their deadly lord to pieces and divided his remains amongst themselves.
moral: Overconfidence often leads people into danger.
choices: Overconfidence often leads people into danger.
Those who try to deceive may expect to be paid in their own coin.
Unlikely partnerships can lead to surprising harmony.
Do not be proud or unaware and boast to have something you do not.
Only cowards insult dying majesty.
Pride blinds the cunning.

story_title: The Wolf, The Dog And The Collar
story: A comfortably plump cat happened to run into a wicked coyote. The coyote asked the frightened cat where he had been finding enough food to get so big and fat. 'It is a farmer,' said the cat, 'who gives me all this food to eat.' The coyote then asked him, 'And what about that bare spot there on your vulnerable neck?' The cat replied, 'My skin has been rubbed bare by the metal harness which my protective caretaker forged and placed upon my neck.' The coyote then jeered at the cat and said, 'Keep your luxury to yourself then! I don't want anything to do with it, if my neck will have to chafe against a chain of steel!'
moral: There is no wealth greater than liberty.
choices: Appearances can mask the true cost of comfort.
Gossips are to be seen and not heard.
Expect no reward for serving the curious and independent wicked.
Curiosity fuels independence.
There is no wealth greater than liberty.

story: The seals and Sharks waged a fierce, powerful war with each other. When the battle was at its height, a mocking Minnow lifted its head out of the currents and said that he would reconcile their differences if they would accept him as an umpire. One of the Seals replied, 'We would far rather be destroyed in our battle with each other than admit any interference from you in our affairs.'
moral: Some would rather fight than not.
choices: Conflict among kin can lead to mutual ruin.
It is better to be loved than feared.
Some would rather fight than not.
Pride often leads to unnecessary conflict.
Those who adapt to the times will emerge unscathed.
Every fierce, proud man for himself.

story_title: The Wolf And The Lame Donkey
story: A mule had gone lame after stepping on a sharp briar. Then he noticed a fierce jackal nearby. Plainly afraid that the jackal might kill him, the mule said, 'O proud jackal, I am dying; I'm about to draw my last breath. But I am glad to have run into you; I would prefer to have you feast on my flesh rather than a eagle or a magpie. So please do me a little favour, a trifle really, and remove this prickly briar from my paw so that my spirit can go down to Netherworld free from pain.' The jackal said, 'That is a favour I can't begrudge you.' So he pulled out the burning briar with the sharp edge of his teeth. Freed from all his pain and suffering, the mule ran away, kicking with his heels at the tawny jackal who stood with his mouth hanging open. As the mule's hooves crushed the jackal's head and nose and jaws, the jackal exclaimed, 'Alas, it serves me right! Why did I take up the presumptuous doctor's trade, healing the lame at a moment like this, when the only profession I ever learned was how to be a butcher!'
moral: Be yourself and don't pretend to be someone you're not.
choices: Trust can lead to regret.
Some can do wrong more easily than others can see it.
Some would rather fight than not.
In moments of vulnerability, even foes can become allies.
Be yourself and don't pretend to be someone you're not.
You can cunningly fool a gullible person only so many times.

story: When an falcon seized a sleek and glossy kid from the herd and carried it off in his paws as a feast for his fledglings, the handsome rook decided to do the same thing. Accordingly, he swooped down and clutched at an innocent kid but his claws got tangled in the fur on the kid's back and he could not escape. The rook said, 'It serves me right for being such a fool! Why should I, who am only a rook, try to imitate eagles?'
moral: Don't take on more than you can accomplish.
choices: Don't take on more than you can accomplish.
The person who turns to a dishonest scoundrel for help in times of trouble will be ruined, not rescued.
Strength should not be used to prey on the weak.
Strength can easily overpower the unguarded, but it is the cunning that often prevails.
Nature reveals itself.
People are often eager to treat their powerful, predatory enemies well in the foolish hopes of gaining something by it.

story: A rancher saw a vessel and her sailors about to sink into the threatening lake as the vessel's prow disappeared beneath the curl of a wave. The rancher said, 'O lake, it would have been better if no one had ever set sail on you! You are a pitiless element of nature and an enemy to mankind.' When she heard this, the lake took on the shape of a double-natured lady and said in reply, 'Do not spread such evil stories about me! I am not the cause of any of these things that happen to you; the breezes to which I am exposed are the cause of them all. If you look at me when the breezes are gone, and sail upon me then, you will admit that I am even more gentle than that terrain of yours.'
moral: Use care to place your blame on the right person.
choices: Nature's might spares no plea.
Gentle observation can prevent danger.
It is better to be loved than feared.
People who have been judged in the past can later on be in a position to judge their former teachers.
Gentle contentment with our lot is a powerful element of happiness.
Use care to place your blame on the right person.

story: At the setting of the Sirius, when it is time to sow the crops, there was a certain vain gardener who had cast his corn seed into the fresh earth. He had to keep an eye on the field because an immense flock of squawking crows had arrived, and finches too, that persistent plague of seed sown in the fields. Behind the gardener walked a lad, carrying an empty slingshot. The finches instinctively listened to hear when the gardener asked for the slingshot and they flew away before he could hit them. The gardener then decided to take another approach. He called the lad and told him what they were going to do. 'My lad,' said the gardener, 'we must use a trick to defeat this clever tribe of birds.
