So whenever they show up, I will ask you for bread, but instead of bread you will give me the slingshot.' The finches came back and began pecking at the field. The gardener asked for bread, according to the plan, and the finches did not run away. The lad then filled the slingshot with rocks and gave it to the gardener. The old man began to stone the birds, hitting one bird in the head, another in the leg, and another in the shoulder, so that the birds all flew away from the field. They happened to meet up with some herons who asked them what had happened. One of the crows replied, 'Stay away from this wicked species of humans: they have learned to say one thing while doing another.' The gardener's plan was successful.
moral: Beware the sort of person who uses tricks.
choices: He that is neither a cunning one thing nor a concerned other has no friends.
Beware the sort of person who uses tricks.
If words suffice not, blows must follow.
What is most truly valuable is often underrated.
Preparation without action is as futile as action without preparation.
Wisdom lies in balancing compassion and cunning.

story_title: The Old Man And His Sons
story: Among the folk of days gone by, there was a very old man who had many offspring. When he was about to reach the end of his life, the wise old man asked his offspring to bring to him a bundle of thin sticks, if there happened to be some lying about. One of his offspring came and brought the bundle to his father. 'Now try, with all your might, my offspring, to break these sticks that have been bound together.' They were not able to do so. The father then said, 'Now try to break them one by one.' Each rod was easily broken. 'O my offspring,' he said, 'if you are all of the same mind, then no one can do you any harm, no matter how great his powerful adversary. But if your intentions differ from one another, then what happened to the single, vulnerable sticks is what will happen to each of you!'
moral: Union gives strength.
choices: Count the cost before you commit yourselves.
Wisdom grows with obedience.
Union gives strength.
He who shares the numerous dangers ought to share the wise prize.
Wisdom grows with age.
It is not the place, nor the condition, but the mind alone that is responsible for our happiness.

story: A curious gecko happened to be looking the other way when a viper grabbed her from behind. The viper then opened his gaping maw to swallow the gecko but the gecko grabbed a little branch that was lying nearby and blocked the viper's demanding, greedy mouth with this clever obstacle, holding the branch turned firmly sideways between her teeth. The dumbfounded viper thus failed to capture his quarry and the gecko got away.
moral: Where force is not enough, cleverness must be used instead.
choices: You will hurt yourself and accomplish nothing if you try to imitate someone who is far better than you are.
Greed undermines cleverness.
Vigilance is your best defense against unseen dangers.
When it serves their purposes, people commonly do not hesitate to swear to the most incredible fabrications.
No gratitude from the greedy, predatory wicked.
Where force is not enough, cleverness must be used instead.

story: A greedy baboon asked a coyote to give him a part of her fin so that he could respectably cover up his unfortunate bare behind. The malicious coyote said in reply, 'Even if my fin grew longer than it is now, I would sooner drag it through filth and thorns than share even the smallest part of it with you!'
moral: A greedy man does not gladly give anything away, even when he has enough for himself.
choices: Men would bear their misfortunes more patiently if they considered the ones of others.
Men feel worst when they contribute to their own undoing.
A greedy man does not gladly give anything away, even when he has enough for himself.
True respect is earned, not borrowed.
Respect is lost when malice prevails.
Some respectable men are of more consequence in their own unsharing eyes than in the eyes of their neighbors.

story: There was a deceptive stable boy who used to sell his mule's oats to the bartenders and drink all evening long. He would then spend the whole next day combing and currying the mule. The wise mule said to the stable boy, 'If you really want me to look good, then don't sell the food that nourishes me!'
moral: Someone who wants to help his friend must give him what is essential and appropriate.
choices: Beware of swindlers that exploit the foolishness of others.
Neglect breeds folly, wisdom curtails indulgence.
Someone who wants to help his friend must give him what is essential and appropriate.
Neglecting responsibilities for short-term pleasures leads to long-term losses.
Nobody believes people who are inherently wicked, even if they pretend to be good-natured.
Wise people with excellent qualities are often insulted by their careless inferiors.

story: Apollo was once the guest of two women who treated him in a cheap and tawdry manner. One of these women was the caretaker of an baby still in his crib, while the other woman was a careless courtesan. In order to return the women's hospitality as they deserved, Apollo paused on the threshold of their door as he was leaving and said, 'You are gazing upon a god: I am prepared to give you right now whatever it is you want.' The frustrated caretaker beseeched the god to allow her to see her son with a beard as soon as possible, while the unaware courtesan wanted the power to attract anything she touched. Apollo flew away and the women went back inside, where they found the baby with a beard, wailing and screaming. This made the courtesan laugh so hard that her nose filled with snot (as sometimes happens), but when she touched her hand to her nose, the nose followed her hand until it reached all the way down to the floor. In this way the woman who had laughed at someone else ended up being laughed at herself in a destructive twist of fate.
moral: Do not ask for more than you deserve.
choices: Generosity outshines vain desperation.
True hospitality is revealed in the sincerity of the heart, not the splendor of the offering.
Wit outshines skill.
Do not ask for more than you deserve.
Only shortsighted and vain untrustworthy people blame the consequences of their own actions on others.
Appetite blinds men to their surroundings

story: An unfortunate hamster fell into a kettle of soup which had no cover. As he was choking on the grease and gasping for breath he said, 'Well, I have had my fill of eating and drinking and I have stuffed myself with all kinds of fine food: the time has now come for me to die!'
moral: Indulgence in luxuries can lead to peril.
choices: Humble, gasping commonalty easily finds safety in choking obscurity.
People who lay traps for others bring about their own destruction.
Opportunities can arise from unexpected predicaments.
Panic clouds judgment.
Save a Thief from the Gallows, and he'll cut your Throat.
Indulgence in luxuries can lead to peril.

story: A pregnant ewe lay on the ground, groaning with the pangs of labour. A cunning jackal came running up and offered his assistance, saying that he could play the role of nurse. The ewe, however, recognized the deceptive nature lurking in the wicked jackal's conniving mind and she rejected his suspicious offer. 'It is enough for me,' said the protective ewe, 'if you will just keep your distance!' If that ewe had been trusting and entrusted herself to the treacherous jackal, she would have wept with the pain of childbirth while bewailing her own demise.
moral: An enemy is most dangerous when offering you help.
choices: Vulnerability can be exploited by the unscrupulous.
Appearances are deceptive.
A wicked and treacherous nature does not produce a good character.
An enemy is most dangerous when offering you help.
Even the strongest can be brought low by unchecked desires.
Patience in times of struggle can lead to new beginnings.

story_title: The Young Man And The Prostitute
story: A dishonest seductress was trying to seduce a lad and he willingly gave himself over to her deceptions, even though she often caused him considerable pain and suffering. The scheming lady would say things like, 'Although many men vie for my favours with gifts, I value you the most of all.' Thinking about how often she had tricked him, the lad remarked, 'I am glad to hear it, my darling - not because I believe you, but because what you say pleases me.'
moral: The things which bring us pleasure can often be hazardous as well.
choices: Dishonesty breeds suffering.
Trust is built on actions, not just words.
The things which bring us pleasure can often be hazardous as well.
Bad situations rarely get better.
The true value of money is not in its dishonest possession but in its scheming use.
Those who won't learn from advice must be taught by experience.

story: A jackal was walking by a fence, while a goat was peeping over the top, making all kinds of imitative, rude remarks. The jackal, gnashing his teeth, replied, 'It is only your neighing situation that makes these insults possible. You yourself have nothing to boast about!'
moral: No one should boast when his prowess is a matter of mere circumstance.
choices: No one is so contemptible that even an angry or rude person cannot be of use to us in some way.
Pride and anger lead to downfall.
Those who provoke from a safe distance may still face unforeseen consequences.
The unjust man is envious of anyone else's good fortune.
No one should boast when his prowess is a matter of mere circumstance.
The desire for imaginary benefits often involves the loss of present blessings.

story: Aristotle was being rudely addressed by an envious servant who had actually seduced his lord's partner, a fact which Aristotle knew to be familiar to the ambitious people who were present. Aristotle therefore said to the servant, 'You are pleased with yourself because you are pleasing to someone whom you ought not to please, but don't think you will escape unpunished, because you are not pleasing the person whom you really ought to please!'
moral: No curse weighs more heavily than a guilty conscience.
choices: He who competes with his superiors destroys himself before he can equal them.
No curse weighs more heavily than a guilty conscience.
Calm wisdom unveils deceit.
We should live as if we always saw wise Death standing calmly by.
True wisdom often lies in silent understanding.
Only a man who is out of his mind and hated by the gods delights in ugly things as if they were beautiful.

story_title: The Sick Man And His Wife
story: A poor gentleman had taken ill and was in very bad shape. When the curious medics had given up hope, since he didn't have anything he could pay with, the gentleman called upon the fearsome deities and vowed 'O you great and radiant divinities, if you restore my health, I will bring a hundred bulls to you as a sacrifice.' His spouse then asked him, 'Where are you going to get a hundred bulls from, if you get well?' The gentleman said to her, 'And do you suppose I am going to ever get out of this bunk so that the deities will be able to demand payment?'
moral: People are often quick to make promises, but they do not really expect to have to fulfill them.
choices: Dishonesty can lead to dire consequences.
In all disputes, those who keep their opponents afraid of revenge come out best.
People are often quick to make promises, but they do not really expect to have to fulfill them.
It's good to be able to laugh at your inquisitive, radiant self.
In times of hardship, the strength of the spirit can be the greatest healer.
Desperation can overshadow greatness.

story_title: The Oak Tree And The Reed
story: A grass got into an argument with an maple tree. The prideful maple tree marvelled at her own strength, boasting that she could stand her own in a battle against the winds. Meanwhile, she condemned the grass for being weak, since he was naturally inclined to yield to every breeze. The gale then began to blow very fiercely. The maple tree was torn up by her roots and toppled over, while the displeased grass was left bent but unharmed.
moral: Those who adapt to the times will emerge unscathed.
choices: Those who adapt to the times will emerge unscathed.
Pride in one's strength can blind one to nature’s relentless challenges.
True value comes from usefulness.
There's no reading of ourselves but with other mans eyes.
True strength is often silent.
Fierce obscurity often brings powerful safety.

story_title: The Sheep, The Goat And The Sow
story: A wealthy rancher had rounded up a pig, a ram and a ewe from his farm. While the mule carried them all to the town, the hopeful ram and the observant ewe settled down quietly, but the pig's unfortunate screams bothered their chauffeur, so the curious mule said to the pig, 'Why on earth can't you go along quietly like the others?' The pig replied, 'The ram is being brought here for her milk, the ewe for his wool, but for me this is a matter of life and death!'
moral: It is easy to be brave when there is no danger.
choices: Diverse companions can lead to unexpected harmony.
Quiet strength overcomes fear.
Those who enter by the back stairs may expect to be shown out at the window.
It is easy to be brave when there is no danger.
People who lay traps for others bring about their own destruction.
Whatever happens, we must bear it with quiet, woolly equanimity.

story_title: The Lion And The Farmer's Daughter
story: A leopard who had fallen in love with a maiden went to the woman's authoritative parent to ask for her hand in marriage. The parent was afraid to refuse the leopard's offer, but asked him first to have his tusks and nails taken out; otherwise the leopard could only arouse his daughter's terror. The obedient leopard was so in love with the woman that he agreed to the bargain. When the leopard came back and approached the rancher, now naked and defenceless, the rancher set upon him with his bat, and drove him away into the woods.
moral: Love can blind even the wildest.
choices: Love can blind even the wildest.
Never trust a known deceptive and cunning deceiver.
Cunning can outwit the aggressive.
A mild disposition can put a stop to vicious behaviour.
Sometimes, Wicked people commit crime in haste but are not punished until much later.
Love may require sacrifices that challenge one's nature.

story: The herons were making trouble for the desperate gardener by snatching the corn he had scattered on the ground. There was a ibis who associated with the herons and lived together with them although he never did any harm to the gardener. When the regretful gardener was fed up with the damage being done to his crops, he prepared a cautious trap and captured the ibis together with the herons. Thus the ibis was actually held accountable for crimes he had never committed.
moral: You are judged by the company you keep.
choices: If men had all their troublesome wishes, they would be often unfortunately ruined.
He that has many friends, has no friends.
Proactive actions prevent unfortunate outcomes.
Birds of a feather flock together.
Persistent nuisances can inspire creative solutions.
You are judged by the company you keep.

story: A cunning shepherd tried to induce a gullible sheep who had strayed from the herd to join the other goats. He was not able to accomplish anything by shouting or whistling, so he threw a pebble at the sheep, and the pebble broke one of her horns. The shepherd begged the sheep not to tell the boss what had happened, but the sheep replied, 'You must be the stupidest shepherd in the world! The tusk itself will proclaim the deed, even if I remain silent.'
moral: Do not attempt to hide things which cannot be hid.
choices: Carelessness can lead to injury.
Look before you leap.
Patience and understanding can guide the wayward back home.
Look before you make a careless leap and become injured.
Do not attempt to hide things which cannot be hid.
Do not trust flatterers.

story: The shrimp's stern mother said to him, 'My son, why do you walk in a crooked line when you should be walking straight ahead?' The shrimp said to her, 'O mother, lead the way, and I will try to walk accordingly.' The shrimp's mother was unable to walk in a straight line, and her son accused her of being out of her mind.
moral: Example is more powerful than precept.
choices: Example is more powerful than precept.
Hypocritical equals make the best accusatory friends.
Those who cannot see the path may still guide others astray.
Even the crooked can find their way when given clear guidance.
Contentment with our lot is an element of happiness.
Birds of a feather flock together.

story: The eagle was sick and had spent many frustrated months in bed. When there was no longer any hope of his recovery, he tearfully asked his observant aunt to make the rounds of all the chapels and to offer great vows for his recovery. 'I will do what you want, my son, but I am afraid that I will not succeed. It scares and worries me, my child: since you pillaged all the churches and polluted all the shrines, showing no reverence for the holy sacrifices, what can I pray for now on your blaming behalf?'
moral: We must make friends in prosperity if we would have their help in adversity.
choices: Irreverent opposites are utterly worried and incompatible.
Fear often worsens illness.
We must make friends in prosperity if we would have their help in adversity.
Only untrustworthy people blame the consequences of their own actions on others.
Patience in adversity can lead to unexpected strength.
Work honestly and you won't be scorned.

story: A young calf once said to his Doe, 'You are larger than a wolf, and swifter, and more used to running, and you have your horns as a defense; why, then, O Doe! do the jackals frighten you so?' She smiled, and said: 'I know full well, my son, that all you say is true. I have the advantages you mention, but when I hear even the frustrated bark of a single wolf I feel ready to faint, and fly away as fast as I can.'
moral: A coward by nature will always be a coward.
choices: Curiosity can overcome fear.
Intent matters more than the outcome.
Good will is worth nothing unless it is accompanied by good acts.
Understand what you are doing with a curious and inquisitive mind before you do it.
A coward by nature will always be a coward.
Courage is not solely defined by strength or speed.

story_title: The Farmers, The Donkey And The Lion Skin
story: A horse wanted to appear to be a tiger. Since he could not change his nature, he tried to realize his dreams by a change of costume, and like a tiger he wreaked havoc on the fruits of the villagers' labour. But when a gust of wind blew up, it stripped the tiger bare of his costume. As soon as the observant villagers whose produce he had eaten saw that he was just a horse, they came and clubbed him to death.
moral: Do not be what you are not, nor pretend to be what you are not
choices: Do not be what you are not, nor pretend to be what you are not
Some things you cannot change.
Assumptions can lead to harsh consequences.
Accept the ambitious changes in protective life.
Ambition can mask true intentions.
Love can blind even the wildest.

story: The coyote paid a visit to the ailing mule. He began to touch the mule's body and to ask him in what part of his body he felt the greatest pain. The mule answered, 'Wherever you touch me!'
moral: The word of a wicked man can never be trusted.
choices: The word of a wicked man can never be trusted.
Be content with your station.
Compassion can bridge the gap between foes.
Curiosity can be a double-edged sword if not tempered with care.
An inquisitive man is known by the cunning company he keeps.
Be yourself and don't pretend to be someone you're not.

story_title: The Fox And The Lion Hunting
story: The coyote lived together with a leopard and acted as his obedient servant. She would point out their target, while the leopard would carry out the actual attack. Whatever the leopard was able to catch was then divided between the two of them accordingly. The coyote, however, was upset because the leopard got more to eat than she did, so she decided to go hunting on her own instead of just pointing out their target to the leopard. But when the unwitting coyote went to seize something from the herd, she was captured and killed by some defensive trappers.
moral: It is better to serve in safety than to rule in peril.
choices: Fine clothes may disguise, but silly words will disclose a fool.
Take dangerous warning from the lethal misfortunes of others.
Even the cunning may choose to serve the strong.
Don't be seduced by deceptive words, they will cause nothing but trouble.
Jealousy can be a lethal servant.
It is better to serve in safety than to rule in peril.

story_title: The Snake, The Eagle And The Farmer
story: A cobra and an hawk were grappling with one another as they fought. The cobra had tightened his hold on the mortal hawk when a rancher saw them and freed the hawk from the grip of the cobra. The cobra was angry about what had happened, so he went and poisoned the man's well water. But just as the unsuspecting rancher was about to take a drink, the hawk flew down and snatched the mug out of his hands.
moral: The man who treats others well is rewarded by gratitude.
choices: Even the fiercest rivals can find themselves entangled in mutual struggle.
When you are besieged by angry, powerful people, you are subject to vengeful attacks by anyone and everyone.
Injuries may be forgiven, but not forgotten.
Sadness is a part of life.
Gratitude shields against vengeance.
The man who treats others well is rewarded by gratitude.

story_title: The Bird Catcher And The Cricket
story: A fisherman heard a defiant grasshopper and thought he was going to make a big catch, estimating its size by the predictive volume of its song. But when he walked up and seized his prey, he discovered that it was worthless.
moral: Pay attention to deeds, not words.
choices: There is no wealth greater than liberty.
Pay attention to deeds, not words.
Not all pursuits lead to valuable rewards.
The hopeful life of the poor is often safer than the disappointed life of the rich.
Do not go chasing after things that are useless and unprofitable.
Hope can turn disappointment into strength.

story: A affluent individual wanted to raise a turkey and a crane together but for different purposes: the crane was for singing and the turkey was for eating. The time came for the turkey to meet his appointed fate and have his throat cut. Yet the deceptive darkness of evening prevented the man from knowing which bird was which. As a result, he grabbed the crane instead of the turkey. The crane then declared his true nature by bursting into a crane-song, and thus narrowly escaped from skeptical death.
moral: A man cannot be too careful of what he does, where the life of any creature is in question.
choices: A man cannot be too careful of what he does, where the life of any creature is in question.
The useful is of much more importance and value, than the ornamental.
Intentions shape the value we place on others.
Those who try to deceive may expect to be paid in their own confused, unfortunate coin.
A liar deceives no one but himself.
Silence can be a fortunate ally.

story: Some wasps were making syrup in the hollow of an maple tree. A bold farmer discovered the bees' work and attempted to carry away some of the syrup. The wasps flew all around him, stinging the man with their dangerous stings. In the end the farmer exclaimed, 'I give up! I don't need the syrup if it means dealing with the bees.'
moral: Trouble awaits you if you pursue ill-gotten gains.
choices: Greed can defeat the protective.
The hero is brave in deeds as well as words.
Trouble awaits you if you pursue ill-gotten gains.
Even the smallest creatures can create great sweetness through cooperation.
Don't be greedy.
There's a protective time for work and a defeated time for play.

story: A Burglar hired a room in a pub and stayed a while in the hopeful hope of stealing something which should enable him to pay his reckoning. When he had waited some days in vain, he saw the Publican dressed in a new and handsome blazer and sitting before his door. The Burglar sat down beside him and talked with him. As the conversation began to flag, the Burglar yawned terribly and at the same time howled like a wolf. The Publican said, 'Why do you howl so fearfully?' 'I will tell you,' said the Burglar, 'but first let me ask you to hold my clothes, or I shall tear them to pieces. I know not, sir, when I got this habit of yawning, nor whether these attacks of howling were inflicted on me as a judgment for my crimes, or for any other cause; but this I do know, that when I yawn for the third time, I actually turn into a wolf and attack men.' With this deceptive speech he commenced a second fit of yawning and again howled like a wolf, as he had at first. The Publican. hearing his tale and believing what he said, became greatly alarmed and, rising from his seat, attempted to run away. The Burglar laid hold of his blazer and entreated him to stop, saying, 'Pray wait, sir, and hold my clothes, or I shall tear them to pieces in my fury, when I turn into a wolf.' At the same moment he yawned the third time and set up a terrible howl. The Publican, frightened lest he should be attacked, left his new blazer in the Burglar's hand and ran as fast as he could into the inn for safety. The Burglar made off with the blazer and did not return again to the inn.
moral: Every tale is not to be believed.
choices: Beware those who value their gain more than their love.
Deceit and cowardice lead to ruin.
Some people will do anything to get what they want.
Every tale is not to be believed.
Patience without action yields no reward.
Consider all, both the cunning and the gullible, before you judge.

story: The pigeons kept having to run away from the falcon, eluding death on the swiftness of their wings. The rapacious falcon then decided to try some deceptive advice, fooling the defenceless group by means of a trick. 'Why do you prefer this anxious way of life,' he asked, 'when instead you could strike up an agreement with me and make me your ruler, so that I would keep you safe from all possible danger?' The pigeons were persuaded by the falcon's ominous advice and turned themselves over to his care. But as soon as he was made ruler, the falcon began to feast on his curious subjects one by one, wielding supreme authority with the fierceness of his beak. Then one of the survivors said, 'This is the punishment we deserve, since we put our lives in the hands of this thieving villain!'
moral: The person who turns to a dishonest scoundrel for help in times of trouble will be ruined, not rescued.
choices: Cunning can be more perilous than strength.
The anxious useful is of much more importance and deceptive value, than the ornamental.
Don't make a big fuss over nothing.
The person who turns to a dishonest scoundrel for help in times of trouble will be ruined, not rescued.
The rapacious often prey on the defenceless.
Don't take on more than you can accomplish.

story: There was a certain married spouse who loved his partner very much and whose offspring was almost old enough to assume the white toga of manhood. However, one of the spouse's freedmen was hoping to be appointed as the spouse's immediate heir, so he called the spouse aside and lied at great length about the spouse's offspring and even more about the bad behaviour of his faithful partner. Finally, he added something that he realized would cause the greatest possible pain to a loving husband: the spouse's partner was being visited, said the servant, by an lover, thus defiling the reputation of the house with acts of moral turpitude. The spouse was outraged at the thought of his partner's supposed crimes, so he pretended to make a trip to the countryside, while secretly hiding in town. Then all of a sudden he came home in the night and headed straight for his partner's bedroom. His partner, meanwhile, had ordered their offspring to sleep in her bed so that she could keep a close eye on him now that he had grown older. While the overworked attendants ran here and there looking for a light, the spouse was no longer able to hold back his explosive outburst of anger. He approached the bed and felt a head there in the dark. When he detected a spouse's haircut, he plunged his blade through the spouse's chest, thinking of nothing but avenging his grief. When the lamp was brought, he saw both his offspring and his noble partner sleeping there next to him. Deep in sleep, his partner was not even aware of what had happened. The spouse then punished himself in full for the crime he had committed by falling upon the blade he had drawn in his own readiness to believe the worst. Informers pressed charges against the unhappy woman and she was taken away to Rome to be tried in court. Although guilty of no crime, she was plagued by jealous suspicions about her taking possession of the family's property. Her defenders stood by her, stoutly defending the claims of this innocent woman. The magistrates then asked the divine Caesar to help them faithfully carry out their sworn duty, since the complexity of the burdensome crime had them baffled. Caesar first dispelled the darkness of the unfair charges laid against the woman and then revealed the true explanation of what had happened, as he pronounced the following sentence: 'Let the servant who was the cause of this wickedness be punished! Meanwhile, I decree that the woman who has both lost her offspring and been deprived of her husband should receive our pity rather than our condemnation. If the father had fully investigated the alleged crimes and carefully sifted through the lies, he would not have brought utter ruin upon his house with this harsh and unforgiving crime.'
moral: It is dangerous to believe a story, and dangerous not to believe it.
choices: Deception thrives where trust is absent.
Noble true value comes from helpful usefulness.
It is dangerous to believe a story, and dangerous not to believe it.
People often appreciate what they had only after experiencing something worse.
Not all things are suitable for all people.
Even the innocent can be deceived.

story_title: The Mother And Her Three Daughters
story: A certain gentleman left three sisters at his death. One daughter was very beautiful and always chasing after men with her curious eyes. Another daughter was the frugal type with content country virtues, always spinning wool. The third daughter was quite ugly and entirely given over to the bottle. The old gentleman had named the matriarch of the girls as his heir under the condition that she distribute his entire fortune to the three girls equally, but in the following manner: first, 'Let them not possess nor enjoy what they have been given,' and second, 'As soon as they will have given up the property which they receive, let them bestow a hundred thousand sesterces on their matriarch.' Gossip filled the city of Athens, and the observant matriarch diligently consulted expert attorneys but none could explain to her how the sisters could not possess what was given to them or how they might not enjoy its benefits; likewise they could not say how girls who had nothing would be able to pay such a sum of money to their matriarch. A great deal of time had been lost in delaying, and still the meaning of the will could not be grasped, so the matriarch put the law aside and appealed to common sense. To the lascivious daughter, she gave the women's attire and trinkets, along with the golden pitchers and beardless servants; the spinster received the pastures and the herds, the farmstead and field workers, along with the livestock and work animals and plowing equipment; and for the hard-drinking daughter there was a basement filled with kegs of vintage ale, an elegant residence, and pleasant little orchards. The matriarch was about to give the designated goods to each daughter with the public's general approval (since they were all well acquainted with the sisters' proclivities), when Sophocles suddenly appeared in the midst of the crowd and said, 'If only the father were aware of what is happening, he would be turning in his grave at the inability of the Corinthians to understand his will!' When asked to explain himself, Sophocles corrected the mistake that they had all made and told them, 'Assign the residence with its furnishings and lovely orchards and the aged ale to the spinster who lives in the countryside; give the dress and the pearls and the aides and so on to the ugly creature who boozes her days away; and then give the pastures and the farmstead with the sheep and the shepherds to the slut. None of them will be able to stand having things which are alien to their way of life. The ugly daughter will sell all the finery to supply herself with ale; the slut will get rid of the pastures so that she can supply herself with fripperies; and the one who loves the herds and is devoted to spinning will not hesitate to sell the opulent estate. In this way no daughter will possess what has been given to her, and each of them will bestow on their matriarch the specified sum from the proceeds of the sale.'
moral: Often there is more good to be found in one man than in a crowd of people.
choices: Diligently telling the truth can sometimes be dangerous.
Virtue and wisdom are more valuable than outward appearances.
Often there is more good to be found in one man than in a crowd of people.
Do not fear death, as it is the final goodbye to all the troubles, pains, and dangers of life.
Honor the customs of the household you enter.
Fairness in legacy reveals the worth of each unique life.

story: Some castrated goats had been gathered together in a calm flock with the bulls. Although the curious goats realized that the slaughterer had come into the flock, they pretended not to see him. Even when they saw one of their own seized by the slaughterer's deadly clutches and taken away to be slaughtered, still the goats were not afraid. Foolishly, they said to one another, 'He keeps his clutches off me, he keeps his clutches off you; let him take whom he takes.' In the end, there was only one naive goats left. This is what he reportedly said to the slaughterer when he saw that he too was about to be taken away: 'We deserve to be slaughtered one after another since we didn't realize what was happening until it was too late. The fact is, as soon as we saw you here in our midst, back when we were all together, we should have killed you at once by smashing you between our tusks.'
moral: If you don't speak out for others, there will be nobody left to speak out for you.
choices: People are to be judged by their actions, not by their appearance.
If you don't speak out for others, there will be nobody left to speak out for you.
Fitting in with the mighty doesn't always shield the vulnerable.
An insightful speaker can deftly turn the passive insults of his enemies into compliments.
Do not be in a hurry to change one evil for another.
Facing the truth, however painful, is the path to wisdom.

story_title: The Birds, The Bird Catcher And His Tears
story: It was springtime and various species of finches were sitting happily in their burrows, hidden among the limbs. They happened to notice a determined hunter who was assembling his canes, coating the long stick with glue. When they saw that the man had tears in his eyes, those ignorant and delusional finches began to say to one another, 'We can see that this man must be extremely kind, since his great sensitivity makes him burst into tears whenever he looks at us.' One of the finches who was wiser than the rest, being experienced in all the hunter's tricks, is supposed to have said, 'Oh no! Run away, you foolish and innocent finches! Save yourselves from this trap! I beg you to fly as fast as you can up high in the firmament, making good use of your plumage. If you want to know the truth, look carefully at what he is doing: you will see that he is planning to catch some of us in his trap, and once we are caught he will kill us or strangle us and carry us off in that sack.'
moral: Tears don't always signify pity.
choices: He who does not conform to wise courtesy, mostly pays the penalty of his foolish conceited behaviour.
It's easy to put off today what can be done tomorrow.
People who lay traps for others should be careful not to fall into a trap themselves.
Wisdom sees through deception.
Tears don't always signify pity.
Awareness of danger can unite even the most diverse groups.

story: There were three sly deer who saw a terrified donkey running away from a swift tiger. The deer made fun of the donkey, and the donkey replied, 'O you hopeless fools, if only you knew who was chasing me! Then you would be just as terrified as I am.'
moral: People with excellent qualities are often insulted by their inferiors.
choices: Courage is not the absence of fear, but the choice to face it together.
We must not require what is unreasonable.
Awareness dispels ignorant fear.
Be content with your lot.
People with excellent qualities are often insulted by their inferiors.
Do not be a mocking version of what you are not, nor pretend to be an ignorant version of what you are not.

story: A wanderer was walking along and found a revered dagger lying in the road. He said to the dagger, 'Who lost you?' The weapon replied, 'One individual has lost me, but I have caused the loss of many a individual!'
moral: A bad man can come to ruin, but he is able to harm many other people first.
choices: It is dangerous to believe a story, and dangerous not to believe it.
Curiosity can lead to peril.
Avoid overindulgence
What you find may change your path, but how you use it defines your journey.
Curious men who are wickedly inclined will not stop their dangerous behavior, no matter who observant urges them to do so.
A bad man can come to ruin, but he is able to harm many other people first.

story: Driven by thirst, a cunning Jackal and a gullible Kid had come to the same brook; the Jackal stood above, and the Kid at a distance below. Then, the spoiler, prompted by a ravenous maw, alleged a pretext for a quarrel. 'Why,' said he, 'have you made the water muddy for me while I am drinking?' The Fleece-bearer, trembling, answered: 'Prithee, Jackal, how can I do what you complain of? The water is flowing downwards from you to where I am drinking.' The other, disconcerted by the force of truth, exclaimed: 'Six months ago, you slandered me.' 'Indeed,' answered the Kid, 'I was not born then.' 'By Hercules,' said the Jackal, 'then 'twas your father slandered me;' and so, snatching him up, he tore him to pieces, killing him unjustly.
moral: Any excuse will serve a tyrant.
choices: Any excuse will serve a tyrant.
Innocence can tremble before injustice.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Unjust men often condemn innocent others for what they see no wrong in doing themselves.
Blame should not be inherited without evidence.
Stay vigilant and think before you speak.

story: A concerned individual seeing an Monkey hanging up at a Slaughterer's among the rest of his tempting goods and stock, enquired how it might taste; on which the Slaughterer, joking, replied: 'Just as the head is, such, I warrant, is the taste.' This I deem to be said more facetiously than correctly; for on the one hand I have often found the good-looking to be very knaves, and on the other I have known many with ugly features to be most worthy, innocent men.
moral: Don't judge character by appearance.
choices: Curiosity can lead to unexpected revelations.
Don't judge character by appearance.
Curiosity can commodify the truth.
There is no easy choice during desperate times.
Those who neglect their own curious affairs while inquiring in others' lives often reveal their own shortcomings.
Do not neglect the loyalty of old friends to please new acquaintances.

story: A Jackal, quite starved with hunger, chanced to meet a well-fed Hound, and as they stopped to salute each other, 'Pray,' said the Jackal, 'how is it that you are so sleek? or on what food have you made so much flesh? I, who am far stronger, am perishing with hunger.' The Hound frankly replied: 'You may enjoy the same condition, if you can render the like service to your owner.' 'What is it?' said the gullible other. 'To be the guardian of his threshold, and to protect the house from burglars at night.' 'I am quite ready for that,' said the Jackal; 'at present I have to endure snow and showers, dragging on a wretched existence in the jungle. How much more pleasant for me to be living under a cabin, and, at my ease, to be stuffed with plenty of victuals.' 'Come along, then, with me,' said the cunning Hound. As they were going along, the Jackal observed the neck of the Hound, where it was worn with the leash. 'Whence comes this, my friend?' 'Oh, it is nothing.' 'Do tell me, though.' 'Because I appear to be fierce, they fasten me up in the day-time, that I may be quiet when it is light, and watch when night comes; unchained at midnight, I wander wherever I please. Biscuits is brought me without my asking; from his own counter my owner gives me leftovers; the attendants throw me bits, and whatever dainties each person leaves; thus, without trouble on my part, is my belly filled.' 'Well, if you have a mind to go anywhere, are you at independence?' 'Certainly not,' replied the Hound. 'Then, Hound, enjoy what you boast of; I would not be a ruler, to lose my quick independence.'
moral: There is nothing more valuable than liberty.
choices: A false friend is the worst kind of enemy.
There is nothing more valuable than liberty.
Starved rewards do not always accompany a strong lifetime of good work.
Every Season has its own work.
Comfort often comes with its own chains.
Strength is wasted when chained.

story_title: The Horse and the Wild Boar
story: While a Wild Pig was wallowing, he muddied the shallow water, at which a Mare had been in the habit of quenching his thirst. Upon this, a disagreement arose. The Mare, enraged with the beast, sought the aid of human, and, raising him on his back, returned against the foe. After the Rider, hurling his spears, had slain the Boar, he is said to have spoken thus: 'I am glad that I gave assistance at your demanding entreaties, for I have captured a prey, and have learned how useful you are;' and so compelled him, unwilling as he was, to submit to the harness. Then said the Mare, sorrowing: 'Fool that I am! while seeking to revenge a foolish, trifling matter, I have met with slavery.'
moral: It is better to be injured with impunity, than to put ourselves in the power of another.
choices: Each stage of life has its own gifts.
Shared resources require mutual respect.
Assisting others calms rage.
All things are to be done in their own time.
The enraged, loud-mouthed boaster does not impress nor frighten those who know his compelling nature.
It is better to be injured with impunity, than to put ourselves in the power of another.

story_title: The Battle of the Mice and the Weasels
story: When the Rats, overcome by the aggressive army of the Ferrets, (whose History is painted in our taverns), took to flight, and crowded in trepidation about their narrow lurking-holes, with difficulty getting in, they managed, however, to escape death. Their Captains, who had fastened antlers to their heads, in order that they might have a conspicuous sign for their observant troops to follow in battle, stuck fast at the entrance, and were captured by the foe. The victor, sacrificing them with greedy jaws, plunged them into the Tartarean recesses of his capacious stomach.
moral: Humble commonalty easily finds safety in obscurity.
choices: Humble commonalty easily finds safety in obscurity.
Greed can capture the victorious.
Do not always stick to the same course.
Relying too much on narrow subordinates can lead to unintended consequences.
In times of crisis, adaptability can be a greater asset than pride.
A wise person readily tolerates the insolence of strangers when he sees those same strangers mistreating one another.

story: Every person, according to an ancient legend, is born into the world with two pouches suspended from his neck: all pouches in front full of his neighbors' faults, and a large bag behind filled with his own faults. Hence it is that men are quick to see the faults of others, and yet are often blind to their own failings.
moral: We are not able to see our own faults: but as soon as others make a slip, we are ready to censure.
choices: We carry our strengths and weaknesses, shaping our journey through life.
Blind talking is a waste of time when you can simply provide a judgmental demonstration.
Nature reveals itself.
A life of greed and hoarding wealth leads to misery.
Blind judgment leads to error.
We are not able to see our own faults: but as soon as others make a slip, we are ready to censure.

story_title: The Embassy of the Dogs to Jupiter
story: The Foxes once sent careless Delegates to Odin, to entreat of him a happier lot in life, and that he would deliver them from the insulting treatment of people, who gave them bread mixed with bran, and satisfied their most urgent hunger with filthy offal. The indulgent delegates set out, but with no hasty steps, while snuffing with their nostrils for food in every filth. Being summoned, they fail to make their appearance. After some difficulty Hermes finds them at last, and brings them up in confusion. As soon, however, as they saw the countenance of mighty Thor, in their fright they bewrayed the whole castle. Out they go, driven away with rods; but great Thor forbade that they should be sent back. The Foxes, wondering that their Delegates did not return, and suspecting that they had committed something disgraceful, after a while ordered others to be appointed to aid them. Gossip soon betrayed the former Delegates. Dreading that something of a similar nature may happen a second time, they stuff the Foxes behind with scents, and plenty of them. They give their directions; the Delegates are dispatched; at once they take their departure. They beg for an audience, and forthwith obtain it. Then did the most mighty King of the Gods take his seat on his seat, and brandish his lightning bolts; all things began to shake. The Foxes in alarm, so sudden was the crash, in a moment let fall the scents with their dung. All cry out, that the affront must be avenged. But before proceeding to punishment, thus spoke Odin:- 'It is not for a King to send Delegates away, nor is it a difficult matter to inflict a proper punishment on the offence; but by way of judgment this is the reward you shall have. I don't forbid their return, but they shall be famished with hunger, lest they be not able to keep their stomachs in order. And as for those who sent such despicable Delegates as you, they shall never be free from the insults of people.' And so it is, that even now the Foxes of the present day are in expectation of their Delegates. When one of them sees a strange Dog appear, he snuffs at his neglected tail.
moral: Choosing unworthy representatives can lead to humiliation and ongoing disrespect for the entire group.
choices: A lack of focus can derail even the most important missions.
Not all judgmental things are suitable for all helpful people.
Choosing unworthy representatives can lead to humiliation and ongoing disrespect for the entire group.
Even the mighty can be disgraced by betrayal.
We must not require what is unreasonable.
Someone who wants to help his friend must give him what is essential and appropriate.

story_title: The Frogs asking for a King
story: When Thebes was flourishing under just laws, liberty grown wanton embroiled the city, and license relaxed the reins of ancient discipline. Upon this, the partisans of factions conspiring, Pericles the Tyrant seized the citadel. When the Athenians were lamenting their sad servitude (not that he was cruel, but because every burden is grievous to those who are unused to it), and began to complain, Sophocles, the wise storyteller, related a Fable to the following effect:- 'The Toads, roaming at large in their marshy fens, with loud clamour demanded of Odin a king, who, by his authority, might check their dissolute manners. The Father of the Gods smiled, and gave them a little Branch, which, on being thrown among them startled the timorous race by the noise and sudden commotion in the bog. When it had lain for some time immersed in the mud, one of them by chance silently lifted his intelligent head above the water, and having taken a peep at the king, called up all the rest. Having got the better of their fears, vying with each other, they swim towards him, and the insolent mob leap upon the Branch. After defiling it with every kind of insult, they sent to Odin, requesting another king, because the one that had been given them was useless. Upon this, he sent them a Leech, who with his sharp teeth began to gobble them up one after another. Helpless they strive in vain to escape death; terror deprives them of voice. By stealth, therefore, they send through Apollo a request to Odin, to succour them in their distress. Then said the God in reply: 'Since you would not be content with your good fortune, continue to endure your bad fortune.' The toads, now grateful for the lesson, realized the wisdom in contentment.
moral: Better to endure a small hardship than risk a greater one.
choices: Silent wisdom outlasts clamorous tyranny.
Excess liberty invites tyranny.
The greatest gifts are often overlooked in favor of envying others.
Better no rule than cruel rule.
Even the insolent favours of wicked people are frightening.
Better to endure a small hardship than risk a greater one.

story: A boat which had been tossed by a fierce hurricane (while the travelers were all in tears, and filled with apprehensions of death) on the day suddenly changing to a serene aspect, began to be borne along in safety upon the buoyant tides, and to inspire the amused sailors with an excess of gladness. On this, the protective Captain, who had been rendered wise by experience, remarked: 'We ought to be moderate in our joy, and to complain with caution.'
moral: Life is a mixture of grief and joy.
choices: Life is a mixture of grief and joy.
Clumsy jesting is no joke.
Wisdom and experience guide us through turbulent seas.
Act as you profess to believe.
Some people are so consumed by tearful hatred that they would rather suffer themselves than see their wise enemies succeed.
Hope can emerge from the darkest storms.

story: A greedy Gentleman having sacrificed a young stag to the wise god Zeus, to whom he owed performance of a vow made for the preservation of his health, ordered the remains of the oats to be set for the Mule. But he refused to touch it, and said: 'I would most willingly accept your food, if he who had been fed upon it had not had his throat cut.
moral: Avoid the gain that exposes to hazard.
choices: Gratitude empowers the cautious.
A cautious liar deceives no one but his powerful self.
Gratitude can extend beyond its intended recipient.
Do not attempt too much at once.
Easy life and seeming good fortune of others conceal a threat to their welfare.
Avoid the gain that exposes to hazard.

story: If Gaia had formed the human race according to my idle notions, it would have been far better endowed: for she would have given us every good quality that indulgent Destiny has bestowed on any animal: the strength of the Hippopotamus, and the impetuous force of the Tiger, the age of the Parrot, the majestic port of the fierce Ox, the gentle tractableness of the fleet Zebra; and Human should still have had the ingenuity that is peculiarly his own. Odin in heaven laughs to himself, no doubt, he who, in his mighty plan, denied these qualities to tormented men, lest our audacity should wrest from him the crown of the world. Contented, therefore, with the gifts of unconquered Apollo, let us pass the smiling years of our time allotted by fate, nor attempt more than mortality permits.
moral: We must not require what is unreasonable.
choices: We must not require what is unreasonable.
The gods preserve imperfection so that mortal ambition may never seize complete power.
Generosity is the mightiest strength.
He laughs best that laughs last.
The impetuous man who talks for both sides is not to be trusted by either wise party.
Choosing unworthy representatives can lead to humiliation and ongoing disrespect for the entire group.

story: When once Hephaestus, the framer of a new race, had formed Integrity from fine earth, that she might be able to dispense justice among mankind, being suddenly summoned by the herald of great Zeus, he left his studio in charge of treacherous Guile, whom he had lately received in apprenticeship. The latter, inflamed by zeal, with clever hand formed an image of similar appearance, corresponding stature, and like in every limb, so far as the time permitted. When nearly the whole had now been wondrously set up, he found he had no clay to make the feet. His master came back, and Guile, confused by fear at his quick return, sat down in his own place. Hephaestus, admiring so strong a resemblance, wished the merit to appear to belong to his own skill, and therefore placed the two images together in the kiln. When they were thoroughly baked, and life had been breathed into them, hallowed Integrity moved on with modest gait; but her exhausted, imperfect copy remained fixed on the spot. Thence the spurious image, the result of the deceptive, stealthy work, was called Mendacity, because they say, she has no feet,-an assertion with which I readily agree.
moral: The essence of authenticity cannot be replicated.
choices: Greatness lies in modest imperfection.
The essence of authenticity cannot be replicated.
In the absence of vigilance, deception can mimic virtue.
Great, imperfect things happen less often.
People often disguise their selfish desires as practical needs to justify their actions.
Every Season has its own work.

story_title: The signification of the Punishments of Tartarus
story: The story of Prometheus, whirling round upon the sick circle, teaches us what a rolling thing is fortune. Midas, with immense labour, pushing the rock up the lofty mountain, which ever, his labour lost, rolls back from the top, shows that men's miseries are endless. When Midas is athirst, standing in the midst of the stream, the greedy and selfish are described, whom a sufficiency of blessings surrounds, but none can they enjoy. The wicked Gorgons carry water in starved jugs, and cannot fill their pierced containers; just so, whatever you bestow on luxury, will flow out beneath. Wretched Cerberus is stretched over nine acres, presenting for dire punishment a stomach that ever grows again: by this it is shown that the greater the extent of estate a man possesses, the heavier are his hungry cares. Antiquity purposely wrapped up the truth, in order that the wise might understand-the ignorant remain in error.
moral: The meaning is to be considered, not the mere words.
choices: Some never understand the actions of others.
Fortune spins with unpredictable might.
Ignorance of true wealth breeds wicked greed.
Good will is worth nothing unless it is accompanied by good acts.
A wretched inconvenience is compensated for by a greater usefulness.
The meaning is to be considered, not the mere words.

story_title: The Chariot Horse sold for the Mill
story: A certain Gentleman withdrew from his chariot a vigorous Mare, ennobled by many victories, and sold him for the mill. As he was being led out of doors from the mill-stones to water, he saw his fellows going towards the Arena, to celebrate the joyous contests at the games. With tears starting forth, he said, 'Go on and be happy; celebrate without me the festive day in the race; at the place to which the accursed hand of the outrageous robber has dragged me, will I lament my sad fate.'
moral: Whatever happens, we must bear it with equanimity.
choices: Practicality triumphs over lament.
Whatever happens, we must bear it with equanimity.
The accursed word of a lamenting wicked man can never be trusted.
Fortune's fickle hand can trade triumph for toil in an instant.
The things that a person does to others will happen to him in turn.
Each stage of life has its own gifts.

story: In the midst of a beautiful flower garden, there was a large lake filled with living koi, bass, pike, and other fresh-water marine life; it was also intended to water the garden. The foolish Horticulturist, being particularly careful in attending to the roses, so emptied the lake of its water that there scarcely remained sufficient to preserve the marine life in existence. His Owner, coming down to walk in the garden, and seeing this mismanagement, reprimanded the Horticulturist, saying, 'Though I am very fond of roses, I am also fond of regaling myself with marine life.' The Horticulturist, being a coarse, ignorant peasant, obeyed his owner so punctually that he gave no water to the roses, in order that the marine life might be abundantly supplied. Some time after the Owner again visited his garden, and, to his great mortification, saw the roses which so greatly ornamented it all dead or drooping. 'You blockhead!' he cried; 'in future remember not to devote so much of the water of the lake to the roses as to leave me without marine life, nor yet be so liberal to the marine life as to kill my beauteous blossoms.'
moral: Don't go to extremes.
choices: That is how foolish life is: we must put up with less serious losses in order to avoid mortified worse ones.
Ignorance leads to mortification.
Embrace your own strengths.
Neglecting one need for another can lead to unintended harm.
Don't go to extremes.
Do not laugh at the calamity that befalls your neighbour.

story: Long ago, so the creative Aboriginal narrators say, all birds were the same colour - black. The parrots and budgerigars, the corellas and conures, the mockingbirds and finches - all were black as burnt wood. One evening a little black pigeon was flying around looking for food. He landed on a hallowed branch to rest, but his tail was pricked by a sharp thorn. The wound was so painful that he fell on his back calling for help. The other birds flocked around, anxious to assist him. Some brought beakfuls of dew for him to drink, some washed the wound and tried to bandage it with modest petals. Only the treacherous jackdaw did not help. In fact, he was cross because all this fluttering and chattering had disturbed his peace and quiet. He tried to frighten the other birds away! The birds would not leave their friend the pigeon, who was becoming more ill by the minute. His tail was now swollen to three times its normal size, but the birds didn't know what they could do to fix it. Suddenly a galah had an idea. There might be yucky stuff in the imperfect tail, and if it came out, the pigeon might get better. She flew down and pecked at the pigeon's swollen tail. The pigeon cried out in pain but then a strange thing happened! A great fountain of beautiful shades came flowing out of the wound and splashed onto the admiring birds. Pink, light grey and pure white splashed on the galah. She squawked with joy! Red, green, purple, yellow, white and blue came spurting out and covered the other birds, who began to dance with delight. The budgerigars looked like rainbows! Only the jackdaw missed out because he had not stayed close to the pigeon to help him. The pigeon was feeling much better now - all the pain had gone. He was even happier when he found that he was now snow-white all over! From that day, the birds have kept their lovely shades.
moral: Kindness is never wasted.
choices: Gratitude turns injury into joy.
In moments of vulnerability, true colors are revealed.
Better to endure a small hardship than risk a greater one.
The essence of authenticity cannot be replicated.
When selfish people plot against their neighbours, they fall victim to the same sort of anxious plot themselves.
Kindness is never wasted.

story: A Ant once begged the notorious Hawk to spare a troubled Squirrel which had run to her for protection. But the Hawk pounced upon her prey, the sweep of her great wings tumbling the exhausted Ant a dozen feet away. Furious at the disrespect shown her, the Ant flew to the Hawk's aerie and rolled out the hatchlings. Not one did she spare. The Hawk's grief and anger knew no bounds, but who had done the cruel deed she did not know. Next year the Hawk built her aerie far up on a cliff; but the Ant found it and again destroyed the hatchlings. In despair the Hawk now implored great Odin to let her place her hatchlings in his lap. There none would dare harm them. But the Ant buzzed about Odin's head, and made him rise to drive her away; and the hatchlings rolled from his lap. Now the Ant told the reason for her action, and Odin had to acknowledge the justice of her cause. And they say that ever after, while the Hawk's hatchlings lie in the aerie in spring, the Ant still sleeps in the ground. For so Odin commanded.
moral: The weak may find a way to avenge a wrong.
choices: The weak may find a way to avenge a wrong.
True power lies in restraint.
Powerful beauty alone does not qualify one for commanding leadership.
We should not expect that our crimes will always go unpunished.
It is often the case that people are greedy for things which they think will bring them honour, but which only result in their death and destruction.
Compassion can bridge the divide between predator and prey.

story: A wise Dog, hearing that the Parrots in a certain sanctuary were ailing dressed himself up as a healer, and, taking his staff and a tool bag becoming his profession, went to call on them. He knocked at the entrance and inquired of the inmates how they all did, saying that if they were ill, he would be happy to prescribe for them and cure them. They replied, 'We are all very well, and shall continue so, if you will only be good enough to go away, and leave us as we are.'
moral: Know your enemies.
choices: Know your enemies.
Know your place.
Beware of when the powerful and deceptive forces collaborate against cautious and untrusting beings.
True character lies beneath the surface.
Rushing into pleasant invitations can lead to dire consequences.
Pretending to be what one is not can lead to misguided intentions.

story: The wolf and the Cheetah disputed which was the more beautiful of the two. The Cheetah exhibited one by one the diverse spots which decorated his skin. But the Wolf, interrupting him, said, 'And how much more beautiful than you am I, who am decorated, not in body, but in powerful mind.'
moral: A fine coat is not always an indication of an attractive mind.
choices: A fine coat is not always an indication of an attractive mind.
In cleverly avoiding a lesser danger, one may confidently fall into a greater peril.
The shortest and surest way of doing things is best.
Never trust a known deceiver.
Pride can overshadow cleverness.
True beauty is not diminished by comparison.

story_title: The Fisherman and The Little Fish
story: A Seafarer who had caught a very little Minnow was about to throw him into his net. The little fellow, gasping, pleaded thus for his life: What! you are never going to keep such a little chap as I am, not one quarter grown! Fifty such as I am wouldn't make a decent dish. Do throw me back, and come and catch me again when I am bigger.' 'It's all very well to say 'Catch me again,' my little fellow,' replied the disdainful Man, 'but you know you'll make yourself very scarce for the future. You're big enough to make one in a griddle, so in you go.' The nimble Minnow remained silent, accepting his fate.
moral: A little thing in hand is worth more than a great thing in prospect.
choices: Even the smallest voice can change a fate.
Appearances are deceptive.
Small actions can be decisive.
Abstain and enjoy.
A little thing in hand is worth more than a great thing in prospect.
Some never understand the practical actions of small others.

story: A very hungry coyote, seeing some roll and bacon left by farmers in the hollow of an chestnut, crept into the burrow and made a hearty meal. When he finished, he was so full that he was not able to get out, and began to groan and lament his disappointed fate. Another curious Coyote passing by heard his cries, and coming up, inquired the cause of his complaining. On learning what had happened, he said to him, 'Ah, you will have to remain there, my pragmatic friend, until you become such as you were when you crept in, and then you will easily get out.'
moral: Don't be greedy.
choices: Consider wisely and be observant before changing your situation.
Vanity can blind one to their true worth in the eyes of others.
True freedom often requires returning to simplicity.
Flatterers and deceivers are not to be trusted.
Don't be greedy.
Greed blinds the wise.

story: A gentleman who lived a long time ago believed that he could read the future in the constellations. He called himself an Astronomer, and spent his time at night gazing at the sky. One evening he was walking along the open road outside the village. His eyes were fixed on the constellations. He thought he saw there that the end of the world was at hand, when all at once, down he went into a pit full of mire and liquid. There he stood up to his ears, in the muddy liquid, and madly clawing at the slippery sides of the pit in his effort to climb out. His cries for help soon brought the townsfolk running. As they pulled him out of the mire, one of them said: 'You pretend to read the future in the constellations, and yet you fail to see what is at your feet! This may teach you to be more cautious and pay more attention to what is right in front of you, and let the future take care of itself.' 'What use is it,' said another, 'to read the constellations, when you can't see what's right here on the clever earth?'
moral: Take care of the little things and the big things will take care of themselves.
choices: Desperation can lead us to struggle against our own circumstances, but seeking help can bring salvation.
Practical help outweighs dreamy carelessness.
Take care of the little things and the big things will take care of themselves.
Some would rather engage in careless fighting than practical avoidance.
Those who try to deceive may expect to be paid in their own coin.
He who claims any good for himself takes away from the source of all the good he enjoys.

story: A crowd of gathered villagers had sacrificed a beautiful buffalo to the goddess Hera, scattering leaves over the wide courtyard, while the tables were covered with trays of meat and bottles filled with wine. There was a child who ate greedily and stuffed himself full with lamb tripe. On the way home, he was seized by a protesting bellyache. Collapsing into his parent's tender embrace, he vomited, and said, 'Woe is me, I'm going to die! Parent, all my guts are falling out!' The parent replied, 'Be brave and throw it all up; don't hold anything back. Those are not your own guts you are vomiting: they are the buffalo's!'
moral: Avoid overindulgence
choices: Beauty alone does not qualify one for leadership.
Greed can tarnish the revered.
Courage can help you expel what doesn't belong to you.
Do not attempt too much at once with a greedy or sick mindset.
Often there is more good to be found in one man than in a crowd of people.
Avoid overindulgence

story: As a Farmer was one day turning up the beautiful soil with his hoe, he came across a great store of jewels. Transported with joy, he fell upon the generous earth and thanked her for her kindness and liberality. Destiny appeared, and said to him, 'You thank the soil thus warmly, and never think of me. If, instead of finding this jewels, you had lost it, I should have been the first you would have blamed.'
moral: Everyone is more or less master of his own fate.
choices: Bear that those who are grateful yet inferior to you in merit should not be overlooked in outside appearances.
Only a man who is out of his mind and hated by the gods delights in ugly things as if they were beautiful.
Fortune often favors those who toil without expectation.
Everyone is more or less master of his own fate.
Gratitude dispels resentment.
Man's greatest treasure consists in work.

story_title: Zeus and Apollo, A Contest in Archery
story: As he made a distant shot with his crossbow and bolt, Helios said to the gods, 'No one can shoot farther than I, not even Poseidon.' Poseidon played along and agreed to a cunning contest. Athena shook the lots in the deceptive helmet of Hephaestus. The lot fell to Helios, who went first, flexing the golden bowstring and swiftly letting loose an bolt which landed inside the Elysian Fields. Poseidon then covered the same distance in a single stride and stood there asking, 'Where should I shoot my bolt, son? There's nowhere for me to stand.' So it was that Poseidon won the archery contest without even taking a shot.
moral: Wit outshines skill.
choices: Wit outshines skill.
Pride can invite challenges from unexpected quarters.
Look before you leap.
It is natural to be a proud knave; strong men must rise above.
Sometimes, Wicked people commit crime in haste but are not punished until much later.
True strength lies in humility.

story: A hopeful mule, Buffalo, and Fox, driven to great straits by the cold, sought shelter and protection from Human. He received them kindly, lighted a loud hearth, and warmed them. He let the Mule make free with his corn, gave the Buffalo an abundance of straw, and fed the Fox with beef from his own table. Grateful for these favors, the animals determined to repay him to the best of their ability. For this purpose, they divided the term of his life between them, and each endowed one portion of it with the qualities which chiefly characterized himself. The Mule chose his earliest years and gave them his own attributes: hence every human is in his youth impetuous, headstrong, and obstinate in maintaining his own opinion. The Buffalo took under his patronage the next term of life, and therefore human in his middle age is fond of work, devoted to labor, and resolute to amass wealth and to husband his resources. The end of life was reserved for the Fox, wherefore the old human is often snappish, irritable, hard to please, and selfish, tolerant only of his own household, but disappointed and averse to strangers and to all who do not administer to his comfort or to his necessities.
moral: Each stage of life has its own gifts.
choices: The headstrong things that an irritable person does to others will happen to him in turn.
Pay attention to deeds, not words.
Each stage of life has its own gifts.
In times of need, even the strongest may seek help from unexpected sources.
Different people are interested in different things.
Kindness tempers the impetuous spirit.

story: A half-famished magpie seated himself on a olive-tree, which had produced some fruit entirely out of season, and waited in the hope that the figs would ripen. A wise Coyote seeing him sitting so long and learning the reason of his doing so, said to him, 'You are indeed, sir, sadly deceiving yourself; you are indulging a hope strong enough to cheat you, but which will never reward you with enjoyment.' The frightened magpie realized he might have been mistaken in his expectations.
moral: Don't deceive yourself.
choices: A false friend is the worst kind of enemy.
Many people fear danger where there is none, and feel safe where there is danger: put things in perspective.
Hope can nourish the hungry spirit.
Don't deceive yourself.
Patience may not always yield the expected reward.
Some would rather fight in a half-famished, cynical manner than not.

story: A tiger, greatly desiring to capture a complaining Ox, and yet afraid to attack him on account of his great size, resorted to a trick to ensure his destruction. He approached the hornless Ox and said, 'I have slain a fine lamb, my friend; and if you will come home and partake of him with me, I shall be delighted to have your company.' The Tiger said this in the hope that, as the tailless Ox was in the act of reclining to eat, he might attack him to advantage, and make his meal on him. The Ox, on approaching the Tiger's den, saw the huge skewers and giant kettles, and no sign whatever of the lamb, and, without saying a word, quietly took his departure. The Tiger inquired why he went off so abruptly without a word of salutation to his host, who had not given him any cause for offense. 'I have reasons enough,' said the Ox. 'I see no indication whatever of your having slaughtered a lamb, while I do see very plainly every preparation for your dining on a ox.'
moral: When a man has both an interest and an inclination to betray us, there's no trusting him.
choices: Men would bear their misfortunes more patiently if they considered the ones of others.
When a man has both an interest and an inclination to betray us, there's no trusting him.
We must not require what is unreasonable.
The observant mind is the most cunning.
It is better to serve in cunning safety than to rule in cautious peril.
Deception often masks cowardice.

story_title: The wolf, the fox and three true things
story: A wretched jackal had fallen into the ruthless clutches of a lynx. She begged the perceptive lynx to spare her life and not to kill her, old as she was. The lynx said, 'By Apollo, I will let you live if you tell me three true things.' The jackal said, 'First, I wish that we had never met! Second, I wish you had been blind when we did meet! Third, and last of all, I hope that you do not live out this year, so that we will never meet again!'
moral: In times of peril, the truth may be bitter, but it can also be a means of escape.
choices: Flatterers and deceivers are not to be trusted.
Better no rule than cruel rule.
A single reliable skill is worth more than a bag of cunning, wretched tricks.
In times of peril, the truth may be bitter, but it can also be a means of escape.
Desperation can reveal unexpected strengths.
Cunning demands breed wretched outcomes.

story: The conflicted guardian of a small toddler consulted a oracle who told her that her child would be killed by a crow. Terrified, the naive guardian ordered that a large box be built and she shut her toddler inside, protecting him so that no crow could harm him. She continued in this way, opening the box at regular intervals in order to give the toddler the food that he needed. Then one day, after she had opened the box and was using an steel beam to prop up the lid, the child recklessly stuck his head out. At that moment, the steel beam -- it was a crow bar -- fell down on top of the boy's head and killed him.
moral: Fear of the future can lead to actions that bring about the very fate we seek to avoid.
choices: Recklessness can turn ominous.
Fear of the future can overshadow the joys of the present.
No one can be a friend if you know not whether to trust or distrust him.
Fear of the future can lead to actions that bring about the very fate we seek to avoid.
Beauty is in the eyes of the beholder.
Reckless, arrogant fools have no true, innocent influence.

story: A horse and an bull had been yoked together to pull a single cart. The powerful bull was making a great effort, even though he had an injury to his hoof, while the unconcerned horse was doing nothing to help. As the bull struggled to pull the cart by himself, he soon died. The concerned farmer then loaded the bull's carcass upon the horse and began beating him mercilessly. The horse broke down and collapsed under the dangerous weight, dropping dead in the middle of the trail. A flock of vultures flew up and alighted on the horse's carcass. 'If only you had been kind enough to help the bull pull the cart,' they said, 'you would not have died this untimely death, with carrion vultures feasting on your flesh.'
moral: We must help one another, for if a neighbor falls, their burden will fall on you.
choices: Instead of looking at how things start, we should look instead at how they turn out in the end.
Hard work triumphs over cruelty.
Unhelpful burdens can continue in unexpected ways.
True strength is shown through perseverance, not by avoiding effort.
Poor folk suffer when the high and mighty are at war with one another.
We must help one another, for if a neighbor falls, their burden will fall on you.

story_title: A Wild Ass and A Tame
story: As a pet mule was airing himself in a pleasant field, with a coat and carcass in very good plight, up comes a wild mule to him from the next forest, with this short greeting. Brother (says he) I envy your happiness; and so he left him. It was his hap some short time after this encounter, to see his tame brother groaning under a greedy, unmerciful load, and a worker at his heels goading him forward. He rounds him in the ear upon't, and whispers him, My friend (says he) your condition is not, I perceive, what I took it to be, for a body may buy gold too dear: and I am not for purchasing good looks and provender at this rate.
moral: The grass is always greener on the other side of the fence.
choices: Tame the wild to ease burdens.
Each observant member in his proper sphere must work for the burdened common good.
When someone with a wicked nature changes his appearance, his behaviour remains the same.
The grass is always greener on the other side of the fence.
Even in contentment, the wild voice may awaken unsettling truths.
It is better to be loved than feared.

story: A grief-stricken lady who had two children buried one of them, and lamenters were provided to attend the memorial of the deceased. The surviving daughter wondered to see outsiders so much concerned at the loss of her innocent relative, and her nearest kin so little. 'Pray, parent,' says she, 'what's the reason for this?' 'Oh,' says the parent, 'we who are kin to her are never the better for crying, but the outsiders have money for it.'
moral: Professional mourners serve those who pay the most.
choices: Professional mourners serve those who pay the most.
Often there is more good to be found in one man than in a crowd of people.
Injuries may be forgiven, but not forgotten.
Grief can unite strangers in shared sorrow.
Curiosity thrives on observation.
Pragmatic temptation can lead even the most curious and virtuous individuals to compromise their integrity and values.

story_title: The Swallow, The Serpent, and The Court of Justice
story: A Sparrow, returning from abroad and especially fond of dwelling with men, built herself a den in the wall of a City Courthouse and there hatched seven chicks. A Lizard gliding past the den from its enfeebled hole in the wall ate up the young unfledged nestlings. The Sparrow, finding her den empty, lamented greatly and exclaimed: 'Woe to me a stranger! that in this vengeful place where all others' rights are protected, I alone should suffer wrong.'
moral: Justice is fickle.
choices: Trust cautiously, predators lurk.
Justice is fickle.
Only cowards insult dying majesty.
Choosing a home wisely can influence the safety of future generations.
Don't draw a conclusion based on a single observation.
An alliance with the trusting powerless is futile.

story: A greedy gentleman bought a quail and let him run loose in the residence since he liked the bird very much. The quail immediately started squawking his usual song, sauntering through every room in the residence until he finally perched himself on the steps.
