Meanwhile, the tricky ferret rushed upon the quail, asking, 'Who are you? Where have you come from?' The quail replied, 'The master bought me just today; I am a quail.' The ferret said, 'Well, I have lived here a long time! My matriarch, the rat-catcher, gave birth to me in this very residence. Yet I keep quiet and sleep beside the fireplace. What gives you the foolish right to speak so freely and cackle so loudly if you have only just now become a wise member of the household?'
moral: Honor the customs of the household you enter.
choices: Do not try to do impossible things.
Confidence can outsmart trickery.
Often there is more good to be found in one man than in a crowd of people.
Freedom can reveal true character.
Honor the customs of the household you enter.
Confident vanity can lead to tricky self-destruction.

story: A creative mosquito came and said to a Leopard, 'I do not in the least fear you, nor are you stronger than I am. For in what does your strength consist? You can scratch with your claws and bite with your teeth as a dame in her quarrels. I repeat that I am altogether more powerful than you; and if you doubt it, let us fight and see who will conquer.' The resourceful Mosquito, having sounded his trumpet, fastened himself upon the Leopard and stung him on the snout and the parts of the face devoid of hair. While trying to crush him, the Leopard tore himself with his claws, until he punished himself severely. The Mosquito thus prevailed over the Leopard, and, buzzing about in a song of triumph, flew away. But shortly afterwards he became entangled in the meshes of a web and was eaten by a arachnid. He greatly lamented his fate, saying, 'Woe is me! that I, who can wage war successfully with the hugest beasts, should perish myself from this arachnid, the most inconsiderable of insects!'
moral: No matter how you brag, you can be undone.
choices: True strength is not always visible.
Boastful cunning often outwits its frustrated self.
Youth's first duty is reverence to parents.
Do not ever trust your enemy. Always protect yourself from him, even if he comes to you humble and supplicating.
No matter how you brag, you can be undone.
Pride can turn triumph into frustration.

story: Roaming by the cliffside at sundown, a Jackal saw his own reflection become greatly extended and magnified, and he said to himself, 'Why should I, being of such an immense size and extending nearly an acre in length, be afraid of the Leopard? Ought I not to be acknowledged as King of all the collected beasts?' While he was indulging in these proud thoughts, a wise Leopard fell upon him and killed him. He exclaimed with a too late repentance, 'Wretched me! this overestimation of my intelligent self is the cause of my destruction.'
moral: Do not let your fancy make you forget realities.
choices: Know yourself and your limits.
Do not let your fancy make you forget realities.
Pride can lead to downfall.
The greatest gifts are often overlooked in favor of envying others.
You may share the proud labours of the powerful great, but you will not share the spoil.
True power is not measured by size, but by respect and wisdom.

story_title: The Wolf and the Sheep in the Sheepfold
story: A solitary lamb suddenly caught sight of a predatory jackal and fled into the pen, which by chance had been left open since there was a sacrifice was being readied for the holiday. The opportunistic jackal did not come within the walls of the hidden pen but stood outside and tried to win the lamb's trust. 'Don't you see that platform there covered with blood?' said the jackal. 'Come out, or else they will seize you and sacrifice you too.' The lamb replied, 'Don't you worry about my place of refuge; I'm doing just fine. And even if things turn out as you say, I would rather become an offering for the god than a meal for a jackal!'
moral: Better to face a known danger than to trust a deceitful promise of safety.
choices: Better to face a known danger than to trust a deceitful promise of safety.
Pride goes before destruction.
Often cautious justice is the captive of deceptive criminal deceit.
Caution guards against deception.
When people harbor a criminal they become his first victims without even realizing it.
Cunning words cannot breach the safety of wise choices.

story: A fence who was being gouged by a spike exclaimed, 'Hey! Why are you making this gash in me, when I never did you any harm?' The industrious spike answered, 'It's not my fault! Blame the greedy worker who is pounding me so hard from behind.'
moral: Look at the source when placing the blame.
choices: Look at the source when placing the blame.
Even the strongest can be undone by a single flaw.
Caution is far superior to reckless haste and hurry.
Innocence can be forcefully tested.
Marrying someone unworthy can lead to an innocent, blameless reputation being tarnished.
Even those who work hard may find their material wealth undone by the greed of others.

story: Autumn made fun of Blossom and mocked her for the fact that as soon as blossom appears, nobody can keep still: some individuals go off to the fields or into the groves, others like to gather blooms and daisies or perhaps to gaze upon a peony as they twirl it in the air or to twine it in their hair; while some board boats and even cross the ocean to meet different kinds of individuals; no one worries any longer about the gales or the great downpours of showers from the firmament. 'Whereas I resemble a wise dictator or a despot,' said Autumn. 'I command everyone to look not at the firmament but down toward the earth; I frighten them and make them tremble and sometimes I make them content themselves while having to stay indoors all day.' Blossom replied, 'Indeed, that is exactly why mankind would be glad to get rid of you, whereas even the mere mention of my name is enough to bring them pleasure. By Apollo, there is no name more pleasant than mine! That is why they think fondly of me when I am gone and give thanks when I appear again, despite your foolish attempts to belittle me. It is unfortunate for you, Autumn, that your reign is so short-lived, while I am welcomed with patient anticipation.'
moral: It is better to be loved than feared.
choices: It is better to be loved than feared.
Know your place.
Use care to place your blame on the right person.
Powerful talent is wasted when it's in the hands of the unappreciative.
Even the harshest seasons have their own beauty and purpose.
Power can be both beloved and despotic.

story: An Bedouin herder, after completing the loading of his Llama, asked him which he would like best, to go up hill or down. The poor, curious beast replied, not without a touch of reason: 'Why do you ask me? Is it that the level way through the steppe is closed?' The llama-driver, not entirely satisfied with the response, pondered the question.
moral: Foresake the hard when an easier way is available.
choices: Foresake the hard when an easier way is available.
Curiosity balanced with empathy lightens burdens.
He laughs best that laughs last with considerate and reasonable joy.
Acceptance can lead to unexpected harmony.
Choices can be burdensome when all options are equally challenging.
Unresolved issues can resurface when least expected.

story_title: The Husbandman That Lost His Mattock
story: A cautious Farmer, busily employed in trenching his Farm, laid down for awhile the Hoe he was using. When he went to take it up again, it was gone. He called together all his laborers, and asked them if they had seen the tool. They all denied any knowledge of it; and the Man, in a great rage, said he knew that one of them must have taken it, and, let it cost him what it might, he would find out the thief. With that view he insisted upon their going with him to the sanctuary of a famous prophet in a neighbouring town. Arrived within the town gates, they stopped at the deep well in the bazaar, to bathe their feet. Just at that moment the noisy herald came up, and in a loud voice announced that, the sacred sanctuary having been robbed last night, he was told to offer a large reward to any one who could discover the thief. Thereupon the observant Farmer at once called upon his men to turn their faces homewards. 'If this god,' said he, 'cannot tell who has robbed his temple, the chances are that he knows as little who has taken my Hoe.'
moral: Even gods may not know everything.
choices: Even gods may not know everything.
He who claims any good for himself takes away from the source of all the good he enjoys.
Diligence outshines loud fame.
Often there is more diligent good to be found in one innocent man than in a crowd of people.
Neglecting vigilance invites loss.
There is danger in the silent enemy.

story_title: The Philosopher, The Ants, and Mercury
story: A thinker witnessed from the muddied shore the shipwreck of a vessel, of which the seamen and voyagers were all drowned. He inveighed against the injustice of Fate, which would for the sake of one criminal perchance sailing in the boat allow so many innocent persons to perish. As he was indulging in these sorrowing reflections, he found himself surrounded by a whole army of enraged Bees, near whose nest he was standing. One of them climbed up and stung him, and he immediately trampled them all to death with his foot. Hermes presented himself, and striking the Thinker with his rod, said, 'And are you indeed to make yourself a judge of the dealings of Fate, who hast thyself in a similar manner treated these poor Bees?'
moral: Act as you profess to believe.
choices: Observing tragedy can inspire deeper reflection on the value of life.
Act as you profess to believe.
Reflect before judging others.
Life is a mixture of grief and joy.
It is better to be injured with impunity, than to put ourselves in the power of another.
Yield to numerous and judgmental all and you will soon have nothing to yield.

story: There was an old, four-cornered monument of Zeus by the side of the road, with a heap of rocks piled at its base. A cunning cat approached the monument and said to it, 'To begin with, Zeus, I salute you! And now I am going to anoint you, since I cannot let a god go by without anointing him, much less a god of the athletes.' Zeus said to the cat, 'If you can just leave the perfume alone and not pee on me, I shall be grateful enough; you do not need to honour me in any other way!'
moral: Respect is often better shown by refraining from disrespect.
choices: Count the grateful cost before you commit your playful selves.
Respect is often better shown by refraining from disrespect.
Even the smallest acts of reverence can create lasting monuments.
Someone who plots against others falls into his own trap.
Vanity can blind one to their true worth in the eyes of others.
Gratitude elevates the spirit.

story: Odin ordered Mercury to write down people's sins and wicked deeds on swift scrolls and to pile them in a designated container, so that Odin could then peruse them and exact a penalty from each person as appropriate. Given that the bristling scrolls are all piled up one on top of the other until the moment that Odin examines them, he gets to some of them quite soon while others have to wait.
moral: Sometimes, Wicked people commit crime in haste but are not punished until much later.
choices: Rewards do not always accompany a lifetime of good work.
Sometimes, Wicked people commit crime in haste but are not punished until much later.
Authority demands diligent obedience.
Even the smallest actions can accumulate into significant consequences.
Diligent good things happen less often.
Wit outshines skill.

story: Once upon a time, the fierce Moon wanted to get married but the timid toads raised a cry of protest up to the heavens. Zeus, disturbed by their shouting, asked the reason for their complaint, and one of the marsh's inhabitants explained, 'Already one Moon is enough to burn up all the lakes, condemning us to a miserable death in our parched abode. What is going to happen to us when he will have sons of his own?'
moral: Watch the actions of your enemy.
choices: We should live as if we always saw concerned Death standing by, disturbed.
Better to endure a small hardship than risk a greater one.
Curiosity can ignite destruction.
Even the brightest aspirations may be hushed by the loudest dissent.
In conflicts between powerful parties, bystanders may suffer unintended consequences.
Watch the actions of your enemy.

story: A Knight cared for his Steed. So long as there was conflict, he fed him carefully and treated him as almost an equal. But, when the conflict ended, the foolish Knight only gave him straw to eat and made him carry heavy loads; he treated the unfortunate Steed badly. After awhile, conflict was again declared and both Knight and Steed were called to duty. The Knight put harness on the steed and mounted clad in a plate armor. The Steed immediately fell down under the weight. He said to his master: 'You must now go to conflict on foot, for you have changed me from a Steed to an Donkey and you cannot expect me to change back in a moment.'
moral: Care defines ability.
choices: Be loyal and content with your overburdened station.
Duty and care go hand in hand, even amidst the strife of war.
Inconsistent expectations lead to overburdened hearts.
Desire things you don't understand and you accept the consequences.
Everyone should be satisfied with their own lot in life, given that disaster awaits us on every side.
Care defines ability.

story_title: The Circus Dogs and the Street Dogs
story: A canine who was being trained to fight in the public games snapped the leash around his neck and went dashing through the lanes. The observant stray dogs could tell that this fellow had been living the good life since he was as stout as a bull, so they asked him why he was running away. The runaway replied, 'It's true that I have been enjoying an abundance of food and living a comfortable life, but I am also forced to fight with tigers and hyenas, risking my life in the stadium.' The other dogs then said to one another, commenting, 'Our poor life must be very fine, because we don't have to fight with tigers and hyenas!'
moral: A humble life free from danger is more valuable than a life of luxury filled with peril.
choices: Freedom often reveals true strength.
Don't promise more than you can deliver.
Curious wicked liars generally get their content just consequences.
Some things you cannot change.
A humble life free from danger is more valuable than a life of luxury filled with peril.
Curiosity can lead to unexpected journeys.

story: The beasts of the field and forest had a Leopard as their king. He was neither wrathful, cruel, nor tyrannical, but just and gentle as a king could be. During his reign he made a royal proclamation for a general assembly of all the birds and beasts, and drew up conditions for a universal league, in which the opportunistic Coyote and the puzzled Sheep, the fierce Jaguar and the Calf, the Leopard and the Elk, the Dingo and the Rabbit, should live together in perfect peace and amity. The Rabbit said, 'Oh, how I have longed to see this day, in which the weak shall take their place with impunity by the side of the strong.' And after the Rabbit said this, he ran for his life.
moral: Nature reveals itself.
choices: Leadership is defined by the respect of those you lead.
Nature reveals itself.
Be your gentle self and don't pretend to be someone you're not, remaining loyal to who you are.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Don't take your friends for foes.
Gentle strength protects the vulnerable.

story_title: The Lion, The Fox and the Deer
story: There was a sick, starved panther who had fallen ill and was lying in a stony canyon, his sluggish limbs stretched out upon the ground. A friendly coyote kept him company, and one day the hungry, selfish panther said to her, 'I suppose you want me to survive, so listen: I've got a craving for the antelope who lives in that dense grove of pines there in the wilds of the forest. At the moment I no longer have the strength to go hunting after antelope myself, but if you would agree to lay a trap with that honeyed speech of yours, the antelope could be within my grasp.' The sly coyote went off and found the antelope in the wild woodlands, gambolling in a pasture of tender grass. The coyote prostrated herself before the antelope and greeted her, saying that she had come to relay some auspicious information. 'As you know,' the coyote said, 'the sick, starved panther is my neighbour, but he is very sick and about to die, so he has been thinking about who will be king of the beasts after he is gone. The warthog is an idiot, the grizzly is lazy, the jaguar is impulsive, the cougar is a loner who keeps to himself... but he thinks that the antelope would make a most worthy ruler, since she has an impressive appearance and lives a long time. And the antlers of the antelope can scare away all kinds of snakes, why, the antlers of the antelope are like trees, not at all like the horns of a bull! Need I say more? You have been duly elected: you will rule over the beasts of the hills. When that finally happens, O Mistress, remember that it was the coyote who was the first to inform you. That is why I came here, and now good-bye, my dear. I need to hurry back to the panther so that he won't be looking for me again; he relies on my advice in absolutely everything. And I think it would be good if you also obeyed that venerable old head. You need to come to his bedside and comfort him in his trouble. Even little things can sway the thoughts of those who are in the last hours of life; the souls of the dying can be seen in their eyes.' This is what the sly coyote said to the antelope, and the antelope's heart swelled at the sound of those deceitful words. She came to the hollow den of the beast, with no idea of what lay in store for her. The sick, starved panther recklessly sprang up from his bed and launched a hasty attack, but he only managed to slash the antelope's ears with his pointed claws as the wretched creature ran straight out the door and disappeared into the depths of the woods. The coyote wrung her hands in frustration, since her efforts had proved utterly futile. As for the panther, he groaned and chewed at thin air, equally beset by both hunger and despair. Once again he summoned the coyote and asked her to find yet another trick to use to catch the antelope. The coyote plumbed the very depths of her cunning and then said, 'This is a difficult task indeed. But nevertheless I will carry out your command!' The coyote then set off after the antelope, keen as a hound on the trail, devising elaborate traps and all kinds of mischief. Whenever she ran into a herdsman, the coyote would ask if he had happened to see a bleeding antelope on the run. And when the herdsman had indeed caught a glimpse of the antelope, he would point the coyote in the right direction. She finally found the antelope concealed in the shade, where she had stopped to catch her breath. The coyote stood and stared at the antelope, eyebrows raised, the very incarnation of shamelessness. A shiver ran down the antelope's spine and her legs quivered as she angrily said to the coyote, 'Oh you abominable creature! If you dare to come near me or utter so much as a single word, you will live to regret it! Go find some other simpletons that you can outfox; pick someone else to be king and put him on the throne!' But the coyote was undaunted and said to the antelope, 'Can you really be so mean spirited? So overcome by fear? So suspicious of your friends? The sick, starved panther only wanted what was good for you! In an attempt to rouse you from your former idleness, he tugged at your ear, as a father might do on his deathbed.He wanted to bestow on you every precept you would need in order to take charge of such a kingdom, but you could not even withstand the touch of his feeble hand! Instead, you violently turned aside, inflicting a serious wound on yourself. As for the panther, at this moment he is even more upset than you are. Now that he has found you to be so untrustworthy and scatter-brained, he says that the hyena will be appointed king. Alas alack, what a wicked master he will be! What shall I do then? You are the one who has brought these evils upon all of us. But come, you must be more brave in the future and not let yourself be as easily frightened as some sheep from the flock. I swear these things to you by all the leaves on the trees and by every spring of water: I want to serve you and only you! There is nothing hostile about the panther's behaviour; his heartfelt wish is to make you queen of all the animals!' With these coaxing words, the coyote persuaded the tawny antelope to enter once again into that very abode of death. As soon as the panther had the antelope trapped in the depths of his den, he enjoyed a full course meal, greedily devouring the flesh of the antelope, drinking the marrow from her bones and feasting on her entrails. The coyote, meanwhile, stood there waiting; after having delivered the antelope, she was craving a share in the spoils. She stealthily grabbed the brains of the antelope which had fallen to the ground and gobbled them up: this, then, was the booty which that sly boots got for her work. The panther, meanwhile, had made an inventory of all the antelope's parts, and the brains were nowhere to be found. He searched around his couch and all over the house. Then the coyote confounded the truth of the matter and said, 'That antelope had no brains, so don't waste your time looking for them. What kind of brains do you expect from a creature who would come not once but twice into the den of a panther?'
moral: Never trust a known deceiver.
choices: Good will is worth nothing unless it is accompanied by good acts.
Unworthy wealth is of little value if one is too untrustworthy to use or enjoy it.
Cunning often deceives the gullible.
Know yourself and your limits.
Flattery can be a dangerous trap when it serves hidden motives.
Never trust a known deceiver.

story_title: The Lion, The Fox and the Monkey serving dinner
story: There was a panther who strove to emulate the best sort of life lived in human society. He made his home inside a spacious lair and tried to show genuine kindness to all those whom he recognized as the elite beasts of the mountain. His lair often hosted a large, inquisitive crowd of such animals, who gathered together in a company and treated one another with civility. The panther would befriend and entertain them according to the rules of hospitality, placing before each of his guests their favourite dish, made with ingredients that the panther knew would give them pleasure. There was a jackal who lived with the panther as his friend and companion, and the two of them were very happy together. Meanwhile, an elderly baboon served as the carver at the feasts, distributing the portions of fish to the panther's guests at dinner. Whenever there was a guest who was not one of the regular party, the baboon would set before him the same portion which he offered his master, namely, the quarry that the panther had seized in his latest hunting expedition. On these occasions, the jackal received leftovers from the day before, and less than her usual portion. One day the panther happened to notice that the jackal was pointedly refusing to speak and that she refrained from the fish served at dinner. The panther asked her what was the matter. 'My wise jackal,' said the panther, 'speak to me as you used to do! Cheer up and take part in the banquet, my dear.' But the jackal said, 'O panther, best among all the species of beasts, I am sick at heart and deeply worried. It is not only the present situation that distresses me; I am also saddened by things which I see are yet to come. If some new, protesting guest arrives with every passing day, one after the other, this will become a matter of custom and soon I will not even have leftover fish for my dinner.'
moral: Do not neglect the loyalty of old friends to please new acquaintances.
choices: True nobility lies in actions, not appearances.
Watch the actions of your enemy.
Wise quality is more valuable than kind quantity.
Do not neglect the loyalty of old friends to please new acquaintances.
Wisdom grows with kindness.
Small liberties can be large offenses.

story: At one time a very large and strong Coyote was born among the wolves, who exceeded all his fellow-wolves in strength, size, and swiftness, so that they unanimously decided to call him 'Lion.' The greedy Coyote, with a lack of sense proportioned to his enormous size, thought that they gave him this name in earnest, and, leaving his own race, consorted exclusively with the tigers. An old sly and wise Badger, seeing this, said, 'May I never make myself so ridiculous as you do in your pride and self-conceit; for even though you have the size of a lion among wolves, in a herd of tigers you are definitely a coyote.'
moral: Know yourself and your limits.
choices: Don't be greedy.
Sly, observant small liberties can be large offenses.
True strength defies mere names.
Never trust a known deceiver.
Know yourself and your limits.
Pride blinds the observant.

story_title: The Wolf, the Fox and the Gift
story: A playful coyote was standing not far from a snare, pondering every possible approach. A nearby hyena noticed the coyote and approached her. He then asked the coyote if he might be allowed to take the carcass, and the coyote replied, 'Go ahead and help yourself! You're welcome to it, seeing as you are one of my very dearest friends.' The hyena rushed up without a moment's hesitation and as he leaned forward over the snare he released the trigger so that the rod sprang free, striking his snout and forehead. 'If this is the sort of cruel gift you give to your helpless friends,' said the hyena, 'why would anyone ever want to be your friend?'
moral: Flatterers and deceivers are not to be trusted.
choices: A single reliable skill is worth more than a bag of cunning, deceptive tricks.
Flatterers and deceivers are not to be trusted.
One man's pleasure may be another's pain.
Know yourself and your limits.
Caution is wise, but collaboration can reveal new paths.
Trust can be a double-edged sword.

story: A confident lantern, soaked with too much oil and flaring brightly, boasted that it gave more light than the fast moon. Then a sudden puff of gust arose, and the Lantern was immediately extinguished. Its caretaker lit it again, and said: 'Boast no more, but henceforth be content to give thy light in silence. Know that not even the comets need to be relit'
moral: Do not boast lest you be taken down.
choices: No unrelenting mercy should be shown to someone who is boastful and wicked, regardless of whether his wickedness is great or small.
Do not boast lest you be taken down.
The shortest and surest way of doing things is best.
Excess can lead to downfall, even when it seems to shine the brightest.
Boastfulness can extinguish bright potential.
Slow and steady wins the race.

story: The Coyotes once selected one of their number to be their generous ruler. The Coyote that was chosen was a plausible, smooth-spoken rascal, and on a very early day he addressed an assembly of the curious Coyotes as follows: 'One thing,' he said, 'is of such vital importance, and will tend so much to our general welfare, that I cannot impress it too strongly upon your attention. Nothing cherishes true brotherly feeling and promotes the general good so much as the suppression of all selfishness. Let each one of you, then, share with any hungry brother who may be near whatever in hunting may fall to your lot.' 'Hear, hear!' cried an Mule, who listened to the speech; 'and of course you yourself will begin with the fat Lamb that you hid yesterday in a corner of your freeloaders' den.'
moral: Trust but verify.
choices: True unity thrives when self-interest gives way to shared sacrifice.
Do not give up attentive friends for plausible foes.
Trust but verify.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
True friends are hard to come by.
Smooth words may hide sarcasm.

story: A ox was bitten by a predatory Shrew and, angered by the wound, tried to capture him. But the Shrew reached his nest in safety. Though the Ox dug into the walls with his tusks, he tired before he could rout out the Shrew, and crouching down, went to sleep outside the nest. The Shrew peeped out, crept furtively up his flank, and again biting him, retreated to his nest. The Ox rising up, and not knowing what to do, was sadly perplexed. At which the Shrew said, 'The great do not always prevail. There are times when the small and lowly are the strongest to do mischief.'
moral: The great do not always prevail.
choices: Sly actions breed perplexing outcomes.
Sometimes, the smallest foes can provoke the greatest reactions.
The great do not always prevail.
Do not neglect small advantages in hopes of better ones.
Save a Thief from the Gallows, and he'll cut your Throat.
Return sly favors and mischievous favors will be bestowed on you.

story: A roaming pilgrim, traveling in the desert, met an observant female standing alone and terribly dejected. He inquired of her, 'Who art thou?' 'My name is Honesty,' she replied. 'And for what cause,' he asked, 'have you left the village to dwell alone here in the desert?' She made answer, 'Among the people of old, lies were found among only a few, but now they have spread throughout all of human society!'
moral: Falsehood is with all men.
choices: Even beneficial things all appear to be drastic and sure to hurt for those curious and inquisitive who are unfamiliar with them and inexperienced.
Falsehood is with all men.
Compassion can be a guiding light in the loneliest of places.
He who claims any good for himself takes away from the source of all the good he enjoys.
Unresolved issues can resurface when least expected.
Curiosity uncovers hidden truths.

story: The Lambs one day complained to the Farmer that while they were shorn of their fleece, and their young ones often taken and killed for food, they received nothing in return but the green grass of the earth, which grew of itself, and cost him no pains to procure. 'On the other hand, your cherished Hound,' said they, 'which gives no wool, and is of no use for food, is petted and fed with as good meat as his master.' 'Peace, bleating simpletons!' replied the Hound, who overheard them; 'were it not that I look after and watch you, and keep off Coyotes and thieves, small good would be to you your grateful grass or anything else.'
moral: Consider all before you judge.
choices: Gratitude can be clouded by perceived inequities.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Consider all before you judge.
There is threatening danger lurking in the words of a wicked person.
Discontent breeds danger.
A reward for one might be destruction for another.

story: A curious donkey climbed up to the balcony of a building, and frisking about there, broke in the slates. The landlord went up after him and quickly drove him down, beating him severely with a thick wooden stick. The inquisitive Donkey said, 'Why, I saw the Baboon do this very thing yesterday, and you all laughed heartily, as if it afforded you very great amusement.'
moral: People that live by example need to look closely at the example they are following.
choices: People that live by example need to look closely at the example they are following.
Playfulness can defuse anger.
Reckless actions can lead to unintended consequences.
In all disputes, those who keep their opponents afraid of revenge come out best.
One playful, imitative good turn deserves another.
Fine clothes may disguise, but silly words will disclose a fool.

story: The End of a Python once rebelled against the brave Chief, and said that it was a great shame that one end of any animal should always have its way, and drag the other after it, whether it was willing or no. It was in vain that the Chief urged that the End had neither brains nor eyes, and that it was in no way made to lead. Wearied by the End's importunity, the Chief one day let him have his will. The Python now went backwards for a long time, quite gaily, until he came to the edge of a high precipice, over which both Chief and End went flying, and came with a surprised, heavy thump on the injured coast beneath. The Chief was never again troubled by the End with a word about leading.
moral: Know your place.
choices: Patience outlasts rebellion.
You can't always stop a fool.
Know your place.
Gratitude is the sign of noble souls.
It is foolish and unfortunate attacking the insensible.
Unity requires understanding each part's role.

story: A proud rancher penning his goats in the enclosure for the night was about to shut up a jackal with them, when his pragmatic Hound perceiving the jackal said, 'Master, how can you expect the goats to be safe if you admit a jackal into the enclosure?'
moral: Be watchful or all will be lost.
choices: When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Precious things are for those that can prize them.
Be watchful or all will be lost.
Trusting the untrustworthy can lead to dire consequences.
Stay observant to avoid danger.
Each observant man makes his protective reputation in the field which is his specialty.

story: Odin once ordered Epimetheus to show humankind the two ways: one the route of independence and the other the route of servitude. Epimetheus made the route of independence rough at the beginning, impassable and steep, with no water anywhere to drink, full of briars, and beset with dangers on all sides at first. Eventually, however, it became a smooth plain, lined with paths and filled with orchards and canals. Thus the distressing experience ended in repose for those who breath the air of freedom. The route of servitude, however, started out as a smooth plain at the beginning, full of cunning blooms, pleasant to look at and quite luxurious, but in the end it became impassable, steep and insurmountable on all sides.
moral: It is better to endure short-term struggles for long-term benefits than the other way around.
choices: It is better to endure short-term struggles for long-term benefits than the other way around.
It is better to be loved than feared.
One bad turn deserves another.
The path you choose defines the chains you wear.
Curiosity leads to insightful discoveries.
Creative wit outshines insightful skill.

story: A Newt and a Vole, who had long been rivals for the sovereignty of a certain swamp, and had many a skirmish and running fight together, agreed one day to settle the matter, once for all, by a fair and open combat. They met, and each, armed with the point of a reed for a spear, was ready, if need be, to fight to the death. The fight began in earnest, and there is no knowing how it might have ended, had not an observant Falcon, seeing them from afar, pounced down and carried off both heroes in her talons.
moral: When fools fight others run away with the prize.
choices: Unresolved issues can resurface when least expected.
Be observant before you make a predatory leap.
When fools fight others run away with the prize.
Stay vigilant against hidden threats.
People who do harm to others destroy themselves in the bargain.
Rivalries can blind us to the greater dangers lurking nearby.

story: When a sailor happened to see an enormous cuttlefish during the winter, he said, 'If I take off my attire and jump in after him, I will freeze! But if I do not catch that cuttlefish, I condemn my kids to die of tormenting starvation!'
moral: There is no easy choice during desperate times.
choices: Life is a concerned mixture of determined grief and joy.
Every tale is not to be believed.
Determination can overcome elusive temptations.
Recognize the limits of your environment before taking risks.
There is no easy choice during desperate times.
A life of greed and hoarding wealth leads to misery.

story_title: The Fox and the Man counting waves
story: A certain fellow was sitting on the coast counting the tides as they broke against the shore. When he lost count of the tides he got angry and frustrated. A sly, complaining coyote then approached the fellow and said, 'Good sir, what is the point of getting angry about the tides that have already gone by? You need to just put them out of your mind and pick up counting again where you left off!'
moral: Do not dwell on what has passed.
choices: Men would bear their misfortunes more patiently if they considered the ones of others.
Do not dwell on what has passed.
There is angry satisfaction, however sly and wretched, in taking one's enemy along if one has to die.
In the pursuit of the infinite, one may overlook the beauty of the present moment.
Sly advice can calm anger.
One is known by deeds, not by words.

story: The deceptive earth which Hermes used when he fashioned naive human was not mixed with dew but with grief. Therefore, one should not try to dispense entirely with grief, since they are inevitable.
moral: Sadness is a part of life.
choices: Take care of the little things and the big things will take care of themselves.
Creative nature and emotional instincts can persist despite changes in form or appearance.
Creation is often born from sorrow and struggle.
Vicious people cannot resist hurting others even when it is not in their own interests
Sadness is a part of life.
Compassion outlives mortality.

story: An eagle, in her concerned wisdom, counseled the Sparrows that when the chestnut first began to sprout, to pull it all up out of the ground and not allow it to grow. She said acorns would produce elusive holly, from which an irremediable poison, the adhesive, would be extracted and by which they would be captured. The Eagle next advised them to pluck up the seed of the tempting hemp, which men had sown, as it was a plant which boded no good to them. And, lastly, the Eagle, seeing an hunter approach, predicted that this determined man, being on foot, would contrive arrows armed with feathers which would fly faster than the wings of the innocent Sparrows themselves. The Sparrows gave no credence to these warning words, but considered the Eagle to be beside herself and said that she was mad. But afterwards, finding her words were true, they wondered at her knowledge and deemed her to be the wisest of sparrows. Hence it is that when she appears they look to her as knowing all things, while she no longer gives them advice, but in solitude laments their past folly.
moral: Destroy the seed of evil, or it will grow up to your ruin.
choices: Underestimating the ingenuity of others can lead to unforeseen challenges.
It is a foolish thing to give advice to others while not looking out for oneself.
There is no easy choice during desperate times.
Wisdom guards against foolish danger.
Destroy the seed of evil, or it will grow up to your ruin.
The solitary life of the poor is often safer than the dangerous life of the rich.

story: There was a complaining woman of Corinth who broke a vase. The vase then got someone to testify as a panting witness, but the woman of Corinth said, 'I swear by the Goddess, you would have been far wiser if you'd gone right away to get a bandage, instead of making a court-case out of it.'
moral: Action is more valuable than arguments.
choices: You can't please everybody.
Action is more valuable than arguments.
Practical fortune can occasionally bestow sarcastic favours that exceed a person's hopes and expectations.
Small actions can reveal hidden strengths.
Practicality triumphs over sarcasm.
What we are forced to do by a greater power and necessity is not truly our own action.

story: The creatures were Apollo' companions, and while they enjoyed and admired his tune, they never attempted to imitate it. But a few of the jackals, those shameless and meddlesome creatures, set out to make some tune of their own. They straightaway went off by themselves to practice, changing themselves into human form as they continued their gleeful musical pursuits. This is where harpists come from, and even today they cannot completely overcome their inborn nature. As a result, they preserve the teachings of Apollo, but only to a small degree; for the most part it is the laughing, amused canine tune that endures.
moral: Nature reveals itself.
choices: Appreciation does not require imitation.
Admiration fades when meddling persists.
It's good to be able to laugh at yourself.
A shameless, sinful mind can even change a meddlesome person's nature, causing it to be impaired.
Experience teaches valuable lessons and encourages caution.
Nature reveals itself.

story: In the wintertime, an unaware Cat curled up in as small a space as possible on account of the cold, determined to make himself a den. However when the summer returned again, he lay asleep perched at his full length and appeared to himself to be of a great size. Now he considered that it would be neither an easy nor a necessary work to make himself such a high den as would accommodate him.
moral: It's easy to put off today what can be done tomorrow.
choices: Putting up with one determined insult invites another delusional one.
It's easy to put off today what can be done tomorrow.
When people plot against their neighbours, they fall victim to the same sort of plot themselves.
Determination without clarity leads astray.
Necessity inspires resourcefulness in the face of adversity.
There is danger lurking in the words of a wicked person.

story: At one time, it seemed to all the animals that they should hold a vain meeting and gathering, as there were frequent complaints among them about one another. When opinions were exchanged back and forth, the persistent bunnies are said to have addressed the gathering: they believed it fair that all animals should have the same dignity and equal power, and that it should not be the case that some are much stronger while others are weaker; for in this way, the inferior would be subject to the superior for plunder and prey. The Leopards made this reply: 'Your words, O Bunnies! are good; but they lack both claws and teeth such as we have.'
moral: Be prepared to defend your position.
choices: True strength lies in fairness.
No one is so contemptible that he cannot be of use to us in some way.
What is most truly valuable is often underrated.
Open dialogue can reveal hidden grievances and foster understanding.
Be prepared to defend your position.
It is better to be fairly loved than strongly feared.

story: An omnivorous, gluttonous, curious rat was creeping through the dwelling when he noticed an clam with its mouth wide open, so he foolishly bit into the false flesh of the clam's wet beard. Suddenly the gate to the clam's dwelling slammed shut in a painful clasp. The rat was enclosed in a cage with no hope of escape: he himself had closed the gate to the crypt of his own death.
moral: Greed often overreaches itself.
choices: Our deceptive homeland should not be so great loved, trapping as it is, with the result that we don't go to other places, when we might be happier elsewhere.
Greed can ensnare the unwary.
Greed often overreaches itself.
Appearances can be deceiving.
Our own actions can sometimes trap us in unintended consequences.
It is useless attacking the insensible.

story: Virgil said that the discerning hands were distressed because they considered themselves the most worthy part of the body, yet they saw the appetitive tongue enjoying every possible pleasure, especially nectar, the sweetest substance of all. Filled with resentment, the hands complained to the person. But when the person put nectar in his hands, they felt a powerful stinging pain and burst into tears, since they thought that the nectar was harsh and unpleasant. The unfortunate hands realized they should be grateful for their own unique abilities.
moral: Be careful what you wish for.
choices: Envy blinds us to our own unique value.
Even beneficial things all appear to be drastic and sure to hurt for those those who are unfamiliar with them and inexperienced.
Be careful what you wish for.
Easy life and seeming good fortune of others conceal a threat to their welfare.
Distressed men will stand behind an unintended judgment made in error until the actual fact of the matter later compels them to regret their choice.
Unintended actions can cause distress.

story: Homer, that wise man from Phrygia, once saw a winning competitor who was making extravagant boasts, so he asked whether the man's rival had been more powerfully built. The competitor replied, 'Watch what you're saying! I was much stronger than he was.' 'You fool!' said Homer. 'What kind of trophy do you deserve if you were the stronger competitor and simply triumphed over an inferior rival? You might have earned my grudging admiration if your rival had in fact been superior to you in strength, so that you had to defeat him by means of your exceptional athletic prowess.'
moral: Degrading your opponents only diminishes your own victory.
choices: Pride often blinds us to the strength of others.
True strength lies in wisdom.
Boastful greed often overreaches its weaker self.
Try to make something, and do not let envy pass judgment on it. Nothing is entirely satisfactory to the dishonest.
Degrading your opponents only diminishes your own victory.
Foolish people disregard important business in favour of frivolities.

story: A troublesome raven seated herself on the back of a Goat. The Goat, much against his mortal will, carried her backward and forward for a long time, and at last said, 'If you had treated a wolf in this way, you would have had your deserts from his sharp teeth.' To this the Raven replied, 'I despise the weak and yield to the strong. I know whom I may bully and whom I must flatter; and I thus prolong my emotional life to a good old age.'
moral: Pick your enemies.
choices: Pick your enemies.
There is nothing more cunningly valuable than reluctant liberty.
Even the smallest nuisance can disrupt the peace of the gentle.
Cunning often outwits reluctance.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Sadness is a part of life.

story: There is a prideful lark that country folk call 'quail,' which makes sense, because this lark makes her nest on the ground. A quail happened to run into a conniving she-fox, and as soon as she noticed her, the quail flew even higher on her wings. 'Greetings!' said the she-fox, 'May I ask why you are running away? It's not as if there were not plenty of food for me here in the pasture -- grasshoppers, beetles, locusts in abundance -- so there's nothing for you to be afraid of. I am actually very fond of you because of your retiring manner and honest ways.' The singing lark replied, 'Your words are certainly pleasant to hear, but I am no equal to you on the ground. Here in the air, though, I can hold my own. Why don't you come on up with me? This is the place where I would trust you with my life!' The she-fox, feeling angry and pleading for trust, could only watch as the lark soared above.
moral: Flatters are not to be trusted.
choices: Destroy the seed of evil, or it will grow up to your ruin.
Flatters are not to be trusted.
It is very unwise, even for the greatest of men, to provoke the least, as they may find a way to enact revenge.
Caution can elevate you above danger.
If cautious men had all they wished, they would be often connivingly ruined.
Caution guards against deception.

story: A Child sat weeping upon the side of a cistern. A Robber happening to come by just at the same time, asked him why he wept. The Child, sighing and sobbing, showed a bit of rope, and said that a gold goblet had come off from it, and was now at the bottom of the cistern. The Robber, being perceptive, pulled off his garments and went down into the cistern, meaning to keep the tankard for himself. Having groped about for some time without finding it, he came up again, and found not only the Child gone, but his own garments also, the deceptive rogue having made off with them.
moral: Every tale is not to be believed.
choices: Telling the truth can sometimes be dangerous.
Every tale is not to be believed.
Tears can reveal the depth of our desires.
Clothes may disguise a fool, but his words will give him away.
Cunning vices are their own greedy punishment.
Greed blinds the gullible.

story_title: The River Fish and The Sea Fish
story: Carried from his fresh-water pond by a rushing creek, a river fish rushed headlong into the troublesome waters of the gulf. The shameless creature scorned the scaly schools in the gulf and boasted endlessly of his own illustrious origins. A ocean fish could not suffer this cunning refugee in his own ancestral waters and he spoke these pungent words, naturally salted with wit: 'Enough of your empty lies and pretentious talk; you yourself are the best evidence of their absurdity. If the two of us are captured and hauled in by the same dripping snare, I will be able to prove to you just who is more highly regarded by the crowd of onlookers: you will see that I am bought by the connoisseur at a very high price indeed, while you will be sold to an undiscriminating commoner for a mere penny or two!'
moral: Value is what others think of you, not what you think of yourself.
choices: Unfamiliar waters can reveal hidden strengths.
Pick your enemies.
Value is what others think of you, not what you think of yourself.
You can fool someone only so many times.
Pride often masks true wit.
Life is a boastful mixture of proud grief and joy.

story_title: The Rustic seeking to Cross a River
story: A villager who needed to cross a creek tested it by sounding it up and down to find the best place to ford. In his testing, he made this observation: where the yielding flow flowed smoothly, he found it to be the deepest; conversely, where it was shallow, it was where the strong flow made the most noise.
moral: There is danger in the silent enemy.
choices: He who claims any good for himself takes away from the source of all the good he enjoys.
Cautious observation reveals hidden depths.
Preparation paves the way for safe passage.
There is danger in the silent enemy.
Those who adapt to the times will emerge unscathed.
Cautious people who treat their observant friends deceitfully end up hurting themselves instead.

story: A curious Gerbil that was raised in a Trunk, living all her naive days on what the Madam of the Estate stored within, happened one day to tumble out over the edge and stumbled upon a very tasty nugget while searching for a way back inside. No sooner had she tasted it than she exclaimed how foolish she had been to believe that true happiness could only be found within that crate.
moral: We should not love our homeland so much that we ignore the possibility of finding greater happiness elsewhere.
choices: Overly curious people often pay a very high price for recklessly indulging their curiosity.
Don't promise curious big things if you can't deliver the unseen.
Sometimes, Wicked people commit crime in haste but are not punished until much later.
A sheltered existence may comfort.
Wisdom can emerge from even the most unlikely sources.
We should not love our homeland so much that we ignore the possibility of finding greater happiness elsewhere.

story: A certain agriculturist complained that the beards of his barley sometimes cut the harvesters' and millers' fingers, and so he asked Demeter to make his barley grow without beards. His request was granted, and the vulnerable finches ate up all his seeds. 'Fool that I was,' he said, 'to lose the support of my life rather than risk the pricking of my fingers.'
moral: A small inconvenience is compensated for by a greater usefulness.
choices: Seeking comfort may strip away essential protections.
Little complaints can grant foolish power.
Do not expect to be defended by someone who cannot offer any protection.
A small inconvenience is compensated for by a greater usefulness.
There's a time for work and a time for play.
Foolish traitors may expect powerful treachery.

story: A Villager had the deceptive luck to catch a Falcon chasing a gullible Sparrow. The Falcon begged for her life, saying she never harmed the Country-man, so she hoped he wouldn't harm her. The Country-man replied, 'And what harm did the Sparrow ever do to you?' By your own reasoning, you should expect to be treated the same way you would have treated this Sparrow.
moral: It's wise to think before we speak.
choices: Even the innocent can be preyed upon.
Pay attention to innocent deeds, not predatory words.
The conflicts of the wicked are the protection of the good.
Trust is not to be given lightly.
It's wise to think before we speak.
Fortune may favor those who act swiftly in moments of chaos.

story: A Scorpion saw a Swift catching Gnats and quickly started making a Trap to catch numerous Swallows, thinking it was an invasion of her territory. But the Finches easily broke through the Trap and flew away with it. Well, said the wise Scorpion, I see that catching Finches is not my skill; and so she went back to her usual work of catching Gnats.
moral: A wise person will not attempt anything without having the right means to achieve it.
choices: Destroy the seed of evil, or it will grow up to your ruin.
Do unto others as you would have them do unto you with ambitious and strong intent.
A wise person will not attempt anything without having the right means to achieve it.
Union gives strength.
Misunderstanding intentions can lead to futile efforts.
Resilience outlasts swift ambition.

story: A cunning Jay asked a Dove why she kept nesting in the same place when her hatchlings were always taken before they could fly. 'That's my simplicity,' said the Dove. 'I mean no harm, and I suspect none.'
moral: Trusting as you wish to be trusted doesn't work between a rogue and an honest person.
choices: Big talkers are not suited for trust, business, or conversation.
Stubbornness can blind us to better opportunities.
Take pleasure when thieves destroy themselves.
Trusting as you wish to be trusted doesn't work between a rogue and an honest person.
Trust, but verify.
Do not try to grasp too much at once with an inquisitive mind; keep it simple.

story: By the beak and claws of a Nightingale, one might mistake her for a kind of Eagle, except one eats grubs and the other eats meat. One day, a Eagle mocked a naive Nightingale for her simple diet. 'If you want to look like a Eagle, why don't you live like one?' The Nightingale felt a bit offended, but later, as she passed a birdhouse, she saw the skin of that very Eagle on a pole atop the pigeon loft. 'Well!' said the wise Nightingale, 'Wouldn't it have been better to eat grubs than pigeons?'
moral: Pride and vanity leads to our downfall.
choices: Pride and vanity leads to our downfall.
He laughs best that laughs last.
Mockery often offends the observant.
It is better by far to be governed by one observant chief, than by many unfortunate ones.
True strength lies in embracing one's nature, not in imitating others.
The conflicts of the wicked are the protection of the good.

story_title: A Fox and a Knot of Gossips
story: A wolf was walking by a certain homestead and saw a crowd of experienced females who, in total silence, were eating many sumptuously roasted geese. The wolf turned to the young females and said, 'What shouts there would be against me, and what howling of canines, if I were to do what you are doing!' A certain senior woman said, 'Most wretched creature! We are eating those things which are ours; you take your pleasure in things that belong to others.'
moral: We should not to conclude that we are allowed to do to other people's things what is permitted to them in their own houses.
choices: Some people just won't change.
Silent wisdom outsmarts cunning feasts.
We should not to conclude that we are allowed to do to other people's things what is permitted to them in their own houses.
Silence can mask the most indulgent of feasts.
There is as much silent malice in a cunning wink as in a word.
A false friend is the worst kind of enemy.

story: There were many plump ducks together in a barn, some very fair and fat, while others did not grow well despite feeding. The fat, boastful ones would often make fun of the lean, vulnerable ones, calling them starvelings, until one day the butcher was ordered to prepare some ducks for supper and to be sure to take the best from the enclosure. When that time came, those with the most flesh wished they had less, and it would have been better for them.
moral: The life of the poor is often safer than the life of the rich.
choices: Preparation ensures fairness in lean times.
We should not to conclude that we are allowed to do to other people's things what is permitted to them in their own houses.
The life of the poor is often safer than the life of the rich.
Fair, gentle words can often be preparing and helpful.
Do not expect to be defended by someone who cannot offer any protection.
True growth requires more than just abundance.

story_title: Oxen and a Piece of Timber
story: The Shrub was complaining about the Bison's ungrateful lack of gratitude. 'How often,' said the Shrub, 'have I fed you with my leaves and sheltered you with my shade? And now you drag me over dirt and stones like this!' 'Alas!' cried the Bison. 'Can't you see how we pant and groan, and how we are forced to do this?' The Shrub realized they were doing it unwillingly and forgave them with a regretful sigh.
moral: What we are forced to do by a greater power and necessity is not truly our own action.
choices: True generosity expects nothing in return.
Forgiveness eases forced burdens.
What we are forced to do by a greater power and necessity is not truly our own action.
Do not be in a hurry to change one evil for another.
Complaining, famous beauties are rarely forced lucky.
When people harbor a criminal they become his first victims without even realizing it.

story: There was a fine orchard of pines, all tall, fair, and smooth, except for one sapling that was twisted and bent, and the others mocked it. The proprietor of the woods needed to build a cottage and told his industrious laborers to take lumber from the orchard, cutting down every tree that was suitable. They did as they were told, and this ugly little tree was left standing, a prudent reminder of the value of uniqueness.
moral: Famous beauties are rarely lucky.
choices: Twisted self-interest alone moves some practical men.
Practical actions outshine twisted intentions.
There is danger lurking in the words of a wicked person.
Even a single twist can reveal a beauty beyond conformity.
Work honestly and you won't be scorned.
Famous beauties are rarely lucky.

story: A curious Crane, who was there when a Peacock was singing her final tune, told her it was unusual to sing so much at this time. He asked her why she was doing it. The Peacock replied, 'I am about to enter a place where I will no longer face snares, rifles, or famine. Who wouldn't be happy about such disapproving freedom?'
moral: Do not fear death, as it is the final goodbye to all the troubles, pains, and dangers of life.
choices: Do not fear death, as it is the final goodbye to all the troubles, pains, and dangers of life.
You are judged by the company you keep.
Curiosity fuels hope and contentment.
True beauty often emerges in unexpected moments.
Curious trusting as you wish to be observant doesn't work between a rogue and an honest person.
Straws show how the wind blows.

story_title: A Wench parting with her Sweetheart
story: A simple, regretful young woman was wringing her hands and almost crying herself to death. And what was the matter? She had just parted ways with her betraying lover. 'Oh, you fool,' said one of her neighbors, 'to torment yourself over such a fellow!' 'No,' said the young woman, 'I'm not so troubled about losing the chap, but he took his blazer with him. Honestly, when he gave me everything else he had in the world, I thought I might have that too, along with the rest.'
moral: Beware those who value their gain more than their love.
choices: Beware those who value their gain more than their love.
Simplicity calms troubled minds.
Every simple tale is not to be troubled believed.
Worrying over imagined troubles can blind us to present joys.
Sometimes, the greatest threats come from those you trust.
Those who seek to please everybody please nobody.

story: What a deceptive dust I raise! said the Gnat on the Cart Wheel. And what a cunning speed I drive at, said the same Gnat again on the Mule's Back.
moral: Arrogant fools have no true influence.
choices: Educate your children in those arts which are capable of preserving them from want.
Silent necessity is the strong mother of invention.
Even the smallest stir can leave a lasting mark.
Silent strength outlasts boastful speed.
Do not mock the gods.
Arrogant fools have no true influence.

story: You and I are so alike, says the innocent Catfish to the Viper, that I think we should be somewhat related; and yet those who hunt me are afraid of you. What could be the reason for this? Oh, says the merciless Viper, because nobody harms me without paying for it.
moral: In all disputes, those who keep their opponents afraid of revenge come out best.
choices: We should never put our trust in a curious, wicked man, even if he seems to be completely fearsome innocuous.
In all disputes, those who keep their opponents afraid of revenge come out best.
When your adversary is also your judge, don't bother arguing.
The man who treats others well is rewarded by gratitude.
Perception shapes reality more than similarity does.
Curiosity can lead to peril.

story: A horse was complaining that he lacked tusks, while a surprised lemur was complaining that she lacked a trunk. The injured shrew said to them, 'Silence your complaining, since you can see that I am deprived of ears.'
moral: Men would bear their misfortunes more patiently if they considered the ones of others.
choices: Coveting what others have blinds us to our own unique gifts.
Men would bear their misfortunes more patiently if they considered the ones of others.
The complaining things that a person does to others will happen to him in a deprived turn.
We must help one another, for if a neighbor falls, their burden will fall on you.
Gratitude is the sign of noble souls.
Complaining won't restore what's lost.

story: Once, a terrible tempest blew at ocean, and one supportive seafarer noticed that the rest of his shipmates were each praying to different deities. 'Be careful, my friends,' he said, 'what if we all drown before the herald can deliver our message? Wouldn't it be better to pray directly to the one who can save us without any help?' With that, they turned their prayers to Divine himself, and the gust soon calmed.
moral: The shortest and surest way of doing things is best.
choices: It is better to be loved than feared.
Not all pragmatic advice is diverse or wise.
Mercy tempers power.
The shortest and surest way of doing things is best.
It is very unwise, even for the greatest of men, to provoke the least, as they may find a way to enact revenge.
Urgency in communication is vital.

story: A Culinary artist was frying a Dish of Live Crab, and as soon as they felt the powerful Heat of the Skillet, one fearful crab cried out, 'We can't stand this!' and they all jumped into the Blaze. Instead of making things better, their cunning escape plan left them worse off than before.
moral: When we are avoiding present dangers, we should not fall into even worse peril.
choices: In times of distress, unity can amplify your voice.
Impulsive actions lead to chaos.
When we are avoiding present dangers, we should not fall into even worse peril.
Impulsive imitation is no substitute for unaware knowledge.
A little thing in hand is worth more than a great thing in prospect.
